preface.title: FOREWORD
preface.p: Ibn Ezra’s commentary on the Book of Numbers follows the pattern established in his commentaries on the first three books of the Pentateuch. It is marked by fidelity to the plain meaning of the text, an application of philosophical and scientific beliefs in elucidating texts, independence of interpretation when halakhah is not involved, and a strict respect for rabbinic tradition when halakhah is involved.

I.E.’s dedication to both the literal meaning of the text and his philosophical views can be seen in his interpretation of the law of the Nazirite. Numbers 6:2-5 states: When either man or woman shall clearly utter a vow, the vow of a Nazirite, to consecrate himself to the Lord, he shall abstain from wine and strong drink…All the days of his vow of Naziriteship there shall no razor come upon his head; until the days be fulfilled, in which he consecrated himself unto the Lord, he shall be holy, he shall let the locks of the hair of his head grow long.

Some sages of the Talmud took a dim view of the Nazirite. “Eleazar ha-Kappar Berabbi says: What is Scripture referring to when it says [of the Nazirite], and make atonement for him, for he sinned by reason of the soul (Num. 6:11). Against which soul did he sin? [It must refer to the fact that] he denied himself wine. We can now make this inference from minor to major: If the Nazirite who denied himself wine only is called a sinner, a fortiori one who denies himself the enjoyment of many other things (Ta’anit 11a).”

Ibn Ezra disagrees. He insists on taking Scripture at face value. There is nothing in the Torah and the prophets which implies that the Torah does not fully endorse Naziriteship. First of all, the Torah lays down the law of the Nazirite. Second, Scripture refers to the Nazirite as a holy person. Furthermore, the prophet Amos declares: And I raised up of your sons for prophets, and of your young men for Nazirites (Amos 2:11). The prophet Jeremiah had only praise for the Rechabites who abstained from wine (Jer. 35:14-19).

Thus the notion that the Nazirite is a sinner seems to run counter to the literal meaning of Scripture. Indeed, I.E. considers Eleazar ha-Kappar Berabbi’s proof from Num. 6:11 that the Nazirite is a sinner purely midrashic and contrary to the literal meaning of the text.

Aside from the literal meaning of the text, I.E. had a philosophical reason for rejecting the opinion that the Nazirite is a sinner. According to I.E. the way for a person to develop his soul is to separate himself from the pleasures of this world and dedicate himself solely to God. “The intelligent man will not occupy himself with the vanities of the world. On the contrary, he will isolate himself for the purpose of studying and mediating upon God’s law and observing the Lord’s precepts. God will then open the eyes of his heart and will create a new and different spirit in him. He will be beloved of his creator while yet alive. His soul will cleave to God and enjoy the fullness of the joy of God’s presence. Furthermore, God’s right hand of bliss will be eternally upon his soul when it separates from the body” (Ibn Ezra, Yesod Mora, translated by H. Norman Strickman, p. 107).

According to I.E. sex is one of the things that creates a barrier between man and God (Yesod Mora, chapter 7, pp. 107 and 108). The Nazirite is an individual who takes a vow to abstain from wine and haircutting. I.E. connects wine and hair to sexuality. He believes that most sexual taboos are violated because the transgressor has imbibed wine. As to the prohibition of cutting the hair, I.E. writes, “A woman who does not fix her hair does not seek to engage in sexual relationships” (Num. 5:31). He similarly notes that the Torah states that “a razor shall not come upon the head of a Nazirite so that he does not make himself attractive to women.” (Yesod Mora, p. 62).

I.E. believed the Nazirite to be a prince of men. He writes: “All men are slaves of the lusts of the world. The true king, the one who has the diadem and the crown of kingship over his head is the one who is free of lust” (Num. 6:7). “The Nazirite is a holy person. When the Nazirite completes his term and wants to go back to drinking wine, he must bring a burnt offering, a sin offering, and a peace offering. He must also shave his head at the entrance of the tent of meeting. He is treated disrespectfully because he is distancing himself from his holiness and is descending in state (Yesod Mora, p. 145).”

I.E.’s approach to sex is seen in his acceptance of the aggadic interpretation regarding the enigmatic incident of Moses’ relation to a Cushite women. The Torah tells us (Num. 12:1,2): And Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses because of the Cushite woman whom he had married; for he had married a Cushite woman. And they said: Hath the Lord indeed spoken only with Moses? hath he not spoken also with us?

The rabbis explain that Moses ceased having relations with Zipporah, for he was constantly in contact with God. Zipporah complained about this, and Miriam and Aaron supported her. They argued that they too were prophets, and they did not refrain from having sexual relations (Sifre 99). I.E. accepted this aggadic interpretation because it fit with his philosophical ideology.

Ibn Ezra’s rendering of the word selach, which is usually translated as forgive, is unique. According to I.E. the meaning of selach is to postpone punishment. I.E. bases his interpretation on the punishment meted out to the Israelites for accepting the words of the spies sent to Canaan, i.e., that they would be unable to conquer the land. Scripture tells us that God wanted to destroy Israel for their lack of faith. However, when Moses prayed on behalf of Israel, God told Moses, salachti ke-devarekha (I have pardoned according to thy word) (Num. 14:20). God then goes on to say that since Israel did not hearken to His voice they shall not come into the land, and their children shall be wanderers in the desert for forty years until they (the original sinners) have all died (Num. 14:22,3). We thus see that Israel was ultimately punished for their lack of faith in God, even though God had told Moses, salachti ke-devarekha. I.E. thus concluded that the term selach refers to a postponement of punishment.

According to the Torah, Moses sinned at Meribah by failing to sanctify God in the eyes of the children of Israel (Num. 20:12). According to I.E., Moses’ sin was in being distracted by the people from properly directing his heart to God. As a result Moses was initially unable to bring water from the rock and God’s name was desecrated.

I.E. uses astrology to explain the ability of Balaam to utter efficacious blessings and curses. According to I.E., Balaam was no true prophet. He was an astrologer who carefully tailored his words to what was written in the stars. He thus appeared to have the power to bless and curse.

According to I.E. the Biblical narratives do not necessarily follow in chronological order. He thus places Korah’s rebellion (Num. 16) in the first year of Israel’s sojourn in the desert, not in the fortieth year as implied by its position in Scripture.

While I.E. maintains an independent position regarding Biblical interpretations, he always defers to the sages of the Talmud on halakhic issues. Thus in regard to the law concerning fringes, I.E. notes it is possible that Biblical rules require that the corners of garments be left unwoven so that their threads hang down to form fringes. He further notes that the law of fringes applies to pants. However, he then goes on to say that this interpretation is of no consequence, for the rabbis say that the fringes are specially prepared threads which are placed on the corner of any garment having four corners. Therefore pants are not included in the law of fringes.

Although I.E.’s commentary is distinguished by independence and by occasional bold theological statements, his commentary is also marked by a nonrationalistic bent. Thus in dealing with the copper serpent made by Moses to heal anyone bitten by poisonous snakes (Num. 21:8), I.E. takes issue with those who tried to explain this miracle rationally. He argues that God’s powers are beyond explanation.

Ibn Ezra’s commentary on the Book of Numbers thus reflects a confluence of the literal and the scientific, the traditional and the interpretive, the theological and the philosophical. His style of Biblical exegesis is unique and always thought-provoking and rewarding.
H. Norman Strickman
Touro College
25 Tishre, 5759
October 15, 1998

chapter.title: CHAPTER 1
chapter.p: In the name of God who counted those numbered above1 and below;2
I begin to explain according to the plain meaning
the Torah portion which begins with va-yedabber.3
1. IN THE WILDERNESS. This verse4 informs us that Moses did not go up to Mount Sinai5 since God’s glory was now present in the tent of meeting.6

ON THE FIRST DAY OF THE SECOND MONTH. To tell him to arrange the standards and to instruct him how the Israelites were to journey and how they were to camp with reference to the tabernacle,7 for they journeyed on the twentieth day of the second month.8

2. TAKE YE THE SUM. Se’u et rosh bene yisra’el (take ye the sum of all the congregation of the children of Israel) is similar to ki tissa et rosh bene yisra’el (when thou takest the sum of the children of Israel) (Ex. 30:12). I have explained its meaning there.9
BY THEIR FAMILIES BY THEIR FATHER’S HOUSES. For pedigree is not determined by the mother.10
BY THEIR POLLS. I have already explained the meaning of gulgelotam (their polls).11
3. IN ISRAEL. This excludes the mixed multitude.12

4. EVERY ONE HEAD OF HIS FATHERS’ HOUSE. Ish rosh le-vet avotav (every one head of his fathers’ house) is an abridged phrase. The text should have read, ish ish rosh le-vet avotav (every one head of his fathers’ house).13
5. OF REUBEN. Scripture begins with Jacob’s first-born,14 as it is stated, yet not so that he was to be reckoned in the genealogy as first-born (I Chron. 5:1).15

10. OF THE CHILDREN OF JOSEPH. The children of Joseph are mentioned after the children of Leah because Rachel’s status was greater than that of the handmaids.16 Scripture begins with Ephraim, in keeping with the actions of our father Jacob.17 Scripture places Ephraim and Manasseh18 before Benjamin because they are in place of Joseph.19

Scripture then begins with Dan,20 who was the first-born of the handmaids.21 Asher follows Dan22 because God knew that Asher would be the head of those who camp under the standard of Dan.23 Scripture then mentions Gad because he was the first-born of Leah’s handmaid.24
16. THESE WERE THE ELECT OF THE CONGREGATION. The meaning of keru’e ha-edah (the elect of the congregation)25 is that the congregation does nothing unless they are called.
THE TRIBES OF THEIR FATHERS. The meaning of mattot avotam is the tribes of their fathers. Thus each one26 was prince of a tribe.
THEY WERE THE HEADS OF THE THOUSANDS OF ISRAEL. Each one was a leader over all the thousands that comprised a tribe, for there was also a chief over one thousand.27
17. AND MOSES AND AARON TOOK. With them.
THAT ARE POINTED OUT BY NAME. Nikkevu means that are pointed out. Compare, yikkvennu (mark out) in Which the mouth of the Lord shall mark out (Is. 62:2).
18. AND THEY DECLARED THEIR PEDIGREES. They were asked for their birth dates,28 for only those from twenty and above were to be counted. Their progeny were then recorded.29
19. SO DID HE NUMBER THEM. The reference is to Moses,30 who was the most important.31

Scripture begins32 with Reuben,33 as he was the first-born. Simeon is next34 because he was born after Reuben. Gad the first-born of Leah’s handmaid,35 follows. We thus have Reuben’s standard.36 Next37 comes the standard of Judah,38 followed by the standard of Ephraim39 and the standard of Dan.40 Those who camped around each standard did so in the same manner in which they offered the sacrifices dedicating the altar.
Note, there were twelve tribes,41 for Levi was not counted and Joseph’s two sons were. Now the world has four sides.42 Behold, three tribes camped on each one of the four sides.43

Now Leah had five sons,44 for one of her six sons45 was not counted. She had two standards.46 They [Moses and Aaron] completed one of her standards47 with [Gad] the first-born of her handmaid.48 They placed Gad with the standard of Reuben, who was also a first-born.
Judah made up the second standard [of Leah]. His younger brothers camped with him.49
Rachel had a standard of her own.50 Ephraim was in place of Joseph. He preceded Manasseh, in keeping with the words of Jacob.51

The fourth standard was that of Rachel’s handmaid. It was led by [Dan] her first-born.52 Asher followed53 even though he was younger than Naphtali.54 The son of Leah’s handmaid55 was so honored because the standard belonged to Rachel’s handmaid.56

If you look carefully into things, you will know that the south is the head and the north the tail.57 I cannot explain the aforementioned.58 Reuben was therefore placed in the south59 because he was the head.60 Dan was placed in the north.61

Observe, there was no one among the tribes comparable in might to Judah, who was compared to a lion’s whelp (Gen. 49:9),62 and to the tribe of Dan, who is likewise compared to a lion by Moses.63 These tribes were thus first and last.64
Scripture mentions by their polls (le-gulgelotam) with regard to Reuben65 and also with regard to Simeon66 to show that it was the same case with the other tribes,67 for Scripture was being brief.

45. [AND ALL THOSE THAT WERE NUMBERED OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL BY THEIR FATHERS’ HOUSES, FROM TWENTY YEARS OLD AND UPWARD.] It means that only those who were aged twenty and above were counted. Scripture then goes on to say,68 even all those that were numbered. The latter refers to their69 total number.70
47. WERE NOT NUMBERED AMONG THEM. The word hotpakdu (were not numbered) is of two forms. It is both a hitpa’el and a hofal.71
49. HOWBEIT THE TRIBE OF LEVI THOU SHALT NOT NUMBER. This explains were not numbered (v. 47),72 that the Levites were not numbered because this is what God commanded.
NEITHER SHALT THOU TAKE THE SUM OF THEM. Their total number, as I have explained.73

50. BUT APPOINT THOU THE LEVITES OVER THE TABERNACLE. Scripture explains here why the Levites were not counted. They were not counted because the charge of the tabernacle was upon them. Therefore they did not serve in the army.74
THE TABERNACLE OF THE TESTIMONY. The reference is to the tent of meeting and the tabernacle of the ark, which contains the testimony.75
AND OVER ALL THE FURNITURE76 THEREOF. Such as the menorah, the table, and the altars.
AND OVER ALL THAT BELONGETH TO IT. The reference is the utensils which serve the furniture.77

AND THEY SHALL BEAR THE TABERNACLE. They are the very ones who carry the tabernacle when the camp journeys, and they are the ones who shall minister unto the tabernacle when they camp. They shall camp around the tabernacle.
51. AND WHEN THE TABERNACLE SETTETH FORWARD, THE LEVITES SHALL TAKE IT DOWN. They shall remove its bars and posts. When the tabernacle rests, they shall set it up.
AND THE COMMON MAN.78 A person who is not a Levite, even if he is an Israelite.
SHALL BE PUT TO DEATH. A law court shall put him to death.
52. [AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL SHALL PITCH.] Its meaning is, “when” the children of Israel shall pitch.79
EVERY MAN WITH HIS OWN CAMP. The meaning of every man is each tribe.80
[AND EVERY MAN WITH HIS OWN STANDARD.] Its meaning is that the tribe of one standard shall not be mixed with the tribe of another standard.

53. BUT THE LEVITES SHALL PITCH ROUND ABOUT THE TABERNACLE OF TESTIMONY. Our verse explains why the earlier verse81 stated that the Levites were to encamp round about the tabernacle:82 so that no one from the congregation of Israel should draw close to the tabernacle and die. This is the meaning of that there be no wrath upon…the children of Israel, as there was in the case of Uzzah, who touched the ark. Scripture there states, And the anger of the Lord was kindled against Uzzah (II Sam. 6:7).

The meaning of upon the congregation of the children of Israel is, upon anyone from the children of Israel.83 It is similar to and was buried in the cities of Gilead84 (Jud. 12:7)85 and Even upon a colt the foal of asses86 (Zech. 9:9).87 There are many such cases.
AND THE LEVITES SHALL KEEP THE CHARGE. The Levites are obligated to guard the tabernacle.
54. THUS DID THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. They never touched the tabernacle.
chapter.ftnote: 1 The stars. See Ps. 147:4, He counteth the number of the stars.
2 Israel.
3 The Book of Numbers begins with the word va-yedabber (spoke).
4 Which states that the Lord spoke unto Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, in the tent of meeting.
5 For revelation.
6 Otherwise, what follows would have been told to Moses on Mount Sinai.
7 Filwarg suggests emending ba’avur ha-mishkan (with reference to the tabernacle) to be’evre ha-mishkan (on the sides of the tabernacle).
8 Hence it was necessary to inform Moses of these things prior to their journey.

9 See I.E. on Exodus, (Vol. 2, p. 631). I.E. explains that ki tissa et rosh literally means: when you lift up the head. One who takes a census writes the particulars after the sum, which he writes at the top of the page. Thus when Scripture speaks of raising up the head, it means take up the sum.
10 Hence Scripture qualified by their families with by their fathers’ houses.

11 The word gulgelotam (their polls) literally means their skulls. In his short commentary (S.C.) on Exodus, I.E. explains that the word gulgolet means a head. The head is so called because it is round. Compare, galgal (wheel, i.e., a round object). See I.E. on Ex. 16:16 (S.C.).
12 Foreigners who joined Israel during the Exodus. See Ex. 12:38.

13 The first part of the verse reads, ish ish la-matteh (a man of every tribe). Hence, in keeping with the rules of parallelism, the second part of the verse should read, ish ish rosh le-vet avotav hu) (every one head of his father’s house).
14 Even though Jacob took away Reuben’s birthright. See Gen. 49:3,4.
15 I Chronicles explains that even though Reuben lost his birthright to Joseph, he was always to be reckoned as the first-born as far as genealogy was concerned.
16 Hence Rachel’s descendants are mentioned before those of the handmaids even though the children of the handmaids precede them in birth.
17 Manassah was older than Ephraim. However, Jacob placed Ephraim before Manasseh. See Gen. 48:21.
18 Joseph’s sons.
19 Joseph was born before Benjamin.
20 The son of Bilhah, Rachel’s handmaid.
21 Of the children born to the handmaids’. See Gen. 30:6.
22 Gad and Asher were the sons of Zilpah, Leah’s handmaid. According to Gen. 30:10-13, Gad was Zilpah’s first-born. Thus Scripture should have mentioned Gad before Asher. Hence I.E.’s comment.
23 Asher pitched next to Dan and was therefore next in importance under that standard. Gad was third under the standard of Reuben. See Num. 2:14,27.
25 Literally, the called of the congregation. Hence I.E.’s comment.
26 Each one of those listed in verses 5-16.

27 The tribes were divided into units of thousands. Each of these units was headed by a sar (chief). See Ex. 18:21, sarei alafim (rulers over thousands). Also see I Sam. 17:8, sar ha-elef (the captain of their thousand). Each one listed in verses 5-15 was the head of all the captains of the thousands of their respective tribes.
28 The Biblical text reads, va-yityalledu (and they declared their pedigrees). I.E. translates this as: they gave their birth dates.
29 See verse 2. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, “Or, their progeny were recorded.” According to this interpretation, va-yityalledu means: and they declared their children.
30 Va-yifkedem (so did he count them) is in the singular. Hence I.E.’s comment.
31 Actually Aaron and the heads of the tribes also participated in counting the people (see verse 44). However, Scripture here mentions only Moses, because he was the most important.
32 The count.
33 Verse 20.
34 Verse 22.
35 See note 24.
36 In verses 20-25. The tribes listed in verses 20-25 (Reuben, Simeon, and Gad) made up the standard of Reuben. See Num. 2:10-16.
37 Verses 26-30.
38 See Num. 2:3-9.
39 Verses 32-37. Also see Num. 2:18-24.
40 Verses 38-43. Also see Num. 2:25-31.
41 In verses 20-43; and in Num. 2:10-31.
42 North, south, east, and west.
43 For purposes of symmetry.
44 That is, five of Leah’s six sons were counted among the twelve tribes of Israel. They were Reuben, Simeon, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.
45 Levi.
46 The standards of Judah and Reuben. See Num. 2:3-16.
47 The standard of Reuben. See Num. 2:10-16.
48 See note 20.
49 Issachar and Zebulun.
50 The standard of Ephraim. See Num. 2:18-24.
53 That is, Asher pitched next to Dan. See Num. 2:27.
54 The standard of Dan consisted of Dan, Asher, and Naphtali. Asher, who was younger than Naphtali, pitched next to Dan.
55 Asher.
56 In other words, Asher, son of the handmaid Zilpah, was pacified for being under the standard of Dan, the son of the handmaid Bilhah, by being placed before Naphtali, another son of Bilhah.
57 The sun in its annual journey moves from north to south. The face of the sun is thus to the south while its back, the tail, is to the north (see Weiser).
58 When I.E. uses this expression it means that he is unable or does not want to explain further.
59 The standard of Reuben was on the south side of the tabernacle. See Num. 2:10.
60 He was the first-born.
61 That is, at the tail of the camp. See Num. 2:25.
62 In Jacob’s blessing.
63 See Deut. 33:22.
64 When the tribes marched, the standard of Judah marched first and that of Dan last. See Num. 10:14-25.
65 Verse 20.
66 Verse 22.
67 Even though the term is not mentioned with regard to the other tribes.
68 In verse 46.
69 Those 20 and older.
70 In other words, our verse speaks of the age of those numbered, while verse 46 speaks of the total number of those who were counted.
71 The heh and tav placed in front of the root is the sign of the hitpa’el. The kamatz katan placed beneath the heh is the sign of the hofal.
72 Otherwise, why inform us once again that the Levites were not counted.

73 Scriptures reads, ve-et rosham lo tissa (neither shalt thou take the sum of them). This literally means neither shalt thou lift up their heads. I.E. earlier noted that to lift up the head means to write the total sum at the top of a page. See I.E.’s comment on verse 2.
74 I.E. believes that those who were counted were counted for military purposes. This is also the view of Rashbam. See Rashbam on verse 2.

75 The tent of meeting was called the tabernacle of testimony because it served as a tabernacle for the ark, which contained the tables of testimony (luchot ha-edut) (Weiser). Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: The tabernacle of testimony refers to the ark wherein the testimonies are (that is, the tablets on which the ten commandments were written).
76 The Hebrew reads kelim, which means articles, utensils, or vessels. This is the way I.E. interprets the term.
77 Such as the utensils which served the menorah and the table of showbread.
78 The literal meaning of zar is a stranger. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
79 The verse reads, And the children of Israel shall pitch…every man with his own standard. However, the command to set up standards had not yet been given. Hence I.E.’s interpretation
80 According to I.E. the meaning of ish in our verse is each and every man.
81 Verse 50.

82 Krinsky’s edition of I.E. reads, “The explanation of and shall encamp round about (v. 50). Our verse explains why the earlier verse stated that the Levites were to encamp round about the tabernacle.”
83 For God would not punish all of Israel for the acts of one person.
84 Translated literally.
85 The meaning of which is, And was buried in one of the cities of Gilead, for Jephthah was not buried in all the cities of Gilead.
86 Translated literally.
87 Its meaning is, Even upon a colt the foal of an ass.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 2
chapter.p: 1. [AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO MOSES AND UNTO AARON.] Scripture reads, unto Moses and unto Aaron1 because Aaron and his sons were to command the Kohathites as to which burdens they were to carry upon their shoulders.2
2. ACCORDING TO THE ENSIGNS. There were signs upon each and every standard.

The ancients3 said that the banner of Reuben had the form of a person on it.4 Their statement is based on a midrashic interpretation concerning the mandrakes found by Reuben.5 The ancients also tell us that there was an image of a lion on the standard of Judah, for Jacob had compared Judah to a lion.6 They also tell us that the banner of Ephraim7 had the image of an ox upon it, in keeping with the verse, His firstling bullock (Deut. 33:17). The flag of Dan had the image of an eagle. Thus the banners were similar to the cherubim which the prophet Ezekiel saw.8
A GOOD WAY OFF. The word mi-neged means a good way off.9
3. ON THE EAST SIDE TOWARD THE SUNRISING. The beginning of the east.10
4. AND HIS HOST (U-FEKUDEHEM). Scripture could have read u-fekudav (and his host).11 There is no difference between the two terms.12
5. AND THOSE THAT PITCH NEXT UNTO HIM. Ve-hachonim alav means those that pitch with him.13 Issachar was behind Judah and in front of Zebulun who was third.
9. THEY SHALL SET FORTH FIRST. The meaning of rishonah yissa’u is, they shall set forth first.14
10. ON THE SOUTH SIDE. The word temanah (on the south side) comes from the same root as the word yemin (right).15
15. SECOND. Sheniyyim (second) is an adjective.

17. THEN THE TENT OF MEETING, WITH THE CAMP OF THE LEVITES, SHALL SET FORWARD IN THE MIDST OF THE CAMPS. In the midst of the above-mentioned camps,16 for the Gershonites and Merarites journeyed between the banner of Judah and the banner of Reuben.17 And the Kohathites, and with them Aaron and his sons, journeyed between the banner of Reuben and the banner of Ephraim.18

AS THEY ENCAMP, SO SHALL THEY SET FORWARD. The reference is to the camps, which refers to the camp of the Israelites. It19 does not refer to the camp of the Levites. The Gershonites, who pitched on the west20 of the sanctuary, and the Merarites on the north21 journeyed together,22 after the camp of Judah who pitched on the east.23

EVERY MAN IN HIS PLACE. The meaning of al yado (in his place) is, in his corner and place.24 The same applies to yad ha-yarden (by the side of the Jordan) (Num. 13:29) and ve-yad tiheyah lekha (and thou shalt have a paddle) (Deut. 23:13).25

32. THESE ARE THEY THAT WERE NUMBERED OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. When they journeyed,26 they were the same number as on the day that they were counted.27 Thus not one of them died in twenty days. This is a great wonder.
33. BUT THE LEVITES WERE NOT NUMBERED AMONG THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. Scripture makes it clear that we should not count even one Levite among those who were counted when they journeyed.28
34. THUS DID THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. All the days that they spent in the desert.
chapter.ftnote: 1 In most cases, only Moses is mentioned when God addresses commands. Hence I.E.’s comment.
2 For the burden of the Kohathites, see Num. 4:4-19.
3 The Talmudic sages.
4 See Ba-Midbar Rabbah 2:6.
5 The mandrakes have the appearance of a person. See I.E. on Gen. 30:14.
6 See Gen. 49:9.
7 The son of Joseph.

8 Each one of the cherubim seen by Ezekiel had four faces, the face of a man, an ox, an eagle, and a lion. See Ezek. 1:10. The camp of Israel similarly carried each one of these four images. In Ezekiel’s vision these cherubim supported the divine throne. Similarly, according to the sages, God’s spirit rested upon the camp of Israel.
9 The word neged literally means opposite. Hence I.E.’s comment.

10 Our verse reads, kedemah mizrachah. This literally means toward the east. According to I.E., kedemah mizrachah is a technical term for the beginning of the east, i.e., northeast. See I.E. on Ex. 27:9 and the notes thereto (Vol. 2, pp. 581-2).
11 As it does in verse 8.
12 U-fekudehem literally means and their host. U-fekudav means and his host. I.E. indicates that Scripture employs the singular for the plural, as the Bible uses collective nouns.
13 Alav literally means on him. Thus the literal meaning of ve-hachonim alav (and those that pitch next unto him) is, and those that pitch upon him. Hence I.E.’s comment that alav means with him.
14 In other words, rishonah yissa’u should be read as if written ba-rishonah yissa’u. (Krinsky).
15 When a person faces east, the south is at his right.
16 The camps of Judah and Reuben.
19 As they set encamp, so shall they set forward.
22 Num. 10:17. Unlike the way they camped.

23 Judah who pitched on the east marched first, followed by Reuben who pitched on the south, followed by Ephraim who pitched on the west, followed by Dan who pitched on the north. However, the Levites who camped on all four sides of the tabernacle did not follow this order.
24 The word yado literally means his hand. Hence I.E.’s comment.
25 The word yad, literally hand, is to be rendered as place in both of these verses.
26 On the twentieth day of the second month (Num. 10:11).
27 On the first day of the second month (Num. 1:1).
28 Scripture repeats in verse 33 what it said in Num. 1:47 to emphasize this point.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 3
chapter.p: 1. NOW THESE ARE THE GENERATIONS OF AARON AND MOSES. Scripture states this1 because it wants to inform us that their offspring did not beget children and did not increase2 in close to ten months.3

God chose the tribe of Levi at the time God spoke to Moses on Mount Sinai, when Moses ascended to atone for the making of the golden calf. God then said to Moses, Bring the tribe of Levi near (v. 6). The Lord then also related all that is contained in the section4 that opens with And I, behold, I have taken the Levites from among the children of Israel (v. 12). When the tabernacle was erected, God told Moses, Number the children of Levi (v. 15). God’s presence was then manifest in the tabernacle. Scripture therefore reads, in the wilderness of Sinai (v. 14).5
Now the descendants of Aaron and Moses in the wilderness of Sinai numbered the same as they did at Mount Sinai. However, two sons of Aaron were missing.6
I therefore7 said that the Levites did not give a ransom for their souls, for Scripture clearly states, for every one that passed over to them that are numbered (Ex. 38:26).

Some say that Moses did not count the Israelites before the tabernacle was constructed. He knew their number only by way of prophecy. However, Scripture contradicts them. It clearly states, When thou takest the sum of the children of Israel (Ex. 30:11).
3. THE PRIESTS THAT WERE ANOINTED. With the anointing oil, for they were high priests.8
[AND THEY HAD NO CHILDREN.]9 They did not leave behind any grown or small children. Therefore the Levites were lacking in number,10 for it is possible for the grown children to beget children.11
4. IN THE PRESENCE OF. I have previously explained the meaning of al pene (in the presence of).12
6. BEFORE AARON THE PRIEST. Who was the prince of the tribe.
The meaning of ve-ha’amadt (and set them)13 is, that they may minister. As the Lord liveth, before whom I stand (amadti) (II Kings 5:16) is similar.14
[7.] AND THE CHARGE OF THE WHOLE CONGREGATION. In the offering of sacrifices.
8. AND THE CHARGE OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. They will make sure that an Israelite does not enter the tabernacle.
9. THEY ARE WHOLLY GIVEN UNTO HIM. Forever. Or to them and their descendants who take their place.15
UNTO AARON AND TO HIS SONS. Both those who are presently alive and those who will arise after them.
FROM THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. To be separated from the children of Israel.
10. AND THOU SHALT APPOINT AARON AND HIS SONS. His sons includes the sons of his sons.
The meaning of and thou shalt appoint (tifkod) is, you shall appoint each one of them.16
The meaning of that they may keep their priesthood is that they not do anything that will disqualify them from being priests.
AND THE COMMON MAN THAT DRAWETH NIGH. To the priest, to serve as a priest.
[SHALL BE PUT TO DEATH.] An Israelite or a Levite who serves as a priest shall be put to death.

The chapter that opens with the words And I, behold, I have taken the Levites17 is also18 connected to the chapter which preceded it,19 for the Torah contains chapters that are separated but are connected by content. Similarly, Moreover the hand of the Lord was against them, to discomfit them from the midst of the camp, until they were consumed (Deut. 2:15),20 and, And it came to pass on the day when the Lord spoke unto Moses in the land of Egypt (Ex. 6:28).21
12. AND I, BEHOLD, I HAVE TAKEN THE LEVITES. The Levites have been greatly elevated.
FIRST-BORN. Bekhor (first-born) is connected to peter (openeth).22
AND THE LEVITES SHALL BE MINE. They shall be holy unto Me.
13. FOR ALL THE FIRST-BORN ARE MINE. Its meaning is, for also the first-born are Mine.
ON THE DAY THAT I SMOTE. This means at the time that I smote.23 There are many such cases.24
MINE THEY SHALL BE. This means they are Mine and they shall be Mine,25 for all human first-born and similarly the first-born of unclean cattle26 shall be redeemed.

15. FROM A MONTH OLD AND UPWARD. Until the sun and moon are once again in conjunction,27 or until the moon returns to its approximate place of departure28 and its original position and its present place are near each other.29 The intelligent person will understand this.30
17. GERSHON. For he was the first-born. In Chronicles the name is spelled with a mem31 in place of a nun (I Chron. 6:1).
21. OF GERSHON WAS THE FAMILY OF THE LIBNITES, AND THE FAMILY OF THE SHIMEITES. Its meaning is, these two families numbered the following amount.32
23. BEHIND THE TABERNACLE. Achare (behind) means the same as achore (behind).33 Compare, achor va-kedem (behind and before) (Ps. 139:5).34
WESTWARD. The term employed for westward is yamah because the great Spanish sea35 lies west of the Land of Israel.
25. THE TABERNACLE. The reference is to the ten curtains.36
THE TENT. The reference is to the eleven curtains.37
THE COVERING THEREOF. The covering which covered the cover is included.38
26. WHICH IS BY THE TABERNACLE. Which is inside the court.
AND BY THE ALTAR. Which is outside the tabernacle.39
[ROUND ABOUT.] Its meaning is that there was no place40 that was not enclosed; there was no opening that was uncovered.
EVEN WHATSOEVER PERTAINETH TO THE SERVICE THEREOF. I will explain this later.41
28. KEEPERS OF THE CHARGE OF THE HOLY.42 The reference is to the ark. The ark, as I have previously explained,43 is referred to as the holy, in contrast to the tabernacle.

29. SOUTHWARD. Kohath was placed at the right44 because he was the most important of all the sons of Levi, and the right is more important than the left45 or the back.46 There is no side, with the exception of the east,47 more important.

Gershon had an advantage over Merari, for Gershon was the first-born of Levi. Hence he carried that which was holy,48 in contrast to what Merari carried.49 Gershon50 therefore camped on the west,51 like the standard of Ephraim.52 Merari camped on the north53 like Dan,54 who was the son of the handmaid.
Now the Kohathites camped next to the banner of Reuben. Korah55 therefore joined with Dathan and Abiram.56 I will explain this later.
31. AND THE ALTARS. Both of them.57
AND THE VESSELS OF THE SANCTUARY WHEREWITH THE PRIESTS MINISTER. The reference is to the vessels of the menorah, the table, and the altars.
Many erred in explaining the meaning of and the screen,58 and all that pertaineth to the service thereof. It is clearly true that the reference is to the screen of the door of the tent of meeting.
AND ALL THAT PERTAINETH TO THE SERVICE THEREOF. Its cords.
32. PRINCE OF THE PRINCES OF THE LEVITES. There were three princes of Levi.59

The term nesi’e (princes) in the phrase nesi’e ha-levi (princes of Levi) applies to the word levi and also to another word.60 It is like the word lo (not) in It is not the great that are wise (Job 32:9).61

The second part of our verse is to be interpreted as if written the princes having the oversight of them that keep the charge of the sanctuary.62 Its meaning is that these three princes had oversight over the keepers of the charge of the sanctuary, who were Levites.

35. NORTHWARD. It is possible that the word tzafonah (northward) is derived from the word tzafanta (laid up) in Thou hast laid up for them that fear Thee (Ps. 31:20) and from the word tzafon (laid up) in laid up for the righteous (Prov. 13:22). The north is so called because there is nothing in the south.63
38. EASTWARD…TOWARD THE SUNRISING. Mizrachah means toward the sunrising. It refers to the place where the circles64 come together.
Observe, the tent of Moses, the tent of Aaron, and the tent of his children and his children’s children and all their entire households were in the east.65
AND THE COMMON MAN THAT DREW NIGH. To the holy place.66 Note, all the Levites camped around the tabernacle in order to guard it.

39. WERE TWENTY AND TWO THOUSAND. In all. When you add up the figures you will find that they come to three hundred above the figure given in Scripture.67 Some say that Scripture is being brief and mentions only the thousands and neglects the hundreds.68 However, this cannot be the case. Scripture mentions less than three hundred over and above a round number.69 The truth is in accordance with tradition which states that a first-born does not free a first-born.70 The meaning of our verse thus is, all that were numbered of the Levites with the exception of the first-born [were twenty and two thousand].

Judah the Persian71 calculated to prove, from the number that the first-born of the Levites were one seventy-third of the Levites.72 He went on to say that if you divide the number of Israelites73 by seventy-three,74 and take the number of Levites who came to serve in the tabernacle75 rather than the number of Levites age one month and above,76 then the number will be close.77

However, all this is nothing. The Israelites were counted from twenty and above. No other fixed unit was used.78 However, the Levites were counted from twenty to fifty. There is a large difference between them.79 We will rely only on tradition.80
40. NUMBER ALL THE FIRST-BORN MALES. Note that males is an adjective.81
41. AND THE CATTLE OF THE LEVITES.82 So that the Levites do not lose. The firstlings among the cattle are also for the Lord.83

45. TAKE THE LEVITES. A second time.84 It is as if it stated, when you take the Levites, then those who are over and above will be redeemed.85 The word peduye (redemption of) is connected to the number.86 There are many other such instances.

The disputers say87 that here we learn that the redemption price of every first-born is five shekels. However, there is no proof here,88 for this commandment stands by itself.89 The truth is in keeping with tradition.90
49. REDEMPTION. Pidyom (redemption) is spelled with a mem in place of a nun.91 Compare, Gershon.92
chapter.ftnote: 1 Our Torah portion deals with the census taken in the second year following the Exodus (see Num. 1:1; 3:14). The question thus arises, why does Scripture then tell us how many offspring Moses and Aaron had on the day that the Lord spoke to Moses on Mount Sinai?

2 In other words, the generations of Moses and Aaron were the same at the time of the census as they had been on the day that Moses stood on Mount Sinai ten months earlier. Hence it was not necessary to count them again when the Levites were counted. See verse 15.
3 Ten months passed from the day that Moses stood on Mount Sinai in the month of Sivan and the census was taken on the first day of the second month (Iyyar) following the Exodus.
4 Verses 12 and 13.

5 And not on Mount Sinai. The point is that the Levites were numbered when the tabernacle stood at the foot of Mount Sinai. Scripture tells us that God spoke to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai and told him to number the Levites, because once the tabernacle was erected God’s presence was manifest there, and God spoke to Moses there. Thus what is reported in 3:1-13 took place on Mount Sinai, and what is reported in 3:14-39 took place in the wilderness of Sinai.
6 This is the point of verse 4.

7 According to I.E. only those who went forth to war were counted by offering half a shekel as ransom for their souls. However, the Levites were in the service of God and did not have to offer a ransom for their souls. See I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 38:25.
8 Being anointed with the anointing oil (shemen ha-mishkhah) gave the sons of Aaron the status of high priests.
9 And they had no children appears in verse 4, but I.E. comments upon it here.
10 For the other tribes increased in number from the first census. The tribe of Levi did not do so due to the loss of Nadab and Abihu.
11 Hence Scripture tells us that Nadab and Abihu did not have any.
12 See I.E. on Gen. 11:28 (Vol. 1, p. 146). There I.E. explains that al pene means in the presence of. The literal meaning of al pene is, upon the face of.
13 Literally, and stand them up.
14 Its meaning is, As the Lord liveth, before whom I minister.

15 The Hebrew reads, netunim netunim (wholly given). This literally means, given given. I.E.’s first interpretation is that the repetition of the tern netunim indicates forever. His second interpretation is that the first netunim refers to them, and the second to their children.
16 Tifkod can meant to count. Hence I.E.’s comment.
17 Verses 12 and 13.
18 Like many other such chapters.
19 In other words, verse 12 is connected to verse 10. In the Masoretic Bible, verse 11 opens a new chapter.
20 Deut. 2:16 is connected to Deut. 2:17 even though they are in different chapters in the Masoretic Bible. See I.E. on Deut. 2:16.
21 According to I.E., Ex. 6:28 is connected to that which follows even though they are in different chapters in the Masoretic Bible. See I.E. on Ex. 6:28 (Vol. 2, pp. 141-2).
22 I.E. comments thus because the canticle reading is, every first-born, openeth the womb.
23 The first-born were smitten at night. See Ex. 11:4,5.
24 Where day means time.
25 The verse opens in the present (for all the first-born are Mine) and concludes with the future (Mine shall they be).
26 The reference is only to first-born asses.
27 If the child was born on the New Moon (rosh chodesh) (Rabbi Joseph Tov Elem).
28 If the child was born at any other time of the month.
29 For when a child is not born on a New Moon, it is very difficult to visually determine when he is exactly a month old.
30 That a complete lunar cycle has astrological significance.
31 Gershom.
32 7,500. In other words, verses 21 and 22 form one unit.
33 Achare literally means after. Thus achare ha-mishkan literally means after the tabernacle. Hence I.E.’s comment.
34 We thus see that the word achor means behind, for kedem means front.
35 The Mediterranean. The Hebrew word for sea is yam.
39 In contrast, the altar of incense was inside the tabernacle.
40 In the hangings around the court.
41 See I.E. on verse 31.
42 Hebrew, ha-kodesh. J.P.S. renders it as the sanctuary.
43 See I.E. on Lev. 6:23.
44 The south when one faces east.
45 The north when one faces east.
46 The west.
47 Where Moses and Aaron encamped.
48 Gershon carried the covering of the tabernacle, the tent of meeting, its covering, and the covering of tachash that is above it. See Num. 4:25.
49 For the burden of Merari, see verse 36.
50 The first-born of Levi.
51 Verse 23.
52 The first-born of Joseph. Thus the two first-born camped together.
53 Verse 35.
55 A Kohathite.
56 See Num. 16:1.
57 See I.E. on Num. 16:24.
58 They apparently identified the screen with the screen that hung in front of the Holy of Holies (Ex. 40:21). See Rashi on this verse.
59 See verses 24, 30, and 35.
60 It also applies to the word pekudat (having the oversight of) in the second part of our verse.

61 The second part of Job 32:9 literally reads, and the aged discern judgment. According to I.E. the word lo is carried over to the second half of the sentence, which is to interpreted, and the aged do not (lo) discern judgment.

62 I.E. interprets our verse as if written, Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest being prince of the princes of the Levites, the princes having the oversight of them that keep the charge of the sanctuary.

63 I.E. apparently believed that no one lives south of the equator, for the temperature there is too hot. It is only in the north where the necessary elements to sustain life are found. See I.E. on Gen. 12:9 (Vol. 1, p. 153).

64 Hebrew, agalot (wagons). Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, agulot (circles). It isn’t clear what I.E. is referring to. Meijler suggests that the reference is to where the heaven and earth appear to touch, i.e., the horizon. For other interpretations, see Weiser and Krinsky.
65 The east is the most important side. See I.E. on verse 47.
66 Not to the camp of Moses and Aaron.
67 7,500 Gershonites (v. 22), 8,600 Kohathites (v. 28), 6,200 Merarites (v. 34). This comes to 22,300.
68 In other words, 22,000 is a round number.
69 In listing the first-born, Scripture gives their number as 22,273 (v. 43). We thus see that Scripture does not employ round numbers in our chapter.
70 See Bekhorot 4a. In other words, there were 300 first-born who were Levites. These 300 did not free Israelites from the necessity of redemption, because they had to free themselves.
71 An early Karaite scholar. See I.E. on Ex. 12:2 (Vol. 2, p. 203).
72 22,000 divided by 300 comes to 73 and a fraction.
73 There were 603,550 Israelites (2:32).
74 The result of which is 8,267.
76 Of whom there were 22,273.

77 If we deduct the 300 uncounted Levites from the number of Levites who served in the tabernacle (8,580), we get 8,280. This is a number close to the 8,267. We thus see that 300 Levites were uncounted in order to provide a relationship between the Levites who served in the tabernacle and one seventy-third of the Israelites (Weiser).
78 There was no other age limitation.
79 We cannot draw any conclusion from the number of Israelites and the number of Levites given by Scripture, for they apply to different age groups.
80 That the 300 were first-born. We cannot prove that this was the case from Scripture itself.
81 Males (zakhor) qualifies first-born.
82 The cattle of the Levites which redeemed the first-born cattle of the Israelites remained with the Levites. Thus the Levites did not lose.
83 The first part of our verse indicates that all human first-born belong to the Lord. It does not say the same with regard to the first-born of the cattle. Hence I.E.’s comment.
84 In other words, Scripture repeats itself, for it has already told us in verse 41 that God told Moses to take the Levites.
85 In other words, take the Levites should be interpreted, when you take the Levites. Furthermore, when you take the Levites is connected to verse 46.

86 Our text reads, peduye ha-sheloshah. Now a word is usually not in the construct with a number. We thus say, shene chakahamim (two wise men), not chakhme shenaim (wise men of two) (Filwarg). Hence I.E.’s comment.

87 Hebrew, yesh makhhishim (there are those who dispute). This is a term usually applied to Karaites. However, in view of the fact that what the alleged disputers say is not in contradiction to tradition, it is hard to understand why I.E. refers to them as disputers. Indeed, Motot suggests changing the reading to yesh mefareshim (some interpret), and Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, Some say. Meijler suggest that the disputers also brought proof from this that (contrary to halakha) the first-born of Levites require redemption, for the first-born of the Levites did not exempt the first-born of Israel for all time.
88 That the redemption money for a first-born is five shekalim for all time.
89 Our text deals with a specific case; one cannot derive a law for all times from it.
90 That the redemption money is five shekalim. However, we do not derive it from our chapter.
91 For the Hebrew word for redemption is pidyon.
92 Here a nun has been substituted for a mem. See I.E. on verse 17.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 4
chapter.p: 2. TAKE THE SUM OF THE SONS OF KOHATH. First, because of Moses and Aaron.1
3. FROM THIRTY YEARS OLD AND UPWARD. Close to four weeks.2
[EVEN UNTIL FIFTY YEARS OLD.] A fifty-year-old is seven weeks of age. The body’s strength then declines.
TO DO WORK IN THE TENT OF MEETING. The work of bearing.
4. ABOUT THE MOST HOLY THINGS. The reference is to the ark.
5. THE VEIL OF THE SCREEN. Which covers the ark.3
6. AND SHALL PUT THEREON. On the cover.4 Others say that the word alav (thereon) refers to the word et (v. 5), which precedes parokhet (the veil).5 Va-titzpeno (and hid him)6 (Josh. 2:6) is similar.7
AND SHALL SPREAD OVER IT A CLOTH ALL OF BLUE. Kelil tekhelet means all of blue.
OVER IT. Some say, over the covering of tachash (sealskin). However, it appears to me that its meaning is, and they had already spread a cloth all of blue over the screen covering.8
If the blue cover was used in order to glorify the ark, then the first interpretation appears correct.9 The tachash covering served to protect [the ark] from the rain and the dust.10
AND SHALL SET THE STAVES THEREOF. Note, they removed the staves until the ark was covered.11 Some say that they shall set the staves upon the shoulders of the bearers.12
[7.] AND UPON THE TABLE OF SHOWBREAD. To teach us that there were other tables there13 for the use of the meat.14 Furthermore, the showbread which was placed upon this table was not removed.15

8. A CLOTH OF SCARLET. Look. There were two cloth coverings16 plus a covering of skin upon the table. There were similarly a screen covering,17 a blue cloth covering, and a covering of skin over the ark.18 A cloth covering and a cover of skin were over the menorah.19
10. AND SHALL PUT IT UPON A BAR. For it did not have any staves.20 It is similar to and they bore it upon a pole (Num. 13:25).21
11. AND UPON THE GOLDEN ALTAR THEY SHALL SPREAD. Another cloth22 and a covering.23
[15.] OF COVERING THE HOLY FURNITURE, AND ALL THE HOLY VESSELS.24 The ark, the table, the menorah, the altars, and all the utensils of ministry such as the knives, the spoons, and the plates.
13. AND THEY SHALL TAKE AWAY THE ASHES. It means, and they shall take away the ashes from the altar.25
15. THESE THINGS ARE THE BURDEN OF THE SONS OF KOHATH IN THE TENT OF MEETING. For they did not carry the tent and the tabernacle.26
16. AND THE CHARGE OF. U-fekudat (and the charge of) is related to the word pakid (overseer).27

THE OIL FOR THE LIGHT. Some say that Eleazar carried oil for one night’s light and similarly the continual meal offering.28 However, I believe that Eleazar was in charge of giving the oil for the light, that is, of the utensil containing the oil for the light, and similarly the vessel containing the anointing oil and the vessel containing the sweet incense, to the children of Kohath.

[HE SHALL HAVE THE CHARGE OF ALL THE TABERNACLE.] Scripture states this because Eleazar had charge over the tabernacle along with his brother Ithamar.29 However, Eleazar alone had charge over the oil, the sweet incense, and the meal offering because of his great status.
17. [UNTO MOSES AND UNTO AARON.] Scripture states this because Aaron and his sons were commanded to take heed that the sons of Kohath do not come to the penalty of excision (karet).
18. The command Cut ye not off was given to Moses, Aaron and his sons.
19. THAT THEY MAY LIVE. That their lives may be extended.

AND NOT DIE. By excision. The meaning of our verse is that the family of the Kohathites will be rewarded if they observe and will be punished if they do not. Without the phrase and not die, our verse could be taken to imply that they will not be punished.
AND APPOINT THEM.30 The ark, the table, the menorah, and the altars.
EVERY ONE TO HIS SERVICE. This refers to the holy vessels.
AND TO HIS BURDEN. To be carried on the shoulder.
20. BUT THEY SHALL NOT GO IN. The Kohathites shall not go in to the tent of meeting to see the holy things as they are being covered.
The meaning of ke-vala et ha-kodesh (the holy things as they are being covered) is, when the structure is taken down, the veil of the curtain is removed and the ark is revealed.31

Others say that the meaning of ke-vala is, when they are being covered. Thus the meaning of ke-vala et ha-kodesh is, when they cover the ark in order to carry it.32 This interpretation is more plausible than the first one. Now there are two prohibitions. One, not to touch the holy vessels-they are to be carried only by staves. Two, the Kohathites shall not see the holy things.
22. TAKE THE SUM. Naso (take the sum) is an infinitive. It is like zakhor (remember) in Remember the sabbath day, to keep it holy (Ex. 20:8).33 The meaning of naso is, take the sum.34
ALSO. Because he had already counted the Kohathites.
24. IN SERVING. To put up the tabernacle, to make the showbread, to slaughter, and to guard.

AND IN BEARING BURDENS. Le-massa35 (bearing burdens) is an infinitive. Similarly le-massa36 (causing to set forward) in and for causing the camps to set forward (Num. 10:2). The forms of verbs change.37
25. AND THE COVERING OF SEALSKIN THAT IS ABOVE IT. Scripture is being brief, for it does not mention the ramskin covering.38 Some say that the two coverings were attached.39
26. AND ALL THE INSTRUMENTS OF THEIR SERVICE. Such as tables, pegs, and cords.
AND WHATSOEVER THERE MAY BE TO DO WITH THEM. The instruments of service, or the tabernacle and the altar.
29. AS FOR THE SONS OF MERARI. Scripture does not mention that they were counted, for this section40 is connected to the one above.41
47. THE WORK OF SERVICE. This is to be understood as I have already explained.42
Now the meaning of All those that were numbered (v. 46) is, all those from thirty years old that were numbered.43
49. EVERY ONE. The reference is to Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
TO HIS SERVICE, AND TO HIS BURDEN. Hence and his numbered44 follows.

The section put out of the camp every leper, and every one that hath an issue, and whosoever is unclean by the dead (Num. 5:2) follows, because God’s presence was in the camps of Israel when they journeyed and when they rested.45
chapter.ftnote: 1 Moses and Aaron were descended from Kohath. Hence the sons of Kohath were counted first.

2 The Hebrew word for week is shavu’a. Shavu’a is related to the word sheva (seven). Hence I.E. believes that shavu’a can also refer to seven years. Thus “four weeks” would equal 28 years. According to I.E. there is a mystical significance to the number seven. See I.E. on Gen. 8:5 (Vol. 1, p. 114, n. 16) and the notes thereto. Also see The Secret of the Torah, a translation and annotation of Ibn Ezra’s Yesod Morah by H. Norman Strickman (Jason Aaronson, NJ, 1995, p. 125).
3 The Hebrew reads, parokhet ha-masakh. This literally means the screen which covers. I.E. explains that the screen is so called because it covers the ark. See Ex. 40:3.

4 Our verse reads, ve-natenu alav (and put thereon). However, parokhet is feminine. Thus our text should read aleha rather then alav. Hence I.E. notes than alav refers to the word masakh (covering/screen).

5 The word et (the sign of the accusative) serves both the masculine and the feminine. Hence I.E. believes that either a masculine or a feminine proportional pronoun may follow a word which has et in front of it (Filwarg). Thus the word alav can refer to et parokhet.
6 Translated literally. See next note.

7 The text should have read, and hid them, for the reference is to the two spies sent by Joshua. Now hid him is preceded by et shene ha-anashim (the two men). However, since the word et is used both with the singular and the plural, a singular or a plural may follow a phrase preceded by et.

8 In other words, u-fareshu (and shall spread) is a pluperfect and is to be rendered, and they had already spread. According to this interpretation, the blue cover was placed on the ark, and the tachash (sealskin) covering was placed over the blue covering.
9 Blue is a royal color. Hence it stands to reason that if it was placed on the ark, it should be visible.
10 Unlike the blue covering, which served as a decoration.

11 According to Ex. 25:15 the staves were never to be removed from the ark. I.E. believes that the staves were momentarily removed while the ark was being covered. Hence Scripture states, and shall set the staves thereof (back in place).

12 In other words, the meaning of and they shall set the staves thereof is, they shall set the staves upon the bearers of the ark. Thus our verse does not imply that the staves were ever removed from the ark. See Tosafot Yoma 72a.
13 Hence Scripture identifies the table.
14 For the use of the sacrificial meat.
15 Hence it is referred to as the table of showbread.
16 One of blue (v. 7) and one of scarlet (v. 8).
17 The parokhot ha-masakh (v. 5).
18 Verse 6.
19 Verses 9 and 10.
20 By which to carry it.

21 There too the grapes, which of course did not have any staves, were placed on a bar in order to be carried. Weiser suggests that I.E. believed that bar is to be interpreted as two bars, in the same manner that pole is to be interpreted as poles.
22 Hebrew, beged acher. Some emend to one cloth (beged echad) (Filwarg).
23 The reference is to a covering of tachash (sealskin).
24 I.E.’s comment is misplaced. It belongs in verse 15.

25 The word deshen means ashes. Thus ve-dishenu literally means, and they shall ash. This might be taken to mean, and they shall put on ashes. Hence I.E.’s interpretation that ve-dishenu means, and they shall remove the ashes.
26 Scripture states, These things are the burden, because they did not do any carrying.
27 One who assigns tasks.

28 The daily continual meal offering. See Yerushalmi, Sabbath 10:13. Eleazar carried oil for the lighting in his right hand and the sweet incense in his left hand, while the continual meal offering hung from his arm.
29 If Eleazar was in charge of the entire tabernacle, why does Scripture tell us that he was in charge of the oil, the sweet incense, and the meal offering? Hence I.E.’s comments.
30 Hebrew, ve-samu otam, which literally means, and put them. This can be interpreted as referring to the kohanim. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
31 According to I.E. the meaning of the holy things as they are being covered is, when the holy (i.e., the tabernacle) is taken down.
32 In other words, ke-vala means when it is covered. The word bala means swallowed. Thus ke-vala literally means when he swallows, i.e., when he covers.
33 Which is an infinitive too.
34 In other words, even though naso is an infinitive, it has the meaning of an imperative. The same applies to zakhor.
35 From the root nun, sin, alef.
36 From the root nun, sin, ayin.
37 Le-massa in our verse is vocalized kamatz, pattach. Le-massa in Num. 10:2 is vocalized pattach, pattach. Hence I.E.’s comment.
38 Which was above the sealskin covering. See Ex. 26:14.
39 Thus the covering of sealskin includes the ramskin covering.
40 Verses 29-37.
41 Verses 21-28. Thus the command Take the sum of in verse 22 also applies here.

42 In his comments on verse 15, I.E. hints that the term work of service applies to the carrying of the tent and the tabernacle, which was the work assigned to the sons of Gershon and Merari, while the term the work of bearing burdens refers to the work done by the sons of Kohath (Weiser).
43 In other words, our verse is a continuation of verse 46.

44 Hebrew, u-fekudav. The singular u-fekudav is employed because the terms which precede it (avodato, his service, and masa’o, his burden) are i n the singular. It should be noted that J.P.S. renders u-fekudav as they were also numbered.
45 Hence all those who were unclean had to leave the camp.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 5
chapter.p: 2. EVERY LEPER, AND EVERY ONE THAT HATH AN ISSUE,1 AND WHOSOEVER IS UNCLEAN BY THE DEAD. These are states of uncleanliness that last for seven days. They also render others unclean.2 Therefore a person who had a seminal omission does not leave the camp.3 Similarly, no place was setaside outside the camp4 for the performing of bodily functions.5 On the contrary, each person dug in his own tent6 as is the custom with all the camps, for there were children among them.7 Now the section which opens with When thou goest forth in camp against thine enemies (Deut. 23:10) speaks of a small camp wherein there are no women, and the ark is among them and they do not surround the ark.8 [They have to leave the camp],9 for God’s presence is in the center of any Israelite camp. I will explain this in its proper place.10
3. FEMALE. A woman who has an irregular menstrual flow,11 a normal menstrual flow,12 a woman who is a leper13 or who was made unclean by a dead body.14

4. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL DID SO. Immediately, before they journeyed. When the unclean journeyed, they journeyed between the standard of Ephraim15 and the standard of Dan.16 The aforementioned is based on logic,17 for this is not explained in Scripture.

The section that begins with When a man or woman [shall commit any sin that men commit, to commit a trespass against the Lord]18 follows the previous chapter19 because leprosy and unclean issue20 are brought about by trespassing against the Lord.21
The reason this section is repeated22 is that the Torah wants to mention but if the man have no kinsman (v. 8).23
7. THEN THEY SHALL CONFESS. Whichever one it be, a man or a woman.
IN FULL. Be-rosho (in full) means as it is, not less than it is.24

AND ADD UNTO IT THE FIFTH PART. If he confesses on his own. However, if there are witnesses then he shall add two fifths. Those who transmitted the law25 say a fifth of a fifth.26 Their minds are greater than ours.
8. THE RESTITUTION…SHALL BE THE LORDS. For he made restitution because of his fear of the Lord.27

10. AND EVERY MAN’S HALLOWED THINGS SHALL BE HIS. Its meaning is that they belong to the one who hallows them. He may give them to any kohen that he wants to. This is noted because Scripture mentions the gifts given to the kohanim.28
The portion dealing with a straying wife follows29 because the straying wife commits a trespass against her husband.30
12. IF ANY MAN’S WIFE GO ASIDE. Tisteh means will go aside from the right way.31 Similarly seteh (go aside) in Go aside from it (Prov. 4:15).
13. CARNALLY. Shikhvat zera (carnally) refers to carnal laying. It is called shikhvat zera32 because its purpose is for seed.33
AND IT BE HID. She did not reveal the matter. There is not even one witness through whom she is suspect.
NEITHER SHE BE TAKEN IN THE ACT. By witnesses, men or women, so that she be suspected.
14. AND THE SPIRIT OF JEALOUSY COME UPON HIM. Ru’ach (spirit) is masculine here.34 Similarly ru’ach (wind) in and a great and strong wind (I Kings 19:11).35
COME. Come upon his mind.
15. BRING. Against her will.
FOR HER. Aleha (for her) means with her or because of her.36

BARLEY MEAL. Our rabbis said, she acted like a beast, let her bring the food of a beast.37 A free-will meal offering consists of pure wheat flower so that the celebrant will be remembered for good. However, this meal offering recalls a sin, if a sin was committed. Hence it is an inferior offering and consists of barley without oil and without frankincense.
16. AND THE PRIEST SHALL BRING HER NEAR. Her38 refers to the meal offering.39
AND SET HER40 BEFORE THE LORD. Before the altar.
17. HOLY WATER. From the basin, for it has already become holy.41
ON THE FLOOR OF THE TABERNACLE. The reference is to the well-known floor.42 The word afar (dust) has a definite article before it. It refers to the earth which is beneath the floor.43

18. AND LET THE HAIR OF THE WOMAN’S HEAD GO LOOSE. Para (go loose) means he shall uncover.44 However, I believe that it means he shall take out the hair of the woman, which was covered, and let it go loose.

THE WATER OF BITTERNESS. It is my opinion that the word me (water) is in the construct45 and the word ha-marim is an adjective.46 If so, then its secret is known.47 It is also possible that the waters were so called because of their ultimate taste.48 Compare, And stripped the naked of their clothing (Job 22:6).49 And the water that causeth the curse shall enter into her and become bitter (v. 24) is proof of this, for this verse indicates that the oaths,50 which they that cause the curses51 refers to, will make the sweet waters bitter.
The word ha-me’arerim (that causeth the curse) is a hifil. It is like the word erarah (cursed) in which the Lord hath cursed (Gen. 5:29).52
19. [SHALL CAUSE HER TO SWEAR.] Its meaning is that the woman shall answer, Amen, Amen.
IF NO MAN HAVE LAIN WITH THEE. Its meaning is, if another man has not forced himself upon you.53
AND IF THOU HAST NOT GONE ASIDE. Willingly. Satit means you have gone aside and committed an unclean act.54 It is similar to thou shalt not build it of hewn stones (Ex. 20:25).55
BE THOU FREE. The meaning of hinnaki is, be thou free.56 It is similar to and die in the mount (Deut. 32:50).57

It is possible that the first time Scripture says, and the priest shall cause her to swear58 means, and the priest shall cause her to swear by invoking God’s name. The second time this phrase is used59 it means, as Scripture notes,60 via the curses.
21. THY THIGH…THY BELLY. They are the neighbors.61
TO SWELL. The word tzavah means to swell. The word is not found anywhere else in Scripture.62
22. TO FALL AWAY. The lamed of lanpil (to fall away) is vocalized with a pattach because the heh of the form63 is missing.64 The same is true of the word lashmid (to destroy) (Is. 23:11).65
AMEN, AMEN. The word amen is repeated for emphasis.66
23. [IN A SCROLL.] They had a specific scroll for curses.67
26. THE MEMORIAL-PART THEREOF.68 That which served as her memorial, for good or bad in accordance with her deeds.
27. AND HAVE ACTED UNFAITHFULLY. Va-timal ma’al (and have acted unfaithfully) is to be understood here as I have explained.69 It refers to something covered.70
28. AND SHALL CONCEIVE SEED. God will give her seed in recompense for the shame which befell her.
31. SHALL BEAR HER INIQUITY. If she was defiled.

Our verse states, And the man shall be clear from iniquity.71 For if a spirit of jealousy came upon him she is prohibited to him. He is not allowed to he with her.72 If he sleeps with her, he is guilty of sin.

Some say that the section dealing with the Nazirite follows the section dealing with the wife who is accused of adultery because if the latter was not defiled, then she will have a son who is a Nazirite. However, I believe that the chapter dealing with the Nazirite follows [the chapter dealing with the wife who is accused of adultery] because it lays down the law regarding a female Nazirite who is the reverse of the unfaithful wife. Now wine73 causes most sins. Furthermore, a woman who does not fix her hair74 does not seek sexual relations.75
chapter.ftnote: 1 Hebrew, zav. A zav or a zavah is a person who has an abnormal discharge from the genital organs.
2 For the uncleanliness of the zav and the zavah, see Lev. 15:1-28. For the uncleanliness of those who come into contact with the dead, see Num. 19:1- 22.

3 The camp discussed in our chapter, i.e., the camp of the entire people of Israel. I.E. comments thus because one who has a seminal mission is obligated to leave a camp of soldiers who go to war. See Deut. 23:10-14.
4 See note 3.
5 As there was in the case of a camp of soldiers. See Deut. 23:10-14.
6 Dug a pit for his bodily excretions.
7 It would be very difficult to take children outside of the camp every time they had to relieve themselves.

8 With a fence as they do in a large camp (see I.E. on Deut. 23:10). Thus in a small camp, or a war camp, the ark is exposed. Some manuscripts read, and they surround the ark; i.e., they are in close proximity to the ark.
9 A war camp.
10 See I.E. on Deut. 23:10. For another interpretation, see Weiser.
15 The standard of Ephraim journeyed in front of the standard of Dan.
16 The standard of Dan journeyed at the rear. See Num. 10:25.
17 For it is hard to believe that the unclean traveled outside of the standards and were thus exposed to danger.
18 Verses 6-10.
19 Verses 1-4.
20 Hebrew, zav.
21 They are punishments for sin. See Arakin 16b.
22 The material in verses 5-10 repeats what has already been stated in Lev. 5:20-26.
23 This law is not mentioned in Lev 5:20-26.
24 Be-rosho literally means at its head, or at first. Hence I.E.’s comment.
25 The Talmudic sages.

26 See Baba Kamma 108a. See Rashi on Lev. 5:24, “If he denies the fifth (i.e., he asserts that he has repaid both capital and fifth, but has not really paid the latter, for which a claim is now made against him) and takes an oath that he has paid it but afterwards admits the claim, then he must now bring (pay) a fifth in addition to this fifth (a fifth of the original fifth which now become the keren (capital) in addition to it).” (Rosenbaum and Silbermann translation).
27 He confessed because of his fear of the Lord.
28 In verse 9.
29 The portion that deals with one who trespasses against the Lord.
30 They are thus thematically connected.
31 In other words, the word tisteh means to go aside. Here, to go aside from the right path.
32 Literally, laying of seed.
33 Its purpose is for ejaculation (Weiser). Or its purpose is to produce children.
34 Avar (come upon), the verb governing ru’ach, is masculine.
35 Here too chazak (strong), one of the verbs governing ru’ach, is masculine.
36 The usual meaning of aleha is, upon her. Hence I.E.’s comment.
37 Mishnah, Sotah 2:1.
38 Hebrew, otah.
39 Not the woman. The word otah literally means her. However, it also means it.
40 The meal offering. I.E. explains our verse in this way because verse 18 tells us that the kohen is to make the woman stand before the Lord.
41 By being in the basin.
42 The word afar (dust) has a definite article before it, a heh with a segol beneath it. Hence I.E.’s comment.
43 In other words, be-afar (in the dust) refers to the earth which is beneath the floor of a certain spot in the tabernacle. See Mishnah Sotah 2:2.
44 According to this opinion the meaning of our verse is, and he shall uncover (u-fara) the hair of the woman.
45 With a missing word.
46 Describing the missing word.
47 We know what word is missing. According to I.E. the phrase me ha- marim is short for me ha-sammim ha-marim (the water containing the bitter ingredient). See Sotah 20a.
48 The waters were not yet bitter. They only turned bitter at the end. Hence I.E. explains that they are called the bitter waters because they were ultimately bitter.
49 One cannot strip a naked person. Thus what Scripture means is that the one who was ultimately naked was stripped.
50 Mentioned in verse 19. The waters turned bitter after the oaths were dissolved in it.
51 The curses come about through her false swearing.
52 It too is a hifil. The root alef, resh, resh usually comes in the kal. Hence I.E.’s comment.
53 If no man have lain with thee cannot be taken literally because we are dealing with a married women. Hence I.E.’s comment.
54 In other words, satit is short for satit tume’ah.

55 Ex. 20:25 literally reads, you shall not build them uncut stones. I.E. believes that this is short for: you shall not build a hewn structure out of them. See I.E. on Ex. 20:25 and the notes thereto (Vol. 2, p. 443-4).

56 Hinnaki is an imperative. It literally means free yourself. However, it cannot mean that here, for it is not in the power of the woman to free herself. Hence hinnaki must be taken as an imperfect rather than as an imperative, even though it has the form of the latter.

57 U-mot (and die), an imperative, must be interpreted as if written ve-tamut (and you will die), for the time of one’s natural death is not in one’s hands. See I.E. on Gen. 1:22 and the notes thereto (Vol. 1, p. 42).
58 That is, in our verse.
59 That is, in verse 21.
60 In verse 21.
61 They are near the genital organs.
62 Literally, has no neighbor except in this chapter. Neither this word nor any word with the same root is found any where else in Scripture, only here.
63 The hifil.
64 Lanpil is short for le-hanpil.
65 Lashmid is short for le-hashmid.
66 To indicate that the woman fully agrees with what the kohen says.
67 According to I.E. they had a special book which was used for this ritual. Our verse reads ba-sefer (in a book). Ba-sefer literally means in the book. Hence I.E.’s comment.
68 The Hebrew reads azkaratah. This literally means her memorial. Hence I.E.’s comment.
69 See I.E. on Lev. 5:15.

70 According to I.E. on Lev. 5:15, the phrase li-me’ol ma’al means to remove a cover (me’il), to uncover that which should remain covered. Va-time’ol ma’al thus means, and have committed an act of treachery.
71 If the woman is exonerated and he has relations with her.
72 If a man suspects his wife of adultery, he is prohibited from having sexual relations with her until she is exonerated.
73 Which the Nazirite forswears.
74 The Nazirite is prohibited from cutting hair.
75 Thus the female Nazirite who abstains from wine and does not cut her hair is the reverse of the unfaithful wife who drinks wine and does cut her hair.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 6
chapter.p: 2. SHALL CLEARLY UTTER A VOW. The word yafli means to set aside. On the other hand, it might mean doing something out of the ordinary,1 for most people follow their lusts.2
THE VOW OF A NAZIRITE. Neder nazir means an oath to be a Nazirite, for the word nazir (Nazirite) is an adjective.3 The word ve-yenazeru (that they separate) (Lev. 22:13) is related to it.

[TO CONSECRATE HIMSELF UNTO THE LORD.]4 To distance himself from lust. He does this in order to serve God, for wine destroys reason and the proper service of God.5 I will hint at a secret in the chapter that opens with When thou goest forth in camp against thine enemies (Deut. 23:10).
3. [HE SHALL ABSTAIN FROM WINE AND STRONG DRINK.] Its meaning is, if he took a vow to be a Nazirite and holy, then he shall separate himself from wine and strong drink.
According to the transmitters of tradition, shekhar (strong drink) is aged wine.6 Others say that shekhar is to be taken literally; it refers to any drink that intoxicates a person.
[HE SHALL DRINK NO VINEGAR OF WINE…NEITHER SHALL HE DRINK ANY LIQUOR OF GRAPES, NOR EAT FRESH GRAPES.] This explains the oath.7 He must distance himself from anything connected to wine.8
In the account of the wife of Manoah,9 Scripture states, and eat not any unclean thing (Jud. 13:7). She10 may not eat of any thing that cometh of the grape-vine (Jud. 13:14).

LIQUOR OF. The word mishrat (liquor of) is not found elsewhere in Scripture. The tav indicates that the word is feminine and is in the construct. Mishrat anavim refers to anything that has been mashed with grapes. Others say that mishrat anavim refers to a cooked drink.11

4. PRESSED GRAPES. The word chartzannim (pressed grapes) is not found anywhere else in Scripture. The same applies to the word zag (grape-stone). The commentaries tells us that chartzannim refers to the outer skin of the grape and zag to the pits. Others say the reverse.12 According to these interpretations, me-chartzannim (from the pressed grapes)13 is connected to nothing that is made of the grape-vine. The meaning of our verse is that the Nazirite shall eat nothing made from the grapevine, that is, from these two things.14
5. HE SHALL LET THE LOCKS OF THE HAIR OF HIS HEAD GROW LONG. The word gaddel (grow) is a pi’el infinitive.15 The meaning of gaddel is, he shall grow.
6. THAT HE CONSECRATETH. The word hazziro (that he consecrateth) is a hifil infinitive.16
A DEAD BODY.17 The word met (dead) is an adjective describing body (nefesh). On the other hand, the word guf (body) is missing from our text.18
7. FOR HIS FATHER, OR FOR HIS MOTHER. And certainly not for his wife, his daughter, and others.
Some say that the word nazir (Nazirite) is related to the word nezer (crown). Because his consecration (nezer) unto God is upon his head19 is proof of this. This interpretation is not farfetched.20
Note that most people are slaves to worldly lusts. The true king, the one who has a crown, the one who wears the royal diadem, is the person who is free from this lust.21
9. VERY SUDDENLY. The words peta and pitom22 are close in meaning. The same applies to admat afar (dust of the earth) (Dan. 12:2).23
AND HE DEFILE. The corpse will defile him.24
IN THE DAY OF HIS CLEANSING. By the waters of purification,25 for he was defiled by a corpse.26
11. ONE FOR A SIN-OFFERING AND THE OTHER FOR A BURNT-OFFERING. Its secret was explained by the sages. They said that the reward of sin is sin.27

FOR THAT HE SINNED BY REASON OF THE BODY.28 The reference is to a dead body. Compare the word nefesh (body) in Ye shall not make any cuttings in your flesh for a body (Lev. 19:28).29 If the sin referred to a sin committed against his very own body,30 then Scripture would not command him to return to his sin.31
12. AND HE SHALL CONSECRATE UNTO THE LORD THE DAYS OF HIS NAZIRITESHIP. All the days that he vowed to be a Nazirite. He shall now begin to count them.32
BECAUSE HIS CONSECRATION WAS DEFILED. For he vowed to be a Nazirite for a fixed number of days in succession without anything intervening and breaking them up.

13. FULFILLED. Melot (fulfilled) is an infinitive. Its final root letter is an alef.33 It is conjugated like a word that has a heh as a final root letter.34 It is like the word kero’ot (call)35 in that thou didst call us (Jud. 8:1).

HE SHALL BRING IT.36 Yavi oto (he shall bring it) means he37 shall bring himself.38 Compare, but the shepherds fed themselves (Ezek. 34:8).39 Or yavi oto means that the kohen shall bring him40 against his will by commanding that he be forced to bring his sacrifice.
14. ONE HE-LAMB. A male, as is the law regarding all burnt offerings.41
ONE EWE-LAMB. A female, as is the law with all sin offerings.42
AND ONE RAM…FOR PEACE-OFFERINGS. As an expression of joy that he fulfilled his vow.
16. HIS SIN-OFFERING. The sin offering is mentioned first43 because it was mentioned last,44 for this is Hebrew style.
18. THE HAIR OF. The Hebrew word for hair of is vocalized in two ways.45
19. WHEN IT IS SODDEN. The meaning of beshelah (when it is sodden) is, and it46 is sodden.47

AFTER HE HATH SHAVEN HIS CONSECRATED HEAD. This is a sign that the kodesh hu (this is holy) (v. 20) refers to the word shoulder,48 for that is the main organ that is being waved. On the other hand, the word hu (this)49 may refer to all that is waved.50

[21. BESIDE THAT FOR WHICH HIS MEANS SUFFICE.] It means that he is obligated to give in accordance with his wealth. He is also obligated to give in accordance with the days of his vow, whether they are few or whether they are many.51

The chapter dealing with the blessings of the kohanim52 follows the chapter dealing with the Nazirite because, after concluding the laws of the Nazirite who is holy, Scripture mentions the laws of the kohanim who are holy.

Those who contradict Rabbinic tradition53 say that the kohen used this blessing to bless all who brought a gift. They claim that the blessing of the kohanim follows the law of the Nazirite because the latter concludes with “beside that which the means of the celebrant suffice.”54 However, the truth is in keeping with the tradition of our sages of blessed memory.55 And Aaron lifted up his hands toward the people, and blessed them (Lev. 9:22)56 on the eighth day57 is proof of this. This portion58 was written because God commanded Aaron to bless the people when the tabernacle was erected. Scripture there59 mentions, nesi’at kappayim (the lifting of the hands),60 for the word kappayim means the same as yadayim (hands).61 However, the term yadayim is a more general term.62
