24. THE LORD BLESS THEE. The Lord increase your life and your wealth.63
AND KEEP THEE. God will protect what he has increased so that no one steals it.

25. THE LORD MAKE HIS FACE TO SHINE UPON THEE. Its meaning is the same as In the light of the king’s countenance is life (Prov. 16:15). It means may God make his face to shine upon you when you ask something of Him and at the time that you make the request. May God accept you and may His will be to immediately fulfill your request.

[AND BE GRACIOUS TO THEE.] If you make a request of God in a time of trouble, may He be gracious to you. Ve-yechunekka (and be gracious to thee) is similar to channuni (have pity) in have pity upon me, O ye (Job. 19:21) and chanan (graciously given) in The children whom God hath graciously given (Gen. 33:5).64 Ve-yechunekka comes from the same root as chanan.65

26. THE LORD LIFT UP HIS COUNTENANCE UPON THEE. The reverse of I will hide Mine eyes from you (Is. 1:15). As I have already explained,66 its meaning is, wherever you go My face shall be lifted up to you.
AND GIVE THEE PEACE. Its meaning is similar to, no evil — from stones, from evil animals, from any enemy — touch thee (Job. 5:19).

27. SO SHALL THEY PUT MY NAME. Its meaning is similar to to set His name there (Deut. 14:24),67 that is, the children of Israel be sanctified by God’s name. Or it means that when they shall mention My name over the children of Israel [I will bless them], for God’s revered and awe-inspiring name is found in each one of the three verses.68

AND I WILL BLESS THEM. It is possible that the mem69 of avarekhem (I will bless them) refers to the kohanim who utter the blessing. It means they will bless Israel, and I will bless those who bless.70 It is also possible that the mem of avarekhem refers to Israel.71 Its meaning is, if the kohanim bless Israel, then I will bless Israel; that is, I will fulfill the blessing of the kohanim. In my opinion, the mem of avarekhem refers to all of them, the kohanim and the Israelites.72
chapter.ftnote: 1 The word yafli is related to the word pele (wonder).
2 But this person took an oath to separate himself from the pleasure of drinking. Hence what he did was wondrous.
3 Nazir modifies the person who takes the oath, for according to I.E. the meaning of neder nazir is to be a Nazirite person. See Weiser.
4 The Hebrew reads, le-hazir la-Adonai. This literally means to separate himself unto the Lord. Hence I.E.’s comment.
5 Thus le-nazir la-Adonai means to separate (himself from wine) in order to serve God.
6 In other words, shekhar refers to old wine while yayin refers to young wine. See Targum and Rashi.
7 Taken by the Nazirite.
8 Hence he must not eat any grapes or grape products even if they are not intoxicating.
9 The mother of Samson.
10 Samson’s mother.
11 Made from grapes.
12 See Nazir 34b.
13 That is, me-chartzannim ad zag (from the pressed grapes even to the grape-stone).
14 The outer skin and the pit of the grape.
15 Scripture employs an infinitive with the meaning of a third person imperfect (yegaddel).
16 It is not a perfect; if it were, it would be vocalized hiziro.
17 Hebrew, nefesh met.
18 In this case, the word met is describing the word guf. Our verse reads, nefesh met.
19 I.E. renders this clause, “Because the crown of (nezer) his God is upon his head.”
20 It is not aggadic.
21 Hence the term nazir, the one who wears the crown.
22 J.P.S. renders peta pitom as very suddenly. According to I.E. the literal meaning of peto pitom is suddenly, suddenly.
23 For adamah and afar mean the same. See I.E. on Gen. 8:11 (Vol. 1, p. 115.
24 In other words, and he defile his consecrated head does not mean and the Nazirite will defile himself, but that the corpse will defile the Nazirite.
26 Ibid.
27 Abot 4:2. I.E.’s point is that the Nazirite must have been guilty of some sin for uncleanliness to have befallen him during his period of Naziriteship (Filwarg).
28 Hebrew, nefesh. J.P.S. renders it as dead.
29 Hebrew, la-nefesh. J.P.S. renders it as the dead.
30 According to Rabbi Eleazar Ha-Kappar, the Nazirite sins by abstaining from wine. See Nazir 19:a; Nedarim 10:2.
31 To start the days of his Nazirite term anew (v. 12).
32 He shall now start to count them anew.
33 Its root is mem, lamed, alef.
34 Hence the ending ot. Words that end in an alef end in an o in the infinitive. Thus the infinitive of mem, lamed, alef should be melo.
35 Which comes from the root kof, resh, alef, but whose infinitive form follows the paradigm of a word ending in a heh.
36 Hebrew, oto. Oto can mean him or it. I.E. renders our phrase, he shall bring him.
37 The Nazirite.
38 In other words, oto (him) here has the meaning of himself.
39 Hebrew, otam. Literally, them (otam). However, in order to makes sense of the verse we must render otam as themselves. Similarly, oto (him) in our verse is to be rendered as himself.
40 The Nazirite if he refuses to bring his offering.
41 See Lev. 1:3.
43 In our verse, even though the burnt offering was offered first.
44 In verse 14.
45 Se’ar (sheva, pattach) in our verse, and sa’ar (pattach, pattach) in Is. 7:20.
46 The shoulder.
47 Our verse reads, ha-zero’ah beshelah. This literally means the shoulder cooked. Hence I.E.’s comment.
48 In our verse.
49 In kodesh hu.
50 Even though hu is a singular. Thus kodesh hu refers to all that is being waved.
51 The additional offerings brought by the Nazirite are contingent upon the length of his vow; the longer the vow period, the more sacrifices to be brought.
52 Verses 22-26.
53 The Karaites.
54 I.E.’s paraphrase of beside that for which his means suffice.
55 The rabbis teach that this is a blessing to be given to all of Israel. This is so even though it is written in the singular.
56 We thus see that Aaron blessed all of Israel. I.E. assumes that the reference is to the blessing mentioned in verses 24-26.
57 Of consecration when the tabernacle was dedicated.
58 Verses 24-26.
60 The Rabbinic term for the blessing given by the kohanim.

61 Lev. 9:22 reads: Va-yissa et yadav (lifted up his hands). According to I.E. this means the same as va-yissa et kapav. Thus Lev. 9:22 refers to what the rabbis call nisi’at kappayim, that is, the blessing given by the kohanim.
62 It takes in the entire hand, while kappayim technically refers to the fingers and their sockets (Weiser).
63 According to I.E. a blessing means an increase in the good. See his comments on Gen. 2:3 (Vol. 1, p. 50).
64 According to I.E. this should be rendered, The children whom God out His pity hath given.
65 Which I.E. renders, to have pity. See I.E. on Ex. 22:26 (Vol. 2, p. 490).
66 It isn’t clear where I.E. made this comment earlier.
67 It means that “the place” will be sanctified because it shall be called by God’s name.
68 Hence this is what So shall they put My name upon the children of Israel refers to.
69 The mem of va-avarekhem is a pronominal suffix meaning them.
70 In other words, the meaning of So shall they put My name upon the children of Israel, and I will bless them is: the kohanim shall bless Israel and I will bless the kohanim.
71 Thus and I will bless them means and I will bless Israel.
72 Thus the meaning of and I will bless them is, I will bless both Israel and the kohanim.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 7
chapter.p: 1. [AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE DAY THAT MOSES HAD MADE AN END OF SETTING UP THE TABERNACLE.] Moses made an end to the setting up of the tabernacle after the blessing of the kohanim,1 as this was how events unfolded.2 On the day that Aaron lifted up his hands toward the people and blessed them,3 the dedication of the tabernacle began.4

The verse And it came to pass on the day that Moses had made an end of setting up the tabernacle is proof of the words of our sages, that Moses took the tabernacle down, raised it up and took it down again, and erected it again throughout the seven days of dedication to train the kohanim.5 For the meaning of and sanctified them is that he sanctified them [the furniture, the altar, and the vessels] by the sprinkling of the blood6 during the seven days of dedication.7
AND THE ALTAR AND ALL THE VESSELS THEREOF. This is connected to on the day that Moses had made an end of setting up the tabernacle.8 It means that he set the altar up in its place.
AND ALL THE VESSELS THEREOF, AND HAD ANOINTED THEM. With the anointing oil
AND SANCTIFIED THEM. With blood. Scripture mentions the altar because of its dedication.9
2. THAT THE PRINCES OF ISRAEL…OFFERED. Scripture employs a general term.10 Its meaning is that they brought their offering to the Lord before the opening of the tabernacle.

3. COVERED. The word tzav (covered) here is similar to the word tzabbim (Utters) in and in litters, and upon mules (Is. 66:20). The reference is to a type of ox that pulls wagons.11 Others say that eglot tzav (covered wagons) refers to a wagon that is overloaded and that tzav is connected to the word tzavah (swell) (Num. 5:21). However, this is farfetched.

[AND TWELVE OXEN.] I have already explained in my work moznayim12 that the mem in shenem asar (twelve) remains both in the absolute13 and in the construct.14 The meaning of shenem asar (twelve) is two (shenayim) and ten (eser).15 The word shenem is connected to aser for purposes of brevity. The same applies to shelosh elleh (these three) (Ex. 21:11).16 The phrase shene asar (twelve)17 without the mem is an abridged form.18
FOR EVERY TWO OF THE PRINCES. Al shene ha-nesi’im means for every two of the princes.19

[13. AND HIS OFFERING.] Scripture reads, and his offering because Scripture had already stated, And he that presented [his offering] (v. 12). The vav of ve-korbano (and his offering) means, and this was his offering.

Scripture writes with regard to the second day, hikriv et korbano (he offered his offering)20 (v. 18), for this is the style of Scripture. Compare, And Isaac spoke unto Abraham his father, and said: ‘My father’ (Gen. 22:7). The word father is repeated because Scripture is being lengthy. Then spoke the king Ahasuerus and said unto Esther the queen (Esth. 7:5) is also similar.21

Scripture does not mention the term hikriv (he presented) with regard to the other princes,22 for Scripture wanted to be brief. Similarly the term le-gulgelotam (by their poles) is used only in the numbering of Reuben23 and Simeon.24 There are many such examples.25

48. ON THE SEVENTH DAY. Some say that Elishama the son of Ammihud presented his offering on the Sabbath. It was a ruling for that time.26 Others say that the reference is to the seventh day of the dedication of the tabernacle.27 Those who disagree with our sages say that the first day of the altar’s dedication did not fall on the first day of the week.28 However, this is of no avail, for it is impossible that there be no Sabbath in twelve days.

I believe that the second interpretation29 is correct, because of the peace offering.30 The seventh day of the circling of Jericho is similar.31 Likewise the seven days of the dedication of the temple (I Kings 8:65) because of the Day of Atonement.32
51. ONE YOUNG BULLOCK. Ben bakar means a young bullock. Compare, ben yonah (young dove).33

53. TWO OXEN. These were also male bullocks.34 The meaning of bakar (oxen) is, from the kind of cattle.35 And all the oxen for the sacrifice of peace-offerings twenty and four bullocks (v. 88) is proof of this.36

72. ON THE ELEVENTH DAY. I have already explained in my work moznayim why this number37 differs [from the other numbers].38 The word ashte in (ashte asar, eleven) is similar to the word eshtonotav (his thoughts) (Ps. 146:4). It (ashte) refers to that which a person’s thoughts give birth to. The number ten, as it were begets [eleven, etc.]. This is a great secret.39

Rabbi Jonah the Sephardi40 says that ashte asar is short for al shete asar. Its meaning is, the number that precedes twelve.41 Now Rabbi Jonah made two great mistakes. One, contrary to his words, the number twelve is beyond (al) the number eleven.42 From twenty years old and upward (va-ma’alah) (Num. 1:3) is proof of the aforementioned.43 His second mistake is that if the word ashte is short for al shete, then the text should have read ashne asar,44 not ashte asar. For ashte is in the feminine.45 Ashte is therefore one word.

89. [AND WHEN MOSES WENT IN.] It is likely that the beginning of God’s word to Moses [in the tabernacle], which is what And the Lord called unto Moses (Lev. 1:1) refers to, was uttered when the dedication of the tabernacle was completed.

All the grammarians say that the word middabber (speaking) in speaking unto him is a hitpa’el46 with the tav swallowed.47 However, in my opinion middadbber is an infinitive. It is similar to the word dabber (speak)48 in behold, I cannot speak (Jer. 1:5). The mem prefixed to middabber is in place of the word min, as is the rule in the Hebrew language.49

The meaning of va-yishma (then he heard) is that only Moses heard the voice. Anyone in the tent of meeting outside of the curtain did not hear the voice. The following is also correct: God made Moses’ ear supersensitive50 as he added to the sight of Elisha’s young man (II Kings 6:17). Similarly Then the Lord opened the eyes of Balaam (Num. 22:31).51
AND HE SPOKE UNTO HIM. This was the way God’s word always came to Moses.52
chapter.ftnote: 1 After the kohanim blessed Israel. See Num. 6:24-26; Lev. 9:22.
2 Chapter 7 follows the blessing of the kohanim at the end of chapter 6.
4 Our verse.

5 According to the rabbis, had made an end of setting up the tabernacle indicates that the tabernacle had been set up and taken down a number of times. See I.E. on Ex. 40:2 and the notes thereto (Vol. 2, p. 754). It should be noted that I.E. there rejects the opinion that Moses erected and took down the tabernacle during the seven days of dedication.
7 When the tabernacle was set up and taken down.
8 In other words, And it came to pass on the day that Moses had made an end of setting up the tabernacle also applies to and the altar.
9 Prima facie, the altar is included in the furniture thereof. Hence I.E. points out the altar is singled out for special mention because it had a special dedication.

10 Our verse tells us in general terms that the princes brought an offering. Unlike the offerings brought by the princes when the altar was dedicated (verses 12-83), Scripture does not list the offerings prince by prince.
11 According to this interpretation, here eglot tzav (covered wagons) means wagons pulled by a tzav. This commentary renders Is. 66:20, and upon oxen and mules.
12 A work on grammar.
13 That is, in the word two (shenayim).
14 In the phrase shenem asar (twelve). When a word ending in a mem is connected to another word, the mem is dropped. Hence I.E.’s comment.
15 In other words, shenem asar is short for shenayim ve-asar, Hence the change in the vowel, shenem rather than shenayim.
16 Shelosh is in the construct with elleh. Otherwise the phrase would be written shalosh elleh. See I.E. on Ex. 21:11 (Vol. 2, p. 464).
17 This is the form used in our verse.
18 Shene asar is short for shenem asar.
19 The word al usually means on. I.E. points out that here it means for.
20 Translated literally. J.P.S. renders, he presented for his offering. There is no reason to say he offered his offering. Scripture should have read, he offered.
21 Here too Scripture employs a lengthy style (said and spoke).
22 It is used only in regard to the offering of Nethanel the son of Zuar.
24 Num. 1:22. Also see I.E. on 1:19.
25 Where Scripture employs an abbreviated style.
26 For personal offerings cannot be offered on the Sabbath.
27 According to this interpretation, the Sabbath day is not included in the days of dedication, for no sacrifice was offered on the Sabbath.
28 Hence the seventh day of dedication did not fall on the Sabbath.
29 That the seventh day refers to the seventh day of dedication, not to the seventh day of the week.
30 Brought by Elishama. Peace offerings were not brought on the Sabbath.
31 See Josh. 6:6-15. According to I.E. the seventh day on which the Israelites circled Jericho was not a Sabbath.

32 The second series of seven days of the dedication of the first temple apparently took in the Day of Atonement. Now if this is the case, then the people ate on Yom Kippur. This is the opinion of the sages of the Talmud. According to I.E. these seven days do not include Yom Kippur, for there were no dedication festivities on that day.
33 See Lev. 1:14.
34 They were of the same sex and kind as the young bullock.
35 Thus bakar shenayim (two oxen) literally means two of the kind of cattle, the reference being to two bulls.
36 That bakar refers to bullocks.
37 Ashte asar (eleven).

38 All the other teens are written by adding the one number to ten. For example, 12 is written shenem (2) asar; 13, sheloshah (3) asar (10); etc. However, the word for eleven in our verse is ashte asar and not ahad (1) asar (10).

39 According to I.E., “Ten is the foundation of all sums, for all sums that follow ten are made up of a part or parts of ten, or come into being by doubling ten, multiplying ten, or a combination of the two” (The Secret of the Torah, p. 163).
40 Jonah ibn Janach, the eleventh-century grammarian.
41 In other words, ashte asar means eleven.
42 In other words, the word al means above, not before. Hence if ashte asar is short for al shetem asar, then its meaning is, not before 12 but beyond 12.
43 Va-ma’alah and al come from the same root. We thus see that al means upward or beyond, not before.
44 Because the word for 12 is shenem asar.
45 According to Rabbi Jonah, ashte is short for shetem asar. Shetem asar is feminine. Now yom is masculine. Why would Scripture employ a feminine?
46 So too Rashi.
47 By the dallet. In other words, middabber is short for mitdabber.
48 Which is an infinitive.

49 A mem placed in front of a word has the meaning of from. I.E. renders va-yishma et ha-kol middabber elav (then he heard the voice speaking unto him) as, then he heard the voice of the One who spoke to him.
50 So that Moses heard what others did not
51 Which, according to I.E., means God made his eyes more sensitive than the eyes of other people.
52 Once the tabernacle was erected.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 8
chapter.p: 2. SPEAK UNTO AARON. For he is obligated to fulfill the commandment of lighting the lamps.1

IN FRONT OF THE CANDLESTICK. This explains to give light (he’ir) over against it (Ex. 25:37).2 Now the word he’ir (give light)3 is transitive. It is similar to the word ta’ir (dost light) in For Thou dost light my light (Ps. 18:29). However, this is not the case with the word ya’iru (shall give light)4 and the word he’irah (did shine) in and the earth did shine (Ezek. 43:2).
This section5 follows6 in order to teach that God’s word also came at night, for the light was to burn in the tabernacle and was not to be extinguished.
4. AND THIS WAS THE WORK OF THE CANDLESTICK. Scripture teaches that no such menorah was ever seen.7
BEATEN. I have already explained the meaning of mikshah (beaten).8
THE BASE THEREOF. This refers to the shaft upon which it stood,9 for Scripture explicitly states, its base, and its shaft (Ex. 25:31).

THE FLOWERS THEREOF. The meaning of the word pirchah (flowers thereof) is well known.10 If God had not shown Moses the menorah in a prophetic vision, then no wise craftsman would have had the ability to make the menorah described in Scripture.
SO HE MADE. This refers to Moses. The meaning of made is, made by command.11 The same applies to And thou shalt make a candlestick of pure gold (Ex. 25:31).

The section dealing with the Levites follows the one dealing with the lighting of the menorah to teach us that Aaron shall occupy himself with the kindling of the lamps.12 However, the Levites shall assist him in the other services and shall stand before him to do all that he commands.13
6. TAKE THE LEVITES FROM AMONG THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. For they were mixed in.14 The same was true of all the tribes before they journeyed on from Mount Sinai.15

7. THE WATER OF PURIFICATION. Chattat (purification)16 here is similar to the word techatteni (purify me) (Ps. 51:9).17 Or it is possible that the me chattat (the water of purification) was similar to a sin offering (korban chattat).18
SPRINKLE…UPON THEM. Rabbi Moses19 says that the first root letter of hazzeh (sprinkle) is a nun.20 Compare, hakkeh21 takkeh (thou shalt surely smite) (Deut. 13:16). Rabbi Moses is correct.

AND LET THEM CAUSE A RAZOR TO PASS OVER ALL THEIR FLESH. Its meaning is, and they have already caused a razor to pass over their flesh.22 The sages said23 even the beard,24 but not the corner of the beard.25
AND LET THEM WASH THEIR CLOTHES. And after this26 they will be cleansed, being purified by the waters of purification.

[AND CLEANSE THEMSELVES.] The word ve-hitteharu (and cleanse themselves) is a hitpa’el.27 The tav of the hitpa’el is swallowed.28 Compare, ha-mitkaddeshim ve-ha-mittaharim29 (They that sanctify themselves and purify themselves) (Is. 66:17).
8. A YOUNG BULLOCK. The term ben bakar indicates a young bullock.30
FINE FLOUR. Three-tenth parts (of an efah) as is the law.

SHALT THOU TAKE. By issuing a command, for the Levites shall take.31 The meaning of Then let them take (ve-lakechu) is, then let them give.32 Compare, ve-yikechu li terumah (that they take for Me an offering).33 On the other hand, the meaning of Then let them take might be that they shall take with them.34 Compare, they shall take (ve-yikechu) to them every man a lamb, according to their fathers’ houses (Ex. 12:3).

11. BEFORE THE LORD. Its meaning is, when you present the Levites before the tent, the Levites shall lay their hands upon the head of each one of the bullocks.35 There are many similar instances in Scripture.

12. AND OFFER THOU. Offer by command, for Aaron was the celebrant. Scripture’s statement that the sin offering and also the burnt offering were to make atonement for the Levites is true proof of the aforementioned.36 Furthermore, Scripture states, and Aaron made an atonement for them37 (v. 21).
[13. AND THOU SHALT SET THE LEVITES BEFORE AARON.] After Aaron shall make atonement for the Levites, you shall set them up before Aaron, and Aaron shall offer them for a wave offering.
AND OFFER THEM FOR A WAVE-OFFERING. Via your command. Compare, And offer thou (v. 12).38
14. AND THE LEVITES SHALL BE MINE. This is a great status.39
15. AND AFTER THAT SHALL THE LEVITES GO IN. After you purify them.
AND OFFER THEM. Via your command.

16. FOR THEY ARE WHOLLY GIVEN UNTO ME. They, and their children, are given unto Me.40 The Israelites gave them to Me41 and I took them unto Me;42 that is, I accepted them. Why are they given [unto Me]?43 In order to redeem all that openeth the womb.
The word pitrat (openeth) and peter (openeth)44 are two different words.45 Compare, tzedek (righteousness) and tzedakah (righteousness).46 Or they might be the same word in two paradigms.47
17. ON THE DAY THAT I SMOTE. The word yom (day)48 means time.49 Compare, Thou art this day (yom) to pass over (Deut. 2:18).50

18. [AND I HAVE TAKEN THE LEVITES.] Scripture has already stated, have I taken them unto Me (v. 16). This is the style of Scripture.51 And I have taken the Levites is connected to the verse which follows. It means, when I took the Levites, I gave them to Aaron and his sons (v. 19).
19. AND TO MAKE ATONEMENT. To be an atonement for the souls of the children of Israel, as I have already explained.52
20. THUS DID MOSES AND AARON. Moses by command, Aaron by waving them, and Israel by the laying of their hands on them.
21. [AND THE LEVITES PURIFIED THEMSELVES.] Scripture tells us that they also performed [purification rituals].

AND AARON MADE ATONEMENT FOR THEM. And Aaron had already made atonement for them.53 Others say that the Levites first purified themselves and afterwards laid their hands on the bullocks.54 This interpretation is not far off the mark.55 If this is so, then the meaning of And thou shalt set the Levites (v. 13) is: and you have already set the Levites56 at the beginning.57
22. SO DID THEY UNTO THEM. So did the sons of Aaron always unto the children of the Levites.58

24. THIS IS THAT WHICH PERTAINETH UNTO THE LEVITES. Its meaning is, this is the set time of service which pertains to the Levites.59 The verse reading from thirty years and upward (Num. 4:23)60 does not contradict our verse,61 for from thirty years and upward refers to the service of bearing burdens (Num. 4:24), while our verse, which reads from twenty and five years all and upward, refers to the service in the work of the tent of meeting. The meaning of li-tzeva (to perform the service) is, to be counted among the host of workers.62
26. TO KEEP THE CHARGE. This command is directed to the elders.63

The section dealing with the Passover follows the section dealing with the consecration of the Levites because the dedication of the altar took place in the first month.64 The Levites were separated65 at that time.66

The section dealing with Passover67 is written here because, concerning the Passover, it was written, And it shall come to pass, when ye be come to the land (Ex. 12:25); And it shall be when the Lord shall bring thee into the land (Ex. 13:5).68 This chapter69 records that God commanded that they were obligated to offer the Passover sacrifice in the desert also.70
chapter.ftnote: 2 In other words, the meaning of to give light over against it is, shall give light in front of the candlestick.
4 In our verse. According to I.E., ya’iru (shall give light) is intransitive and means shall shine, not shall shine upon. I.E. renders our clause, shall shine in front of the candlestick.
5 Verses 1-4.
6 The statement telling us that God spoke to Moses in the tent of meeting.
7 Scripture describes the menorah because it was a unique work of art. The menorah had already been described in Ex. 25:31-40. Hence I.E.’s comment.
8 “Mikshah means equal” (I.E. on Ex. 25:31, Vol. 2, p. 547). According to I.E. the various parts of the menorah were of equal size.
9 The shaft, to which the menorah’s branches were attached.
10 Hence there is no reason to explain it.
11 Moses commanded a craftsman to make the menorah.
12 By himself, as stated in verse 2.
13 See verse 19.
14 They were living among the children of Israel.
15 Before the standards were set up, the various tribes were intermingled.
16 The word chattat usually means sin. Hence I.E.’s comment.
17 Translated according to I.E.
18 In this case, me chattat (the water of purification) means sin water, water which serves as a sin offering. In other words, the water atones for sin.
19 Moses ibn Gikatilla, an 11th-century Spanish philologist and Bible commentator.
20 In other words, the root of hazzeh is nun, zayin, heh.
21 The root of hakkeh (and of takkeh) is nun, kof, heh. Thus hazzeh is like hakkeh. They are both in the hifil and they both come from a root that opens with a nun.
22 In other words, ve-he’eviru (and let them cause to pass) is a pluperfect. I.E. comments thus because the shaving of the body preceded the sprinkling.
23 See Nazir 40-41.
24 See Lev. 14:9.
25 See Lev. 21:5.
26 After they wash their clothes.
27 Even though it does not have a tav in it.
28 By the tet.
29 Mittaharim is in the hitpa’el and does not have a tav in it, for its tav is swallowed by its tet.
30 The Hebrew literally reads, a bull (par) ben bakar (the son of cattle). I.E. points out that this should be interpreted as a bull, a young bovine.
31 Our verse opens by saying, Then let them (the Levites) take a young bullock. Thus it is the Levites who do the taking.
32 In other words, shalt thou take means shalt thou offer.
33 Literally, that they give (ve-yikechu) to Me an offering. We thus see that the Hebrew word yikkach (to take) sometimes has the meaning of to give.
34 In this case, ve-lakechu (then let them take) has its usual meaning.
35 Our verse reads, al rosh ha-parim (upon the heads of the bullocks). This literally reads, upon the head of the bullocks. I.E. interprets this to mean upon the head of each one of the bullocks.
36 That Aaron was the celebrant, for Aaron was the one making atonement offerings (v. 21).
37 The Levites.
38 So Vat. Ebr. 38. The Mikra’ot Gedolot reads, and whatsoever there may be to do with them (Num. 4:26). However, this appears to be an error. See Filwarg.
39 In other words, the Levites were elevated to a great status.
40 The Hebrew reads, ki netunim, netunim li (for they are wholly given unto Me). I.E. believes that the first netunim refers to the Levites and the second to the children of the Levites.
41 See verses 9 and 10.
42 “And I took them unto Me” is I.E.’s paraphrase of have I taken them unto Me.
43 So Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed texts apparently read, they are not given (unto me). This is an obvious error.
44 Our verse refers to the first born as pitrat…ṙechem (that openeth the womb). The Book of Exodus refers to the first-born as peter…rechem (openeth the womb) (Ex. 13:2).
45 There is a difference in nuance between these two words. However, I.E. does not explain how they differ. For another interpretation, see Filwarg.
46 Tzedek refers to any act of righteousness. Tzedakah in rabbinic literature refers to a gift of charity.
47 In other words, there is no difference between peter and pitrat.
48 Here.
49 The first-born were slain at night. See Ex. 12:29. Hence I.E.’s comment.
50 The meaning of this is, you are about to pass over, for Israel did not pass over the Jordan until Moses died.
51 To repeat itself after digressing.
52 See I.E. on Ex. 32:29.
53 Before Aaron offered them as a sacred gift before the Lord. Thus va-yekhapper is a pluperfect that means had made atonement.
54 After which Aaron offered them for a wave offering and made atonement for them (Krinsky).
55 For it is based on a literal interpretation of va-yekhapper (and made atonement).
56 The atonement ritual was the final act in the cleansing ritual of the Levites.
57 That is, before Aaron made atoonement fot them. Thus our verse does not contradict verse 13. In this case, va-yekhapper (had atoned) is not a pluperfect.
58 The reference is to the commandments in our chapter regarding the Levites (verses 6-14). This apparently applies to future generations as well.
59 In other words, zot (this is) is short for zot ha-kitzvah (the set time of service).
60 Num. 4:23 gives as the age of all that enter…to do service in the tent of meeting.
61 According to Hullin 24a, they begin their studies at the age of 25 and their service at the age of 30. See Rashi.
62 The word tzava means a host. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
63 The Levites who are above the age of 50.
64 See Num. 7:1, Ex. 40:2, and Lev. 9:1.
65 From Israel and consecrated.
66 See Num. 3:1 and Ex. 32:29.
68 These verses imply that Israel was obligated to offer the Passover sacrifice only in the Land of Israel.
70 Sinai.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 9
chapter.p: 6. BUT THERE WERE CERTAIN MEN. It is impossible for a camp to be big as that of the Israelites without people dying every day.
7. WHEREFORE ARE WE TO BE KEPT BACK. Niggara (kept back) is a nifal.
8. STAY YE. At the opening of the tent of meeting.
10. IN A JOURNEY AFAR OFF. We do not have to search for the meaning of this phrase, for our sages have already transmitted to us the meaning of afar off.1
OF YOU. This refers to being unclean by reason of a dead body.
OR OF YOUR GENERATIONS. This refers to both a person who is unclean by reason of a dead body and to one in a journey far off.
13. AND IS NOT ON A JOURNEY. U-ve-derekh (and on a journey) is to be rendered, or is on a journey.2 U-makkeh aviv ve-immo (and he that smiteth his father, or his mother)3 (Ex. 21:15) is similar.4
SHALL BEAR HIS SIN. He alone.5
14. AND IF A STRANGER SHALL SOJOURN AMONG YOU. He too shall observe the second Passover6 in accordance with the ordinance. Others say that the reference is to the first Passover.7

15. AND ON THE DAY THAT THE TABERNACLE WAS REARED UP. Scripture begins to count the journeys of Israel. It was thus compelled to make mention of the cloud that rested on the tabernacle, for when it camped they camped and when it journeyed8 they journeyed.
EVEN THE TENT OF THE TESTIMONY. Le-ohel (even the tent) is to be rendered, on the tent.9 There are many such instances in Scripture.
18. AT THE COMMANDMENT OF THE LORD THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL JOURNEYED. Its meaning is clear, for God caused the cloud to rest and God caused it to journey.
19. AND WHEN THE CLOUD TARRIED. The meaning of u- ve-ha’arikh (and when it tarried) is to be rendered, and if it tarried.10
Scripture first speaks in general terms.11 It then goes on to say that sometimes the Israelites would journey for a few days or encamp according to the commandment of the Lord.

21. OR IF IT CONTINUED BY DAY AND BY NIGHT. They thus occasionally journeyed at night.12 Others say that yomam va-laylah (by day and by night) is to be interpreted literally.13 This interpretation appears correct to me. The term yomayim (two days) (v. 22)14 is proof that this interpretation is correct.15
22. OR A YEAR. The word yomam means a full year.16
23. AT THE COMMANDMENT OF THE LORD THEY ENCAMPED. This is stated at the end of the chapter to indicate that this was the procedure as long as Israel lived in the wilderness.
chapter.ftnote: 1 According to the Mishnah, Pes. 9:2, afar off means outside of the threshold of the temple courtyard. For other opinions see Pes. 9:2.

2 In other words, the vav of u-ve-derekh is to be rendered “or,” not “and.” I.E. comments thus because he believes that the law of being far off did not apply in the wilderness (I.E. on verse 10). Hence he reads our verse as follows: But the man that is unclean in the wilderness, and is on a journey in future generations. So Filwarg. For additional interpretations see Krinsky and Avi Ezri.
3 Literally, and he that smiteth his father and his mother.
4 In that its meaning is, and he that smiteth his father, or his mother.
5 Not his descendants.
6 If unclean or far off.
7 The Passover observed in Nisan.
8 So Vat. Ebr. 38. Our texts read, when they journeyed, they journeyed.
9 The lamed usually has the meaning of to. Hence I.E.’s comment. I.E. renders our verse, the cloud covered the tabernacle, on the tent of the testimony.
10 Nahmanides interprets similarly.
11 That Israel travelled and camped in the wilderness.

12 This means that yomam va-laylah (by day and by night) is to be rendered, by day or by night. Our verse reads as follows: or if it (the cloud) continued by day or by night, when the cloud was taken up they journeyed. In other words, sometimes the cloud stayed over the tabernacle during the day and was taken up at the beginning of the night. Thus Israel at times took up their journey at night.

13 In other words, the vav of yomam va-laylah is to be translated literally. Thus yomam va-laylah means by day and by night. Therefore what the verse is telling us is that the cloud continued on the tabernacle a day and a night and was taken up in the morning, and then Israel journeyed. The verse thus teaches that Israel journeyed in the morning, not at night.
14 So Vat. Ebr. 38. See also Filwarg. The printed texts have yomam.
15 The term yomayim follows yomam va-laylah. Yomayim refers to two days and two nights. Hence yomam va-laylah must refer to a day and a night.
16 See Lev. 25:29.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 10
chapter.p: 2. MAKE THEE TWO TRUMPETS OF SILVER. Chatzotzerot (trumpets) is a noun. In its verbal form, one of the tzadis is not pronounced even though it is written.1

FOR THE CALLING. Le-mikra (for the calling) is an infinitive. The same applies to u-le-massa (and for causing to set forward). On the other hand, they might be nouns. In this case, the word le-mikra (for the calling) means at the time of calling, and le-massa (and for causing to set forward), at the time of journeying.2 The first interpretation appears correct to me.

3. AND WHEN THEY SHALL BLOW WITH THEM. And when the trumpeters shall blow with them.3 It is similar to and he said to Joseph4 (Gen. 48:1) and whom she bore to Levi (Num. 26:59).5 Now its meaning is,6 if they blow both trumpets,7 then the princes and the congregation shall gather.8

4. AND IF THEY BLOW BUT WITH ONE. This means if they blow with one trumpet, then the princes alone shall come. If a tru’ah (an alarm)9 sounds, then the standard of Judah shall journey, even though the cloud is upon the tabernacle.10 In the opinion of many, another cloud11 journeyed before the Israelites.12
5. THE CAMPS THAT LIE ON THE EAST SIDE SHALL TAKE THEIR JOURNEY. For they consisted of three camps.13

6. AN ALARM THE SECOND TIME. So that the standard of Reuben will take up its journey. They did not blow the trumpets again,14 for the family of Kohath and with them the kohanim who blew the trumpets journeyed before the standard of Ephraim.15
THEY SHALL BLOW AN ALARM FOR THEIR JOURNEYS. The kohanim shall blow an alarm for their journeys, for they journeyed after the standard of Reuben.16
8. AND THEY SHALL BE TO YOU FOR A STATUTE FOR EVER. The camps now journeyed to battle.17 Is this not Moses’ words18 when the ark journeyed?19

Note that Scripture explains this statute.20 It says that Israel shall do the following: The kohanim shall sound the alarm upon trumpets when Israel goes forth to war, to battle in the land of their enemies, and similarly if an enemy enters their land and Israel goes forth to fight them.
9. AND YE SHALL BE REMEMBERED. For you have done what God the glorious commanded you do. The alarm (tru’ah) also serves as a reminder to the people to cry out to God.21

10. ALSO IN THE DAY OF YOUR GLADNESS, AND IN YOUR APPOINTED SEASONS. When you return from the land of your enemies, or you defeat the enemy who attacks you22 and you establish a day of rejoicing, such as the days of Purim or the seven days of rejoicing in the days of Hezekiah.23 However, our transmitters of tradition explained that the day of your gladness refers to the Sabbath.24
The trumpets were sounded25 so that Israel would hear that the burnt offerings were being offered and that they should direct their hearts to God.
11. ON THE TWENTIETH DAY OF THE MONTH. The standards first journeyed on this day. Thus Israel was at Sinai close to a year.26
12. BY THEIR STAGES.27 As it was fit for them to journey.28
AND THE CLOUD ABODE IN THE WILDERNESS OF PARAN. I will explain this and, And they took their first journey (v. 13)29 later.
17. TAKEN DOWN. The Levites took it down.
21. THE BEARERS OF THE SANCTUARY. The reference is to the ark.
MIGHT BE SET UP. That the Gershonites and the Merarites might set up the tabernacle before the coming of the Kohathites so that the kohanim could immediately bring the ark into its place.
25. REARWARD. According to the standards,30 for Naphtali was last.31
28. THUS WERE THE JOURNEYINGS OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. Its meaning is, thus did they journey all the days that they were in the wilderness.

[29. AND MOSES SAID UNTO HOBAB, THE SON OF REUEL.] We find Scripture telling us that Zipporah was the daughter of Reuel, for it is written, and he [Reuel] gave Moses Zipporah his daughter (Ex. 2:21). Furthermore, Scripture states, to water their father’s flock32 (Ex. 2:16), and to Reuel their33 father (Ex. 2:18). Now Hobab was the son of Reuel.34 Thus Hobab35 was the brother of Zipporah.36

According to a rational analysis of Scripture, Hobab is to be identified with Jethro, because the Torah states, as thou [Hobab] knowest how we are to encamp in the wilderness (v. 31) and it states with regard to Jethro when he came to the wilderness, into the wilderness where he was encamped (Ex. 18:5).

Should one disagree37 and argue that Scripture refers to Jethro as choten mosheh (Moses’ father-in-law) (Ex. 18:1), then one can respond that it is the way of Scripture to refer to the father and the brother of a young woman by the term choten (father-in-law).38 Unto Hobab, the son of Reuel…choten mosheh (Moses’ father-in-law)39 is proof of the aforementioned. For it has already been made clear to you that Hobab was the brother of Zipporah, and Scripture calls him choten mosheh (Moses’ father-in-law). Should one argue that choten mosheh (Moses’ father-in-law) is not connected to Hobab but to Reuel, then the response is, Scripture explicitly states Hobab choten mosheh (the father-in-law of Moses) (Jud. 4:11).

Many say that Hobab and Jethro are one and the same. They maintain that Jethro/Hobab was the father of Zipporah and that Reuel was the grandfather of Zipporah. They argue that Scripture says, to Reuel their father (Ex. 2:18)40 in the same manner that Jacob said, O God of my father Abraham (Gen. 32:10).41 Scripture similarly refers to Zipporah as Reuel’s daughter in the same manner that it refers to Belshazzar as Nebuchadnezzar’s son,42 when in fact he was Nebuchadnezzar’s grandson.
Our sages say that Jethro had seven names.43 There are seventy faces to the Torah.44
30. TO MINE OWN LAND, AND TO MY KINDRED.45 Where I was born and where I live unto this very day.46
31. LEAVE US NOT, I PRAY THEE. The word na (I pray thee) means now. The same applies to the word na in all of Scripture. The opposite is the case in Arabic.47

FORASMUCH AS THOU KNOWEST. Ki al ken (forasmuch) here means the same as ki al ken in forasmuch as I gave her not to Shelah my son (Gen. 38:26). Since (ki al ken)48 you know the place where we encamped, come with us.
AND THOU SHALT BE TO US INSTEAD OF EYES. You will show us the way.49

Many say that ve-hayita (and thou shalt be) is to be taken as a perfect50 and alludes to the advice which Jethro gave Moses.51 He showed Moses what Moses did not know. They say this is what eyes refers to.
The meaning of And he said: Leave us not, I pray thee is, and he had already said to him [leave us not I pray thee]52 but it was to no avail.53

[33. AND THEY SET FORWARD FROM THE MOUNT OF THE LORD THREE DAYS’ JOURNEY.] In my opinion the first journey was unlike the rest of the journeys. The verse which states, and the Kohathites…set forward (v. 21) after the two standards journeyed refers to all the other journeys except this one, for54 the ark journeyed before the camp of the Israelites.55 However, this was the case for only three days. This is the meaning of three days (v. 33). Similarly, And they went three days’ journey in the wilderness of Etham (Num. 33:8) does not mean that they traveled a three days journey in one day.56 Others say57 that they traveled a three-day journey in one day.58

Others say that they traveled a journey of three days corresponding to the journeys when they left Egypt,59 and the ark was a three-day distance from them.60 This is the meaning of and the cloud abode in the wilderness of Paran (v. 12).61 They explain that And they took their first journey (v. 13), means that they journeyed by the command of Moses, for the cloud traveled immediately.62 However, this is not so, for Moses did not distance himself from the ark, as proved by And it came to pass, when the ark set forward (v. 35) And when it rested (v. 36). What I said above appears correct to me.63

Paran, in and the cloud abode in the wilderness of Paran (v. 12), is a general name for Taberah,64 which is the same as Kibroth-hattaavah (v. 34), Hazeroth (Num. 33:17), Rithmah (Num. 33:18), and many other journeys.65 The fact that Scripture does not mention the wilderness of Paran in the Torah portion Elleh Mase (these are the stages)66 is proof of this. I will explain this later.67
The meaning of according to the commandment of the Lord (v. 13) is, when the trumpets sounded the alarm.68
35. RISE UP, O LORD. As people do when they rise up to battle.
[BE SCATTERED.] When Your enemies see that You arose to do battle, they will immediately be scattered.
[THEM THAT HATE THEE.] The word mesanekha (them that hate Thee) is a pi’el.69 The nun70 does not receive a dagesh71 in order to simplify the enunciation of the word.
SCATTERED…FLEE. Scripture repeats itself as is its style in all prophecies,72 as I will explain in the portion dealing with Balaam.73

36. AND WHEN IT RESTED. When the ark rested. U-venucho (when it rested) is spelled with a heh74 in the same way that the word oholo (his tent) (Gen. 13:3) is,75 for the letters alef, heh, vav, yod interchange.76

RETURN, O LORD. Rabbi Judah, the first grammarian, says that every time the word shav in the kal conjugation is related in meaning to teshuvah (return), it is intransitive, not transitive.77 However, when it means peace and quiet, as in in sitting still (be-shuvah) and rest shall ye be saved (Is. 30:15), and similarly in Return (shuvah), O Lord, unto the ten thousands of the families of Israel,78 it means that God will give them rest and they will not be disturbed by any enemy.79

Note, the word revavah (ten thousand) comes from the same root as the word rav (many). Revavah in our verse is similar to the word revavah (increase) in I cause thee to increase (Ezek. 16:7). It is possible that ten thousand is called a revavah because it is a great number. The word revavah80 is therefore connected to the word alfe (thousands).81 Moses prayed that God would grant rest and quiet to all of Israel, though they be many.
chapter.ftnote: 1 See machtzerim (did blow) in I Chron. 15:24. Machtzerim is spelled with two tzadis. However, only one of them is pronounced.
2 According to this interpretation the last clause of our verse reads, and they shall be unto thee (for use) at the time of the calling of the congregation and at the time when the camps set forward.
3 The subject of “and when they shall blow” is not in the text. Hence I.E.’s comment.
4 Translated literally.
5 See I.E. on Gen. 48:1 (Vol. 1, p. 412) and the notes thereto. See also I.E. on Num. 26:58.
6 The meaning of our verse.
7 I.E.’s paraphrase of with them.
8 I.E.’s interpretation of all the congregation.
9 According to tradition a tru’ah is a wavering sound.

10 And thus could not as yet lead Israel, for the tabernacle was dismantled after the tribe of Judah started their journey. See verse 17. I.E. points this out because, according to Num. 14:14, Israel was led by a cloud. See next note.
11 Aside from the one that rested on the tabernacle.
12 For Num. 14:14 clearly states, And Thou goest before them, in a pillar of cloud.

13 The reference is to the standard of Judah (Num. 2:3). Now the standard of Judah (and so every other standard) consisted of three camps. Hence Scripture refers to the standard of Judah by the term “camps.”
14 After the tribe of Reuben journeyed.

15 The kohanim journeyed between the standard of Reuben and the standard of Ephraim. Thus when it came time for Ephraim to journey, the kohanim had already journeyed and were not in a position to sound the trumpets.
16 Hence after the standard of Reuben journeyed, the trumpets were no longer sounded.
17 Israel now journeyed to Canaan where they were going to engage the Canaanites.
18 Which allude to war.
19 See verses 35 and 36.
20 Scripture explains what a statute for ever refers to.
21 An additional reason for sounding the tru’ah.
22 In your own land.
23 See II Chron. 30:23. Some manuscripts read Chanukah. In this case, the text should be emended to read, the eight days of Chanukah (Krinsky).
24 See Sifre on this verse.
25 Over the burnt offerings and sacrifices.

26 Israel came to the wilderness of Sinai on the first day of the third month. See I.E. on Ex. 19:1 (Vol. 2, p. 370). They journeyed from there on the twentieth day of the second month. They thus spent a year minus ten days in the wilderness of Sinai.
27 Literally, by their journeys. Hence I.E.’s comment.

28 By God’s dictate. “In accordance with the regulation set forth for the journeys of their divisions–which should be the first to set out and which the last” (Rashi; Rosenbaum and Silbermann translation).
29 See I.E. on verse 31.
30 The standard of Dan was the last to journey.
31 The tribe of Naphtali, which was part of the standard of Dan, was the last tribe to journey.
32 The reference is to Reuel’s daughters, that is, Zipporah and her sisters.
33 Zipporah and her sisters.
34 This is stated in our verse.
35 The son of Reuel.
36 The daughter of Reuel.
37 With the identification of Hobab with Jethro.
38 Thus according to I.E. the word choten means a father or brother-in-law.
39 Our verse.
40 The father of Zipporah and her sister.
41 Isaac, not Abraham, was Jacob’s father. Thus father is used for grandfather. Similarly, in Ex. 2:18 father refers to grandfather.
43 Mekhilta,Va-yishma Yitro 1.

44 A quote from Otiyyot de-Rabbi Akiva, a late aggadic Midrash on the alphabet composed sometime between 700-900 C.E. Some manuscripts read, there are seven faces to the Torah. According to the rabbis, Jethro, Hobab, and Reuel are one and the same person (see Rashi on Ex. 18:1 where he quotes all seven names). Hence I.E.’s comment.
45 The Hebrew reads moladti. This literally means my birthplace.
46 I.E.’s interpretation of mine own land.
47 In Arabic the word for now is an or malan. See I.E. on Gen. 12:11 (Vol. 1, p. 154).
48 Thus the meaning of ki al ken is since.
49 Eyes is a metaphor for a guide (Weiser).
50 Even though it is technically an imperfect.
51 With regard to the appointment of judges, see Ex. 18:21-23.
52 In other words, what is reported in verse 31 took place before what is reported in verse 30.
53 I.E.’s paraphrase of our verse.
54 During the first journey.
55 And in all of the other journeys, it journeyed amidst the camp of the Israelites. See Num. 2:17.
56 It means they traveled for three days.
57 That the meaning of our verse is.
58 This is the opinion of Rashi.
59 When Israel crossed the Sea of Reeds, they journeyed for three days (Ex. 15:22). They similarly journeyed for three days when they left the wilderness of Sinai.
60 This is how others interpret, And the ark of the covenant…went before them three days’ journey to seek out a resting-place for them.

61 According to this interpretation Paran is three days’ journey from Sinai. The ark traveled three days’ distance from Israel and rested in the wilderness of Paran. When the ark rested, Israel began its journey.
62 With the ark. In other words, the cloud which led Israel was with the ark, not with the camp of Israel.
63 That the first journey was different from all other journeys (Weiser). Or, that the ark did not travel a three days’ journey from the camp but that it journeyed in front of the camp (Krinsky).
65 In other words, is the name of the district where Israel encamped in the wilderness.
66 Which lists the journeys of the children of Israel. See Num. 33:1-49.
67 The meaning of verse 12. See I.E. on Num. 12:16.
68 For Moses and the cloud were traveling before the camp.

69 The term used by I.E. is the heavy added conjugation. I.E. usually uses this phrase to describe a hifil. Pi’el is referred to as the heavy conjugation. There is apparently an error in our texts and manuscripts.
70 Of mesanekha.
71 The middle root letter of words in the pi’el receives a dagesh. Hence I.E.’s comment.
72 See I.E. on Gen. 49:3 (Vol. 1, p. 149) and the notes thereto.
73 See I.E. on Num. 23:7.
74 Rather than a vav. The pronominal suffix o is usually spelled with a vav. Hence I.E.’s comment.
75 Oholo ends in a heh and not, as expected, in a vav.
76 In other words, a heh was substituted for a vav in oholo and u-venucho.
77 In other words, whenever the word shav has the meaning of return, it is intransitive.
78 Then it is transitive.
79 According to I.E. our clause should be rendered, give rest (shuvah), O Lord, unto the ten thousands of the families of Israel.
80 In its plural form revevot.
81 Thus I.E. renders our clause, Give rest, O Lord, unto the many thousands of Israel (revevot alfe yisra’el).

chapter.title: CHAPTER 11
chapter.p: 1. AND THE PEOPLE. This chapter is connected to the one before,1 because the Israelites camped in kibroth-hatta’avah2 after the ark journeyed from Sinai. Scripture now tells what happened there.3
AS MURMURERS. Mitonenim (murmurers) is related to the word aven (evil).4 Onekh (evil) in thy evil (onekh) thoughts (Jer. 4:14) is similar.5
[AND WHEN THE LORD HEARD.] The meaning of when the Lord heard is, and when the Lord heard that they spoke evil.

AND DEVOURED. Va-tokhal (and devoured) is penultimately accented. Compare, va-yomer (and he said) (Gen. 14:19).6 However, when it ends a clause,7 then it is ultimately accented. The latter is contrary to the laws of Hebrew grammar,8 but we find it to be so.
2. AND THE PEOPLE CRIED UNTO MOSES. In a conciliatory manner.9
AND THE FIRE ABATED. Va-tishka (abated) means extinguished. The word is not used again in Scripture10 with this meaning.
3. TABERAH. I will explain this term later.11

4. AND THE MIXED MULTITUDE. Who were gathered unto the children of Israel but were not of Israelite stock. The asafsuf (the mixed multitude) refers to the erev rav (the mixed multitude).12 The word is constructed by doubling two root letters.13 Compare, secharchar14 (fluttereth) (Ps. 38:11) and chamarmaru15 (burn) (Lam. 1:20).
AND…WEPT. After they lusted.
THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL…ON THEIR PART. With them.16
5. THE FISH. The word dagah (fish) is a general term.17
FOR NOUGHT. Cheaply, as if we got it for nothing.

THE CUCUMBERS. An alef has been substituted for a heh in the word kishu’im (cucumbers), for kishu’im is related to the word mikshah (cucumber) (Is. 1:8).18 Compare, telu’im (suspense) in And My people are in suspense about returning to Me (Hos. 11:7).19 There are many such instances.
MELONS. We can ascertain the meaning of avatichim (melons) from Arabic.20 It has no cognate in Scripture.21

AND THE LEEKS. The word chatzir (leeks) refers to vegetables,22 which are the grass of the field.23 Compare, Who maketh the mountains to spring with grass (chatzir) (Ps. 147:8). Chatzir is thus an all-inclusive noun.24 However, the Aramaic translation25 says that it refers to a specific kind.26 It too is correct.
AND THE ONIONS, AND THE GARLIC. The meaning be-tzalim (onions) and shumim (garlic) is known.27 They have similar names in Arabic.28
6. BUT NOW OUR SOUL IS DRIED AWAY. The reference is to the lusting soul, which is implanted in the liver.29
THERE IS NOTHING AT ALL. We lack everything.
TO LOOK TO. For the manna came down from heaven.30

7. NOW THE MANNA. Scripture31 describes the stupidity of those who lusted, for the manna was like coriander seed, which is easy to pick, and it was easy to see, for it was white. Furthermore, they could eat it as it was. They could also grind it in mills and make cakes out of it. They could also beat it in mortars and cook it in pots. It had an especially good taste, for it tasted like [food] with the finest oil. Additionally, it came down after the dew had washed the place [upon which it fell]. It thus descended upon a clean place.
LIKE CORIANDER SEED. Zera (seed) is in the construct.32 It is like the word neta (plant of)33 in the plant of His delight (Is. 5:7).
CORIANDER. Some identify this with kusbarta. Others say that it refers to mustard. They connect gad (coriander) with the word gidin (sinews).34 However, I do not know its meaning.

8. THE PEOPLE WENT ABOUT. The word shatu (went about) is related to the word shut35 (going to and fro) in From going to and fro (mi-shut) in the earth (Job 1:7). This shows that the individual pieces of manna did not fall in one place36 but were spread and scattered.
IN MILLS. Operated by hand. The word rechayim (mills) does not come in the singular,37 for a mill consists of two parts.38
IN MORTARS. A vessel made out of wood or stone. It is called a medocha (mortars)39 because they pound in it.40 It was also possible to make cakes from what they pounded.41
AND MADE CAKES. Compare, and make cakes (Gen. 18:6).42

A CAKE. Some say that the lamed of leshad (cake) is superfluous.43 It is similar to the lamed of shalanan (at ease)44 in at ease and quiet (Job 21:23). The word ha-shamen (with oil) should have been ultimately accented45 because46 the word shamen (oil) is an adjective.47

However, I believe that the lamed of leshad is a root letter. The word leshad is similar to the word leshadi (my sap) in My sap was turned (Ps. 32:4). My (leshadi) sap stands in contrast to the droughts (charvone) in the droughts of summer (Ibid.). Leshad refers to the finest part of the oil that floats on top of all oil. In this case, the word ha-shamen is penultimately vocalized in accordance with the meaning of the word.48
10. WEEPING, FAMILY BY FAMILY. The families gathered together to cry, as they do when they mourn for the dead.
EVERY MAN AT THE DOOR OF HIS TENT. In public.
AND MOSES WAS DISPLEASED. The word ra (displeased) is a perfect.49 On the other hand, the word hayah (was) might be missing in our text.50
11. WHEREFORE HAST THOU DEALT ILL WITH THY SERVANT. Scripture describes an impetuous action.51

AND WHEREFORE HAVE I NOT FOUND FAVOUR IN THY SIGHT. When I said, send, I pray Thee, by the hand of him whom Thou wilt send (Ex. 4:13).52 The word matzati53 (found) is missing an alef.54 There are many such instances. There is nothing to wonder about when king Yehu55 is missing.
12. HAVE I CONCEIVED. Am I their mother?
HAVE I BROUGHT THEM FORTH. Or am I their father? Yelidtihu (brought them forth) is like the word yalad (begot) in and Shelah begot Eber (Gen. 10:24).56
CARRY THEM. Until they come to the land.57

13. WHENCE.58 When the word ayin has a mem prefixed to it,59 it means from which place. When ayin appears without a mem prefixed to it, it means no.60 We also find the following clause, Behold, ye are nothing (me-ayin) (Is. 41:24).61

14. BECAUSE IT IS TOO HEAVY FOR ME. The word kaved (heavy) is a verb in the perfect.62 Compare, zaken (was old) in And it came to pass, that when Isaac was old (Gen. 27:1).63 On the other hand, the word hu (it) might be missing from our text.64
[15.] THOU. The word at (Thou) is used for both males and females.65 It is like lakh (to you), bakh (in you), immakh (with you), and ittakh (with you).66 However, attah (you) is only used for males.
KILL ME. Horgeni (kill me) means put me to death. Do this to me because of Your righteousness and my request. This is the meaning of if I have found favour in Thy sight.
AND LET ME NOT LOOK. Anymore upon the evil circumstances in which I find myself. There is no need for any scribal emendation.67

16. GATHER UNTO ME. The word esfah (gather) is irregular.68 It is possible that this is so because of the guttural.69 Erkhah (set in order) in Set thy words in order before me, stand forth ((Job 33:5) is similar.70
AND OFFICERS. For there are elders who are advanced in age but are unfit to be officers. There are also officers who are not elders.71
17. AND I WILL COME DOWN. God’s glory descended in fire in the midst of the cloud.72
AND SPEAK WITH THEE THERE. When you hear the voice they will also hear.

AND I WILL TAKE OF THE SPIRIT. The meaning of ve-atzalti (and I will take of the spirit) is, I will take from that which you possess.73 Note that spirit74 means wisdom. If some of the wisdom of Reuben is given to Simeon, Reuben’s wisdom is not diminished. It remains as is.75 Let the light of a candle serve as an example.76
18. SANCTIFY YOURSELVES.77 Words from the root of kodesh (to sanctify) are found in the positive and the negative.78 Ha-yikdash (Haggai 2:12), which means shall it be unclean, is similar.
19. NOR TWO DAYS. Twice as much.79
NOR FIVE DAYS. Corresponding to the fingers of the hand of those who eat.

NEITHER TEN DAYS. Twice the amount, corresponding to the fingers of the two hands of those who eat.80 Nor twenty days has a similar meaning.81 This may be compared to the saying: Let him eat with the fingers of his hands and with the toes of his feet.82

20. BUT A WHOLE MONTH. I have already explained the meaning of the word chodesh yamim (a whole month).83 The phrase chodesh yamim alludes to the time that it takes for the moon’s light to return to its original amount.84 Shenatayim yamim (two full years) (Gen. 41:1) is similar to chodesh yamim.85
[AT YOUR NOSTRILS.]86 The sense of smell is located in the nose. The sense of smell will depart from your nostrils, and will not be found there.87
AND IT BE LOATHSOME. The word le-zara is spelled with an alef88 in place of the heh. Compare, mara in call me Mara89 (Ruth 1:20), for the letters alef, heh, vav, yod interchange.
The word zara (loathsome) refers to something which is strange90 and abhorrent to the nature of a person who is not used to it.
21. SIX HUNDRED THOUSAND MEN ON FOOT. There is no need to mention the lesser ones.91

Many interpret this section in various ways.92 Some say that Moses paraphrased what the children of Israel would say to him. When they would ask, what sort of meat,93 Moses would answer them, you have no need to ask,94 for is the Lord’s hand waxed short?95

I do not know why we must suffer in this manner.96 The text must be interpreted according to its plain meaning. Moses did not know that God would create a sign or a miracle.97 He thought, as I will explain, that he would do so only to justify his prophet.98
22. WILL THEY SUFFICE THEM. U-matza la-hem (will they suffice them) is to be interpreted as in the Aramaic translation.99
How precious is the interpretation of our ancients to the effect that the word yishachet (be slain) applies to cattle, and ya’asef (be gathered) refers to fish.100
23 WHETHER MY WORD SHALL COME TO PASS, The word ha-yikrekha101 (shall come to pass) is similar to va-yiker mikrehah102 (and her hap was) (Ruth 2:3).
24. AND MOSES WENT OUT. From the tent of meeting.
25. AND TOOK OF THE SPIRIT. In my opinion, the word va-yatzel (and took of the spirit) is a hifil.103
[AND THEY PROPHESIED.] The vav of va-yitnabbe’u (and they prophesied) is like an unaspirated fa in Arabic.104

BUT THY DID SO NO MORE.105 A second time.106 The same applies to the phrase ve-lo yasaf (and it went on no more) in with a great voice, and it went on no more107 (Deut. 5:19) and ve-lo yasaf (now more) in and he knew her again no more108 (Gen. 38:26).
According to the rules of Hebrew grammar, the word yasaf is not related to the word tissafu (swept away)109 in lest ye be swept away in all their sins (Num. 16:26).110

Our sages of blessed memory say that Moses took six men from each tribe. Their number thus came to seventy-two. However, Moses dropped the two111 because God told him to gather seventy men.112 This is correct.
26. AND THEY WERE OF THEM THAT WERE RECORDED. At first.113
BUT HAD NOT GONE OUT. From the camp of Israel to the tent of meeting.114

27. AND THERE RAN A YOUNG MAN. The word na’ar (young man) has the definite article prefixed to it because it refers to the young man115 who, aside from Joshua, was known to serve Moses. For Joshua’s service was not the usual service rendered by young men.116

28. FROM HIS YOUTH UP. Some say that the meaning of mi-bechurav (from his youth up) is, from his youth. It means that he did not speak as an elder speaks.117 Others connect mi-bechurav (from his youth up) to mesharet mosheh (the minister of Moses);118 this means the one who served Moses from the time of his youth.119 However, this is incorrect, for this event occurred in the second year.120
In my opinion, the word mi-bechurav means from the chosen. It means that he was one of those chosen to serve Moses, for there were others with him.121

Note that the word bachur (youth, or chosen) sometimes changes in the plural and sometimes does not.122 The same applies to the word saris (officer).123 It is also possible that they belong to two different paradigms.124
SHUT THEM IN. The lamed of kela’em (shut them in) is vocalized with a pattach125 because a guttural126 follows it.127

[29. ART THOU JEALOUS.] The heh of ha-mekanne (art thou jealous) is vocalized with a pattach. However, it should have been vocalized with a sheva and a pattach.128 It was so vocalized because the mem has a sheva na129 beneath it and two sheva nas130 are never joined together.
[WOULD THAT.] Mi yitten131 (would that) is an expression of desire here. It is like saying, who will grant me this request and desire?
30. AND MOSES WITHDREW. Moses accompanied the elders in order to honor them.
31. AND THERE WENT FORTH A WIND. On the second day.132

AND BROUGHT ACROSS. The word va-gaz (brought across) means cut. It is similar to the word gazi (cut) in Cut off thy hair (Jer. 7:29). The word gez (cutting) in and the first of the cutting of thy sheep (Deut. 18:4)133 is related to it.
Scripture reads, and cut,134 because the quail on the shore of the sea135 were as numerous as the [grains of] sand. Thus God cut off some of the quail from them.136
Va-yagaz comes from a double root.137 It is like the word va-yacham138 (waxed warm) in and the flesh of the child waxed warm (II Kings 4:34).

AND LET THEM FALL. The meaning of va-yittosh (and let them fall) is, and they spread. The quail were spread [all around the camp] and did not have the strength to fly away.139 Compare, they were spread (netushim) abroad all over the ground (I Sam. 30:16).
ROUND ABOUT THE CAMP. Only.140 In addition to being spread about the camp, the quail were always about two cubits above the high and low ground.

32. AND THEY SPREAD. Va-yishtechu means, and they spread. Shittachti (I have spread) in I have spread forth my hands unto Thee (Ps. 88:10) is similar even though they belong to two different forms.141
33. WITH A VERY GREAT PLAGUE. It was the plague of murrain.142
34. WAS CALLED. By someone or by Moses.143
THEY BURIED. Those who bury.144 Compare, And said to Jacob145 (Gen. 48:1).146
THE PEOPLE JOURNEYED UNTO HAZEROTH. Chatzerot (Hazeroth) is to be interpreted as unto Chatzerot. Scripture is being brief.147
And they abode at Hazeroth is connected to And…Miriam spoke (12:1), for they abode there on her account. The latter is clearly stated in Scripture.148
chapter.ftnote: 1 Which deals with the journey of the ark.
2 Which, according to I.E., is the same as taverah, the name of the place as quoted in verse 3. See I.E. on Num. 10:31.
3 At kibroth-hatta’avah.
4 Both words come from the root alef, vav, nun.
5 I.E. renders va-yehi ha-am ke-mitoninim (and the people were as murmurers) as: and the people uttered evil words.
6 When this word comes at the beginning of a clause, it is penultimately accented.
7 When it comes in the middle of a verse (at an etnachta) or at the end of a verse (sof pasuk).
8 For the change of accent indicates a change in tense (Weiser).
9 The word va-yitzaku (cried) literally means screamed. Hence I.E.’s comment.
10 The root shaka means to sink. This root is used in the sense of extinguished only here.
11 See I.E. on Deut. 9:22.
12 Mentioned in Ex. 12:38.
13 Its two final root letters, samekh, feh.
14 From the root samekh, chet, resh, doubling the chet and resh.
15 From the root chet, mem, resh, doubling the mem and resh.

16 The Hebrew reads, va-yashuvu va-yivku gam bene yisra’el (and the children of Israel also wept on their part). I.E. interprets va-yashuvu va- yivku as referring to the mixed multitude. He reads our verse as follows: And the mixed multitude that was among them fell a-lusting, and after lusting turned and wept, also the children of Israel with them. I.E.’s point is that the mixed multitude caused Israel to weep and ask for meat (Krinsky).
17 For all the different species of fish.
18 Mikshah is spelled with a heh.
19 Telu’im is spelled with an alef. However, it comes from the root tav, lamed, heh, and should read teluyim. Thus here too an alef has been substituted for a heh.
20 The Arabic word for melon is batikha.
21 Literally, no neighbor in Scripture.
22 Hebrew, yerakot (literally, greens).
23 Chatzir means grass. However, people do not eat grass. Hence I.E.’s comment.
24 It refers to all types of greens.
25 Onkelos.
26 Onkelos renders chatzir by the term kerate (leeks).
27 I.E. could find no synonyms for these words. Hence his comment that everybody knows what they mean.
28 Basal and tumeh.

29 See The Secret of the Torah, page 96. According to I.E. there are three souls in the body, neshamah, ru’ach, and nefesh. The neshamah (rational soul) is manifested in the brain; the ru’ach (spirit) is located in the heart; and the nefesh (the lusting soul), the part of the psyche that desires food and sex, is in the liver.
30 We watch the manna come down from the heavens (Weiser).
31 In this verse.
32 Hence it is vocalized with a sheva rather than with a segol beneath the zayin.
33 Which is vocalized with a sheva rather than with a segol beneath the nun.
34 Something hard (bitter) to the taste, i.e., mustard seed. See I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 16:31.
35 From the root shin, vav, tet.
36 Literally, together. It did not fall in one large pile but evenly over some distance.
37 The word rechayim is in the plural. However, it also refers to the singular, that is, to a mill as in our verse, for rechayim (mills) is parallel to medochah (mortar), which is singular.
38 An upper and a lower stone.
39 Literally, a mortar. See previous note.
40 The word medocha comes from the root dalet, caf, heh, which means to crush.
41 In addition to cooking it. Scripture reads, and seethed it in pots, and made cakes of it. I.E. notes that this should be interpreted, and seethed it in pots, or made cakes of it.
42 We thus see that the word make can mean bake.

43 The basic word is shad (breast). According to this interpretation, leshad ha-shamen means breast of the oil. See Sifre on Num. 11:8. “Just as the suckling imbibes, so to speak, every possible flavor with the mother-milk, so the Israelites found all flavors in the manna” (translated by Rosenbaum & Silbermann, Num. p. 54). So too Rashi, “Our Rabbis explained it as meaning breasts.”
44 The basic word being sha’anan.
45 However, ha-shamen is ultimately accented. When the word shemen or shamen is a noun, it is penultimately accented; when an adjective, it is ultimately accented.
46 According to this interpretation.
47 Describing leshad.
48 For the word is a noun.
49 And also a present form. Here it is a past.

50 Our verse reads, u-ve’ene moshe ra. The latter literally means: and in the eyes of Moses displeased. I.E. suggests that our verse be interpreted as if it read, u-ve’ene moshe hayah ra (and it was displeasing in the eyes of Moses). In this case, our verse is a continuous present.
51 Moses spoke impulsively, as one is wont to do under pressure.
52 You chose me then. Why, then, do I not find favor in your eyes now?
53 From the root mem, tzadi, alef.
54 That is, it is spelled here without an alef.
55 That is, when either a yod, heh, vav, or alef is dropped. These letters spell the name Yehu, who was a king of Judah. I.E. employs the king’s name as a mnemonic device.
56 I.E. renders our clause: Did I beget them?
57 Scripture reads, sa’eh…al ha-adamah. This literally means, carry them…upon the land. Hence I.E. points out that the word al here means unto, and al ha-adamah is to be rendered as unto the land.
58 Hebrew, me-ayin.
59 As in our verse.
60 Or nothing.
61 In this case, me-ayin has the meaning of nothing even though it has a mem prefixed to it.
62 And also a present. In our case, it is a past.
63 The word zaken can be a perfect or a present form. In Gen. 27:1, it is a perfect.
64 In other words, our text should be read as if written ki khaved hu mi-menni. In this case, khaved is a present.
65 The word at (thou) is usually used when addressing a female. Hence I.E.’s comment.
66 These words are used for both masculine and feminine in the middle (at an etnachta) and end of a Biblical verse.

67 See Rashi: “It ought to have written and let me not see their evil, only that Scripture modified the expression [i.e., it used a euphemistic expression referring the evil to himself instead of to the whole people]. This is one of the variations occurring in the Torah such as writers make for the purpose of modifying and improving the phrase” (Rosenbaum and Silbermann translation). See Vol. 1, p. 18, and p. 195, note 33.
68 The alef of esfah is vocalized with a segol. However, it should have been vocalized with a short kamatz. Compare, zokhrah (Neh. 5:19).
69 The alef of esfah.
70 The alef in erkhah is vocalized with a segol rather than with a kamatz katan.
71 According to I.E. the meaning of the elders of the people and the officers is the elders of the people who also serve as officers.
72 In other words, it was God’s glory that descended, not God himself.
73 Etzel means near, or in one’s possession.
74 Here.
75 Thus Moses’ wisdom was not diminished by having some of it imparted to Joshua.
76 A candle’s light is not diminished if it is used to light another candle.
77 Hebrew, hitkaddeshu.

78 According to I.E. the word hitkaddeshu (sanctify yourself) in our verse has a negative connotation. See Rashi, who explains the word to mean “prepare yourselves to receive punishment” (Rosenbaum and Silbermann translation).
79 Scripture speaks of one day, two days, five days, ten days, and twenty days. I.E. now goes on to explain the reason for these numbers.
80 Of those who demanded meat to eat.
81 The number 20 corresponds to the hands and toes of those who demanded meat.
82 Let him gorge himself.
83 See I.E. on Gen. 4:4 and Ex. 12:2.
84 It refers to the time that it takes for the moon to appear the same way that it did when it started its cycle in the sky. In other words, it refers to a complete month.
85 It means two complete years.
86 Me-appekhem (at your nostrils) literally means from your nostrils. Hence I.E.’s comments.
87 In other words, you will lose your sense of smell and will no longer enjoy the taste of meat.
88 At the end of the word.
89 Which has an alef in place of a heh at the end of the word.
90 The Hebrew word for strange is zar.

91 Those under the age of twenty. If these were included then the number would be much higher. Or the reference is to the 3,550 Israelites above the number of 600,000, for the Israelites numbered 600,350 (Num. 2:32).
92 The commentaries were bothered by Moses apparently doubting the ability of God to provide meat for all of the Israelites.
93 In other words, verses 21 and 22 are Moses’ paraphrase of what the people would tell him when he told them that God would provide meat for them.
94 See verse 23.

95 In some of the printed editions as well as in the Vatican manuscript, is the Lord’s hand waxed short has been detached from the verse and opens a new comment on verse 23. However, this is an error. See Meijler.
96 Of seeing the meaning of verses 21 and 22 perverted.
97 To satisfy the people’s craving for meat.
98 When the prophet is challenged, as in the case of the rebellion of Korach. See Num. 16.
99 Onkelos renders u-matza la-hem as, will they suffice them. The literal meaning of u-matza la-hem is: and he will find them. Hence I.E.’s comment.
100 Scripture speaks of slaughtering sheep and gathering fish. According to the rabbis this verse teaches us that cattle require ritual slaughter (shechitah) but fish do not. See Hullin 27b.
101 From the root kof, resh, heh.
102 Both words come from the root kof, resh, heh.
103 Thus the meaning of our clause is: He caused some of the spirit that was upon him to move (va-yatzel).

104 A verb that begins with a conversive vav usually introduces a new clause. Here it does not. Hence I.E. points out that sometimes the conversive vav merely serves as a conjunction, like the fa in Arabic.
105 Hebrew, ve-lo yasaf.
106 The literal meaning of lo yasefu is, they did not add. Hence I.E. points out that this term is an idiom meaning they did not repeat it.
107 It did not repeat itself.
108 Its meaning is, he knew her not a second time.

109 For the word yasefu comes from the root yod, samekh, peh, while the root of tissafu comes from the root samekh, peh, heh. If our word came from the latter root, it would have read safu not yasefu.
110 If it were, then the meaning of our phrase would be: but they were not destroyed.
111 Eldad and Medad.
113 In the list of the 72.
114 With the others whose names were on the list.
115 Scripture does not identify the young man.
116 Joshua served Moses in more dignified tasks.
117 He spoke as a youth speaks.
118 They read our text as follows: mesharet mosheh mi-bechurav, meaning the minister of Moses from his (Joshua’s) youth on.
119 So Onkelos and Rashbam.
120 Following the Exodus. However, Scripture nowhere tells us that Joshua served Moses before this date.
121 According to I.E. our clause should be interpreted: And Joshua the son of Nun, the minister of Moses, one of his chosen, answered and said.
122 In the plural the word is at times vocalized with a pattach (Ps. 78:31) and at other times with a sheva as in our verse (bechurav, rather than bachurav).
123 The plural of saris is both sarisim (Esth. 2:21) and serisim (Gen. 40:7).

124 Bachurav comes from the singular bachur (vocalized pattach, shurik), bechurav from the singular bachur (vocalized kamatz, shurik). Similarly sarism, and serisim. According to rules of Hebrew grammar, in the former form the kamatz changes to a sheva in the plural. Compare, davar, devarim. However, in the latter case the pattach is maintained in the plural form.
125 That is, a kamatz. There is either a scribal error or I.E. refers to a pattach here by the term kamatz. He occasionally does so in his long commentary on Exodus.
126 An alef.
127 Compare, kara’em, shelachem.
128 A chataf pattach, for the heh of ha-mekanneh is an interrogative heh, and interrogative hehs are vocalized with a chataf pattach.
129 A vocative sheva.
130 The sheva beneath an interrogative heh is a sheva na.
131 Mi yitten literally means who will give. Hence I.E.’s comment.
132 See verse 18.
133 Translated literally.
134 According to I.E. our verse reads, and cut quails from the sea. Hence his comments.
135 I.E.’s interpretation of from the sea.
136 God cut off a portion of the quail that were at the seashore and sent them to the camp of the Israelites.
137 Its root is gimel, zayin, zayin.
138 From the root chet, mem, mem.
139 Hence they were easy to catch.
140 Only round about the camp. Birds fly from place to place. However, in this case, they were limited to near the camp.
141 Va-yishtechu is a kal and shittachti (I have spread) is a pi’el.
142 Hebrew, dever.
143 The subject of “called” is omitted. Hence I.E.’s comment.
144 The subject of “buried” is omitted. Hence I.E.’s comment that we should translate our clause: and those who buried.
145 Translated literally
146 The meaning of which is: and the one who said, said to Jacob.
147 Our text literally reads, and journeyed Hazeroth. Hence I.E.’s comment.
148 See Num. 12:15,16 wherein it is stated that the people abode in Hazeroth because of Miriam.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 12
chapter.p: 1. AND MIRIAM…SPOKE. Miriam spoke. Aaron agreed or was silent.1 Hence he was also punished.

Va-tedabber (spoke) is followed by a bet2 and has a negative connotation. It is similar to va-yedabber ha-am be-Elohim (And the people spoke against God) (Num. 21:5). The verb dabber (spoke) followed by a bet is also found with a positive connotation.3 It also appears in prophetic statements.4

Some say that Moses was king of Cush5 and took a Cushite woman.6 Onkelos renders Cushite, beautiful.7 According to Onkelos, Cushite is an honorific term. The Arabs similarly call pitch white. We too refer to a blind person by the term sege nahor (rich of light).8 But it is illogical9 to turn a positive name into a negative one.10

Some say that Cush the Benjaminite (Ps. 7:1) refers to Saul.11 They say the same with regard to Are ye not as the children of the Ethiopians (Khushiyyim) unto Me (Amos 9:7).12 I have already explained this.13

I believe that the Cushite woman is to be identified with Zipporah, for Zipporah was a Midianite.14 The Midianites are Ishmaelites15 and they live in tents.16 Scripture similarly writes: The curtains17 of the land of Midian do tremble (Hab. 3:7).
