Because of the sun18 they do not have any whiteness at all. Zipporah was black and was like a Cushite.

[FOR HE HAD MARRIED A CUSHITE WOMAN.] These are the words that Miriam spoke. How precious are the words of the ancients who said with regard to the elders, “Happy are they, but woe to their wives.”19 They suspected that Moses refrained from sleeping with Zipporah only because she was not beautiful.20

2. AND THEY SAID: HATH THE LORD INDEED SPOKEN ONLY WITH MOSES? Miriam offered proof that Moses did not act in this manner because of the sanctity of God, for they too were prophets and they were not prohibited from engaging in sexual intercourse.

ONLY WITH. Scripture reads, ha-rak akh.21 One term22 would have sufficed. However, Scripture is employing elegant language.23 Compare, ha-mi-mi-beli en kevarim (because there were no graves) (Ex. 14:11).24
AND THE LORD HEARD IT. Even though they spoke in secret.25
3. WAS VERY MEEK. The word anav26 (meek) is similar to the word shalev27 (at peace) (Job 16:12).28 Its meaning is that Moses did not seek honor over his brother.29

4. SUDDENLY. The mem of pitom (suddenly) is superfluous. It is like the mem of shilshom (three days ago).30 Pitom is related to peti (a thoughtless one) (Prov. 9:4). It refers to something that one did not think of.31

COME OUT YE THREE UNTO THE TENT OF MEETING. Each one from his tent. Scripture first speaks generally.32 It then goes into detail, namely, And the Lord came down in a pillar of cloud…and called Aaron and Miriam (v. 5), and Moses heard.33
6. HEAR NOW MY WORDS. The word na means now.34
A PROPHET AMONG YOU. If there be a prophet of God among you.35

IN A VISION The meaning of im yiheyeh nevi’akhem Adonai36 (if there be a prophet among you, I the Lord) is, if there be a prophet, one who is a prophet of God among you.37 Compare, ve-hanevu’ah oded ha-navi38 (even the prophecy of Oded the prophet (II Chron. 15:8); and ha-ohelah sarah immo (his mother Sarah’s tent) (Gen. 24:67);39 and kisakha Elohim olam40 (Thy throne given of God is for ever) (Ps. 45:7).
IN A VISION. In the visions of the night.
I DO SPEAK WITH HIM IN A DREAM. Scripture repeats itself as is its style in prophecies.41

7. HE IS TRUSTED IN ALL MY HOUSE. It means that Moses is, at it were, a member of My house. He enters without permission. If necessary he states his needs. However, in your case when I make myself known to you in a dream, then you are informed. If not, then you have no permission to ask.
8. WITH HIM DO I SPEAK MOUTH TO MOUTH. The meaning is, I speak to him without an intermediary.42
EVEN MANIFESTLY, AND NOT IN DARK SPEECHES. This means I illustrate my word to him as I did when I commanded the erection of the tabernacle.43
AND NOT IN DARK SPEECHES. Compare, A great eagle (…Came unto Lebanon, And took the top of the cedar) (Ezek. 17:3).
AND THE SIMILITUDE OF THE LORD DOTH HE BEHOLD. As in the case of Show me, I pray Thee, Thy glory (Ex. 33:18).44 Or its meaning is45 that God communicates with Moses when Moses is awake.
9. AND HE DEPARTED. The reference is to God’s glory. And when the cloud was removed46 (v. 10) proves this.
10. FROM OVER THE TENT. From over the opening of the tent.47
AND…BEHOLD, MIRIAM WAS LEPROUS. Ve-hinneh metzora’at48 is to be rendered, and behold, “she” [Miriam] was leprous.49 Compare, ka’asher ka’ah50 (as it vomited out) (Lev. 18:28).
11. OH MY LORD. I have already explained the meaning of bi adoni (Oh my lord).51
LAY NOT, I PRAY THEE. The meaning of al na52 (…not, I pray thee) is, now, do not.53
WE HAVE DONE FOOLISHLY. The word no’alnu (we have done foolishly) is a nifal. It has no cognate54 except for the word no’alu (are become fools)55 in The princes of Zoan are become fools (Is. 19:13).

Some say that the root of no’alnu56 was formed by inverting the root ivvelet57 (foolishness). Compare, Foolishness is bound up (Prov. 22:15) (in the heart of a child). The meaning of no’alnu is known.58

12. LET HER NOT, I PRAY, BE AS ONE DEAD. Let our sister not now be as a stillborn child, half of whose flesh is consumed when it comes out of its mother’s womb. The same is true of the flesh of a leper.59 There is no need for a scribal emendation.60
13. AND MOSES CRIED. This shows that Moses was pained because of what happened to his sister.

O GOD. You who hold the power in Your hands,61 heal her now. God therefore answered him as follows: If her father was angry at her and spat in her face, would she not hide in shame from seeing his face for seven days?
14. SHUT UP. As lepers are, so that they do not harm others.62

AND AFTER THAT SHE SHALL BE BROUGHT IN AGAIN. Ve-acher te’asef (and after that she shall be brought in again) means she shall once again be considered as a member of the community. Va-asafto (and you shall bring him in) in and you shall bring him in from his leprosy (II Kings 5:3) is similar. After Miriam returned to the camp, the people journeyed from Hazeroth.

16. AND PITCHED IN THE WILDERNESS OF PARAN. Many believe that the cloud was there.63 They interpret thus because they found Scripture stating and the cloud abode in the wilderness of Paran (Num. 10:12).64 They interpret And when the cloud was removed from over the Tent (v. 10) literally.65 However, I believe that this is not the correct meaning.66
chapter.ftnote: 1 In other words, And Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses is to be interpreted: And Miriam spoke against Moses, and Aaron remained silent (or agreed). I.E. interprets thus because our verse reads, va-tedabber miriam ve-aharon. Now va-tedabber is in the feminine. Thus our verse is to be rendered, And Miriam spoke, and Aaron. If both spoke, then our text should have read, va-yedabberu miriam ve-aharon.
2 As it is in our verse, which reads, va-tedabber miriam ve-aharon be-mosheh (And Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses).
3 Compare, I will now say (adabberah): Peace be within thee (bakh) (Ps. 122:8).
4 Compare, The spirit of the Lord spoke by me (II Sam. 23:2).
5 Ethiopia.
6 See Yalkut Shimoni on Shemot 168; 247.
7 Onkelos renders ha-ishah ha-cushit (the Cushite woman) as the beautiful women (ittetah shappirtah).
8 See Berachot 58a.

9 However, see Rashi, who explains Zipporah “was called a Cushite because of her beauty. This is similar to the case of a man who calls his beautiful son Cushi so that the evil eye will not harm him.” I.E. apparently did not believe in the evil eye. Hence he did not accept Rashi’s interpretation.

10 When something has a negative connotation we employ a euphemism. However, we do not refer to something positive by a negative term. Hence there is no reason to refer to a beautiful woman as a Cushite.
11 They believe that Saul was very handsome and hence was called cush. See Rashi and I.E. on Ps. 7:1.
12 They say that its meaning is: Are ye not as beautiful children unto me.
13 See I.E. on Amos 9:7, where he explains this verse to mean: You are acting like Cushites in that you do not serve me.
15 See Jud. 8:24. Also see I.E. on Gen. 37:28 (Vol. 1, p. 351).
16 Which are pitched in the wilderness under the hot sun.
17 The reference is to the curtains of the tents. We thus see that the Midianites live in tents.
18 They are very sunburned. See Cant. 1:5.

19 According to the rabbis, Zipporah complained that Moses ceased having sexual relations with her ever since he was chosen to receive Divine revelation. The rabbis say that Miriam spoke on behalf of Zipporah and argued that she too was a prophetess and yet did not abstain from relations with her husband. See Mo’ed Katan 17b; Sifre, Devarim 99; and Yalkut Shimoni, Devarim 738.
20 And not because he was a prophet. According to I.E., because of the Cushite woman whom he had married is to be understood as: because he refrained from sleeping with her because she was a Cushite.
21 Rak means only; so does akh. Thus our clause, which reads ha-rak akh be-mosheh dibber Adonai, literally reads: Hath the Lord spoken only only with Moses. Hence I.E.’s comment.
22 Rak or akh. Our text should have read, ha-rak be-mosheh, or ha-akh be-mosheh.
23 It is considered poetic to repeat certain words in certain contexts.
24 Beli and en mean the same thing. See I.E. on Ex. 14:11 (Vol. 2, p. 277).
25 And did not publicly criticize Moses. Miriam and Aaron spoke only to each other about this. They would not publicly discuss such an intimate matter.
26 From the root ayin, nun, heh.
27 From the root shin, lamed, heh.
28 Both words come from roots that end in a heh. In both words a vav has been substituted for a heh.
29 Contrary to what Miriam had implied in verse 2, Moses did not consider himself superior to Aaron.
30 The mem of which is superfluous.
31 According to I.E. a peti is a person who does not anticipate the consequences of his acts. Similarly, the word pitom (suddenly) means unanticipated.
32 In other words, Come out ye three unto the tent of meeting is a general statement.
33 What God told Aaron and Miriam.
34 See I.E. on Num. 10:31.

35 The Hebrew reads, nevi’akhem, which literally means your prophet. In this case, our verse reads, if your prophet will be. However, this reading makes no sense within the context of our verse. Hence I.E. maintains that im yiheyeh nevi’akhem be rendered, if there be a prophet among you.
36 This literally reads, if they will be your prophet Lord.
37 In other words, nevi’akhem Adonai should be read as if written nevi’akhem nevi Adonai.

38 According to I.E. this should be read as if written, ve-ha-nevu’ah nevu’ot oded ha-navi (even the prophecy, prophecy of Oded the prophet), for the word nevu’ah has a definite article prefixed to it and thus cannot be in the construct with oded. See I.E. on Gen. 2:9 (Vol. 1, p. 54).
39 According to I.E. this is to be read as if written, ha-ohelah ohel sarah immo (the tent, tent of Sarah his mother). See I.E. on Gen. 24:67 (Vol. 1, p. 243).
40 According to I.E. this should be read as if written, kisakha kisse Elohim olam (Thy Throne, Throne of God for ever). See I.E. on Gen. 24:67 (Vol. 1, p. 243).
41 I do speak with him in a dream repeats I…do make myself known unto him in a vision.

42 According to I.E., God at first spoke to Moses via an angel. However, at the giving of the second set of tablets and onward, he spoke to Moses without an intermediary. See I.E. on Ex. 33:21 (Vol. 2, p. 693).
43 See Ex. 25:40, And see that thou make them after their pattern, which is being shown thee in the mount.
44 And God responded, as it were, by showing Moses His back.
45 The meaning of and the similitude of the Lord doth he behold.
46 Which immediately follows.
47 Where it was up to this time. See verse 5.
48 Which literally means, and behold, leprous.
49 In other words, ve-hinneh metzora’at is to be read as if written, ve-hinneh hi metzora’at.
50 Which is to be read as if written, ka’asher hi ka’ah, for ka’asher ka’ah means as spit out.
51 Bi is an expression introducing a request, or the phase of bi adoni is short for: upon me (bi), my lord, is the sin. See I.E. on Gen. 43:20 (Vol. 1, p. 392); and Ex. 4:10 (Vol. 2, p. 99).
52 According to I.E. the word na means now. Hence his comment.
53 According to I.E. our verse should be rendered: oh my lord, do not now lay sin upon us.
54 That is, the root yod, alef, lamed does not appear in Scripture with the meaning of foolishness except when it is in the nifal form. It has a different meaning in the hifil. See Filwarg.
55 And similar nifal forms. See Jer. 5:4 (Filwarg).
56 No’alnu comes from the root yod, alef, lamed.
57 From the root alef, vav (yod), lamed.
58 Its meaning is, we have done foolishly.
59 Hence Moses compared Miriam to a stillborn child.

60 According to the Midrash, His mothers womb should be read as if written our mother’s womb, and “half of his flesh” as if it read half our flesh, for Scripture employed the third rather than the first person plural because it wanted to avoid using non-flattering language regarding Moses and Aaron. See Sifre debe Rav, Be-Ha’alotekha 105. Also see Rashi on our verse. I.E. apparently believes that the Midrash was of the opinion that the scribes changed the original text of the Torah from the first person to the third person. He disagrees and maintains that there is no need to change the reading when interpreting our verse.
61 The term used for God in our verse is El. According to I.E. this name alludes to God’s power.
62 By their proximity to them.
63 In Paran.
64 See I.E. on Num. 10:31.
65 That the cloud left the tent of meeting and took up its journey to Paran. See Num. 10:11.
66 Its meaning is that it left the front of the tent and moved to the top of the tent. See I.E. on verse 10.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 13
chapter.p: 1. SEND THOU MEN. Scripture records that God told Israel: go up, take possession (Deut. 1:21)1 and Israel answered: Let us send men before us (Deut. 1:22).2 God then said, Send thou men.3
The meaning of men is, men known for their might. The same applies to all of them men4 (v. 3) and to be thou [Solomon] strong and show thyself a man5 (I Kings 2:2), for he [Solomon] was a man.6
THAT THEY MAY SPY OUT. The meaning of ve-yaturu (that they may spy out) is that they may search out. Compare, ve-lo taturu7 (and that ye go not about) (Num. 15:39).

EVERY ONE A PRINCE AMONG THEM. Kol nasi ba-hem8 is to be interpreted: each one was a prince among them.9 On the other hand, the word ehad mentioned earlier in our verse also applies here.10 Compare, And two men, captains of bands, were [captains of] the son of Saul11 (II Sam. 4:2).12 There are many such examples.13

16. [THESE ARE THE NAMES OF THE MEN.] The reason that Scripture states, these are the names of the men, after earlier stating, And these were their names (v. 4),14 is to teach us that, unlike Hoshea,15 their names were never changed.

17. GET YOU UP HERE INTO THE SOUTH. Get you up this way in the south.16 It is known that Egypt is south of the land of Israel, as I have explained in the Book of Daniel.17 The following is proof of this. Egypt is less than thirty degrees north of the equator.18 Jerusalem is thirty-three degrees north of the equator.19 The desert of Paran20 is south of the land of Canaan.21

Observe that the meaning of in the South22 is not south of the camp23 but in the south of the land of Canaan. Proof of the aforementioned is that Scripture tells us concerning Hebron, which belonged to the tribe of Judah, Judah shall abide in his border on the south (Josh. 18:5).24
18. AND SEE THE LAND, WHAT IT IS. And the people, what is it?25
WHETHER THEY ARE STRONG. In battle. Scripture then26 goes on to explain, and see the land. It says, and what the land is…whether it is good, that is, whether its air and water are good.
19. WHETHER IN CAMPS. Like the Kederites,27 who live in tents.
20. WHETHER IT IS FAT. In producing wheat.
22. [AND CAME UNTO HEBRON.] Our sages of blessed memory said that and came refers to Caleb the son of Jephunneh,28 for each one of the men went to a different part of the country.29
ZOAN IN EGYPT. Zoan is the name of a city in Egypt.30 Of Beth-lehem Judah31 (Ruth 1:1)32 is similar.33

Some say that the word tzo’an (Zoan) is connected to the word yitzan (be removed) in A tent that shall not be removed (Is. 33:20).34 However, this is farfetched. Scripture mentions Hebron in order to tell us that Hebron came into being before Zoan.
23. UNTO THE VALLEY OF ESHCOL. These are the words of Moses.35 It is possible that it is similar to and pursued as far as Dan (Gen. 14:14) in that it had another name.36
24. WAS CALLED. Kara (was called) is to be rendered, someone called.37 Compare, whom she bore to Levi38 (Num. 26:59).39

25. [AT THE END.] The word mi-ketz (at the end) sometimes means at the beginning and sometimes means at the end.40 Mi-ketz arba’im yom (and the end of forty days) probably means at the start of the fortieth day.41
26. AND THEY WENT. This informs us that they did not go to their tents, which were in the camp, but immediately went [to Moses, Aaron, and all the congregation].
AND BROUGHT BACK WORD. To Moses and Aaron.
27. AND THEY TOLD HIM. They told Moses, for he was the most important one.
30. AND CALEB STILLED THE PEOPLE. Rabbi Jonah the grammarian says that the meaning of va-yahas (and…stilled) is: and he said be still (hasu).

32. AND THEY SPREAD AN EVIL REPORT OF THE LAND. Va-yotzi’u dibbat ha-aretz (and they spread an evil report) means: and they spread a lie. This is not the meaning of va-yave yosef et dibbatam ra (and Joseph brought evil report of them) (Gen. 37:2), for va-yave (brought) is the reverse of va-yotzi (and they spread).42

EVIL REPORT. The word dibbah (evil report) comes from a double root.43 It comes from the same root as the word dovev (moving gently) in Moving gently the lips of those that are asleep (Cant. 7:10). I have explained it in its place.44
EATETH UP THE INHABITANTS THEREOF. For its air is bad.

MEN OF GREAT STATURE.45 Every man is a man of measurements. Anshe middot means men of great measurement, men whose measurements are greater than everyone else’s. The same applies to the phrase anshe levav (men of heart)46 (Job. 34:34).47 There are many other instances similar to the above.
33. THE NEPHILIM. I have already explained this term.48
OF THE NEPHILIM. Its meaning49 is that they were of the Nephilim, who were in the earth in those days, and also after that when…came in (Gen 6:4).50 I have explained it51 there.52
chapter.ftnote: 1 Of the land of Canaan.
2 Thus it appears that the spies were sent to Canaan in response to Israel’s request. However, our Torah portion seems to imply that Moses sent spies to Canaan in response to God’s command.
3 In other words, what is reported in our verse was in response to Israel’s request reported in Deut. 1:21,22.
4 Its meaning is, all of them were men known for their might.
5 The meaning of and show thyself a man is: and show thyself to be a man of valor.
6 Thus and show thyself to be man cannot be taken literally.
7 I.E. renders ve-lo taturu as: and you shall not search out after what your eyes see.
8 Literally, every prince among them. Hence I.E.’s comment.
9 In other words, kol nasi ba-hem is short for kol ehad hu nasi be-hem.

10 Thus the word ehad is not missing in our text, and kol echad nasi ba-hem is not short for kol echad hu nasi ba-hem. There doesn’t seem to be much of a difference between the two interpretations offered by I.E. See Filwarg and Krinsky.
11 Translated literally.
12 This verse is to be interpreted: And two men, captains of (sare) bands, were captains of the son of Saul, for captains of (sare) is to be read as if written twice.
13 Where a word in a verse is to be read as if written twice in a verse. See I.E. on Gen. 6: 13 (Vol. 1., p. 100, note 36).
14 These are the names of the men after And these were their names appears redundant. Hence I.E. comment.
15 Whose name was changed to Joshua (v. 16).

16 In other words, alu zeh ba-negev is to be rendered: get you up this way i n the south (of the land of Canaan). The literal meaning of alu zeh ba-negev is: get you up this into the south. Hence I.E.’s comment.
17 See I.E. on Dan. 11:5.
18 Hebrew, rochav, a term referring to the distance of a plane to the equator.
19 See above.
20 Where Israel was encamped when Moses sent out the spies.

21 The text reads, south of the land of Egypt. Paran was the place where Israel was when it sent out the spies. Geographically speaking, Paran is not south of Egypt. It is north of Egypt and lies between Egypt and Canaan. Hence a number of commentaries suggest emending the text to read, the wilderness of Paran is south of the land of Israel, or the wilderness of Paran is north of the land of Egypt. See Filwarg, Weiser, Krinsky, and Meijler.
22 Hebrew, ba-negev.
23 For taking a road south of the camp would lead them back into Egypt, as Paran is north of Egypt.
24 We thus see that the south (the Negev) is a district in the Land of Israel.

25 In other words, the term ma hi (what is it) is carried over from ha-aretz (and the land) to ha-am (the people). Thus our text is to be read as if written, et ha-aretz mah hi vet ha-am ma hu (the land, what it is and the people what is it,) i.e., what is their nature.
26 In verse 19.
27 An Ishmaelite tribe. See Gen. 25:13; Ps. 120:5.
28 Sotah 34b. Also see Rashi. And came (va-yavo) is in the singular. Hence the rabbinic interpretation.
29 Hence Caleb could visit Hebron by himself.

30 Our verse reads, tzo’an mitzrayim literally, Zoan Egypt. Now a proper name does not come in the construct. Hence I.E. points out that here it does, contrary to the rule. According to I.E. tzo’an mitzrayim is short for tzo’an shel mitzrayim, Zoan of Egypt.
31 Translated literally.
32 The meaning of which is Beth-lehem of Judah.
33 Here too two common nouns are in the construct, for Beth-lehem Judah is short for Beth-lehem of Judah.
34 These commentaries interpret tzo’an mitzrayim as meaning the establishment of Egypt
35 The valley of Eshcol was not yet so called when the spies came there. However, Moses called it by the name which the Israelites later used in referring to it.

36 Dan had two names, Dan and Layish (Jud. 18:29). However, Moses in writing the Torah used the name by which Israel referred to it. So too Nahal Eshcol had another name, and Moses used the name that the Israelites used. For other interpretations, see Filwarg and Meijler.
37 Our verse literally reads, called that place Nahal Eshcol. Scripture omits the subject. Hence I.E. says that “called” is short for “the caller called,” that is, someone called.
38 Translated literally.
39 Here too Scripture does not identify the subject. Thus who she bore has to be rendered whom somebody bore.

41 According to the Torah, God decreed that Israel spend a year in the desert for each day that the spies spent in Canaan. Now Israel spent 39 years in the desert (see Rashi on 14:33). Hence I.E. assumes that the spies spent 39 days in Canaan (Filwarg).
42 For there the report was true. In other words, when dibbatam follows va- yave, it refers to the truth. When it follows va-yotzi, it refers to a lie.
43 Its root is dalet, bet, bet, even though it is spelled dalet, bet, heh, which, prima facie, appears to be its root.
44 Compare, I.E. on Cant. 7:10, “Dovev means to speak. It is possible the word dibbah is similar.” In other words, both dovev and dibbah refer to speech.
45 Hebrew, anshe middot (literally, men of measurements). Hence I.E.’s comments.
46 Translated literally.
47 Its meaning is, men of great hearts, i.e., men of great intelligence.
48 The Nephilim “were so named because anyone who saw them lost heart (she-yippol lev ha-ro’eh otam) at their huge stature).” See I.E. on Gen. 6:4 (Vol. 1, p. 96).
49 The meaning of the Nephilim, the sons of Anak, who came of the Nephilim.

50 The entire verse reads, The Nephilim were in the earth in those days, and also after that, when the sons of God came in unto the daughters of men, and they bore children to them. Thus the Nephilim were descended from the “sons of God.”
51 The meaning of and also after that.
52 And also after that refers to after the flood. See I.E. on Gen. 6:4 (Vol. 1, p. 96).

chapter.title: CHAPTER 14
chapter.p: 1. THEIR VOICE. Et kolam (their voice) is the object of va-tissa (lifted up) and also of va-yittenu1 (and cried).2
2. MURMURED. Va-yillonu (murmured) is a nifal. It is an ayin vav.3 When conjugated in the nifal it looks like a whole root.

3. TO RETURN INTO EGYPT. Shuv (to return) is an infinitive.4 It is like the word kum (to stand)5 in I am not able to stand (Lam. 1:14) and kum (rising up) in And the king, against whom there is no rising up (Prov. 30:31).
4. THEN MOSES…FELL. By his own will.6
6. AND JOSHUA THE SON OF NUN. Moses mentions Joshua first7 out of regard for Joshua’s elevated status.
9. FOR THEY ARE BREAD. We will eat them like bread. Who eat up My people as they eat bread (Ps. 14:4) is similar.
THEIR DEFENSE IS REMOVED FROM OVER THEM.8 For the heart of a warrior frets when he does not have a shield to protect him and to serve as a shade for him.9
10. BADE STONE THEM. Joshua and Caleb.
11. DESPISE ME. Yena’atzuni (despise me) means anger me. It has many cognates in Scripture.10
Scripture employs the singular be-kirbo (among them)11 because at first they were united to do good.
13. WHEN THE EGYPTIANS SHALL HEAR–FOR THOU BROUGHTEST UP THIS PEOPLE. The meaning of ki he’elita (for thou broughtest up) is: that you brought up.12

After Scripture states, When the Egyptians shall hear (ve-shame’u)…they will say to the inhabitants of this land, the reference being to the land of Canaan, it goes on to explain13 what the Egyptians heard. Scripture therefore repeats the word shame’u (have heard) and states they have heard (shame’u) that Thou Lord [Thy glory] art in the midst of this people (v. 14).14

14. ART SEEN FACE TO FACE. The reference is to the glory which the elders saw (Ex. 24:9,10), or to the appearance of the glory of the Lord…in the eyes of the children of Israel (Ex. 24:17). The latter is correct.

ART SEEN. The word nirah (seen) is a verb in the perfect.15 The meaning of attah Adonai nirah is, Thou Lord were seen.16 Ve-nishar17 ani (and I was left) (Ezek. 9: 8) is similar.18 So is ki umlal19 ani20 (for I languish away) (Ps. 6:3), because the lamed of umlal is vocalized with a pattach.21
STANDETH OVER THEM. When they camp.
15. THEN THE NATIONS WHICH HAVE HEARD THE FAME OF THEE. The reference is to Egypt. Also to the Canaanites and other nations.22

16. ABLE. The word yekholet (able) is a noun. It is similar to the word yevoshet (dried up) in until the waters were dried up (Gen. 8:7). It does not mean a measure as in the midrashic interpretation.23
THEREFORE HE HATH SLAIN THEM IN THE WILDERNESS. The meaning of va-yishchatem is, He hath slain them. Scripture employs the term va-yishchatem24 because sheep graze in the wilderness.

17. LET THE POWER OF THE LORD BE GREAT. Let the power…be great connotes being slow to anger, for all who are long-suffering have the great power to break their anger. As Thou hast spoken, that you are slow to anger25 is proof of this. I have explained these attributes26 in the Torah portion Ki Tissa.

19. PARDON, I PRAY THEE. Since we find Scripture saying surely they shall not see the land (v. 23) after salachti ke-devarekha (I have pardoned according to thy word) (v. 20), we learn that the term salach (pardon) refers to being slow to anger.27 Similarly, the meaning of ve-nislach lo (and he shall be forgiven) (Num 15:28) is [the punishment shall be held in abeyance] until he fully repents.28
ACCORDING UNTO THE GREATNESS OF THY LOVINGKINDNESS. The meaning of ke-godel chasdekha (according to the greatness of Thy lovingkindness) is: because of Thy great lovingkindness.29
AND ACCORDING AS THOU HAST FORGIVEN. The word nasata (Thou hast forgiven) is similar to the word nose (forgiving) in forgiving sin (Ex. 34:7).

EVEN UNTIL NOW. Until this place or from the day that they left Egypt until this very day, for the word hennah (now) can refer to a place or to a specific time. Compare, there came men in hither (hennah) (Josh. 2:2) and, and I have not seen him until now (hennah) (Gen. 44:28).30 I have already explained this term.31
21. AS I LIVE. It means as I live, so shall My word come to pass.32
SHALL BE FILLED WITH THE GLORY. As My glory fills the earth.33 However, it most probably refers to the future.34 Its meaning is, I shall do this so that my glory shall be known in the world.35

22. THESE TEN TIMES. The meaning is, these many times. Scripture mentions ten because it is most important. It is the end of the one numbers and the first of the ten numbers in the second series of numbers.36
23. ANY OF THEM THAT DESPISED ME. From among their children.37

24. BUT MY SERVANT CALEB. Caleb alone38 is mentioned because he stilled the people (Num. 13:30). The Levites and the kohanim are not included in the oath,39 for no prince from among them went to spy out the land. Furthermore, Scripture states, all that were numbered of you, according to your whole number (v. 29).40 Now even though there were no kohanim there,41 there were in reality many Levites there.42
ANOTHER SPIRIT. In contrast to the spies.
AND HATH FOLLOWED ME FULLY. He did not he but pursued my word and confirmed it by saying that the land is very good.

25. NOW THE AMALEKITE AND THE CANAANITE. The Canaanite refers to the Amorite, for every Amorite is a Canaanite.43 Scripture does not bother to mention the Amorite by name because the other nation mentioned is the Amalekite, who is of the children of Shem.44 On the other hand, Canaan, who is the father of the Amorite,45 is of the children of Ham.46 Then the Amalekite and the Canaanite…came down (Num. 14:45) is similar.47 And the Amorites…came out (Deut. 1:44)48 is proof of this. Scripture does not mention the Amalekite in the aforementioned verse, as the Amorite was the more important.49

DWELT IN THE VALE. To ambush you. Others say that the meaning of our verse is, even though the Amalekite and the Canaanite dwell in the valley, turn toward the way of the Red Sea and do not fear.50 Now the Israelites did not repent, hence God’s word.51
29. YOUR CARCASSES. The meaning of pigrekhem is your dead bodies.
HAVE MURMURED. Halinotem (have murmured) is related to the word va-yallinu (murmured) in and…murmured against Moses (v. 2).
30. CONCERNING WHICH I LIFTED UP MY HAND. Scripture speaks as humans do, for the sky is above.52
Caleb is mentioned first53 because he acted before anyone else to quiet the people.
32. YOUR CARCASSES.54 Namely, you.
33. SHALL BE WANDERERS.55 For it is the way of shepherds not to remain and rest in one place.56 My habitation is plucked up and carried away from me As a shepherd’s tent (Is. 38:12) is proof of this.
YOUR STRAYINGS. For you turned away from me and said, Let us make a captain, and let us return into Egypt (Num. 14:4).
34. WHICH YE SPIED OUT. By command.57
MY DISPLEASURE.58 I will break my word.59 Or, it means60 who shall break Me; that is, who shall break My oath.61 Compare, But if her father break (heni) her (Num 30:6).
35. THAT ARE GATHERED TOGETHER AGAINST ME. For they wanted to stone62 the servants of God63 because they spoke of God’s glory.64
IN THIS WILDERNESS. The time set for each one shall come to an end, for God has set a specific time for everyone’s death.65
AND THERE THEY SHALL DIE. All of them, close to the time set by God.66
36. And…MADE ALL THE CONGREGATION TO MURMUR AGAINST HIM. Va-yillonu (and made to murmur) is a hifil.
37. DIED. Va-yamutu (died) is to interpreted as if written metu (died).67
BY THE PLAGUE. All together.68
38. BUT JOSHUA THE SON OF NUN. These are the words of Moses. He69 mentions Joshua before Caleb.
41. SEEING IT SHALL NOT PROSPER. The ascent of the mountain will not prosper. Or, the violation of God’s command cannot prosper.
43. FORASMUCH AS YE ARE TURNED BACK. Ki al ken shavtem (forasmuch as ye are turned back) means, since you turned back.70 Compare, since (ki al ken) I gave her not (Gen. 38:26).
44. BUT THEY PRESUMED TO GO UP. Va-yapilu (but they presumed) is related to the word ofel (mound) in the mound and the tower (Is. 32:14). The meaning of va-yapilu is, they went up the hill.

45. AND BEAT THEM DOWN. Rabbi Moses the Spaniard, of blessed memory, says that our text71 should have read va-yakkitum (and beat them down).72 Va-yadbeku (followed hard) in even they also followed hard after them (I Sam. 14:22) is similar.73 However, I believe that va-yakketum (and beat them down) comes from a double root74 and is an irregular word.75
EVEN UNTO HORMAH. Hormah is the name of a place. Others say that the meaning of even unto Hormah is, until they destroyed them.76
chapter.ftnote: 1 Literally, and gave.
2 I.E. reads this verse as follows: And all the congregation lifted up their voice and gave their voice (i.e., they cried).
3 Its root is lamed, vav, nun.
4 Shuv can also be an imperative. Hence I.E.’s comment.
5 Which is an infinitive, even though the word kum can also be an imperative.
6 And not as a result of a prophetic trance (Weiser).
7 Even though in the list of the spies, Caleb is mentioned first. See Num. 13:6-8.
8 Literally, their shadow is removed from over them. Hence I.E.’s comment.

9 In other words, their shadow means their shield. Thus according to I.E. our clause should be understood: their shield is removed from over them; that is, they have no confidence to fight us and they will not confront us with a sword and shield. See Nachmanides on this verse.
10 This word is found many times in Scripture.
11 The word be-kirbo (among them) literally means among him.
12 Ki he’elita is to be interpreted as if written asher he’elita. In other words, the ki (for) in our verse is to be rendered asher (that).
13 In verse 14.
14 In other words, the word shame’u in verse 14 picks up the thought which was interrupted by they will say to the inhabitants of the land.
15 It is a third person perfect. Its meaning is, he was seen.
16 When a second person pronoun (attah) is combined with the third person perfect (nirah) we follow the pronoun.
17 Nishar is a third person perfect.
18 In that we have an anomalous combination of a pronoun and a verb.
19 Umlal is a third person perfect.
20 Ani is a first person pronoun.
21 The pattach indicates that umlal is a third person perfect. However, see I.E. on Psalms 6:3.
22 In other words, the reference is to the Egyptians, Canaanites, and other nations who heard of God’s fame.
23 A Midrash connects the word yekholet to the word yakhil (held a measure). See Kings I 7:26. According to Krinsky the reference is to Midrash Tanhumah on our verse.
24 Which usually applies to the slaughter of cattle.
25 I.E.’s paraphrase of As Thou hast spoken, saying (v. 17): The Lord is slow to anger (v. 18).
26 The attributes mentioned in verse 18.
27 If salach meant full pardon, then (he people would have been permitted to enter the land.
28 Salach in all cases means that punishment is not meted out immediately but is delayed. In the case of Num. 15:28, a sacrifice delays punishment and the person is pardoned if he truly repents.
29 The kof usually has the meaning of like or according. Hence I.E.’s comment that here it means because of.
30 Translated literally.
31 That hennah in Gen 44:28 refers to time.
32 In other words, As I live is short for, As I live, so shall my word come to pass.
33 In other words, yimmale (shall be filled) is to be taken as a present. Thus the meaning of our clause is, and all the earth is filled with the glory of the Lord.
34 For yimmale is an imperfect.
35 According to this interpretation the meaning of our clause is: and all the earth shall be filled with the glory of the Lord.
37 If any of their children will follow in their footsteps (Weiser).
38 Joshua, the kohanim, and Levites are not mentioned in this verse even though they entered the land.
39 Mentioned in verses 21-23.

40 Scripture explicitly states that God’s decree was limited to those who were numbered. Since the kohanim and the Levites were not among those numbered (Num. 1:49), God’s decree did not apply to them.
41 Thus there was no reason to exclude them in verse 29. By no kohanim I.E. means few kohanim, for Aaron and his sons were there.
42 There were 8,580 Levites above the age of 30. See Num. 4:47,48. Hence Scripture excludes them in verse 29.
43 The Amorites are descended from Canaan. See Gen. 10:16.

44 Scripture distinguishes between the Canaanite nations when it speaks of the Canaanites per se. However, when it speaks of one of the Canaanite nations along with a non-Canaanite nation, it does not mention its specific name but uses its general name.
45 Hence the term Canaanite includes the Amorites.
46 The Canaanite is mentioned by name and not called the Hammite because Ham had other sons.
47 There too the reference is to the Amorite.
48 The reference is to the same incident as that in our verse.
49 The Amorite carried the brunt of the battle (Weiser).
50 That the Canaanites and Amalekites shall pursue you.
51 Do not go up for the Lord is not in your midst (v. 42). I.E. believed that verses 39 and 40 do not imply that Israel repented.
52 Hence one raises his hand towards heaven when he takes an oath.
53 Before Joshua.

54 Hebrew, u-figrekhem attem. Literally, and your carcasses, you. Hence I.E.’s comment that the aforementioned is to be interpreted, and your carcasses, namely, you. In other words, Scripture is being explicit.
55 Hebrew, yiheyu ro’im. Literally, will shepherd. Hence I.E.’s comment.
56 Thus “shall shepherd” means shall wander.
57 Via the spies whom you commanded to scout out the land.
58 Hebrew, tenu’ati. I.E. renders this as my breaking. Hence his comments.

59 My promise to bring the generation that left Egypt to Canaan. See Ex. 6:8. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: If I will break My word. In this case, the reference is to God’s oath, which He took not to bring the generation that left Egypt into Canaan. In view of the belief of I.E. that God is unchangeable (see his comments on Gen. 6:6, Vol. 1, p. 96), the reading of Vat. Ebr. 38 appears correct.
60 The meaning of tenu’ati, My breaking.
61 The oath which I took not to allow you to enter the land of Canaan.
62 Verse 10.
63 Caleb and Joshua. God considers an attack on His servants as an attack on God Himself.
64 Verses 7-9.

65 The Hebrew verse reads, ba-midbar ha-zeh yittamu (in this wilderness they shall be consumed). Ba-midbar ha-zeh yittamu literally means, in this wilderness they shall be finished. I.E. interprets this to mean their time shall be finished; that is, the time allotted for their lives shall come to an end.

66 The days of the entire generation shall be completed close to the forty-year period set by God for their sojourn in the desert. In others words, the entire generation shall die in about forty years.

67 Va-yamutu (died) means and they died. Like all verbs with a conversive vav, it usually opens a new clause. However, the context indicates that verse 37 does not open a new clause. Hence I.E.’s comment.
68 Unlike the generation that died in the wilderness.
69 Unlike God. See verse 30.
70 In other words, ki al ken means since. The literal meaning of ki al ken is “for on yes.” Hence I.E.’s comment.
71 Which reads va-yakketum (and beat them down).
72 For the word is a hifil from the root nun, kaf, tav. Rabbi Moses is only commenting on the irregularity of va-yakketum. The meaning remains the same.
73 Here too the reading should be va-yadbiku rather than va-yadbeku, for the word is in the hifil.
74 The root kaf, tav, tav.
75 For the word should have read va-yakkitum.
76 In other words, hormah means destruction, and even unto Hormah means even unto destruction.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 15
chapter.p: 1. WHEN YE ARE COME INTO THE LAND OF YOUR HABITATIONS. This chapter follows [the one dealing with the spies] in order to console the children by informing them that they would enter the land, for the Israelites grew weak and mourned.1

However, the real reason that this chapter follows the one dealing with the spies, is because all the congregation shouted and sinned.2 God forgave their sin because of the prayer of Moses.3 Scripture says, And when ye shall err (15:22).4 And they shall be forgiven (15:25) is proof of this.5 Scripture found it necessary to mention the law of the meal offering and of all burnt offerings and sacrifices.6 At the end,7 it states, But the soul that doeth aught with a high hand (v. 30). The latter alludes to Israel’s deeds.8 Scripture mentions the gatherer of wood (verses 32-34)9 because he acted with a high hand. God designated the fringes as a sign10 because of His great pity on Israel, so that a person will not act with a high hand or11 forget.12

3. CLEARLY UTTERED. Le-fale (clearly uttered) means to separate.13 Similarly the word ve-hiflah (shall make a division) in And the Lord shall make a division (Ex. 9:4). This is so even though ve-hiflah is spelled with a heh,14 for the letters alef, heh, vav, yod interchange.
9.15 A MEAL-OFFERING OF…FINE FLOUR. A tenth of an ephah for each one of the flock.16
11. THE HE-LAMBS. Or the kids.17 Scripture similarly states later, for each lamb.18 If the celebrant offers a ram, then his meal offering is doubled,19 for a lamb is a small animal.
Scripture does not mention the free-will offering20 along with the bullock.21 It mentions the peace offering22 [with the bullock] because it did not mention it above.23 They all have one law.24
12. [ACCORDING TO THE NUMBER.] The reference is to the meal offering, the oil, and the wine.
14. OR WHOSOEVER MAY BE AMONG YOU. Today.25

15. AS FOR THE CONGREGATION. Some say that the heh prefixed to the word kahal (congregation) is the sign of the vocative.26 However, I believe that there is no vocative letter in the holy tongue. The four instances27 are proof of this.28 One of them is Moses, Moses.29 On the contrary, this heh30 is the sign of the definite object.31 It is not a sign of the vocative.
AS YE ARE, SO SHALL THE STRANGER BE. I have already explained the rule governing two kafs joined together.32
16. [ONE LAW.] Its meaning is, one law aside from the burnt offerings, for the burnt offerings are obligated by statute.33
God also says,34 as you bring a meal offering of fine flour along with the burnt offering, thus shall you do with your dough.35

There is no need to mention what our ancients, of blessed memory, received by tradition, namely, that one is obligated to set aside two offerings, a portion of the dough36 and a portion of the grain,37 and their amount.38 Their words are true. Everything else is nonsense.

24. [ONE HE-GOAT.] Scripture adds a he-goat.39 The congregation must bring a sin offering whether they erred by doing something they were prohibited from doing or erred in not doing something they were obligated to do.

25. AND THEIR SIN-OFFERING. The reference is to the he-goat.40 A sei’r izzim (he-goat) refers to a young goat because the word se’ir (he-goat) is connected to izzim (goats). The reverse is the case with the term atud (he-goat).41

27. A SHE-GOAT OF THE FIRST YEAR FOR A SIN-OFFERING. This explains a goat, a female (Lev. 4:28).42 The sin spoken of in our verse refers to a failure, due to error, to do what the Torah commands.43 Now this law is the same for the one who errs and does what he is commanded not to do.44
29. ONE LAW.45 This is similar to This is the law of (torat) the sin-offering (Lev. 6:18).46
30. WITH A HIGH HAND. To show all that he does not fear God.
BLASPHEMETH. This is the way people speak.47
31. BECAUSE HE HATH DESPISED THE WORD OF THE LORD. This is what with a high hand refers to.
AND HATH BROKEN HIS COMMANDMENT. For God commanded him not to act with a high hand. Others say that and hath broken His commandment refers to one who violates God’s commandment in secret.
THAT SOUL. This does not refer to the rational soul.48 as those who err say.49 It refers rather to the connection of the soul to the body.50
HIS INIQUITY SHALL BE UPON HIM. Compare, his blood shall be upon him (Ezek. 33:4).

32. IN THE WILDERNESS. I believe that the reference is to the wilderness of Sinai.51 I have already mentioned52 why this chapter follows the incident of the spies.53 It is also possible that the gatherer of wood acted with a high hand54 and they warned him,55 but to no avail.56
[33. BROUGHT HIM.] Some say they brought him in on Saturday night.57
34. IN WARD. Ba-mishmar (in ward) is vocalized with a pattach.58 It refers to a specific place.59
WHAT SHOULD BE DONE TO HIM. How he should be put to death.60
36. AS THE LORD COMMANDED. Death by stoning.

38. THAT THEY MAKE THEM…FRINGES.61 It is possible to interpret this in two ways. One, that they make fringes (tzitzit) like those in by the fringes (be-tzitzit)62 of my head (Ezek. 8:3),63 the reference in our verse being to threads that are not woven.64
IN THE CORNERS OF THEIR GARMENTS. Upon smooth garments65 or pants,66 for if pants are divided they will have corners.67
A THREAD OF BLUE. Upon the fringes. The reason the thread was blue is that blue is a sky-like color.
39. AND IT SHALL BE UNTO YOU FOR A FRINGE. The thread at the end was like the fringe.68

The other interpretation is the one which the rabbis of blessed memory transmitted.69 Now the first interpretation is nullified in view of the fact that there are true witnesses70 to the second explanation. The rabbis transmitted to us the law that this commandment applies to a garment that has four corners and that the tzitzit are fringes.71 I will explain this law later.72

Now this commandment states that everyone who has a four-cornered garment shall always cover himself with it during the day. He shall not remove it so that he remembers73 the commandments. Those who pray with a tallit during the time of prayers do so because they read in the shema,74 And it shall be unto you for a fringe (v. 39) and that they make them throughout their generations fringes (v. 30).

However, I believe that one is more obligated to enwrap oneself in fringes when he is not at prayer than during the time of prayer, so that he remembers the commandments and does not err and trespass during the other hours of the day, for in the hour of prayer he will not sin.75
THAT YE MAY LOOK UPON IT. The commandment requires that the fringes be seen.

AFTER YOUR OWN HEART. Which lusts. The eye sees and the heart desires. The fringes thus serve as a sign and a mark that a person should not pursue the thoughts of his heart and all that his eyes desire.
AFTER WHICH YE USE TO GO ASTRAY. For one who follows his desires goes astray from the service of his God.

40. THAT YE MAY REMEMBER. Scripture has previously stated, and remember all the commandments of the Lord (v. 39).76 The meaning of our verse is: if you remember the commandments of God, you will be holy and you will not defile yourselves with the lusts of the heart which defile the rational soul.77
41. I AM THE LORD YOUR GOD. I am He who took you out of Egypt to be your God. I therefore say to you: I am the Lord your God.78
chapter.ftnote: 1 See Num. 14:39. This interpretation is found in Rashi.
4 Which is precisely what Israel had just done.
5 The theme connecting the chapters is atonement for sin.
6 Since Scripture mentioned the sin offering and its accompanying meal and drink offering, it felt compelled to mention the same regarding the burnt and other offerings.
7 After mentioning the various offerings.
8 The incident of the spies.
9 After the sin offering.
10 Of the commandments.
11 Deliberately violate God’s commandments.
12 Any of God’s commands.
13 According to I.E., le-fale neder (in fulfillment of a vow clearly uttered) is to be rendered, in fulfillment of a vow set aside.
14 And le-fale is spelled with an alef.

15 The printed texts have verse 9. However, the reference appears to be to verse 4, for verse 8 speaks of the herd while verse 3 speaks of the herd and the flock. Furthermore, verse 4 speaks of a tenth of an ephah and verse 9 does not.
16 Mentioned in the previous verse.

17 This comment as it stands appears very difficult. First of all, what is I.E. adding to the Scriptural text, which reads: for each of the he-lambs, or of the kids? Furthermore, I.E. goes on to say, “Scripture similarly states at the end, for each lamb.” We do not find the phrase for each lamb in any of the following verses. Filwarg suggests that the heading verse 11 is an error and should be eliminated and that our note is a continuation of the previous one. It should read as follows:

[Verse 4.] A MEAL-OFFERING OF…FINE FLOUR. A tenth of an ephah for each one of the flock, (that is) he-lambs or kids. Scripture similarly states at the end (of the verse), for each lamb (v. 5). See note 15.
18 We thus see that the term flock refers to lambs (and by extension also to kids).
19 Verse 6.
20 Hebrew, nedavah.
21 In verse 8. It does so in verse 3. Hence I.E.’s comment.
22 Hebrew, shelamim.
23 In verse 3.

24 The neder (vow) mentioned in verses 3 and 8 and the nedavah (free-will offering) mentioned in verse 3 all have one law. They are considered as shelamim (peace offerings). See Lev. 7:16-20 (Weiser).
25 According to I.E., or whosoever may be among you, throughout your generations should be interpreted as: or whosoever be among you today or throughout your generations.
26 According to this interpretation our verse reads: O congregation (ha-kahal), there shall be one statute both for you, and for the stranger.
27 Where a common noun is repeated. They are: Moses, Moses (Ex. 3:4); Abraham, Abraham (Gen. 22:11); Jacob, Jacob (Gen. 46:2); Samuel, Samuel (I Sam. 3:1).
28 That there is no vocative heh, otherwise why repeat the common noun.
29 Ex. 3:4. I.E. probably quotes Moses, Moses as an example because he is expounding the Book of Numbers, and Moses is the central human character.
30 The heh prefixed to kahal.
31 Thus the meaning of ha-kahal is, the congregation.

32 According to I.E. when two kafs are affixed to two words following each other it indicates an abridged clause. Thus our verse, which states ka-khem ka-ger (as you are, so shall the stranger be) is to be interpreted: as you are, so shall the stranger be; as the stranger is, so shall you be. See I.E. on Gen. 44:18 (Vol. 1, p. 396).

33 For that is what the word chukkah (statute) refers to. Verse 15 states, there shall be one statute (chukkah) both for you, and for the stranger that sojourneth with you. Verse 16 states, One law (Torah) and one ordinance shall be both for you, and for the stranger. Prima facie, Scripture is redundant. Hence I.E. comments that verse 15 deals with that which is obligatory, namely, the burnt offering (for it concludes the law mentioned in verse 14, which deals with sacrifices), and verse 16 deals with all the other commandments, for it speaks of Torah (Filwarg).
34 In verses 19-21.
35 One must set aside a portion of one’s dough as a gift unto God. Hence the law of hallah follows the law of the meal offering.
36 Hallah.
37 Terumah. In other words, one has to set aside a portion from the dough, even though he has already set aside a portion from the grain out of which this very dough was made (Filwarg).
38 How much one has to set aside.
39 To the bullock mentioned in Lev. 4:13,14 for the sin committed in error by the congregation.
40 An offering made by fire unto the Lord refers to the bullock, and their sin-offering before the Lord refers to the he-goat.
41 So Vat. Ebr. 38. An atud is a mature goat. Some texts read atid (the future) in place of atud (he-goat). However, the latter is practically impossible to explain. See Filwarg.
42 Which the Torah in Lev. 4:28 mandates for one who sins through error.

43 Lev. 4:27-31 deals with one who violates a sin by doing something which the Lord has commanded not to be done. Hence I.E. believes that our verse deals with a failure to observe a positive commandment.
44 In both cases he must bring a goat, a female without blemish.
45 Hebrew, torah achat.
46 The word torah (law) (rather than mitzvat, chukkat, mishpat) is used with regard to the rules of the sacrifices (Filwarg).
47 People consider a high-handed act against God as blasphemous.
48 I.E. held that man has three souls: vegetative, animal, and rational. See Foreword, Vol. 1, p. XIII.
49 According to I.E. man’s rational soul is immortal if developed by study.
50 Premature death.
51 For the word midbar (wilderness) has the direct article (ba) prefixed to it. The reference is thus to “the” wilderness, which I.E. is certain must refer to Sinai.
52 See I.E. on verse 2.
53 Even though this incident preceded the sending of the spies, for the sending of the spies took place after Israel journeyed from Sinai.
54 He deliberately violated God’s law.

55 The Bible does not explicitly state that the gatherer of wood was warned. According to Jewish law, however, one cannot be executed for a crime unless one is first warned to desist. Hence I.E. suggests that he was warned but to no avail.
56 He continued to gather wood on the Sabbath. The Sifre explains similarly.
57 For they would not arrest him on the Sabbath.
58 What I.E. means is that the bet of ba-mishmar (in ward) is vocalized with a pattach.
59 For the preposition ba is the sign of the direct object.
60 The Torah earlier stated that whoever violates the Sabbath should be put to death (Ex. 35:2). However, it does not state how the culprit should be executed.
61 Hebrew, tzitzit.
62 That is, the hair.
63 The second interpretation is given in the next verse.
64 According to this interpretation the threads at the corner are not to be woven but are left unfinished, like the hair upon the head. These unfinished threads are to serve as fringes.
65 Such as a sheet.
66 This is still part of the first interpretation.
67 Hence they require fringes now (Krinsky).
68 The blue thread that was placed on the edge of the garment was to resemble one of the loose hanging threads.
69 That the fringes are not part of the garment but are attached to the corners of the garment.
70 Jewish practice throughout the ages.
71 Hanging from but not part of the garment.
72 The reference apparently is to I.E.’s commentary on Deut. 22:11.
73 So Vat. Ebr. 38. Mikro’ot Gedolot reads, so that they remember.
74 The shema is part of the morning and evening prayers. It consists of Deut. 6:4-9; Deut. 11:13-21; Num. 15:37-41.

75 “Now, the person who envelops himself in a tallit [during prayer] does not fully observe the commandment. In reality, one is obligated to wear fringes the entire day, for when a person is in the market and his eyes wander, his heart lusts after what his eyes see much more than it does during prayer.” See The Secret of the Torah, p. 79.
76 Hence why repeat itself and state in our verse that ye may remember.
77 Hence our verse does not repeat verse 39.
78 That is, obey My commandments.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 16
chapter.p: 1. NOW KORAH, THE SON OF IZHAR…TOOK. This event occurred in the wilderness of Sinai when the first-born were set aside1 and the Levites were placed in their stead.2 Israel thought that our master Moses acted out of his own will in giving his brother an elevated position. They suspected that he acted similarly towards the sons of Kohath, who were his relatives, and to all the sons of Levi who were of his family. The Levites rebelled against Moses because they were subservient to Aaron and his sons.

Dathan and Abiram rebelled because Moses3 removed the birthright from Reuben their forefather, and gave it to Joseph. It is also possible that they suspected that Moses favored the tribe of Joseph because Joshua was his assistant.4 Korah too was a first-born, as Scripture clearly states.5 The banner of Reuben camped in the south.6 So did Korah, for he was a Kohathite.7

The princes of the congregation were first-born. They offered the burnt offering. They therefore took the fire pans. The miracle of the staff,8 which demonstrated to all of Israel that God chose the Levites in place of the first-born, is proof that this explanation is correct.9 Hence Scripture reads, that there may be made an end of their murmurings against Me (Num. 17:25), for the murmuring was an account of this.10 Moses also said, that I have not done them of mine own mind (v. 28). He said the aforementioned because Israel had come to believe that he had acted on his own. Furthermore, Moses said, then the Lord hath not sent me (v. 29) in this thing,11 because Israel had come to believe in him.12 Here is another rigorous proof: seeing all the congregation are holy (v. 3). The aforementioned alludes to the first-born who are holy, for Scripture states, Sanctify unto Me all the first-born (Ex. 13:2). The first-born were the priests that come near to the Lord (Ex. 19:22). They were the most important ones of the congregation.
NOW KORAH…TOOK. This is short for, now Korah took men.13 Compare, an ass bread14 (I Sam. 17:20).15 There are many such instances in Scripture.16
Rabbi Jonah says that the meaning of Now Korah took is now Korah took himself to rise against Moses.17
2. IN THE FACE OF MOSES. They did not rise up in secret. There is a difference between li-fene (in the face of) and mi-pene (before the face of) (Gen. 3:8).18
THE ELECT MEN OF THE ASSEMBLY. They were called to the tent of meeting.
MEN OF RENOWN. Before they left Egypt.

A grammarian says that the princes of the congregation are the leaders who stood over those that were numbered (Num 1:4).19 He says that they20 are the object of took. Our text should be read as if written, And Korah and Dathan and Abiram and On took the princes of Israel to speak to them.21 This interpretation is a bit far-fetched.22
3. YE TAKE TOO MUCH UPON YOU. Enough for you. 23 Its meaning is, you have grabbed the greater portion.
SEEING ALL THE CONGREGATION ARE HOLY. For the entire congregation became holy from the day they stood on Sinai.

AND THE LORD IS AMONG THEM. For the Levites were chosen after God’s glory dwelt amidst the children of Israel.24 Now if Moses knew when he was on Mount Sinai that the tribe of Levi was chosen, Israel did not know.25
WHEREFORE THEN LIFT YE UP YOURSELVES ABOVE THE ASSEMBLY OF THE LORD? For Aaron to be kohen gadol (high priest) and Moses, who taught Aaron, to be above him.
4. HE FELL UPON HIS FACE. Willingly. Other say, like prophets when they receive a prophecy.26
5. WHO ARE HIS. Which is the chosen tribe. This was Moses’ answer to Dathan and Abiram and to the leaders of the congregation who were first-born.
AND WHO IS HOLY. In his tribe to be kohen gadol.
6. THIS. Test.27
7. YE TAKE TOO MUCH UPON YOU, YE SONS OF LEVI. The meaning of our clause is found in the following words of Moses: Is it but a small thing unto you (v. 9).28
Scripture says, And Moses said unto Korah (v. 8),29 for the first statement30 was addressed to Korah and to all of his company. However, this one was addressed to the Levites.
9. IS IT BUT A SMALL THING UNTO YOU.31 This means is it but a small thing unto you.
BEFORE THE CONGREGATION TO MINISTER UNTO THEM. When they bring their burnt offerings and sacrifices.
10. AND THAT HE HATH BROUGHT THEE NEAR. And when he has brought you and your brothers near, will you seek the priesthood also?32

11. THEREFORE. Therefore you and your whole congregation that art gathered together, rebel against the Lord.33 Its meaning is similar to And the rulers take counsel together, Against the Lord,34 and against His anointed35 (Ps. 2:2). They gathered in order to fight with God. When they strove against the Lord36 (Num. 26:9) is similar.37
Some say that the heh prefixed to no’adim (gathered together) is superfluous.38
AND AS TO AARON, WHAT IS HE. What is his sin, what did he do?

12. WE WILL NOT COME UP. It is possible that the tent of meeting was on a high place in the middle of the camp.39 Scripture therefore says, Get you up from about (v. 24). On the other hand, one who goes to serve God or to the chosen place is said to go up.
13. IS IT A SMALL THING. Is it a small thing that thou hast brought us up out of a land flowing with milk and honey?
Scripture reads, brought us up, because Egypt is south of the Land of Israel, and one who comes from Egypt to the land of Canaan is in truth going up.40
BUT THOU MUST NEEDS MAKE THYSELF ALSO A PRINCE OVER US. You brought us out of Egypt in order to make yourself a prince over us.
MUST NEEDS MAKE THYSELF A PRINCE OVER US. You and your brother also seek additional positions of power over us.41

14. MOREOVER THOU HAST NOT BROUGHT US UNTO A LAND FLOWING WITH MILK AND HONEY. Its meaning is: You brought us out of a good place.42 Now if you had brought us to a place which is as good as the place you took us out of, and if you had given us fields and vineyards such as we had in Egypt,43 and you sought power over us, then we would tolerate it. However, you removed us from a good place, from our fields and vineyards, and you did not bring us to a place as good as the one that you brought us out of. Why then do you seek power?44

WILT THOU PUT OUT THE EYES OF THESE MEN? Its meaning is: you want to put out the eyes of these men. This alludes to those who left Egypt. It is as if Korah said, you want to put out their eyes so that they do not see. But what you did is visible to the eyes. Therefore we will not come up. It is metaphoric to say so and so’s eyes are closed and he therefore cannot see.45
Others say its meaning46 is: Do you want to darken the eyes so that they do not see? In other words, you are fooling us. We will not come up.47
Others say its meaning48 is: even if you put out our eyes we will not go up.

Korah said of these men because he spoke in the manner of the unintelligent, who do not want to say anything negative about themselves.49 However, I believe that of these men alludes to the elders who were with Moses, for Scripture clearly states, and the elders of Israel followed him (v. 25).
15. AND MOSES WAS VERY WROTH. With what Korah said.50

I have already explained that the burnt offering and the meal offering put off the punishment of the wicked. Dathan and Abiram were important men and offered meal offerings before this event. This is the meaning of Respect not their offering and turn to me, for I have not placed a burden upon one ass of their asses.
[I HAVE NOT TAKEN ONE ASS FROM THEM.] I have not placed a burden upon one of their asses.51
NEITHER HAVE I HURT ONE OF THEM. In any way.
16. AND MOSES SAID UNTO KORAH. Moses had already said so.52 Thus this means: when Moses said to Korah be before God, they took their fire-pan.
TOMORROW. This occurred on the day that Moses called to Dathan and Abiram.53 It is possible that he called them earlier. The latter appears correct because Scripture reads, in the morning (v. 5).54
18. WITH MOSES AND AARON. Moses and Aaron with them.55
21. SEPARATE YOURSELVES. For they56 were with them in front of the entrance to the tent of meeting.
22. AND THEY FELL UPON THEIR FACES. To pray.

[O GOD.] The term El (God) indicates that God has the power to destroy them in a moment.57 God is the God of the spirits. This58 explains the term El, for God can destroy them because their spirits are in His hand.
SHALL ONE MAN SIN. The reference59 is to Korah, who assembled all of the congregation against Moses and Aaron.

There are those who say that the meaning of O God, the God of the spirits is: God has the power to investigate human souls, for He is their God. God knows that one man, namely, Korah alone, sinned. He also knows if he [Korah] caused the others to sin.
I believe that Separate yourselves from among this congregation refers to Korah and his congregation.60 A fire went out and devoured and destroyed them in one moment.

24. THE DWELLING OF KORAH. I believe that Korah had a tent for his household and his wealth. This tent was far from the camp of the Levites. The tents of Dathan and Abiram were close to Korah’s tent, for only Levites camped around the tabernacle.61 We learn from this verse that the bearer of the banner62 camped close to the camp of the Levites.63
25. AND THE ELDERS OF ISRAEL FOLLOWED HIM. I believe that the reference is to the chosen seventy elders.64
26. AND TOUCH NOTHING OF THEIRS. For if one comes to save their money they will go down to the pit like them.
IN ALL THEIR SINS. Because of all their sins.65
27. AND THEIR SONS. The reference is to adults.
AND THEIR LITTLE ONES. Male and female minors.
28. TO DO ALL THESE WORKS. To have the Levites take the place of the first-born.

Note, it is a major and grievous act to the one who does not believe that God ordered the first-born to be removed from their position as kohanim and to have this status conferred only upon the family of Moses. All of this was done66 because of the incident of the golden calf, because and offered burnt-offerings, and brought peace-offerings (Ex. 32:6) speaks of the first-born who offered these sacrifices, for they alone were the kohanim. Also, the sons of Levi67 killed those who served the calf.68
There is a question here.69 Its answer is found in the Torah portion which opens with the words va-yelekh mosheh (Deut. 31:1).70
30. BUT IF THE LORD MAKE A NEW THING. Some say that the word beri’ah (a new thing) refers to the bringing forth of something that was never in existence.

I have already explained that the word beri’ah is related to the word u-vara (hack) in and hack them (Ezek. 23:47).71 Many cities72 have been split open, and those who dwelt in them have gone down to the pit.73 The meaning of bara is to cut.74
AND THE GROUND OPEN HER MOUTH. The word u-fatzetah means and opened. Compare, yiftzeh (doth open) in doth open his mouth (Jud. 35:16).

I have already hinted75 that man’s highest soul,76 which comes from the intermediary world,77 employs human language when speaking of things above her,78 for the body is its palace.79 It similarly employs human language when speaking of things below her.80 It does so in order that people understand her.
32. AND THEIR HOUSEHOLDS. This is a general term for their wives, [grown] children, and their little ones.
AND THEIR GOODS.81 Which all of them possessed.82
33. SO THEY…WENT DOWN. Its meaning is: when they went down, the earth closed and they were not seen.83
AND THE EARTH CLOSED UPON THEM. The earth itself.84
AND THEY PERISHED. For their children who were to take their place died.85
34. AT THE CRY OF THEM. Because of their cry.86
35. [AND FIFTY MEN.] The heh of ha-chamishim (the fifty) is to be read as if written twice.87

Some say that Korah was among the ones who were swallowed. They offer as proof, And the earth opened her mouth, and swallowed them up together with Korah (Num. 26:10). Others say that Korah was burned. They offer, with Korah, when that company died; what time the fire devoured (Ibid.) as proof. Our sages say that Korah was burned and swallowed.88

I believe that only the place of Dathan and Abiram split open,89 for no other place is mentioned.90 Korah was standing with his fire-pan with Aaron and the leaders of the congregation who were offering incense.91 With Korah (Num. 26:10) is not connected to and swallowed them up (Ibid.) but rather to when that company died (Ibid.). This is the way the aforementioned verse is to be interpreted.

If someone should argue and say, “Why isn’t Korah mentioned among those who were burned?” the answer is: once Scripture mentions that Korah’s company, which came to his aid, was burned, it is not necessary to mention Korah. For we know this by arguing from a minor to a major premise.92 Pharaoh’s chariots and his host hath He cast into the sea (Ex. 15:4) is similar.93 Moses does not mention in the song94 that Pharaoh drowned. The truth is that Pharaoh drowned, for Scripture explicitly states, But overthrew Pharaoh and his host in the Red Sea (Ps. 136:15). The verse that he fare not as Korah, and as his company (Num. 17:5) is proof that Korah was among those who were burned.95
chapter.ftnote: 1 From serving as priests.
2 See I.E. on Ex. 32:29 (Vol. 1, p. 680).
3 Actually Jacob did so on his death bed. However, Moses enforced Jacob’s decree. Hence Dathan and Abiram blamed Moses.
4 Joshua was descended from Ephraim the son of Joseph.
7 The family of Kohath camped south of the tabernacle. See Num. 3:29. Thus these two disgruntled factions camped next to each other. Their proximity facilitated their rebellion.
8 The blossoming of the staff of Levi. See Num. 17:23.
9 That the rebellion was triggered by the rejection of the first-born, for otherwise why demonstrate that God chose the Levites.
10 The substitution of the Levites for the first-born.
11 To have the kohanim take the place of the first-born and the Levites be subservient to the kohanim.
12 That Moses acted in accordance with God’s command in all other things. “In this thing” is part of I.E.’s interpretation of the Lord hath not sent me. It does not appear in the verse.
13 The word men is not in the Hebrew text. Hence I.E.’s comment.
14 Translated literally.
15 An ass bread is short for an ass carrying bread.
16 Where a word is left out of the text.
17 Rabbi Jonah connects Now Korah…took (v. 1) to and they rose up (v. 2).
18 Mi-pene is the respectful form. Compare, mi-pene sevah takkum (thou that rise up before the hoary head) (Lev. 19:32).
19 This grammarian, unlike I.E., does not identify the princes of the congregation with the first-born.
20 The princes.

21 To convince them to join the revolt. This commentator reads our text as follows: Now Korah…and Dathan and Abiram…and On…and two hundred and fifty took the princes of the congregation, the elect men of the assembly, men of renown.
22 The interpretation that the princes were the heads who stood over Israel when they were numbered.
23 The literal meaning of rav lakhem is, a lot to you.
24 At Mt. Sinai.
25 Thus they suspected that Moses acted on his own.
26 In other words, he fell upon his face means he fell into a prophetic trance. See Num. 24:4.
27 Our verse reads, This do. According to I.E. this is short for this test do.
28 Verses 9 and 10 explain what Moses meant by ye take too much upon you.
29 Verse 5 reads, And he [Moses] spoke unto Korah. Thus And Moses said unto Korah appears redundant. Hence I.E.’s comment.
30 Verse 5.
31 Hebrew, ha-me’at mi-kem literally, is it small from you. Hence I.E.’s comment.
32 That is, and now that he has brought you and your brothers near Him, you also seek the priesthood? In other words, the vav prefixed to va-yakrev is not to be rendered and but rather as when.

33 In other words, al Adonai means against the Lord, and is to be interpreted as rebel against the Lord. The literal meaning of al Adonai is on the Lord. Thus the literal meaning of our verse is: Therefore you and your whole congregation that are gathered together on the Lord (al ha-Adonai). Hence, I.E.’s comment.
34 Hebrew, al Adonai (literally on the Lord). However, its meaning is against the Lord.
35 Hebrew, ve-al meshicho (literally, and on His anointed). However, its meaning is, and against His anointed.
36 Hebrew, al Adonai.
37 Here too al has the meaning of against.

38 In other words, the word ha-no’adim (that art gathered together) is to be read no’adim (gathered together). If the heh is not superfluous, then our verse is to be interpreted, Therefore thou and all thy company that are gathered together (ha-no’adim) against the Lord. If the heh is superfluous, then our verse reads: Therefore thou and all thy company are gathered (no’adim) together against the Lord.
39 In other words, We will not come up is to be taken literally.
40 Here, brought us up is to be taken literally.

41 Our clause reads, ki tistarer alenu gam histarer (but thou must needs make thyself also a prince over us). The latter literally reads: That you want to rule over us, also to rule. I.E. interprets this as follows: that you want to rule over us, and you also want additional rulership.
42 Verse 13.
43 According to I.E. our verse implies that Israel had fields and vineyards in Egypt.
44 Verse 13.
45 Even when the subject’s eyes are open. Similarly, wilt Thou put out the eyes of these men is not to be taken literally.
46 The meaning of Wilt thou put out the eyes of these men?

47 Prima facie, this interpretation seems to be identical to the one above. Hence Filwarg suggests that this interpretation is that We will not go up means we will not go up to the Land of Israel. In other words, Korah said you are fooling us, for you have no intention of bringing us to the Land of Israel.
48 The meaning of Wilt thou put out the eyes of these men?
49 In other words, of these men refers to Korah himself. According to this interpretation the meaning of wilt thou put out the eyes of these men is, will you put out my eyes?

50 Our verse reads, va-yichar le-mosheh me’od (and Moses was very wroth). The latter literally reads, and to Moses it was wroth very much. I.E. suggest that this be interpreted, va-yichar le-mosheh zeh ha-dibbur me’od (and Moses was very wroth at this statement).
51 I.E. renders nasati (taken) as laden.
52 In verses 6 and 7, Moses had already told them to take censers.
53 See verse 12.
54 Verse 5 tells us that Korah and his men were to bring the fire-pans as soon as morning came. This being the case, there would be very little time for Dathan and Abiram to be called.
55 Our clause literally reads, and stood at the door of the tent of meeting and Moses and Aaron.
56 Moses and Aaron.
57 The meaning of El is mighty. See I.E. on Ex. 3:15.
58 The phrase the God of the spirits.
59 One man.
60 In other words, the congregation spoken of is Korah’s congregation, not the congregation of Israel.
61 Hence the need for the interpretation that Korah had a tent outside the camp of the Levites.
62 The tribe that carried the banner. For the banners, see Num. 2:1-34.

63 Korah’s tent was close to the tent of Dathan and Abiram. The Levites camped around the southern, western, and northern sides of the tabernacle (Num. 3:14-38). The Israelites camped around the four sides of the tabernacle (Num. 2:2). The family of Kohath camped on the south side (Num. 3:29). So did the tribe of Reuben (Num. 2:10). Now Korah’s tent was close to the tent of Dathan and Abiram, who came from the tribe of Reuben, because the tribe of Reuben bore the banner of the tribes that camped on the south and were thus close to the Levites.
64 See Num. 11:16.
65 In other words, the bet before the word be-khol (in all) is to be rendered because. Thus be-khol chatotam (in all their sins) means because of all their sins.
66 The first-born were removed and the Levites substituted in their place.
67 Alone.
68 The first-born did not join Moses in extirpating the worshippers of the calf. Thus the first-born showed themselves unfit to be kohanim.

69 It isn’t clear what the question is. I believe it to be the issue of God changing His mind. According to medieval Jewish philosophy, God and His mind are one. Thus God’s mind is immutable. This being the case, how could He change His mind regarding the fitness of the first-born to serve as priests?

70 I.E. there explains that God does not change. It is people who do. See I.E. on Deut. 31:16. Here I.E. is probably hinting that it wasn’t God who changed His mind but rather the first-born who changed by becoming unfit to serve as kohanim.
71 See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, pp. 22,23).
72 Or countries. The text reads medinot.
73 The reference is apparently to earthquakes.

74 Thus according to I.E., ve-im beri’ah yivra Adonai (But if the Lord make a new thing) should be interpreted, but if God shall certainly split. An alternative interpretation of I.E. is: The meaning of bara is to decree. According to this interpretation I.E. renders ve-im beri’ah yivra Adonai (but if the Lord make a new thing) as, but if God shall decree.
75 See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 (Vol. 1, p. 45).

76 The rational soul. See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, p. 25). I.E. believes that man has three souls, a vegetable, an animal and a rational soul. I.E. refers to the soul as “her” for the Hebrew word for soul is neshamah, which is a feminine noun.
77 For the three worlds, see I.E. on Ex. 3:15 (Vol. 2, pp. 86-90).
78 Such as when speaking of God.
79 Here on earth. Hence it must employ corporeal metaphors. It is philosophically significant that I.E. refers to the body as a palace for the soul.
80 Such as the earth. Hence Scripture reads, and the ground open her mouth.
81 Literally, the goods.
82 In other words, the goods is short for all the goods which they possessed.
83 Prima facie, this verse repeats verse 32. Hence I.E.’s comment.

84 The verb va-tekhas (and closed upon then) literally means and covered. Our clause thus reads, and the earth covered them. Hence va-yekhas may be taken as transitive. In this case, it means that the earth covered them with something. Hence I.E. points out that va-yekhas is intransitive.
85 One who dies without descendants perishes from the face of the earth.
86 In other words, the lamed prefixed to kolam (their voice) means because of. The lamed usually means to.

87 It is also to be placed in front of the word u-matayim (and…fifty men). Our text, which reads ha-chamishim u-matayim, should be read as if written, ha-chamishim ve-ha-matayim (and…the two hundred and fifty men). The latter is the correct grammatical construction. Hence I.E.’s comment.
89 Thus it was only Dathan and Abiram and their families who were swallowed by the ground.
90 Scripture does not mention that any other place split open.
91 And were consumed by fire.
92 If Korah’s followers were burned, then Korah certainly was.
93 In that by employing a similar argument, we learn from this verse that Pharaoh died.
94 The song of Moses wherein Pharaoh’s chariots and his host hath He cast into the sea is stated.
95 For the term company refers to the 250 men who were consumed by fire.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 17
chapter.p: 2. AND SCATTER THOU THE FIRE YONDER. From the altar.
FOR THEY ARE BECOME HOLY. The fire-pans are holy because they [Korah and his company] offered them before the Lord.
3. EVEN THE FIRE-PANS OF THESE MEN WHO HAVE SINNED. This explains the fire-pans (v. 2).1
AND LET THEM BE MADE.2 The reference is to the workers.3
BEATEN PLATES. Compare, And they did beat (ve-yerakke’u) the gold into thin plates (Ex. 39:3).4
[FOR THEY ARE BECOME HOLY.] Because they were offered before the Lord explains for they are become holy.5
THAT THEY MAY BE A SIGN. A memorial and a mark.6
4. AND THEY BEAT THEM OUT. The beaters beat them out.7
5. AS THE LORD SPOKE UNTO HIM BY THE HAND OF MOSES. Unto him (lo) refers to Aaron. Others say that unto him refers to Korah.8 However, I believe the latter to be farfetched.
6. ON THE MORROW. Of this day, for mochorat (morrow) is always connected to the previous day.9

YE HAVE KILLED. Its meaning is, what proof is this10 that the tribe of Levi is the chosen one, and that Aaron was chosen to be kohen gadol?11 It is possible that those who offered the fire-pans were burned because of your prayer12 or through your knowledge of the sciences.13
7. WHEN THE CONGREGATION WAS ASSEMBLED.14 Whenever the word kehillah (assembly)15 is followed by the word al (on),16 it refers to an assembly for the sake of quarreling.
8. AND MOSES AND AARON CAME. Because they saw that God’s glory appeared.
10. GET YOU UP. For they sat in the tabernacle, which was on the high ground in the camp of the Levites, as I explained in my comments on Get you up (Num. 16:24).17
AND THEY FELL UPON THEIR FACES. To pray.
11. TAKE THY FIRE-PAN. The reference is to a specific fire-pan.18
AND LAY INCENSE THEREON. Scripture does not say, and lay “the” incense on.19 The intelligent will understand.20

AND CARRY. The word holekh (and carry) is an imperative.21 It is similar to the word hoshev (make to dwell)22 in make thy father…to dwell (Gen. 47:6). Holekh comes from the same root as helikhi (take away) (Ex. 2:9).23 It means bring,24 the idea being it25 should go with you.

15. [AND AARON RETURNED.] And Aaron returned is connected to the section that follows,26 even though it is separated.27 I have already given you many such examples.28 When Aaron returned and the plague was stayed, God spoke.29
17. RODS. Some say that the rod of Levi is not God’s rod, for God’s rod was already known.30 Why then write Aaron’s name on it.31
Others say that the rod32 was like the other rods. There was no difference between them.33 This interpretation appears correct to me.
[ONE FOR EACH FATHER’S HOUSE.] Each father’s house means each tribe. Reuben and Simeon are examples.34
18. [FOR THERE SHALL BE ONE ROD.] Scripture tells us that there shall be one rod for the tribe of Levi because this tribe was divided into kohanim and Levites.35
19. WHERE I MEET WITH YOU. Permanently.36

20. I WILL MAKE TO CEASE. The word ve-hashikkoti (I will make to cease) comes from a double root.37 It is similar to the word ve-hatimmoti38 (and I will consume) in and I will consume thy filthiness from out of thee (Ezek. 22:15).
