It is related to the word shakhakhah (assuaged) in then was the king’s wrath assuaged (Esth. 7:10).
Ve-hashikkoti (I will make to cease) means I [God] will find rest.39 Scripture employs human language.40
The rod of Levi was among the twelve. Behold, the tribe of Joseph was represented by one rod.41
23. FOR THE HOUSE OF LEVI. The word matteh (rod of) is to be read as if written twice. Our verse42 is to be read as if written: the rod of Aaron, the rod of the house of Levi.
AND BORE RIPE ALMONDS. The word va-yigmol (and bore ripe) is related to the word va-yigammal (and was weaned) in And the child grew, and was weaned (Gen. 21:8).
Many say that the rod43 came from an almond tree because the rod bore almonds. However, this is not proof.
The word shekedim (almonds) has midrashically been related to the word shoked (watch) in I watch over My word to perform it (Jer. 1:12).44
24. AND THEY LOOKED. At the handwriting of each one.

27. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL SPOKE UNTO MOSES, SAYING. It is enough for us that we perished and were undone.45 Now, in addition, everyone that comes near the tabernacle will die like those who were burnt. O that we should cease dying.46 God then spoke to Aaron, who was the leader of the tribe of Levi, and cautioned him that the Levites not cause the Israelites to stumble.47
The meaning of unto Aaron (Num. 18:1) is that God communicated with Aaron through Moses. On the other hand, the clause may be taken at face value,48 because Aaron too was a prophet.
Also, this section49 is proof that the rebellion took place in the desert of Sinai when the tabernacle was erected and the Levites were chosen, and the first-born were disqualified.50
chapter.ftnote: 1 The fire-pans in verse 2 refers to the fire-pans of these men who have sinned.
2 Hebrew, ve-asu otam (literally, and they shall make them).
3 In other words, and they shall make them means and the workers shall make them.
4 In other words, the word reku’e (beaten) in our verse is similar in meaning to va-yerakke’u (and they did beat).

5 Our verse literally reads, because they were offered before the Lord and they are become holy. I.E. believes this should be interpreted as if written, for they are become holy because they were offered before the Lord.
6 See Rashi, “For a memorial, that people will always say: These plates were from those who disputed the priesthood and were burnt.”
7 The subject is omitted. Hence I.E.’s comment. See I.E. on verse 3.
8 See San. 110a.
9 In other words, it always refers to the next morrow. I.E. comments thus, for the word machar (morrow) can refer to a morrow in the far future.
10 The fact that the 250 men who offered the incense were burned.
11 High priest.
12 You prayed that they be burned.
13 You may have arranged for some combustible material to be mixed with the incense.
14 Hebrew, be-hikkahel.
15 That is, a word from the root kof, heh, lamed.

16 As it does in our verse, which reads, be-hikkahel ha-edah al mosheh ve-al aaron (when the congregation was assembled against Moses and against Aaron). The word al usually means on, not against. Hence I.E.’s comment.
17 I.E. apparently renders herommu (Get you up) as, remove yourself from the high place. He cites Num. 16:24, but he actually made his comments on 16:12.

18 Hence the word machtah (fire-pan) has the definite article ha prefixed to it. The literal meaning of kach et ha-machtah is, take the fire-pan. According to I.E. the fire-pan in our verse means the specific fire-pan used to offer incense (Krinsky).
19 “The” incense would refer to the incense usually burned in the tabernacle. Since the definite article is not prefaced to ketroret (incense), it refers to another incense.

20 The difference between the two types of incense. Some of the commentators on I.E. believe that he was of the opinion that the incense used by Moses to stop the plague had the power to clean the air of pollutants that caused the plague (Krinsky, Filwarg).
21 In the hifil. Holekh looks like a kal participle. In this case the word would mean goes or walks. However, the context negates such a rendering. Hence I.E.’s comment.
22 A hifil imperative.
23 Its root is yod, lamed, kaf.
24 Ve-holekh meherah el ha-edah means: and bring (and carry) the fire-pan quickly to the congregation.
25 The incense-bearing fire-pan.
26 Verse 15 is connected to verse 16.
27 According to the masorah, verse 16 starts a new section.
28 Where verses that are in different section are connected. See I.E. on Gen. 1:9.
29 This is the meaning of verses 15 and 16.
30 According to this view the rod of the Lord (the rod employed by Moses to perform miracles in Egypt) was made of different material from that of the other rods.
31 If the rod of the tribe of Levi was God’s rod.
32 God’s rod.

33 According to this view the rod of God was the rod of the tribe of Levi. In this opinion God’s rod was made of the same material as all the other rods. Hence it was necessary to write Aaron’s name on it (Filwarg).
34 Of tribes and fathers’ houses.
35 Hence one might think that each of these divisions has a separate rod.
36 Scripture uses the future form (ivva’ed).
37 Its root is shin, kaf, kaf.
38 From the root tav, mem, mem. Both words are hifils.
39 According to I.E. our clause reads: I will find rest from the murmuring of the children of Israel.
40 When a person is greatly bothered he says, I seek rest from those who trouble me.
41 The tribe of Joseph was divided into Manasseh and Ephraim. These are usually counted as two separate tribes. However, here they are not. Otherwise there would have been thirteen rods.
42 Which literally reads, the rod of Aaron of the house of Levi.
43 Of the tribe of Levi.
44 God (watches) is quick to punish those who oppose the priesthood. See Rashi.
45 I.E.’s paraphrase of verse 27.
46 I.E.’s paraphrase of verse 28.
47 I.E.’s paraphrase of Num. 18:1.
48 That God spoke directly to Aaron.
49 In addition to Num. 16. See I.E. on Num. 16:1.
50 For the section tells us that the Israelites were convinced that God chose the tribe of Levi only after their rod miraculously produced almonds.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 18
chapter.p: 1. THE INIQUITY OF THE SANCTUARY. Which is on the inside of the veil.1 Its meaning is, if you do not guard the sanctuary the sin is upon you.
[AND THY FATHERS’ HOUSE.] For they carried the sanctuary.2
THE INIQUITY OF YOUR PRIESTHOOD. If you do not keep the laws of the priesthood, the sin is upon you.

2. THE TRIBE OF THY FATHER. The reference is to Levi.3 Our sages say that the tribe of thy father is to be taken at face value.4 However, I believe that it is to be explained in keeping with my earlier interpretation. Our verse is to be read as if written, the tribe of Levi which is the tribe of your father.5

THAT THEY MAY BE JOINED. The meaning of ve-yillavu is similar to ve-nispechu (and they shall join) (Is. 14:1). So too the word yillaveh (be joined) in Now this time will my husband be joined (Gen. 29:34). Look, the Levites are joined by their names.6
THOU AND THY SONS WITH THEE. You and your sons, and not the Levites, shall abide before the tent of meeting.
3. NEITHER THEY, NOR YE.7 It is the way of Scripture to speak in this manner.8 Compare, Rule thou over us, also you, also thy son9 (Jud. 8:22). That means this one is like this one.10
[4. AND THEY SHALL BE JOINED UNTO THEE.] So that you do not need the services of a stranger, namely, an Israelite.

7. AS A SERVICE OF GIFT. And someone who is a common man in regard to the priesthood even if he be a Levite [shall be put to death]. The burnt offering of Samuel, who was a Levi, is no argument11 for it was a temporary ruling, as was the case of Gideon.12
8. FOR A CONSECRATED PORTION.13 I have already explained this.14
9. OF THE MOST HOLY THINGS. For there are offerings that have a lesser degree of sacredness.15
RESERVED FROM THE FIRE.16 Of all that they sanctify,17 for isheh (fire-offering)18 and esh (fire) mean the same,19 the heh of isheh being superfluous.
AND EVERY MEAL-OFFERING OF THEIRS. After they sanctify the memorial part thereof.20
[AND EVERY SIN-OFFERING OF THEIRS, AND EVERY GUILT-OFFERING OF THEIRS.] After they offer the designated organs of the sin offering and the guilt offering.21
WHICH THEY MAY RENDER22 UNTO ME. The reference is to a trespass.23
Now the meal offering, the sin offering, and the guilt offering are holier than the peace offerings.24

10. IN A MOST HOLY PLACE SHALT THOU EAT THEREOF. Even in a most holy place, namely, in the tent of meeting shalt thou eat thereof. The tent of meeting is called a most holy place in contrast to the courtyard of the tabernacle.25

11. THEIR GIFT. A tav is missing in the word mattanam (their gift).26 Mattanam is similar to the word pinnah (corner), which has the meaning of pinnatah (her corner) in Passing27 through the street near her corner (Prov. 7:8).28 On the other hand, we may be dealing with two forms.29

12. ALL THE BEST OF THE OIL. Chelev (the best) means the most precious, the best. The reference is to the cream of the oil,30 for the word yitzhar (oil) means light.31 Its root is tzadi, heh, resh.32 The reference is to the fat of the olive oil.
13. THE FIRST-RIPE FRUITS OF ALL THAT IS IN THEIR LAND.33 The first of all the fruits of the ground.

[EVERY ONE THAT IS CLEAN IN THY HOUSE MAY EAT THEREOF.] This verse warns that only the clean in your house may eat of fat things34 and of the breast of waving35 and the thigh of heaving36 and also everything dedicated37 by an Israelite. The Israelite shall not eat of the latter, for it belongs to God. You [the kohen] may eat of it.
15. SHALT THOU SURELY REDEEM. You shall accept the redemption money of the first-born. You shall similarly accept the redemption of the first-born of the unclean beast.38
16. AND THEIR REDEMPTION-MONEY. This only refers to the first-born of humans.39
17. THOU SHALT NOT REDEEM. For they are holy. You shall not accept their redemption money.

Many say that the word redeem40 refers to the Israelites. However,41 the reverse is true for the word tokhelunu (thou shalt eat it) (Deut. 15:20), in which the prefix thou refers to the kohen, for Thou shalt eat it refers to the one who is obligated to eat it.

19. COVENANT OF SALT. A “cut covenant.”42 The word melach (salt) is related to the word melechah (salt)43 in A fruitful land turned into salt (Ps. 107:34). A salted place is said to be cut off, for nothing grows there. Compare, brimstone, and salt44 (Deut. 29:22).
21. IN RETURN. The word chelef means in return.
22. AND HENCEFORTH…SHALL NOT COME NIGH. This45 was written because of Korah’s assembly.
23. BUT THE LEVITES ALONE SHALL DO THE SERVICE.46 The word hu means himself. Others say that hu is the object.47 However, this is incorrect, for the service of the tent of meeting is the object.48
AND THEY SHALL BEAR THEIR INIQUITY. If they do not keep the charge. Now, the tithe is their inheritance. I therefore stated: [and among the children of Israel they shall have no inheritance].
25. AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO MOSES, SAYING. To Moses, not to Aaron, for Scripture goes on to say that the Levites are to give a tithe to Aaron from the tithe [they received].49
27. AND AS THE FULNESS. I have already explained the meaning of the word mele’ah (fullness).50
29. OF ALL THE BEST THEREOF.51 The meaning of mi-kol chelbo is, of all the best thereof. And ye shall eat the fat (chelev) of the land (Gen. 45:18) is similar.52
EVEN THE HALLOWED PART THEREOF. For the tenth part thereof is the holy part.53

[30. WHEN YE SET APART THE BEST THEREOF.] This has already been mentioned by Scripture.54 It is repeated in order to connect it to that which follows. Its meaning is, you55 are prohibited to eat of it56 until you set apart the best thereof,57 and afterwards it58 shall be counted [as the grain of the threshing floor] and you59 may eat it in every clean place.60

32. AND YE SHALL BEAR NO SIN BY REASON OF IT. This means when you set apart the best of it61 you shall bear no sin through it.62 Furthermore, when you give the hallowed part thereof,63 the sacred donations of the children of Israel will be preserved.64 However, if you do not offer to tithe, then you will bear a sin, for you will have trespassed the commandment and profaned the holy things of the children of Israel because you ate its holy part.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Which hung in front of the Holy of Holies. See Ex. 26:31-36 and Lev. 16:1-3.
2 The children of Kohath carried the tabernacle (Num. 10:21). Kohath was the father of Amram, the father of Aaron.
3 In other words, the tribe of Levi, the tribe of thy father is to be understood as the tribe of Levi, the tribe of your patriarch Levi.
4 The reference being to Amram.
5 Matteh levi shevet avikha is to be read as if written, matteh levi she-hu shevet avikha.
6 Hebrew, bi-shemam. Their name indicates that they have joined Aaron. Some editions read, ke-shemam. In this case I.E. reads: The Levites are joined [to Aaron] as their names [indicate].
7 Hebrew, gam hem, gam attem (literally, also they, also you).
8 To say also…also… (gam… gam…).
9 Translated literally.
10 In other words, the same law applies to them and to you.
11 That a person who is not a kohen may offer a burnt offering, for Samuel offered a burnt offering. See I Sam. 7:9.
12 Gideon, who was from the tribe of Manasseh, was commanded by God’s angel to personally offer a burnt offering. See Jud. 6:26.
13 Hebrew, le-moshchah.
14 According to one of I.E.’s interpretations in Lev. 7:35, the word le-moshchah means for greatness.
15 Such as peace offerings.
16 Hebrew, esh.
17 That they offer on the altar.
18 A common term for a sacrifice.
19 Thus reserved from the fire (esh) means reserved from the fire offerings.
20 Hebrew, azkarah. The latter refers to the portion of the meal offering offered on the altar. See Lev. 2:2.
21 On the altar.
22 Hebrew, yashivu (literally, which they return).
23 Money paid in restitution for the unauthorized use of sacred property (me’ilah). See Lev. 5:15.
24 Thus they, not the peace offerings (shelamim), are mentioned in our verse, which speaks of the more holy sacrifices.
25 However, it is not considered a most holy place in contrast to the Holy of Holies. Thus the sacrifices listed in our verse cannot be eaten in the Holy of Holies.
26 The usual Hebrew word for gift is mattanah. Thus the word for their gift should be mattanatam rather than mattanam.
27 Reading over. Some texts have holekhat (going). However, Prov. 7:8 reads over.
28 In other words, pinnah is analogous to mattanam in that it is a feminine noun, but it is connected to the pronominal suffix as if it were masculine.
29 For the word gift (mattan and mattnah). Mattanam is the word mattan plus the pronominal suffix.
30 The top of the oil.
31 Hebrew, tzahor. Others read nahor. Both mean light.
32 The same root as the one for light.
33 The Hebrew literally reads: The first of all that is in their land. Hence I.E.’s comment.
34 Mentioned in verse 12.
35 See Lev. 7:34.
36 Ibid.
37 Anything set aside for God.
38 See Ex. 13:13 And every firstling of an ass thou shalt redeem with a lamb.
39 See previous verse.
40 That is, the statement thou shalt not redeem refers to the Israelite. He shall not buy back the animal from the kohen. See Filwarg and Weiser.
41 This is either a continuation of the previous opinion or I.E.’s comment upon it.
42 The Biblical term for making a covenant is, to cut a covenant. Hence I.E.’s note that a salt covenant is a variant of a cut covenant.
43 In that both words have the meaning of cut.
44 The verse reads: brimstone, and salt, and a burning, that it is not sown, nor beareth, nor any grass groweth.
45 The word henceforth.
46 Our clause literally reads, But the Levites he (hu) shall do the service of the tent of meeting. Hence the interpretations which follow.

47 This interpretation renders hu as it. It maintains that But the Levites he (hu) shall do the service of the tent of meeting should be interpreted: But the Levites shall do the service of it (hu), namely, the tent of meeting (Weiser). Filwarg claims that hu refers to the kohen. In this case, But the Levites he (hu) shall do the service of the tent of meeting should be interpreted: But the Levites shall do the service of him (the kohen) and of the tent of meeting.
48 Of ve-avad (shall do the service).
49 It would be out of place for Aaron to issue such a command.
50 See I.E. on Ex. 22:25, where he explains mele’ah as referring to wine.
51 Literally, of all the fat thereof (chelbo). Hence I.E.’s explanation.
52 Its meaning is, And you shall eat of the best of the land.
53 Thus the hallowed part thereof refers to its tithe.
54 In the previous verse.
55 The Levites.
56 From the tithe given to you.
57 A tenth thereof.
58 The remainder.
59 The Levites.
60 I.E. interprets every place as in every clean place. However, according to the halakha the Levite may eat the remaining tithe even in a cemetery. See Rashi.
61 A tenth of the tithe.
62 By not tithing (Rashi).
63 To the kohen.
64 The tithes which the children of Israel gave to the Levites will not be desecrated.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 19
chapter.p: 2. THIS IS THE STATUTE. This chapter was also1 stated at Sinai. It was given when God commanded that they put out of the camp…whosoever is unclean by the dead (Num. 5:2). There were also people who were unclean by coming into contact with a dead body when Passover2 arrived (Num. 9:6). This chapter is placed here3 because it relates to the kohen.4
A RED HEIFER, FAULTLESS. The heifer is not to be small.5

The Gaon6 says that the water of sprinkling (v. 13)7 is similar to honey, which is injurious to the one who has red bile8 but stimulates the one who has phlegm.9 However, there is no need for this interpretation.

3. AND SHE SHALL BE BROUGHT FORTH. Someone shall bring her forth.10 Or it means he shall have her brought forth by his command.11 The same applies to ve-shachat (and she shall be slain),12 for Eleazar did not slaughter the heifer. The word le-fanav (before his face) proves the latter.13

5. AND THE HEIFER SHALL BE BURNT IN HIS SIGHT. Ve-saraf et ha-parah (and the heifer shall be burnt)14 is to be rendered, and someone shall burn the heifer. The term le’enav (in his sight)15 proves the latter interpretation.
6. CEDAR-WOOD. As in the case of a leper.16 I have hinted there at some secret.17
7. THEN THE PRIEST SHALL WASH HIS CLOTHES. The kohen who burns it.18

AND THE PRIEST SHALL BE UNCLEAN. The meaning of ve-tame ha-kohen (and the priest shall be unclean) is, and the kohen has already been unclean,19 or, as some say, the kohen shall be unclean.20 Until the even refers to the eating of sacred food.
9. A MAN THAT IS CLEAN. The reference is not to the kohen who burns the cow.21
A WATER OF SPRINKLING. The meaning of niddah (sprinkling) is distance.22 Compare, me-naddekhem23 (that hate you) (Is. 66:5).
10. AND BE UNCLEAN UNTIL THE EVEN. Once Scripture states that the gatherer of the ashes shall wash his clothes there is no need to mention that he shall wash in water.24
AND UNTO THE STRANGER THAT SOJOURNETH AMONG THEM. For the Land of Israel is holy because God’s glory is there.25
11. EVEN ANY MAN’S DEAD BODY. Be it the body of a Jew or a non-Jew.
MAN’S…BODY. Not the body of an animal.

SHALL BE UNCLEAN. The meaning of ve-tame is, shall be unclean. It is a future form, for the vav changes the verb26 from a perfect to an imperfect. However, I believe that ve-tame is in the past tense.27

12. THE SAME SHALL PURIFY HIMSELF THEREWITH. The meaning of hu yitchate vo (the same shall purify himself therewith) is, he shall remove his sin therewith.28 On the other hand, the word yitchate (shall purify himself) is similar to the word techatteni (purge me) in Purge me with hyssop, and I shall be clean (Ps. 51:9).29
Those who are acquainted with the secret of numbers know that the number three is like the number seven.30

13. BECAUSE THE WATER OF SPRINKLING. Some say that that me niddah (the water of sprinkling) has the same meaning as me niddah (water of sprinkling) in it shall be purified with the water of sprinkling (Num. 31:23).31
WAS NOT DASHED. The word zorak (dashed) refers to the water.32
IS YET. The word od (is yet) means continuously.33 Compare, od (while) in While the earth remaineth (Gen. 8:22).
14. IN A TENT. A house has the same law as a tent. Scripture mentions a tent because Israel then lived in tents. That killeth an ox, or lamb, or goat, in the camp (Lev. 17:3) is similar.34
AND EVERY THING THAT IS IN THE TENT. Garments.35
15. COVERING CLOSE-BOUND. Two coverings.36
16. OR A GRAVE. Of a human being.
17. AND FOR THE UNCLEAN THEY SHALL TAKE. See, Scripture explains how one who comes into contact with the dead shall purge himself.37
18. A CLEAN PERSON. The reference is most probably to a kohen.38

20. BUT THE MAN THAT SHALL BE UNCLEAN. Scripture has already mentioned, Whosoever toucheth the dead…that soul shall be cut off from Israel (v. 13). It now warns the one who touches a bone or a grave [not to defile the sanctuary].
21. SHALL BE UNCLEAN UNTIL EVEN. And shall not become clean until he washes.
22. AND WHATSOEVER THE UNCLEAN PERSON TOUCHETH SHALL BE UNCLEAN. The reference is to one who has become unclean by touching a dead body, a bone, or a grave.
SHALL BE UNCLEAN UNTIL EVEN. And washes.39
chapter.ftnote: 1 Like the incident of Korah. See I.E. on Num 16:1.
2 Celebrated by Israel in the second year after the Exodus.
3 Following the laws dealing with the tithes.
4 The kohen played a major role in the ritual of the red heifer.
5 For the Bible speaks of a parah (cow), not of an eglah (heifer).
6 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
7 Which cleansed the unclean but made the clean unclean.
8 In medieval medicine red bile was believed to cause a volatile nature. See I.E. on Ex. 23:25 (Vol. 2, p. 516).
9 An excess of phlegm. This causes a phlegmatic nature.
10 The literal meaning of ve-hotzi otah is: and he shall bring her forth. However, since Eleazar did not actually slaughter the cow, I.E. believes that he did not bring it out. Hence his comment.
11 In other words, it means he shall command that it be brought out.
12 Which literally means: and he shall slaughter it.
13 If Eleazar did the slaughtering, then what point would there be for Scripture to say “and he [Eleazar] shall slaughter it before his [Eleazar’s] face.”
14 The literal meaning of ve-saraf et ha-parah is: and he shall burn the cow.
15 Eleazar’s sight.
16 Cedar wood was used in cleansing a leper (Lev. 14:4).
17 I.E. points out that there is a connection between leprosy and death. Hence cedar is employed in cleansing someone who has been contaminated by contract with a leper or a dead body.
18 Prima facie, the reference is to the cow. However, in view of the fact that the latter is stated in the next verse, some say that the reference is to the cedar. See Filwarg and Krinsky.

19 The kohen has been made unclean by performing the ritual. According to this interpretation the vav prefixed to ve-tame means “and.” Hence the meaning of ve-tame ha-kohen is: and the kohen was unclean.
20 In this case ve-tame is a future form meaning: and he shall be unclean. The vav is a conversive vav.

21 Another kohen does this (Krinsky). According to the Sifre on this verse, any clean person, even if not a kohen, may gather the ashes of the red cow. However, I.E. seems to believe that this task was assigned to a kohen.
22 The person who is unclean is distanced from the sanctuary. Thus me-niddah (water of sprinkling) means the water of the distant, i.e., the water to be used to purify the distant.
23 Me-naddekhem comes from the same root as niddah. When one hates another person, he keeps his distance from him.
24 For Scripture earlier linked the two. See verse 7.
25 Hence even a stranger (a non-Jew) must abide by this rule.
26 Tame, a third person perfect.

27 Its vav being conjunctive. Thus the meaning of ve-tame is: and he was unclean. The import of our verse thus is: and after being unclean for seven days he shall purify himself. See I.E. on verse 7 and the notes thereto.
28 That is, by undergoing this ritual he will remove the potentiality of entering the sanctuary in a state of impurity and thus sinning. The word chet means sin. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
29 In other words, yitchatta means purify.

30 The number seven has mystical significance in that seven days make up a lunar quarter. The number three is close to half of the number 7. See I.E. on Gen. 34:25 and the notes thereto (Vol. 1, p. 330).

31 In other words, both refer to water mixed with the ashes of the red heifer. Num. 31:23 deals with the purification of utensils captured from non-Jews. I.E. prefaces these remarks with “some say” because, according to the rabbis, Num. 31:23 refers to water in which a menstruant immerses herself.
32 Even though zorak is singular and me (water of) is plural.
33 He is continuously unclean until sprinkled.
34 The law laid down in Lev. 17:3 applies equally to a town. Scripture speaks of a camp because Israel then lived in tents in a camp.
35 For the next verse deals with vessels.

36 Scripture reads, tzamid, petil (close bound). According to I.E. each one of these terms refers to a covering. The tzamid goes over the opening, while the petil goes round about the above covering and the rim of the utensil (Krinsky). Others claim that I.E. believes that the cover is made of two parts. See Krinsky, Filwarg, and Weiser.
37 Earlier, in verse 12, Scripture had said, the same shall purify himself therewith. However, it did not describe the procedure. Now it does.
38 For kohanim are acquainted with the laws of purification.
39 Verse 7.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 20
chapter.p: 1. IN THE FIRST MONTH. In the fortieth year.1 Look, the Torah does not contain any act or prophecy except in the first and the fortieth year.2

[AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL, EVEN THE WHOLE CONGREGATION, CAME.] Scripture states this because the generation that left Egypt died in the wilderness and they who were entering Canaan came to the desert of Zin.3
AND THE PEOPLE ABODE IN KADESH. For they dwelt there for many days.4 The latter is clearly stated in Scripture.5

2. AND THERE WAS NO WATER FOR THE CONGREGATION. Scripture tells of two incidents.6 One, the death of Miriam. Two, the death of Aaron and Moses and their failure to enter the land.7 It begins by telling the cause of the latter.
3. AND THE PEOPLE STROVE. Va-yarev (strove) is a hifil.
WHEN OUR BRETHREN PERISHED. Bi-geva (when…perished) is an infinitive. It is similar to ki-shekav (when…shall sleep) in when my lord the king shall sleep with his fathers (I Kings 1:21).
OUR BRETHREN. The generation that died in the desert. They were servants of the Lord.8

4. AND WHY HAVE YE BROUGHT. This was addressed to Moses and Aaron, for Scripture goes on to say, and they assembled themselves together against Moses and against Aaron (v. 2). Scripture reads, And the people strove with Moses, (v. 3) because their quarrel with Moses was more intense.9
5. HAVE YE MADE US TO COME UP. He’elitunu (have ye made us to come up) is irregular.10
6. AND MOSES AND AARON WENT11 FROM THE PRESENCE OF THE ASSEMBLY. Like those who flee.12
AND FELL UPON THEIR FACES. To pray. Other interpret, to prophetically inquire of God.

8. TAKE THE ROD. Many interpretations are offered for this incident.13 There is an individual opinion that Moses sinned because he said to Israel, who are the children of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob: Hear now, ye rebels (v. 10). However, if this were the case why did he again say,14 ye have been rebellious against the Lord (Deut. 9:7).

Others say that the word ve-dibbartem (and speak ye) has the meaning, and ye shall strike. It is similar to the word va-tedabber (and destroyed) in and destroyed all the seed royal (II Chron. 22:10). However, this is incorrect, for va-tedabber is related to the word dever (destruction) or to the word yadber (he subdueth) in He subdueth peoples under us (Ps. 47:4). Va-tedabber15 thus means, and destroyed. Indeed, it so reads in the other book.16 The meaning of ve-dibbartem el ha-sela (and speak ye unto the rock) thus is,17 and ye shall destroy the rock.18 Furthermore, if this is the meaning of the word,19 why was Moses punished? The above commentaries answer, because he hit the rock twice. However, if this is the case why was Aaron punished?20

Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen the Spaniard, of blessed memory, says that some signs21 are performed by word of mouth, others by action and speech, as in the case of the salt22 which Elisha cast into the water.23 God commanded Moses to take the staff and strike the rock as he did in the case of the rock [at Horeb].24 He added the word ve-dibbartem (and speak ye)25 so that the water would flow via the speech and the blow. Because Israel angered him, Moses said, are we to bring you forth water from the rock? What Moses meant26 was, we do not have the power to bring water out of the rock. We can only do so by the power of God. Now Moses did not make himself clear. People thought what he said was that God cannot bring water out of the rock. This is the meaning of because ye sanctified Me not in the midst of the children of Israel (Deut. 32:51). Rabbi Moses offered proof from the words of the poet who said, For they embittered his spirit, And he spoke rashly with his lip (Ps. 106:33). The sin was thus in his expressing, not by striking [the rock].

However, this too is incorrect, for Moses said, are we to bring you forth water out of this rock (v. 10). Why was Aaron punished?27 Furthermore, no speech is mentioned in the Torah’s description of the act of striking the rock.28

The proof offered29 by Rabbi Moses is no proof because the meaning of For they embittered his spirit is that they embittered God’s spirit. Scripture similarly writes, But they rebelled, and grieved His holy spirit (Is. 63:10). This is the meaning of They angered Him also at the waters of Meribah (Ps. 106:32). It means they angered God.30 Scripture similarly states, These are the waters of Meribah, where the children of Israel strove with the Lord (Num. 20:13).31 Scripture says, And it went ill with Moses because of them (Ps. 106:32) because they embittered God’s spirit, and He decreed that Moses not enter the land.32
Others say that the meaning of speak to the rock can only mean strike the rock, for a rock cannot hear.33 Now if this is so, why was Moses punished?34

Some say that Moses and Aaron were punished because they did not sing a song of praise35 as in Spring up, O well-sing ye unto it (Num. 21:17). They say that this is the meaning of because ye sanctified Me not (Deut. 32:51).36

Others say that God commanded Moses and Aaron to speak to the rock, but they did not speak to it. On the contrary, Moses struck the rock.37 Therefore they were both punished and they were told, ye trespassed (Deut. 32:51); ye rebelled (v. 24); ye believed not in Me (v. 12), and ye sanctified Me not (Deut. 32:52).
Those who are guided by reason38 say that it is impossible that a messenger of God would alter God’s word.39 If Moses transformed God’s word, how can we believe his Torah?40

However, the aforementioned41 also spoke incorrectly, for if Moses had altered a commandment he would have been punished immediately.42 Look, Moses was punished with regard to something which was not an eternal commandment and not a law given to Israel. Nor did he knowingly violate God’s command. He only did so inadvertently because Israel angered him. Moses clearly said, Also the Lord was angry with me for your sakes (Deut. 1:37).43

Others say that Israel told Moses44 to bring water out of a different rock.45 They offer this rock as proof (v. 10).46 However, Moses was afraid to alter God’s word.47 Moses was punished because he did not believe that he would be able to bring forth water from the rock that Israel chose. He was therefore punished.48 This is the meaning of ye believed not in Me (v. 12). This interpretation is also incorrect, for Scripture states, ye rebelled against My word (v. 24). However, they did not rebel.49
I will reveal in hints the explanation which appears correct to me. Know, when the part50 knows the All,51 he cleaves to the All and creates signs and wonders with the help of the All.52

Now it is true that God told Moses and Aaron, speak ye unto the rock. They did not speak to the rock because the people were quarreling with Moses. The “part” thus remained a “part.”53 He struck the rock, and water did not come out of it54 until he struck it a second time.55 Moses and Aaron thus did not sanctify God’s name. They inadvertently rebelled and trespassed.

It is also possible to explain that And he spoke rashly with his lips (Ps. 106:33) refers to Moses.56 It was unseemly for Moses to say anything57 before fulfilling God’s command. Moses was therefore punished.

The midrashic interpretation of our ancients, of blessed memory, who said that Moses sinned because he said, Hear now, ye rebels (v. 10) is also in keeping with this interpretation. The rabbis hint at this secret.
UNTO THE ROCK. Which I pointed out to you or which is found close to the camp.58

THAT IT GIVE FORTH ITS WATER. Many erred and said that the rock is to be identified with the stone [at Horeb]59 because Scripture reads, its water.60 However, they cannot think straight. The stone was in Horeb and this rock was at the border of the land of Edom, for it was in Kadesh.61 It is also possible to interpret its water as meaning, the water which I will place in it.
9. THE ROD FROM BEFORE THE LORD. The reference is to the rod of God.62 It was the rod which was placed before the testimony.63
10. ARE WE TO BRING YOU FORTH WATER OUT OF THIS ROCK? Do we have the power to bring forth water out of this rock for you?
12. BECAUSE YE BELIEVED NOT IN ME. This alludes to the secret at which I hinted, i.e., that God’s name was not sanctified through them.
13. AND HE WAS SANCTIFIED IN THEM. Through Moses and Aaron.64 Our verse has the same meaning as Through them that are nigh unto Me I will be sanctified (Lev. 10:3).65

14. FROM KADESH. Kadesh is the name of a place where a city is located. It is not to be identified with Kadesh-barnea,66 for the latter was a wilderness.67 Thus Scripture reads, The Lord shaketh the wilderness of Kadesh (Ps. 29:8).68
THE TRAVAIL. I have already explained the meaning of the word tela’ah (travail).69
15. EGYPTIANS DEALT ILL WITH US, AND OUR FATHERS. Who died. The meaning of our clause is that their evil70 lasted a very long time.

[16.] AND SENT AN ANGEL.71 This is to be taken literally. Scripture similarly states, And the angel of His presence saved them (Is. 63:9). Many said that the reference is to Moses72 for they found Then spoke Haggai the Lord’s messenger (malakh)73 (Haggai 1:13). However, this is not my opinion.
17. THROUGH FIELD OR THROUGH VINEYARD. So that they do not destroy it. We will not even drink the water of your wells.
WE WILL GO ALONG THE KING’S HIGHWAY. The major highway upon which the king travels. Or its meaning is, the road that the king, namely, the king of Edom, will command us to travel in.74
19. WE WILL GO UP BY THE HIGHWAY. What harm will it cause you if we up by the highway? If we need water you will sell it to us. This is the meaning of mikhram (v. 19). It means the price thereof.

22. [THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.] Its meaning is, the entire congregation. Because Edom went to fight against them, Scripture relates that no one was missing from the children of Israel when they came from the city of Edom to Mount Hor.75
24. AARON SHALL BE GATHERED UNTO HIS PEOPLE. This is similar to and die in the mount (Deut. 32:50).76 It means that Aaron should prepare himself to die, and go up the mountain.77
YE HAVE REBELLED. I have explained this.
AT THE WATERS OF MERIBAH. Le-me merivah means at the waters of Meribah.78 It is the name of a place. Or le-me merivah means because of the waters of Meribah.79
26. AND STRIP…AND PUT THEM UPON. Ve-hafshet (and strip) and ve-hilbashtam (and put them upon) are hifils.
[AND AARON SHALL BE GATHERED.] Its meaning is, as soon as you strip Aaron of his garments, he shall die.
AND AARON WAS GATHERED TO HIS PEOPLE.80 I have explained this.81
29. AND WHEN ALL THE CONGREGATION SAW. When they saw the event which occurred, they wept for thirty days.82
[DIED.] I have already explained the meaning of the term.83
chapter.ftnote: 1 Following the Exodus.

2 Scripture describes what happened in the first and the last year of Israel’s sojourn in the wilderness. What happened in the other years is ignored. Actually the Book of Numbers opens with a command to Moses in the second month of the second year. Filwarg explains that I.E. was not being precise. Some editions read, “except for the first year, the fortieth year.” The latter is to be interpreted as if written, and the fortieth year.

3 The phrase even the whole congregation appears to be unnecessary. I.E. says that it refers to those about to enter Canaan. They are now the complete congregation, for none of them need die in the wilderness. Rashi comments similarly.
4 Scripture states, and the people abode in Kadesh, because they dwelt there for many days.
5 See Deut. 1:46, So ye abode in Kadesh many days.
6 That happened in Kadesh.
7 I.E. considers this one incident, for the latter was dependent upon the former.
8 Scripture states, our brethren perished. Why add, before the Lord? According to I.E., before the Lord indicates that they worshipped the Lord.
9 Than their quarrel with Aaron.
10 Although this form is grammatically correct, it is not employed in Scripture (Weiser).
11 Hebrew, va-yavo’u. This literally means, and they came.

12 Our verse is to be rendered, And Moses and Aaron fled from the presence of the assembly. I.E. interprets thus because Scripture reads, from the presence (mi-pene) of the assembly. I.E. believes that the latter indicates that they fled.
13 The sin of Moses and Aaron.
14 After being punished.
15 In II Chron. 22:10.
16 Its parallel in the Book of Kings. We read there, and destroyed (va-te’abbed) all the seed royal (II Kings 11:1).
17 According to this interpretation.
18 Not, and you shall hit the rock.
19 If ve-dibbartem means, and you shall strike.
20 Aaron did not strike the rock.
21 Miracles.
22 Some editions read millat (the incident of).

23 And he (Elisha) went forth unto the spring of the waters, and cast salt therein, and said, Thus saith the Lord: I have healed these waters; there shall be not be from thence any more death or miscarrying, (II Kings 2:21).
25 In our case.
26 By are we to bring you forth water out of the rock?
27 If Moses didn’t make himself understood.
28 Thus a verbal pronouncement was not part of this event.
30 In other words, “him” refers to God, not to Moses.
31 Thus “him” in they angered Him also at the waters of Meribah, refers to God.
32 I.E.’s interpretation of Ps. 106:32.
33 I.E. appears to be referring to Rashbam. It should be noted that Rashbam answers I.E.’s question.
34 He did what he was instructed to, viz., to strike the rock.
35 Unto the Lord for giving them water.
36 Its meaning is, you did not sing a song of praise to me.
37 This is the opinion of Rashi. See Rashi on verse 11.
His interpretation is in keeping with the literal meaning of the text.
38 And do not take Scripture literally when it is opposes reason.
39 If God told Moses to speak to the rock, then Moses would not strike the rock.
40 What assurance do we have that Moses did not alter the Torah?
41 Those who said that God told Moses to speak to the rock but that he struck the rock.
42 Moses was not punished immediately. His punishment was delayed.
43 Which shows that he was not punished for deliberately violating God’s command.
44 The text does not state this. These commentaries assume it.
45 Than the one he was commanded to speak to.
46 Are we to bring you forth water out of this rock? implies that we cannot bring water out of this rock, but we can out of another, that is, the rock about which God commanded us.
47 For this was not the rock he was commanded to strike.
48 For not striking the rock chosen by Israel.
49 For they struck the rock which God commanded them to strike.
50 A person.
51 I.E. often refers to God as the All. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 (Vol. 1, p. 47). God is the creator of all. He is all. Also see I.E. on Ex. 33:21 (Vol. 2, p. 695).
53 Moses was distracted and his mind did not cleave unto God.
54 Because he was not cleaving unto God.
55 His anger having been assuaged, Moses now cleaved unto God (Krinsky). This explanation is difficult. If Moses’ anger was assuaged, why didn’t he now speak to the rock?
56 And not to God as previously explained.
57 Such as Hear now, ye rebels, etc. (v. 10).
58 Hence Scripture speaks of the rock and not of a rock.
60 Rather than water. These commentaries assume that its water indicates that the stone had already produced water. See Bahya and Da’at zekenim mi-ba’ale ha-tosafot.
61 See verses 1 and 14.
64 In other words, the term bam (in them) does not refer to the water.
65 God is sanctified when he punishes the righteous. See Rashi.
67 See Deut. 1:19.
68 I.E. assumes that the reference is to Kadesh-barnea, for Kadesh-barnea, unlike Kadesh, was a wilderness. However, his reasoning is circular.
69 See I.E. on Ex. 18:8 (Vol. 2, p. 353): “Its meaning is, an affliction which a person is unable to bear or verbalize.”
70 The evil which the Egyptians did to us, for they afflicted us and our parents.
71 Hebrew, malakh. The word malakh can be rendered as messenger or angel. Hence I.E.’s comment.
72 See Rashi.
73 We thus see that Scripture refers to a prophet by the term malakh.
74 According to this interpretation the meaning of our verse is: we will go on any road which you the king will choose for us to travel on.
75 In other words, no Jews were killed by the Edomites.
76 The meaning of which is: and prepare yourself to die, for it is not in one’s hand to determine the moment of death. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 (Vol. 1, p. 47).
77 Aaron shall be gathered unto his people means Aaron shall go and be gathered to his people.
78 A lamed prefixed to a word means to. Thus le-me meribah might be taken to mean to the water of Meribah. Hence I.E.’s comment.
79 See previous note.
80 This is not in the Biblical text. Our reading in I.E. is probably a scribal error.
81 The meaning of the word gathered. See I.E. on Gen. 25:8 (Vol. 1, p. 246).
82 In other words, And all the congregation saw (the literal interpretation of the verse) is to be rendered, And when all the congregation saw.
83 See I.E. on Gen. 25:8 (Vol. 1, p. 245): “Gava refers to a death wherein the soul leaves the body in a moment without pain and delay.”

chapter.title: CHAPTER 21
chapter.p: 1. AND THE CANAANITE, THE KING OF ARAD. The ancients1 said he2 is Sihon. He is called a Canaanite, for all Amorites are Canaanites.3 Many say that Joshua wrote this section.4 The king of Arad, one (Josh. 12:14) is proof of this.5 They also found that Scripture states that the children of Judah called the name of the place Hormah.6 However, they are wrong, for that place7 was originally called Zephath8 while the place spoken of in our verse was ruled by the king of Arad.9 In reality they are two places.10 There are many such instances in Scripture.11 According to the plain meaning of the text the king of Arad ruled over the eastern bank of the Jordan.12

This portion13 was connected to the death of Aaron, because Scripture relates what happened on Mount Hor14 before they [Israel] journeyed from there. And the Canaanite, the king of Arad… heard…and they journeyed from mount Hor (v. 4) is proof of this.15 If you want to find what the king of Arad heard, observe, it is clearly stated.16
THAT ISRAEL CAME BY THE WAY OF ATHARIM. Some say that the alef of atharim is superfluous. They say that the meaning of ha-atharim is, those who spy. The alef of ezro’akha (your arm) is similar.17
4. TO COMPASS THE LAND OF EDOM. Zalmonah and Punon, for this is explicitly stated in Scripture.18
5. THIS LIGHT BREAD. The word ha-kelokel (this light) means the very light. The word is formed by doubling the word kal.19 There are many similar instances in Scripture.20

6. AND THE LORD…SERPENTS. The word ha-serafim (fiery) is an adjective. The following is a midrashic interpretation. Scripture states, If the serpent bite before it is charmed, Then the charmer hath no advantage (Eccles. 10:11). These people21 sent their tongues to bite.22 They were repaid with snakes being sent against them.
8. MAKE THEE. A form of a fiery serpent out of brass, for Scripture explicitly says so.23
AND SET IT UPON A POLE. So that it be on a high place and everyone will be able to see it.

Many err. They say that this was an image that had the capability of receiving powers from on high.24 Far be it, far be it [for one to believe such a thing], for this thing was made by God’s command.25 We should not investigate why Moses was commanded to make the form of a snake.26 Should someone disagree,27 let him show us if there is a tree that makes bitter waters sweet.28 Even honey will not sweeten them.29 What reason was there to put a cake of figs upon a boil?30 It is not in the nature of figs to remove boils. The truth is that the mind of the Almighty is beyond us.

10. AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL JOURNEYED. From the land of Edom, for Scripture states, to compass the land of Edom (v. 4). Punon31 is on the far border of Edom. The Israelites traveled from Punon to Oboth, for Scripture says so.32
12. AND PITCHED IN THE VALLEY OF ZERED. Zered is elsewhere referred to as Dibon-gad.33
13. FOR ARNON IS THE BORDER OF MOAB. It was so at first.34

14. IN THE BOOK OF THE WARS OF THE LORD. It was a separate book in which the wars of the Lord on behalf of His servants was recorded. It is possible that it originated in the days of Abraham,35 for many books, such as the work of Nathan36 and Iddo,37 the chronicles of the kings of Israel,38 and the songs of Solomon and his proverbs,39 were lost and are not found among us.
VAHEB IN SUPHAH. There were wars in these mentioned places in ancient times.

The word Vaheb is not Hebrew. Neither is Vophsi (Num. 13:14), Vashti (Esth. 1:9), Vaizatha (Esth. 9:9), and also Vashni (I Chron. 6:13). It is possible that the vav of Vashni is a connective.40 I say all this41 because we do not find the vav to be a root letter at the beginning of a word42 except in the word vave (hooks) in the hooks of the pillars (Ex. 27:10). It is found43 only in place of a yod. Compare, valed (child) (II Sam. 6:23).44 The explanation of the Aramaic translation is known.45
15. AND THE SLOPE OF THE VALLEYS. Some say that the word eshed (slope) is Aramaic.46 The end of the matter is: all of these47 are names of places.48
THAT INCLINETH. The reference is to the Israelites,49 for they passed by Ar.50

AND LEANETH UPON THE BORDER OF MOAB. This is what and they51 abide over against me52 (Num. 22:5) refers to. Israel journeyed from there53 to a place called be’er, for the heh of be’erah (to Beer) is in place of the word el (to). It is like the heh of mitzraymah (to Egypt) (Gen. 12 :10).54

This well55 was also56 the result of a miracle. I believe that it is not the well which is called Miriam’s well.57 On the contrary, it refers to a place that Moses commanded to be dug. The princes of Israel dug it with their staffs, and water immediately gushed forth.
17. SPRING UP, O WELL. This is how the song opened. Scripture does not record the entire song.
SING YE UNTO IT. The word enu (sing) is an imperative. Note, Scripture explains58 how it came into being.59
18. WHICH THE NOBLES OF THE PEOPLE DELVED. Scripture repeats itself,60 as is its style.
WITH THE SCEPTRE. The meaning of bi-mechokek (with the sceptre) is, by the governors.61 Compare, My heart is toward the governors (chokeke) of Israel (Jud. 5:9).
This well was in the wilderness, far from an inhabited place. From this wilderness Israel journeyed to Mattanah. From Mattanah they journeyed to Nahaliel.

Note that eshed ha-nehalim (the slope of the valleys) and the wilderness which is called Beer and Mattanah and Nahaliel are all names of places. They are also referred to by a general name, viz., Almon-diblathiam (Num. 33:46), which is found in the Torah portion Ve-Elleh Mase (Ibid.).62 On the other hand, it is also possible that these are the names of places that the Israelites passed over in another journey.63

The mountains of Abarim in front of Nebo (Num. 33:47) are to be identified with Bamoth and the valley that is in the field of Moab (v. 20). The following is proof of this. Scripture states that Israel journeyed from the valley64 to the plains of Moab by the Jordan at Jericho (Num. 22:1).65 It also states that Israel journeyed from the mountains of Abarim to the plains of Moab beyond the Jordon at Jericho (Num. 33:48). It further states, So we abode in the valley66 over against Beth-peor (Deut. 3:29) at the time that I [Moses] pleaded [with God].67 Scripture elsewhere states, Get thee up into this mountain of Abarim, unto mount Nebo (Deut. 32:49).68

Scripture also states, and he was buried in the valley (Deut. 34:6). The Torah there states, And Moses went up from the plains of Moab unto mount Nebo to the top of Pisgah (Deut. 34:1). The valley was thus at the top of Pisgah. Moses died there, and there was no need to move him after his death.69
20. WHICH LOOKETH DOWN. Ve-nishkafah (which looketh down) is in the feminine. It refers to the valley.70

UPON THE DESERT. The word yeshimon (desert) means a wasteland (shemamah). And in the waste, a howling wilderness (yeshimon) (Deut. 32:10) is the proof text. So too is They wandered in the wilderness (yeshimon) in a desert way (Ps. 107:4).
23. TO JAHAZ. Yahtzah means to Jahaz.71
24. FROM THE ARNON. Which he [the king of Edom] took from Moab.

EVEN UNTO THE CHILDREN OF AMMON. Scripture records that half of the land of Ammon belonged to the children of Israel,72 for they73 took it from the Amorites who originally took it from the children of Ammon. Now Scripture tells us that God would not give the Israelites even the size of a footstep from any of the land belonging to the Ammonites and Moabites. The reference is to the land which Ammon and Moab possessed at that time.74 Scripture therefore had to record the words of the poets.75 It did so because Israel lived in Heshbon.76 The Torah explicitly states, And Israel dwelt in all the cities of the Amorite, in Heshbon77 (v. 25).
25. AND IN ALL THE TOWNS THEREOF.78 Heshbon is like a mother, and the towns are like daughters.79
26. FOR HESHBON WAS THE CITY OF SIHON. It turned into the city of Sihon, for, as was well known, he fought against the former king of Moab.80
27. THEY THAT SPEAK IN PARABLES. Who invent parables on their own.81
[COME YE TO HESHBON.] They said this to the Amorites.
BE BUILT. Better than before.
AND ESTABLISHED. To be the city of Sihon.
28. FOR A FIRE IS GONE OUT OF HESHBON. This alludes to the people of Heshbon who conspired against their king.82
A FLAME. The idea is repeated in accord with poetic style.83
FROM THE CITY OF SIHON. From the city that today belongs to Sihon.
AR OF MOAB. Ar is the name of a place. It is in Moab.84 Compare, Beth-lehem Judah85 (Ruth 1:1).
THE HIGH PLACES. Bamot means the high places.86
29. CHEMOSH. The name of an idol; Moab’s god.
FUGITIVES. Those who flee. Fugitives that run from the sword.
30. WE HAVE SHOT THEM. These are the words of Moses.87

The mem of va-niram88 (we shot at them) refers to the king of the Amorites and his troops. It has two interpretations. One, that va-niram is related to the word nir (kingship). It89 is to be read as if written twice.90 It is like even the prophecy, Oded the prophet (II Chron. 15:8).91 Our verse means, and their king the king of Heshbon was destroyed. Va-niram is similar to the word ha-oholi (my tent) in in the midst of my tent (Josh. 7:21), and to ha-erkekha (thy valuation) (Lev. 27:23).92 Va-niram avad cheshbon (we have shot at them—Heshbon is perished) means, their king, that is, the king of Heshbon, perished. Second, that va-niram is related to yereh va-yor (shoot; and he shot) (II Kings 13:17) and yariti (cast)93 (Gen. 31:51). It means,94 when we shot them Heshbon was destroyed.
AND WE HAVE LAID WASTE. Va-nashim comes from a double root.95 The chirik is in place of a short kamatz.96 Compare, va-yasev (led about) in But God led the people about (Ex. 13:18).97

Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that the dagesh in the shin of va-nashim compensates for a missing alef.98 Compare, Who teacheth us more than the beasts of the earth (Job. 35:11) wherein an alef is missing in the word mallefenu (teacheth us).99 The word va-nashim is related to the word tesham100 (shall bear her guilt) in Samaria shall bear her guilt (Hos. 14:1).

Some say that Heshbon was always the city of Sihon.101 In this case, Come ye to Heshbon (v. 27) is the line that the poets directed at the Moabites who came as captive to Heshbon. And for a fire is gone out of Heshbon is a metaphor for the army of Sihon. When the poets speak on behalf of the Moabites, they say, we thought that Heshbon will be destroyed102 and the entire land will be laid waste even unto Nophah. Or these103 are the words of Moses.
33. AND THEY TURNED. I have already explained its meaning.104
EDREI. To Edrei. Scripture is being brief.105
35. NONE LEFT HIM REMAINING. No one of the Israelites.106
chapter.ftnote: 1 The sages of the Talmud.
2 The king of Arad. See Rosh Ha-Shanah 3a: “Sihon, Arad, and Canaan are one and the same.”
3 Sihon was king of the Amorites. See verse 21.
4 Verses 1-3.
5 Josh. 12 lists the kings that Joshua smote. The king of Arad is included in this list. It thus appears that it was Joshua, not Moses, who defeated the king of Arad.
6 In the days of Joshua. See Josh. 12:14.
7 The Hormah spoken of in Josh. 12:14.
8 See Jud. 1:17: And Judah went with Simeon his brother, and they smote the Canaanites that inhabited Zephath, and utterly destroyed it. And the name of the city was called Hormah.
9 It was always called Arad.
10 The Hormah mentioned in our verse is not to be identified with the Hormah in Josh. 12:14.
11 Of two places having the same name.
12 And was thus defeated by Moses.
13 Verses 1-3.
14 The place of Aaron’s death.
15 That the king of Arad fought Israel at Mount Hor.
16 The king heard that Israel came by the way of Atharim (v. 1).
17 For the meaning of ezro’akha is, your arm (zero’akha). The reference is probably to Jer. 32:21. However, the text there reads ezro’a.

18 See Num. 33:41-45. Scripture here omits the places where Israel camped when they compassed the land of Edom. It does include them in Num. 33:41-45. It tells us there that Israel camped at Zalmonah and Punon when it went around Edom.
19 Kelokel is an intensified form. Hence the meaning very light.
20 Compare, adamdam (very red), shecharhar (very black).
21 Who spoke against God and Moses.
22 A metaphor for speaking evil.
23 In the next verse.

24 It was an image in whom heavenly power resided and thus could heal those bitten by the serpents. See I.E. on Gen. 31:19 (Vol. 1, p. 300) and Ex. 20:20 (Vol. 2, p. 437). According to I.E. such an image is banned by Scripture for it is a type of magical practice.
25 God would not command such an object to be made. According to I.E. this is precisely what Ex. 20:20 prohibits. See I.E. on Ex. 20:20 (Vol. 2, p. 437).
26 And argue that there is a scientific reason for the copper snake.
27 Those who offer scientific explanations.
28 Moses healed bitter waters by casting a tree into it. See Ex. 15:22-25.
29 Bitter water.
30 When King Hezekiah was ill with boils the prophet Isaiah prescribed that a cake of figs be applied to his boils. See II Kings 20:7; Is. 38:21.
31 See I.E. on verse 4.
33 In Num. 33:45. The purpose of I.E.’s comments on verses 4, 10, and 12 is to harmonize our chapter with Num. 33.
34 Before Israel conquered Sihon.
35 The first servant of God to wage war. See Gen. 14:13-16.
36 See I Chron. 29:29.
37 II Chron. 12:15.
38 I Kings 14:19.
39 I Kings 5:12.
40 In this case, the meaning of Vashni is, and sheni (sheni being a Hebrew name).
41 That these words are not Hebrew.
42 In other words, we do not find the vav to be a first root letter.
43 As a first root letter.
44 Which comes from the root yod, lamed, dalet.
45 Onkelos renders sufah (Suphah) as yama de-suf (the sea of reeds).
46 Rashi claims that the word eshed means pouring or spilling in Aramaic.
47 Vaheb, Suphah, Eshed, etc.
48 In other words, eshed is the name of a place.
49 Israel inclined towards the city of Ar.
50 Israel passed by the city of Ar. They did not enter it. See Deut. 2:9.
51 Israel.
52 This was said by the king of the Moabites.
53 The border of Moab.
54 Which is in place of the word el.
55 Spoken of in verse 16.
56 Like the manna, the waters of Marah, and the like.
57 Contrary to the opinion of the rabbis. See Ta’anit 9a.
58 In verse 18.
59 Princes and nobles dug the well.
60 Which the nobles…delved repeats which the princes digged.
61 The bet of bi-mechokek means by. The bet usually has the meaning of in. Hence I.E.’s comment.

62 Which records the journeys of the children of Israel in the wilderness. Eshed ha-nehalim (the slope of the valleys), Beer, Mattanah, and Nahaliel are not mentioned there. Almon-diblathiam is. Hence I.E.’s comment.
63 Hence they are not recorded in Num. 33:46.
64 That is in the field of Moab (v. 10).
65 I.E. connects Num. 22:1 to Num. 21:10.
66 Which is in the field of Moab.
67 To allow him to enter Canaan. This was shortly before Moses’ death.
68 We thus see that Moses went up to Mount Nebo from the valley which is the field of Moab.
69 As would be the case if the “valley” where Moses died was not at the top of the mountain. According to I.E. the “valley” was an indentation at the top of the mountain.
70 The word guy (valley) can be masculine or feminine.
71 The heh at the end of the word is in place of the preposition to.
73 The Israelites.
74 In the time of Moses.
75 To the effect that Sihon took the city of Heshbon from the Moabites.
76 Which was originally a Moabite city.
77 We thus see that Israel dwelt in Heshbon.
78 Literally, and in all her daughters.
79 Thus, “and in all her daughters” means: and in all the towns thereof.
80 Scripture speaks of Sihon’s victory over Moab as a well-known fact.
81 The literal meaning of ha-moshelim (they that speak in parables) is the parablers.
82 According to I.E. our verse teaches that Moabites conspired against their king.
83 A flame…repeats For a fire…
84 The Hebrew reads ar mo’av.
85 Translated literally. See I.E. on Num. 13:22.
86 It is not the name of a place.
87 Until now Scripture records what the poets said. Now it records the comments of Moses.
88 A pronominal suffix meaning them.
89 The word nir.
90 Our verse, which reads va-niram avad cheshbon (we have shot at them—Heshbon is perished), is to be read, va-niram avad nir cheshbon (and their king, the king of Heshbon, was destroyed).
91 Which is to be read as if written, even the prophecy, the prophecy of Oded the prophet. See I.E. on Gen. 6:13 (Vol. 1, p. 100) and the notes thereto.

92 The pattach beneath the vav is the sign of the direct object. In other words, va-niram is short for ve-ha-niram. Thus va-niram is similar to ha-oholi and ha-erkekha in that both words are written with the direct object even though they have suffixes. Words with suffixes usually do not come with the direct object. Hence I.E.’s comment.
93 Translated literally.
94 Va-niram avad heshbon (we have shot at them–Heshbon is perished).
95 Even though it is spelled with one mem. It comes from the root shin, mem, mem.
96 A tzere. In other words, the word should have been vocalized va-nashem.
97 Which is vocalized with a tzere.
98 According to Rabbi Moses, va-nashim comes from the root alef, shin, mem (guilty).
99 Which comes from the root alef, lamed, peh.
100 In other words, it comes from the root alef, shin, mem.
101 See I.E. on verses 26-28.
102 They interpret our verse as follows: We (the Moabites) shot at them. W e thought Heshbon is perished…even unto Nophah.
103 We have shot at them…unto Nophah (v. 30).
104 The meaning of va-yifnu (and they turned). See I.E. on Ex. 10:6 (Vol. 2, p. 186). I.E. explains there that va-yifnu means, and they faced.
105 In omitting the preposition el (to).

106 The verse literally reads, until he left (hishir) him [Og] no remainder. Since the first part of the verse is in the plural, our clause should have read, until they left (hishiru) him no remainder. Hence I.E.’s comment.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 22
chapter.p: 2. TO THE AMORITES. The lamed prefixed to the word emori (Amorite) is vocalized with a kamatz.1 Its reference is to the famous Amorites Sihon and Og. There were no kings among the Canaanites as great as they. Whose height was like the height of the cedars (Amos 2:9) is proof of this.2
3. AND MOAB WAS SORE AFRAID. Va-yagar means was afraid. Guru lakhem (be ye afraid) (Job 19:29) is similar.

AND MOAB WAS OVERCOME WITH DREAD. Va-yakatz (overcome with dread) has the same meaning as a similarly spelled word whose letters are inverted.3 U-nekitzennah (and vex it) in Let us go up against Judah, and vex it (Is. 7:6) is similar.
4. UNTO THE ELDERS OF MIDIAN. It is possible that the five Midianite kings are these same elders.4
NOW WILL THIS MULTITUDE LICK UP…AS THE OX LICKETH UP. Yelachakhu (will…lick up) and ki-lechokh (as…licketh up) are two different conjugations.5
5. TO PETHOR. Pethorah means to Pethor.6 Compare, mitzrayemah (to Egypt) (Gen. 37:25).
TO THE LAND OF THE CHILDREN OF HIS PEOPLE. Who were Arameans. Scripture similarly states, from Pethor of Aram-naharaim (Deut. 23:5).

The midrash7 identifies Balaam with Bela.8 [However, the identification is untenable] because Balaam was an Aramean. If we identify Balaam with Bela because of Beor his father,9 then, lo and behold, the son of Ahasuerus10 lived before Ahasuerus.11 They12 are definitely two different people.
WHICH IS BY THE RIVER. The reference is to Aram-naharaim.
THE FACE OF THE EARTH. I have already explained the meaning of this expression.13

6. CURSE ME. The word arah (curse) is an imperative. It comes from a double root with one of the double letters missing. The same is true of with the word kavah (curse) in curse me (v. 18). The word kov (curse) is vocalized according to the paradigm of shemor (keep).14 Kavah15 in kavah li (curse me) minus the heh16 follows the paradigm of shechav (lie), rekhav (ride), and tzelach (rested on).17

THAT WE MAY SMITE THEM. Nakkeh (that we may smite them)18 is an infinitive. The fact that it ends in a heh is no argument against the latter,19 for the word le-khalle20 (to finish), in to finish the transgression (Dan. 9:24) is similar.21

IS CURSED. The silent vav of yu’ar (is cursed) is in place of a dagesh, which is in place of the missing double letter.22 Compare, yusav23 (turned about)24 in turned about upon the cummin (Is. 28:27). There is no other word like it in this form, because of the rules concerning gutturals.25
7. THE ELDERS OF MOAB. The wise men.26

WITH THE REWARDS OF DIVINATION IN THEIR HAND. Rabbi Samuel Ha-Nagid the Sephardi, of blessed memory, said that the meaning of u-kesamim (with the reward of divination)27 is payment for divination. He offers as proof the word be-yadam (in their hand).28 However, he says nothing. U-kesamim be-yadam is to be taken literally.29 Scripture tells us that Balak sent diviners like himself to the diviner [Balaam]. Furthermore, Balaam would not be able to tarry, saying, “I can not find a propitious day, and a propitious hour to go and curse,” for the messengers were members of his guild. In his right hand is the instrument of divination30 (ha-kesom) (Ez. 21:27) is proof that u-kesamim be-yadam is to be taken literally.31
8. AND I WILL BRING YOU BACK WORD. After you spend the night here.

9. AND GOD CAME. Out of regard for Israel, for God knew the coming incident of ba’al pe’or.32 Now if Balaam had cursed them then, all of the world would have said that the plague came because of Balaam’s curse.33

WHAT MEN ARE THESE. This was a way of opening and starting a conversation.34 It is similar to Where is Abel thy brother (Gen. 4:9). Now Cain denied [knowledge of Abel’s whereabouts]. However, God told him, the voice of thy brother’s blood crieth out unto Me (Gen. 4 :10).35
12. FOR THEY ARE BLESSED. Its meaning is, you cannot curse them, for I have blessed them.
13. THE PRINCES OF BALAK. Scripture does not mention the elders of Midian,36 for Balak was the protagonist and he sent the messengers to Balaam.

Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen the Spaniard, of blessed memory, says that even though the yod is the sign of the object37 it can only come with a nun.38 Compare, ha-lehorgeni (thinkest thou to kill me) (Ex. 2:14). It does not read ha-lehorgi. However, he forgot le-titti (to give me) in to give me leave to go with you [our verse] and yabbemi (perform the duty of a husband’s brother unto me) in he will not perform the duty of a husband’s brother unto me (Deut. 25:7).39
Rabbi Jonah the grammarian says that the yod of le-titti40 is superfluous, but what he says is incorrect.41
[14. TO COME WITH US.]42 Its meaning is, to go with us from his place.

15. MORE. The word rabbim (more) is to be taken literally,43 or it is to be rendered as great.44 Compare, to all the officers (rav) of his house (Esth. 1:8)45 and The city46 of the great king (rav) (Ps. 48:3), that is, David, for the city was called the city where David encamped (Is. 29:1).
17. FOR I WILL PROMOTE THEE. With money.

AND WHATSOEVER THOU SAYEST UNTO ME I WILL DO. If this is necessary for you to curse them. Balaam’s statement, If Balak would give me his house full of silver and gold, is proof that the meaning of For I will promote is, and I will promote you with money.47

18. HIS HOUSE FULL. Melo beto means his house full.48 Melo khol ha-aretz kevodo (the whole earth is full of His glory) (Is. 6:3) is similar. Many err who thought that the meaning of the latter is that the contents of the earth is God’s glory,49 as in the earth is the Lord’s, and the fulness thereof (Ps. 24:1).

SMALL OR GREAT. The words ketannah (small) and gedolah (great) are adjectives. However, the nouns50 are missing. But the rich man answers impudent51 (Prov. 18:23)52 and, and his food fat53 (Hab. 1:16)54 are similar.
19. HERE.55 In this place.

The Gaon, of blessed memory,56 says: Should someone argue and say, “How could God tell Balaam rise up, go with them (v. 20) after telling him Thou shalt not go with them (12)?”57 Then we can answer him that God did not want Balaam to go with these messengers but to wait until Balak sent messengers more honorable than they.

However, I believe that there is no need for the Gaon’s interpretation. Its meaning is similar to God telling Israel, Send thou men (Num. 13:2) and go up, take possession (Deut. 1:21). Israel did not believe.58 On the contrary, they said, Let us send men before us (Deut. 1:22). Moses then asked God.59 God told him, Send thou men (Num. 13:2).60

Now after God told Balaam, thou shalt not curse the people (v. 12), what need did Balaam have to say, that I may know what the Lord will speak unto me more (v. 19)? Balaam had an evil thought in his heart. God told him go with the men, but take care that you do not say anything save that which I will tell you. And God’s anger was kindled because he went (v. 22) is proof that my explanation is correct.61
21. AND SADDLED. By command.62
22. FOR AN ADVERSARY AGAINST HIM. I have already explained in the Book of Job that the adversary was an angel.63 The words of the Gaon that the adversary was a human being do not help or hinder.64
23. OUT OF THE WAY. Which was trodden.65 The ass went into a field wherein there was no path.
TO TURN HER INTO THE WAY. The phrase le-hatotah ha-derekh (to turn her the way)66 is abridged. It means to turn her into the way.

24. IN A HOLLOW WAY BETWEEN THE VINEYARDS. The word mishol (hollow way) is to be interpreted according to its context, for it is not found again in Scripture.67 It should be explained as the Aramaic translation renders it.68
25. AND SHE THRUST HERSELF UNTO THE WALL. Va-tillachetz is to be rendered, and she thrust herself.69
UNTO THE WALL. The reference is to the fence.70
AND HE SMOTE HER AGAIN. For he had already hit her when she turned into the field.71

28. AND THE LORD OPENED THE MOUTH OF THE ASS. The rabbis, of blessed memory, said that ten things were created on Sabbath eve at twilight.72 I believe that this means that God specifically decreed the creation of these miraculous phenomena,73 for they are beyond the laws of nature.74

The Gaon75 says that the ass did not speak. Rabbi Samuel the son of Hofni attacked the Gaon.76 However, Rabbi Samuel the Spanish poet tried to save the one who was attacked.77 Note, the rationalists had a need for a non-literal interpretation of our text, for they said that God would not create signs in the world to change the laws which he created.78 He would do so only to justify his prophet.79
However, they did not speak the truth, for, look, a miracle was done for Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, who were not prophets.80
Some of them81 say that Balaam was a prophet.82 However, the truth is that his prophecy83 was because of Israel’s glory, for Balaam was a diviner. Indeed, this is how Scripture refers to him.84
Some say that Balaam knew the mind of the heavenly beings and was able to channel them by images that he made.85 This is the meaning of and he whom thou cursest is cursed (v. 6).

However, it appears to me that Balaam was an astrologer. When Balaam saw in the star of a given person that an evil time had befallen him, he would curse him. When evil befell the one whom he cursed, then those who witnessed and heard the imprecation thought that the evil came because of Balaam’s curse. The fact that Balaam spoke with guile to the lords of Balak is proof of this.86

The meaning of I can not go beyond the word of the Lord my God (v. 18) is, it is not in the hand of any created being to change a deed or a decree of God. The secret is, the part87 can not change a part.88 It is only the decree of the All89 which can change the decree of the part.90 I cannot reveal this secret for it is very deep. The correct interpretation is, the ass spoke.
If you understand the secret of the angels of Abraham91 and of Jacob,92 then you will understand the truth.93
[WITH HIS STAFF.] Scripture states this because Balaam first hit her with a small piece of wood or with a strap.
TIMES. I have already explained the meaning of the term regalim (times).94
29. HAST MOCKED. I have already explained the term hitalalt (hast mocked).95
30. ALL THY LIFE LONG. This means from the day that you started to ride.

WAS I EVER WONT. The meaning of ha-hasken hiskanti is, was I ever wont. Its import is, was this my manner. The word hasken (acquaint)96 in Acquaint (hasken) now thyself with him (Job 22:21) is similar.
31. THEN THE LORD OPENED. As in the case of Elisha’s young man (II Kings 6:17).97 God added to the light of his98 eyes99 or first struck him blind.100
AND BOWED HIS HEAD.101 I have already explained its meaning.102

32. BECAUSE THY WAY IS CONTRARY UNTO ME. The meaning of yarat (contrary) is perverse.103 The word yirteni (twists me) in And twists me by the hands of the wicked104 (Job 16:11), which comes from the root resh, tet, heh, is similar.105

If yirteni comes from the root yod, resh, tet, then it should be vocalized like ye’atani106 (He hath covered me) (Is. 61:10).107 Yarat and yirteni have similar meanings even though they come from two different roots.108 We find the same to be the case with the word ye’atani (Ibid.), which is vocalized like the word ye’atzani (given me counsel) (Ps. 16:7).109 Ye’atani is similar in meaning to oteh (coverest)110 in (Who coverest Thyself with light) (Ps. 104:2).111
33. AND THE ASS SAW ME. Va-tirani is spelled with a pattach112 in place of a tzere. It should have been vocalized va-tireni.113 There are many such cases.114
UNLESS. The word ulai (unless) has many meanings. Here it means unless.
The word even115 is evidence that the ass died after she spoke.116
AND SAVED HER ALIVE. Scripture is being brief. Its117 meaning is, as I killed her I would have killed you, or I would have killed you and left her alive.118

The above is explained by the following.119 When a person sees an angel, he dies. And my life is preserved (Gen. 32:1),120 and the words of Manoah121 are proof. How much more so the case of a beast that has nothing in common with the spirit of an angel as a human being does.
35. GO WITH THE MEN. With these men.
BUT ONLY. The word efes means only. The word efes (howbeit) in Howbeit there shall be no needy among you (Deut. 15: 4) and in Howbeit (efes) the people…are fierce (Num. 13:28) is similar.

37. WHEREFORE CAMEST THOU NOT UNTO ME. The word halakhta122 is to be rendered camest because it is followed by elai (unto me). The same applies, as I have already explained,123 to the word va-ysar (departed) (I Sam. 15:6).
39. KIRIATH-HUZOTH. It is the name of a province.124
41. BAMOTH-BAAL. This is to be identified with Bamotharnon (the high places of Arnon) (Num. 21:28).
AND HE SAW FROM THENCE THE UTMOST PART OF THE PEOPLE. For they camped on all four compass points.125
chapter.ftnote: 1 A lamed so vocalized indicates the definite article.
2 The entire verse reads: Yet I destroyed the Amorite [Sihon and Og] before them, Whose height was like the height of the cedars (Amos 2:9).
3 Va-yatzak. Va-yatzak is spelled vav, yod, tzadi, kof. Va-yakatz is spelled vav, yod, kof, tzadi.
4 Num. 31:8 speaks of five Midianite kings. I.E. identifies the elders in our verse with them.
5 Yelachakhu (will…lick up) is in the pi’el. Ki-lechokh (as…licketh up) is a kal. Both words come from the root lamed, chet, caf.
6 The heh at the end of the word is in place of the preposition to.
7 See San. 105a. Also see Targum Jonathan on Gen. 36:32.
8 An Edomite king mentioned in Gen. 36:32.
9 Both Bela and Balaam had a father called be’or.
10 Darius. See Dan. 9:1.

11 Esth. 1:1. I.E.’s point is that names alone cannot serve to identify historical figures, for more than one person have the same name. According to the midrash (Esther Rabbah 1:1), King Ahasuerus mentioned in the Book of Esther had a son called Darius. There was also a King Darius who lived before Ahasuerus mentioned in the book of Esther. If every Darius in the Bible is one and the same person, then Darius son of Ahasuerus lived before Ahasuerus his father. See I.E. on Dan. 9:1 and Esth. 1:1.
12 Bela and Balaam.
13 This is to be taken metaphorically. See I.E. on Ex. 10:5 (Vol. 2, p. 186).
14 It is vocalized with a cholam.
15 Kavah is an elongated form of kav.
16 Pronounced kav.
17 They are all vocalized with a pattach.
18 From the root nun, caf, heh.
19 The heh changes to a tav in the infinitive in words ending in a heh. Thus our word should have read le-nakkot. Hence I.E.’s comment.
20 From the root caf, lamed, heh.
21 It too is an infinitive, and Scripture employs the form le-khalle rather than the more usual form le-khallot.
22 The root of yu’ar is alef, resh, resh. Yu’ar is spelled with only one resh.
23 Yusav and yu’ar are both pu’als.
24 Yusav comes from the root samekh, bet, bet. In I.E.’s version of Scripture, unlike our versions, it does not have a dagesh.
25 The alef. A guttural according to the rules of grammar does not receive a dagesh.
26 The elders were wise men (Weiser).
27 Balaam was the diviner, not the messengers sent to him. Hence Rabbi Samuel’s interpretation.
28 Rabbi Samuel believed that in their hand refers to the money which they brought with them for the divination.
29 It refers to instruments of divination.
30 Translated literally.
31 For the verse shows that instruments of divination were held in the hand.
32 A Moabite god worshipped by the Israelites. Twenty-four thousand Israelites died for worshipping this idol. See Num. 25:1-9.
33 Otherwise God would have allowed Balaam to curse Israel, for his curse would not have had any effect.
34 God knew who the men were.
35 Thus God knew where Abel was. Hence, Where is Abel thy brother was merely a way of starting a conversation.
36 See verse 4 and 7.
37 When suffixed to a verb, as in titti (give me).
38 That is, the suffix ni has to be added to the verb in order to indicate the object.
39 In both of these words the object is indicated by the yod alone.
40 In other words, le-titti means the same as la-tet. It means to give, not to give me.
41 For the absence of the nun does not mean that the object (me) is missing.
42 Literally, to go with us. Hence I.E.’s comment.
43 It is to be rendered as more.
44 In this case, our term is to be rendered as great princes (sarim rabbim).
45 I.E. renders this as to all the great of his house.
46 The reference is to Jerusalem.
47 For it indicates that Balaam was hinting that he wanted to be well compensated.
48 And not the fullness of his house.

49 They interpreted the verse (Is. 6:3) to mean that God’s glory consists of the contents of the earth (melo khol ha-aretz). However, this interpretation is incorrect, for God’s glory consists of much more than the contents of the earth.
50 Which they modify.
51 Translated literally.
52 But the rich man answers impudent is short for, but the rich answers impudent words. Thus here too the noun which the adjective modifies is missing.
53 Translated literally.
54 And his food fat is short for, And his food a fat lamb. See I.E. on Hab. 1:16.
55 Hebrew, ba-zeh, literally means in this. Hence I.E.’s comment.
56 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
57 According to the medieval Jewish philosophers, God does not change His mind.
58 That they could conquer the Canaanites without first spying out the land.
59 Whether to send spies or not.

60 God told Balaam not to go to Balak to curse Israel. When Balaam told God that he wanted to go, God told him, go but do not curse Israel. In other words, the prohibition was on the cursing, not on the going.
61 Otherwise, God would not have been angry at him for going, after he had received permission to go.
62 He did not personally saddle his donkey.
63 See I.E. on Job 1:6.
64 They contribute nothing.
65 The ass left the trodden path.
66 Translated literally.
67 Hence we do not know its exact meaning.
68 Onkelos renders be-mishol as be-shevil (in a path).
69 The literal meaning of va-tillachetz is, and she was thrust. Hence I.E.’s comment.
70 Mentioned in the previous verse.
71 Verse 23.
72 Among them the mouth of Balaam’s ass. See Abot 5:6.
73 Mentioned in Abot 5:6.

74 In other words, these miraculous phenomena, one of which was the mouth of Balaam’s ass, were not actually created on Sabbath eve at twilight. God decreed that they come into being at their proper time. Maimonides makes a similar point in his commentary on Abot 5:6.
75 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
76 For saying this.
77 Rabbi Samuel the Spanish tried to defend Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
78 The rationalists argue that God would not change the laws of nature.
79 The rationalists argue that God would only change the laws of nature to prove that what a prophet said was true. This was not the case with Balaam’s ass.
80 They were saved from a fiery furnace. See Dan. 2.
81 The rationalists.
82 Hence God suspended the laws of nature for him.
83 God’s appearance to Balaam.
84 Balaam…the soothsayer (Josh. 13:22).
85 Balaam made images which had the power to manipulate the heavenly powers.
86 First he told them that he couldn’t curse Israel. Then he hinted that he could.
87 A human being. A human being is part of creation.
88 Any of the laws of nature.
89 God.
90 Of nature.
91 The angels that appeared to Abraham at Elon Moreh took the form of people. See Gen. 18:1,2.
92 The angel that appeared to Jacob at Jabok had the form of a human. See Gen. 32:2; Gen. 32:25-31
93 The angel that appeared to Balaam took the form of a man.
