94 It means times. See I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 23:14. The word regel means a foot. Hence I.E.’s comment.
95 I.E. explains the term to refer to manipulating events to inflict harm. See I.E. on Ex. 10:2 (Vol. 2, p. 185).
96 Or habituate.
97 Who did not see the angels until God “opened his eyes.”
98 Balaam’s.
99 So that he could now see what he wasn’t able to see before.
100 And then opened his eyes.
101 Hebrew, appav, literally, his nostrils. According to I.E. our phrase should be rendered, and he bowed with his nostrils.
102 The nostrils protrude from the face and touch the ground when one bows. See I.E. on Gen. 19 and the notes thereto (Vol. 1, p. 202).
103 I.E. renders our clause, because the way [you have chosen] is perverse in my sight.
104 Translated according to I.E.
105 Thus yarat comes from the root resh, tet, heh.
106 In meaning.
107 Yeratani.
108 The root of yarat is yod, resh, tet and yirteni comes from resh, tet, heh.
109 Ye’atani comes from the root yod, ayin, tet.
110 From the root ayin, tet, heh.
111 Both of these words come from different roots but have a similar meaning.
112 I.E. reads a long kamatz. However, this appears to be an error. See Filwarg.
113 See I.E. on Ex. 14:11 (Vol. 2, p. 277) and the notes thereto.
114 See Ex. 33:20, which employs yirani in place of yireni.
115 Hebrew, gam, literally, also.
116 I would have slain also you implies that he killed the ass.
117 The meaning of surely now I had even slain thee, and saved her alive.
118 And saved her alive is short for, I would have killed you and left her alive.
119 And saved her alive implies that the ass died. The question arises, “Why?”
120 Stated by Jacob with reference to seeing an angel.
121 Manoah saw an angel and was afraid that he would die. See Jud. 13:22.
122 Which literally means you went.
123 See I.E. on Gen. 19:2 (Vol. 1, p. 202).
124 Or city.
125 They were spread out on all sides. Hence he saw only part of the people.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 23
chapter.p: 1. SEVEN ALTARS. There are deep secrets which only a few can fathom. The number seven occurs with regard to days,1 months,2 years;3 the seven lambs offered for a burnt offering;4 the seven sprinklings.5 God also told Job, take unto you seven bullocks and seven rams (Job 42:8).
When the complete6 is added to the complete,7 then a spirit of understanding is newly created.8 The intelligent will understand what I speak of.
2. ON EVERY ALTAR A BULLOCK AND A RAM.9 On each and every altar.10 Scripture is being brief. It is short for, on one of the many altars.11
3. WILL COME. Yikkareh (will come) is derived from li-kerati (to meet me).12
AND WHATSOEVER13 HE SHOWETH ME. The word devar is connected to mah.14
AND HE WENT TO A BARE HEIGHT. The manner in which the Aramaic translator renders shefi (bare) is known. He translates shefi as alone.15 Now shefi is alone; it is also without a brother.16
Other say that the word shefi means broken in heart (Ps. 109:16).17 They say that the word shefi is related to shuppu (corrode) in and his bones corrode (Job 33:21).

However, I believe that the word shefi is related to shefayim (high hills) in upon the high hills is heard (Jer. 3:20). The word is found spelled both with a yod18 and with an alef.19 We find the same thing with the word peta’im (simple) (Prov. 1:4).20 The meaning of va-elekh shefi (and he went to a bare height) is, he went to a high hill. The word el (to) has been omitted from the phrase.21 We find the same in va-yavo yerushalayim (and he came to Jerusalem)22 (I Kings 3:15) and in nase’u ha-am hazerot (the people journeyed unto Hazeroth)23 (Num. 11:35). There are many such instances.24

Observe, Balaam was divining25 when he went,26 for Scripture clearly states, he went not, as at other times27 to meet with enchantments28 (Num. 24:1). See, I have given you a hint regarding a sealed secret.29
4. AND I HAVE OFFERED UP A BULLOCK AND A RAM ON EVERY ALTAR. By command.30
7. AND HE TOOK UP HIS PARABLE, AND SAID. The parable referred to is, For from the top of rocks I see him (v. 9).31
FROM THE MOUNTAINS OF THE EAST. The word kedem means east.32
COME, CURSE ME JACOB. “And he said” has been omitted from our clause.33 We find many such instances in the Song of Songs. This is an abridged style.
EXECRATE ISRAEL. Scripture repeats itself 34 as is its custom. Its manner is to employ different words to express the same thought. It repeats itself for emphasis.

The word zo’amah (execrate)35 should have been vocalized like the word zokhrah (remember)36 in Remember unto me, O my God (Neh. 5:19). However, since the ayin37 was vocalized with a pattach38 because it is a guttural, a cholam rather than a short kamatz was placed between it and the zayin.

8. HOW SHALL I CURSE, WHOM GOD HATH NOT CURSED. The word kabboh means to curse. Its heh is in place of a vav.39 It is like the heh in oholoh40 (his tent) (Gen. 12:8) and the heh in fera’oh41 (let them loose) in for Aaron had let them loose (Ex. 32:25). Kabboh comes from a double root.42 Its full form43 is kavevo (they curse him). Compare, savevo44 (they surrounded him) although it is irregular.45
AND HOW SHALL I EXECRATE, WHOM GOD HATH NOT EXECRATED. The words ezam (shall I execrate) and za’am (execrate) come from the root, zayin, ayin, mem (anger). Scripture repeats itself.46

9. FOR FROM THE TOP OF THE ROCKS I SEE HIM. Balaam said this because he was high up on the hill. He went not, as at other times, to meet with enchantments. But he set his face toward the wilderness (Num. 24:1)47 and not toward the high place48 is proof that my interpretation of shefi49 is correct.50

It is also likely that from the top of the rocks is a parable symbolizing the decrees that come down from heaven. For Balaam in his wisdom51 saw that this nation would stand alone and not intermingle with other nations that would overpower her and try to force her to give up God’s Torah, as the nations did.
AND SHALL NOT BE RECKONED AMONG THE NATIONS. I will explain this in my comments on When the Most High gave to the nations their inheritance (Deut. 32:8).
10. WHO HATH COUNTED. It is a wonder that Israel is not counted with the nations, when they are a nation as numerous as the sand. It is likely for a small nation not to be counted.52
THE DUST OF JACOB. Its meaning is: Jacob is as numerous as the dust of the earth.
OR NUMBERED THE STOCK OF ISRAEL? One standard.53 It means the same as thou shalt see but the utmost part of them, and shalt not see them all (v. 13).54
[LET ME DIE THE DEATH OF THE RIGHTEOUS, AND LET MINE END BE LIKE HIS!] The Aramaic translator beautifully explained the meaning of yesharim (the righteous).55
I believe that Balaam wanted to die. He wanted his end to be like the end of Israel, who are God’s portion and are not ruled by the stars, for he was a magician.56
Others say that mine end repeats let me die. Balaam wanted to die like the righteous of Israel, for he knew that he would die by the sword.57

The Gaon58 says that Who hath counted refers to God. Our verse means: You who are able to count the dust of Jacob, give me the death of the righteous. However, if this is so, then what meaning is there to Or numbered the stock of Israel?59

Many explain that rova (the stock of) is similar in meaning to rivi, which means my lying down. Compare, Thou measurest my going about and my lying down (rivi) (Ps. 139:3). They explain that the dust of Jacob refers to the time that Jacob journeys.60

11. [THOU HAST BLESSED THEM ALTOGETHER.] It is normal usage to place the infinitive first in the perfect and then the imperfect.61 The reverse is true in the imperative.62 However, there are irregular phrases such as u-verakhta barekh63 (thou hast blessed them altogether) (Num. 24:10); and yava vo64 (and he shall come on) in and he shall come on, and overflow, as he passeth through (Dan. 11:1).
13. BUT THE UTMOST. The meaning of efes katzehu is, but the utmost.

AND CURSE ME THEM. Ve-kovno (and curse them) is irregular.65 According to the rules of grammar the imperative is the same as the imperfect.66 The only difference between them is the prefix.67 Compare, yirdefehu (he shall pursue him); yirdefenu (he shall pursue him); yirdefuhu (they shall pursue him); and yirdefo (shall pursue him68) in The enemy shall pursue him (Hos. 8:3).69 However, kovno comes with a nun vocalized with a cholam joined to the root.

According to Rabbi Judah, the first grammarian, the word kovno comes from the root kof, bet, nun.70 If this is the case, then kovno cannot be an imperative, for we do not find such a vocalization in the kal.71 Perhaps kovno is an infinitive vocalized like the word shomro (keep) in and because He would keep the oath (Deut. 7:8).
18. AND HE TOOK UP HIS PARABLE. The reference is to like the lofty horns of the wild-ox (v. 22) and a people that riseth up as a lioness (v. 24).
GIVE EAR UNTO ME. The word adai (unto me) is related to the word ad (unto). The word adai (unto Me) in Yet have ye not returned unto Me (Amos 4:6) is similar.
Scripture repeats itself.72
The vav in beno tzippor (son of Zippor) is superfluous.73 It is similar to the vav of le-mayeno (a fountain) in into a fountain of waters (Ps. 114:8).74
[19. GOD IS NOT A MAN.] Balaam said this in response to Balak’s request, and curse me them from thence (v. 13). However, Balaam had already told him, God hath not cursed (v. 8).75
WHEN HE HATH SAID, WILL HE NOT DO IT? His word.76
OR WHEN HE HATH SPOKEN. A word.
20. BEHOLD, I AM BIDDEN TO BLESS. Barekh (to bless)77 is an infinitive. It has the same meaning as a noun.78
AND WHEN HE HATH BLESSED. U-verekh (and when he hath blessed) is a verb in the perfect. Its meaning is, when God pronounced a blessing, I cannot call it back.

21. NONE HATH BEHELD INIQUITY IN JACOB.79 I believe that Balak learned from this utterance to send Moabite women into the camp of Israel.80 Scripture’s meaning is that God is not like a man that he should repent (v. 19), for He did not see iniquity in Israel. However, if there be iniquity in Israel, then God’s word will not come to pass, for all of God’s words are conditional unless accompanied by an oath. Compare, At one instant I may speak concerning a nation…to build and to plant…but if it do evil in My sight…then I repent of the good, wherewith I said I would benefit it. (Jer. 18:7-10). This is the meaning of Balaam’s statement.

NEITHER HATH ONE SEEN PERVERSENESS IN ISRAEL.81 Scripture repeats itself.82 The word amal (perverseness) is brother to aven (iniquity). Amal (perverseness) is so called because iniquity (aven) ultimately leads to it. Look, as long as God does not see iniquity in Jacob, He is with Israel.83
AND THE SHOUTING FOR84 THE KING IS AMONG THEM. In the camp of Israel. The reference is to and when ye blow an alarm (tru’ah) (Num. 10:5).85
22. GOD WHO BROUGHT THEM FORTH OUT OF EGYPT. This God who brought them out of Egypt is mighty and showed his miracles in Egypt.

LIKE THE LOFTY HORNS OF THE WILD-OX. Ke-to’afot re’em (like the lofty horns of the wild-ox) is similar to karne re’em (the horns of the wild-ox) (Deut. 33:17).86 The meaning of to’afot is, the might of.87 To’afot (the heights of) in The heights of the mountain are His also (Ps. 95:4) is similar.88 It is also possible that the meaning89 of ve-to’afot harim lo (the heights of the mountains are His) is, the horns of the mountains are also His.90 The meaning of ve-kehsef to’afot lakh (and precious silver unto thee) (Job 22:25) is, and silver, as mighty as the mountains.91 Scripture reads lo (to him). [It means to them.] Compare, and the shouting for the King is among them (v. 21). It means that this God made Israel strong. God did all this for them because Israel cleaves to God and does not seek anything from anyone but the Lord, for they have no need for an enchanter and a diviner.
23. NOW IT IS SAID OF JACOB. Ka-et (now) is to be rendered, like this time.92 Its meaning is: at all times it will be told to them without the assistance of an enchanter.93

WHAT HATH GOD WROUGHT. Mah pa’al el (what hath God wrought) is to be rendered, what God shall do. All things decreed, even those decreed for the future, are decreed in the past. Hence Scripture employs a perfect (pa’al).94 This will be told to Israel prophetically. What is told in prophecy is the truth.
OF JACOB AND OF ISRAEL. Scripture repeats itself in a prophetic utterance. Compare, From the top of Senir and Hermon (Song of Songs 4:8).95

24. BEHOLD A PEOPLE THAT RISETH UP AS A LIONESS. This hints that Israel will conquer the kings of Canaan. It seems most logical to interpret it this way regarding a soon-to-occur event,96 such as the war against Midian.97 A war like it was unprecedented. No Israelites were lost in this war98 and five kings died in it,99 along with thirty-two thousand females who never slept with a man.100

AND DRINK THE BLOOD OF THE SLAIN. The spoil and all their wealth.101 According to the midrashic interpretation it means that Moses would not die until he ate of the prey.102 Scripture similarly reads: Afterward shalt thou be gathered unto thy people (Num. 31:2).
27. THAT THOU MAYEST CURSE ME THEM. Ve-kabbota (that thou mayest curse) comes from a double root.103 Compare, ve-sabboti ani (therefore I turned) (Eccles. 2:20).104
28. UNTO THE TOP OF PEOR. Balaam did not seek to use sorcery, so God’s spirit came upon him. Balaam acted like this because he saw that there is no enchantment with Jacob (Num. 23:23).
chapter.ftnote: 1 The seventh day is holy.
2 Rosh Ha-Shanah falls on the first day of the seventh month.
3 The seventh year is a sabbatical year. The year of jubilee similarly follows seven sabbatical years.
4 Offered on the new moon and the festivals, with the exception of Sukkot. See Num. 28 and 29. On Sukkot, 14 lambs (2 times 7) were offered daily as a burnt offering.
5 On Yom Kippur and on the leper. See Lev. 16:14; 14:7. All of these are among these secrets.
6 Seven is a complete number.
7 To seven. When seven bullocks are added to seven lambs and placed on seven altars. Or when seven animals are sacrificed to God the complete, the celebrant is prophetically inspired.
8 In the celebrant; i.e., he is prophetically inspired.
9 Literally, a bullock and a ram on the altar.
10 Balaam built seven altars. It is unlikely that he built seven altars and used only one. Hence I.E.’s comment.
11 Balaam used all seven altars. However, Scripture tells us what he offered on one of the altars.
12 Thus yikkareh means will meet me.
13 Hebrew, devar mah.

14 Even though the word mah is connected by hyphen to yareni (He showeth me), for the word devar is in the construct. If the word were in the absolute it would be vocalized davar. Thus our text should be read, u-devar-mah yareni (And whatsoever He showeth me), rather than u-devar mah-yareni. (And a thing of, what will He show me). The term devar means “thing of.” Mah literally means what.
15 Onkelos renders our clause, and he went alone.
16 That is, it is not found again in Scripture.
17 These commentaries render our clause: And he went with a broken heart.
19 Is. 49:9. See I.E. on Is. 49:9. It should be pointed out that our texts of Is. 49:9 do not spell the word with an alef.
20 It is sometimes spelled with an alef, and other times with a yod.
21 Our text should be read as if written va-elekh el shefi. Our texts reads va-elekh shefi, which literally means, and he went to high place. Hence I.E.’s comment.
22 This should be read as if written va-yavo el yerushalayim (and he came to Jerusalem), for the literal meaning of va-yavo yerushalayim is, and he came Jerusalem.
23 This should be read as if written nase’u ha-am el hazerot (the people journeyed unto Hazeroth), for nase’u ha-am hazerot means the people journeyed Hazeroth.
24 Where the preposition el has to be added to the text.
25 I.E. does not describe the divination which Balaam employed. He may have cast lots, read the entrails of sacrificed animals, interpreted clouds, or the like.
26 To the mountain.
27 Which implies that until then he divined.
28 Divining.
29 That Balaam practiced enchantment using the number seven.
30 He commanded Balak to build these altars and place the offerings on them. See verse 1.
31 Verses 7 and 8 are not parables.
32 The word kedem can also mean old.
33 Our verse should be read as if written, And he said: Come curse me Jacob, and come…
34 And come execrate Israel repeats Come curse me Jacob.
35 Zo’amah is vocalized with a cholam.
36 Zokrah is vocalized with a short kamatz.
37 Of zo’amah.
38 Rather than with a sheva.
39 The word is spelled kabboh rather than kabbo. The latter is the usual form. Hence I.E.’s comment.
40 The word is written oholoh rather than the more usual oholo.
41 Rather than fe’aro.
42 Its root is kaf, bet, bet.
43 In the perfect.
44 From the root samekh, bet, bet. Both double root letters are present in savevu.
45 The word savevo is not found in Scripture (Krinsky). The form used is sevavuhu (I Kings 5:17). For other interpretations see Filwarg and Meijler.
46 The second half of our verse repeats the first half.
47 I.E. assumes that the wilderness is a flat area.
48 Which he previously faced.
49 See I.E. on verse 3.
50 For Scripture contrasts midbar (wilderness), which is a flat area, with sefi. Thus sefi must refer to an elevated area.
51 Which came to him from on high.
52 Because of its insignificance, but not a large one whose number is like the sand.
53 I.E. interprets rova (stock) as a quarter. The camp of Israel was divided into four standards (Num 2:1-31). Thus a quarter of Israel was one standard.
54 The idea of our verse is, who can count even part of Israel.
55 Onkelos renders yesharim as the honest.
56 According to this interpretation Balaam made two requests: to die the death of the righteous and to be granted a share in the world to come.
57 According to this interpretation Balaam had one request, to die the death of Israel. The Bible merely repeats itself.
58 Rabbi Saadiah Gaon.
59 For Balaam would not say to God, You who are able to count a standard of Israel after saying, You who are able to count the dust of Israel.
60 They interpret our verse as follows: Who can count Israel when Israel camps; Who can count Israel when Israel journeys.
61 When Scripture wants to emphasize a point, it repeats the verb. It does so by placing the infinitive form first and then the appropriate verb next. See Gen. 31:30; Ex. 19:5; and Jud. 15:2.
62 In the imperative the infinitive comes first and the imperative second. See Is. 6:9.
63 Here the infinitive (barekh) comes last.
64 Here too the infinitive (vo) comes last.
65 The word should have read ve-kavnu, for that is the rule when a nun vav is used to indicate the pronoun.
66 It is vocalized similarly.
67 A prefix is placed before the verb in the imperfect.
68 The pronoun him is represented by a cholam only when a heh vav or a nun vav is not used to indicate the pronoun.
69 These are examples of verbs in the imperfect combined with the pronoun.
70 Thus the nun is not a sign of the pronoun. The word kovno is similar to yirdefo; i.e., the pronoun is represented by a cholam.
71 We do not find the imperative combined with the pronoun him signified by a vav (Filwarg).
72 The second part of the last clause repeats its first part.
73 Here beno means son of, not his son.
74 Le-mayeno in this verse means a fountain of, not a fountain.
75 He therefore told him now that God is not a man and consequently does not alter His words.
76 It refers to His word.
77 Literally, blessing.
78 Scripture employs an infinitive (barekh) with the meaning of a noun (borakhah). The meaning of our clause is, I have taken a blessing; i.e., God has given me a blessing.
79 I.E. renders this as: He (God) did not see iniquity in Israel.
80 Therefore Balaam reasoned that it would pay for Balak to send Moabite women to the camp of Israel in order to make them sin. See Num. 25:1-3.
81 I.E. renders this as: Neither hath He (God) seen perverseness in Israel.
82 Neither hath He (God) seen perverseness in Israel repeats, He (God) did not see iniquity in Israel
83 I.E.’s interpretation of The Lord God is with him…
84 Hebrew, tru’at.
85 Shouting refers to the sounding of the shofar in honor of God (tru’at.). The word used for shouting in our verse is tru’at. Hence I.E.’s comment.
86 In other words, re’em refers to an animal.
87 The horns represent the might of the animal.
88 According to I.E., Ps. 95:4 should be rendered: the might of the mountain are also His.
89 The literal meaning of.
90 Horns representing might. There is no difference in meaning between the two interpretations. They only differ with regard to the literal meaning of to’afot.
91 See I.E. on Job 22:25. To’afot is short for to’afot harim (might of the mountains).
92 The literal meaning of ka-et is, like a time. I.E. explains that this means like this time.
93 What God will do.
94 For what God will do.
95 Senir and Hermon refer to the same mountain. See Deut. 3:9.
96 That it relates to a war that occurred prior to the conquest of Canaan.
98 See Num. 31:49.
101 The wealth of the slain. See Num. 31:11.
102 Moses wouldn’t die until he first defeated and looted the Midianites.
103 Its root is kof, bet, bet.
104 Sabboti comes from the root samekh, bet, bet.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 24
chapter.p: 1. BUT HE SET HIS FACE TOWARD THE WILDERNESS. Where Israel was, in the plains of Moab.
2. DWELLING TRIBE BY TRIBE. He saw all the standards.1
Some say that Balaam had a diabolical eye. Such people are called evildoers. Balaam did evil by employing his diabolic eye. I have already made my opinion known to you.2
3. AND HE TOOK UP HIS PARABLE.3 This means he lifted up his voice and uttered his parable. The parable was, As valleys stretched out4 (v. 6).
THE SAYING OF. The word ne’um means the saying of. Compare, va-yimamu ne’um (and say: He saith) (Jer. 23:31).

Some say that who heareth and also Who seeth means who hears and who sees by divination. However, it most likely refers to that which is heard and seen in a prophetic dream. Compare Eliphaz’s statement, A form was before mine eyes; I heard a still voice (Job 4:16).5

WHOSE EYE IS OPENED. The word shetum (opened) has no brother.6 It can be interpreted only in context. Shetum is the opposite of setum (shut).7 Some say that Balaam had only one eye.8 However, this is a midrashic interpretation.
4. FALLEN DOWN. Compare, a deep sleep fell upon Abram (Gen. 15:12).9
YET WITH OPENED EYES. Even though he sleeps, he sees with his eyes. Compare, [I sleep] but my heart waketh (Cant. 5:2).
5. HOW GOODLY. Tovu (goodly) is a verb in the perfect. It is similar to oru (are brightened) in how mine eyes have brightened (I Sam. 14:29).
6. STRETCHED OUT. The tet of nittayu (stretched out) rceives a dagesh to compensate for the nun of natah (stretched),10 which is swallowed.11
Scripture reads stretched out because there are rivers that turn here and there and have trees over them.
AS ALOES. Ahalim (aloes) is similar to the word ahalot (aloes) in myrrh, and aloes (Ps. 45:9).12 Note, Balaam compares the tents13 to stretched-out rivers.14
AS CEDARS. Scripture repeats itself.15 Balaam mentions cedars in the sense of He shall grow like a cedar in Lebanon (Ps. 92:13).
7. WATER SHALL FLOW. Look, mayim is in the singular.16 Compare, the water of (mai) sprinkling was not dashed (zorak)17 against him (Num. 19:13).
FROM HIS BRANCHES. Dalyo (his branches) is similar to daliyyotav (his branches) (Jer. 11:16).
AND HIS SEED SHALL BE IN MANY WATERS. Like seed saturated with water. This means he shall flourish and grow every day.
AND HIS KING SHALL BE HIGHER THAN AGAG. This is a prophecy regarding Saul, Israel’s first king, for prior to Saul there were judges but no kings.

8. GOD WHO BROUGHT HIM FORTH. The meaning of our verse is: the God who brought him [Israel] out of Egypt made him as powerful as the lofty horns of the wild-ox. Let not the one who would dispute this claim that the word him18 refers to God, because Scripture earlier used the plural form motzi’am (brought them forth) when it stated, God who brought them forth (Num. 23:22).19 For such is the style of Scripture.20 Compare, And they21 sit at Thy feet; he22 receives (yissa) Thy words (Deut. 33:3); and How long will this (ha-zeh)23 people despise Me (yena’atzuni)24 (Num. 14:11). There are many such instances.
HE SHALL EAT UP THE NATIONS THAT ARE HIS ADVERSARIES. The reference is to the kings of Canaan.

AND SHALL BREAK THEIR BONES IN PIECES. Garem means a bone. Yigarem means he shall break their bones.25 The word itzemo26 (hath broken his bones) (Jer. 50:17) is similar. So too is the word mesa’ef27 (shall lop) in Shall lop the boughs with terror (Is. 10:33) and tefa’er28 (go over the boughs) in thou shalt not go over the boughs (Deut. 24 :20).29

AND PIERCE THEM THROUGH WITH HIS ARROWS. Each one of his arrows shall pierce.30 So too, But the righteous are secure as a young lion (Prov. 28:1);31 Its branches run over the wall (Gen. 49:22); Blessed be every one that blesseth thee (v. 9).32 The latter means, everyone that blesses you wil be blessed. So too, and cursed be everyone that curseth thee (Ibid.).
9. HE COUCHED. The meaning of our verse is: Israel will inherit Canaan, after which the land will be quiet.
SHALL ROUSE HIM UP. I have already explained this.33
10. AND HE SMOTE HIS HANDS TOGETHER. Va-yispok (and he smote) is similar to safeku (clap) in All that pass by clap Their hands at thee (Lam. 2:15).

14. AND I WILL ANNOUNCE34 TO THEE. Some say that its meaning is: I will advise you with regard to the daughters of Moab. However, this is far-fetched, for Scripture says, in the end of days.35 I believe that we should take it according to its plain meaning; namely, I will advise you, so that you know what you should do, for this people will do this to your people.36
16. AND KNOWETH THE KNOWLEDGE OF THE MOST HIGH. By prophecy, not through enchantment.
17. I SEE HIM, BUT NOT NOW. It appears to me that this prophecy refers to King David. Balaam said but not now, for it referred to an event four hundred years later.
I BEHOLD HIM, BUT NOT NIGH. Scripture repeats itself.37 The star and the sceptre are the parable.
THERE SHALL STEP FORTH A STAR. There are images of stars that step forth in the sky that never existed and were never known.38
AND A SCEPTRE39 SHALL ARISE. The reference is to a royal sceptre.
I believe that shall step means that the star shall be seen making its way, as in The stars in their courses (Jud. 5:20). Many explained that the reference is to the messiah.

The ancients said that Sanherib40 mixed up the nations.41 However, note that Scripture speaks of Moab, Amalek, and Asshur.42 Furthermore, why does Balaam conclude with and shall afflict Eber (v. 24)?43 On the contrary, Balaam should have ended his parable with There shall step forth a star out of Jacob.44

Those who lack intelligence think that anyone who explains that There shall step forth a star refers to King David denies the coming of the messiah.45 Far be it, far be it, for the messiah is clearly stated in the prophecy of Daniel. I have already explained that Daniel first mentions the coming into existence of the Greek kings46 and the arising of the Hasmoneans. He mentions the existence of the second temple, the years of the siege, the exile, and the salvation. He notes these things in order.

There is no conceivable need for another prophet,47 since we have the words of Moses, who is the most important prophet: If any of thine that are dispersed be in the uttermost parts of heaven… the Lord thy God will bring thee (Deut. 30:4,5).48
AND SHALL SMITE THROUGH THE CORNERS OF MOAB. This is what David did.49
AND BREAK DOWN. The word karkar (break down) is similar to mekarkar kir (Is. 22:5), the meaning of which is, breaking the wall. It is similar to the word mesa’ef (shall lop) (Is. 10:33).50
THE SONS OF SETH. People. Seth was the most important son of Adam, for Noah was descended from him.

Yitzchaki51 says that the reference is to the Amonites and the Moabites, and that Scripture repeats itself.52 He also says that the word Seth is derived from the word shet (buttocks) in and with buttocks uncovered (Is. 20:4) and that it alludes to the daughters53 of Lot.54 However, this appears to me to be farfetched, for shet refers to the backside,55 which is the foundation of the body.56 Compare, ki ha-shatot yeharesun (When the foundations are destroyed) (Ps. 11:3).

Many others have explained that the word shet (Seth) in all the sons of Seth, is related to the word ha-shatot (foundations) in When the foundations are destroyed. It means that the cities will be destroyed.57 This interpretation is not far-fetched.
18. AND EDOM SHALL BE A POSSESSION. The word yereshah (possession) is related to the word torishu (drive out)58 in But if ye will not drive out (Num. 33:55).59

Yereshah is a noun vocalized according to the pattern of the word levenah (tile) in take thee a tile (Ezek. 4:1). It is in place of an adjective. Compare the word shemamah (desolation) in and it shall be a desolation (Is. 17:9).60 We know that David’s hand overpowered Edom61 and Mount Seir.62
19. AND OUT OF JACOB SHALL ONE HAVE DOMINION.63 A ruler shall arise out of Jacob.
AND SHALL DESTROY THE REMNANT FROM THE CITY. From every city.64 Its meaning is, from Edom. The reference is to Joab, for Scripture clearly states, and had smitten every male in Edom (I Kings 11:15).

20. AND HE LOOKED ON AMALEK. Via prophecy.65 The first of the nations is the parable. It means Amalek was the first nation to wage war against Israel, but his end shall be utter destruction. This66 took place in the days of Saul, who slew man and woman, infant and suckling (I Sam. 15:3) and old men.
Many explain that the meaning of the first of the nations is that Amalek was considered to be the head of the nations. However, this was not the case.67
21. AND HE LOOKED ON THE KENITE.68 The family of Jethro. Scripture writes, These are the Kenites (I Chron. 2:55) and Now Heber the Kenite (Jud. 4:11).69
And though thy nest be set in the rock is the parable.70 The latter repeats the preceding clause.71 Its meaning is, though your dwelling place be as high as the nest of a bird, it will not save you.

22. KAIN SHALL BE WASTED. Le-va’er (wasted) is similar to the word le-va’er (eaten up) in it shall again be eaten up (Is. 6:13); and yeva’er (sweepeth) in as a man sweepeth away dung (I Kings 14:10); and u-vi’arta (so shalt thou put away) in So shalt thou put away the evil from thee (Deut. 13:6).72 Kain and the Kenite are one and the same.

[HOW LONG? ASSHUR SHALL CARRY THEE AWAY CAPTIVE.] Balaam, as it were, said: How long shall Asshur carry thee73 away captive? He will not let go of you until you are wasted. Asshur is feminine. Asshur is short for the camp of Asshur. Compare, va-tipple sheva va-tikkachem (and the Sabeans made a raid) (Job 1:15); Va-ta’arokh yisra’el (and Israel…put the battle in array) (I Sam. 17:21).
23. AND HE TOOK UP HIS PARABLE, AND SAID. The reference is to But ships shall come from the coast of Kittim (v. 24).

When Balaam mentioned that the Kenite would be carried away captive, he also said that a time would come when Asshur would be afflicted and Eber along with him. The latter refers to the Hebrews that Asshur carried away captive, for the Kenites lived with the Israelites.
The interpretation of the Aramaic translation is well known.74 However, it is not the practice of Scripture to mention the word ever without the word nahar (river) following it.75

Some explain that tzim (ships) is a plural. It is related to the word tzi (ship) in gallant ship (Is. 33:21). Others say that the word tzim is related to the word tziyim (wild-cats) in And the wild-cats shall meet with the jackals (Is. 34:14). Balaam compared the Kittim to wild-cats because people will be gripped by fear when they appear.76

[ALAS, WHO SHALL LIVE AFTER GOD HATH APPOINTED HIM.] The reference is to the king of Asshur who made himself into a god. The latter is noted in the Book of Isaiah.77 Or its meaning is: Who shall survive the decrees which God placed in the world via Asshur, for the king of Assyria conquered all the nations. The latter is clearly stated in Scripture.

24. OF KITTIM. They are descended from Javin, for the latter is clearly stated in Scripture (Gen. 10:4). It is also possible that Scripture alludes to the kingdom of the Greeks. I have already explained in the Book of Daniel, that the kingdom of the Greeks and that of the Kittim are one and the same.78 There is clear proof that it is the third beast.79
FROM THE COAST OF KITTIM. Mi-yad (from the coast of) means from the place. Compare the word yad in the side (yad) of the Jordan (Num. 13:29) and Thou shalt have a place (Deut. 23:13).
AND ALSO HE. The Kittim. Kittim is singular even though it comes in the plural form. And the sons of Javan: Elishah, and Tarshish, Kittim (Gen. 10:4) is proof of this.
25. AND BALAAM ROSE UP. For he was lying down. A deep sleep had fallen over him. Scripture clearly states, Fallen down, yet with opened eyes (v. 16).
chapter.ftnote: 1 He saw Israel camped around their standards.
2 See I.E. on Num. 22:28.
3 Hebrew, va-yissa meshalo va-yomar, literally, and he lifted up his parable and said. Hence I.E.’s comment.
4 The parable ends with verse 9. What comes before is a description, not a parable.
5 Eliphaz was describing a vision he had when asleep.
6 It does not occur elsewhere in Scripture.
7 Thus shetum ha-ayin means whose eye is opened.
8 See Rashi.
9 In other words, fallen down means fallen down in sleep.
10 In other words, nittayu comes from the root nun, tet, heh.
11 Nittayu is a nifal. Its nun is the nun of the nifal form, not the nun of the root. If the nun of the root were present, the word would read nintayu.
12 Even though ahalim (aloes) is in the masculine and ahalot (aloes) in the feminine.
13 Of Israel.
14 Next to which cedar and aloe trees are planted.
15 Cedars are parallel to aloes.
16 Even though mayim is a plural form. The word yizzal (shall flow), which modifies mayim (water), is in the singular. Hence I.E. comment.
17 Zorak, which modifies mayim, is in the singular. See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 (Vol. 1, p. 31).
18 The reference is to the word lo (him) in the clause Is for him like the lofty horns of the wild-ox.

19 Num. 23:22 literally reads: God who brought them forth out of Egypt, for Him (lo) like the lofty horns of the wild-ox. Our verse reads: God who brought him out of Egypt, for him (lo) like the lofty horns of the wild-ox. Now, just as the word lo (him) in the first verse applies to God, so must the word lo (him) in the second verse apply to God.
20 To refer to the nation of Israel both in the singular and in the plural in one verse. Thus the word lo in Num. 23:22 applies to Israel and similarly in our verse.
21 Israel.
22 Israel; translated literally.
23 Zeh (this) is in the singular.
24 Yena’atzuni (will despise me).
25 Garem means a bone. The verb formed from this root means to break a bone.
26 A verb related to the noun etzem (bone).
27 A verb related to the word se’if (bough).
28 A verb related to the noun pe’er (bough).
29 All of these verbs mean to destroy whatever their noun roots refer to.

30 According to I.E. when a verb in the singular governs a noun in the plural, the verb refers to each one within the plural (see Vol. 1, p. XVII). In our verse the word chitzav (arrows) is in the plural, and yimchatz (pierce), the verb which governs it, is in the singular. Hence I.E.’s comment.
31 It means that each one of the righteous is secure as a young lion, for tzadikim (the righteous) is in the plural while yivtach (is secure) is in the singular.
32 Barukh (blessed be) is in the singular; me-varekhekha (they that bless thee) is in the plural. Similarly, korerekha is in the plural, and arur is in the singular.
33 “After a lion tears its prey it sits on its knees and crouches in security and no other passing animal will cause it to get up and flee” (I.E. on Gen. 49:8, Vol. 1, p. 429).
34 Hebrew, iyatzekha, literally, I will advise thee.
35 So it cannot refer to an event that was to happen soon.
36 In the end of days.
37 I behold him, but not nigh repeats, I see him, but not now.
38 New stars appear that were never known. I.E. is probably referring to comets. His point is that the king referred to in our verse shall suddenly appear.
39 Hebrew, shevet (a rod). Hence I.E.’s comment.
40 An Assyrian king who lived in the eighth century.
41 See Yoma 54a.
42 Thus our verse deals with the pre-Sanherib period. Therefore it cannot pertain to the messiah.
43 Eber refers to the Israelites. If Balaam’s prophecy refers to the messiah, why does he conclude with the affliction of Israel? Israel will not be afflicted in the messianic era.
44 For that is what will take place in the messianic era after Israel is afflicted.

45 For “those who lack intelligence” believe that this verse is necessary for belief in the coming of the messiah. Therefore one who interprets this verse as referring to King David denies the coming of the messiah.
46 The kingdoms of the Greeks.
47 We would know about the coming of the messiah even if we did not have the Book of Daniel.

48 Back to the Land of Israel. In other words, although our verse does not allude to the messiah, Deuteronomy does. I.E. notes this because he wants to show that Moses predicted the coming of the messiah.
49 See II Sam. 8:2.
50 In that the verbal form of the noun means to destroy what the noun stands for. See I.E. on verse 8 and the notes thereto.
51 See I.E. on Gen. 36:31 and the notes thereto.
52 Sons of Seth is another term for the Moabites.
53 The ancestresses of the Moabites and the Ammonites. See Gen. 19:37,38.
54 Their father, whose nakedness his daughters uncovered. See Gen. 19:30-38.
55 While Lot’s daughters uncovered his front. The point is, Scripture would not allude to intercourse by employing the phrase “uncovering the buttocks.”
56 In other words, the basic meaning of shet is foundation, not buttock.
57 According to this interpretation, ve-karkar kol bene shet (and break down all the sons of Seth) means: and will break down all foundations.
58 I.E. renders torishu destroy. See I.E. on Ex. 15:9.
59 I.E. renders ve-hayah edom yereshah (And Edom shall be a possession) as, and Edom shall be destroyed.
60 Here too Scripture employs a noun (shemamah) in place of an adjective (shomemah).
61 See II Sam. 8:14.
62 Edom’s abode.
63 Hebrew, ve-yerd mi-ya’akov, literally, and a ruler from Jacob. Hence I.E.’s comment.
64 From city (me-ir) is short for from every city.
65 He did not actually look at Amalek.
66 The destruction of Amalek.
67 Amalek was never the chief of the nations.
68 The father-in-law of Moses.

69 The verse reads, Now Heber the Kenite had severed himself from the Kenites, even from the children of Hobab the father-in-law of Moses. This shows that the Kenites are descended from Moses’ father-in-law.
70 Mentioned earlier in the verse.
71 And though thy nest be set in the rock repeats Though firm be thy dwelling place.
72 In other words, le-va’er means to destroy.
73 The Kenites.
74 Onkelos renders ever (Eber) by ever perat (the other side of the Euphrates).
75 When referring to the other side of the Euphrates.
76 These commentators explain our verse as follows: wild-cats shall come from the land of Kittim.
77 See Is. 10:7. Isaiah did not actually say this. He intimated that the king of Assyria, in destroying nations, acted like a god.
78See I.E. on Dan. 2:39. Some texts read aram instead of kittim. Aram stands for the Romans. See I.E. on Dan. 2:39.
79 See Dan. 7:6.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 25
chapter.p: 1. IN SHITTIM. For Scripture clearly states, And they pitched by the Jordan, from Beth-jeshimoth even unto Abel-shittim (Num. 33:49).1 Everything took place in the plains of Moab, for Israel did not move from there.2 Also, Joshua sent spies from there (Josh. 2:1).
[AND THE PEOPLE BEGAN.] I believe that va-yachel (began) is a hifil.
2. AND BOWED DOWN. Israel and the daughters of Moab.3

3. AND ISRAEL JOINED HIMSELF. The word va-yitzamed is related to the word tzemed (yoke) in a yoke of oxen (I Sam. 11:7). The reference is to the Moabite women; that is, Israel was joined with the women in the religion of pe’or.
4. AND HANG THEM. The reference is to those who were joined.4 The proof text is, And Moses said unto the judges of Israel (v. 5).5

AND HANG THEM. Ve-hoka otam (and hang them) is similar to va-yaki’um (and they hanged them) in and they hanged them in the mountain (II Sam. 21:9). It is to be understood in accordance with the words of the Aramaic translation.6 The proof text is, In the face of the sun.7 The meaning of in the face of the sun is, in public. Compare, in the sight of this sun (II Sam. 12:11).8
5. SLAY YE EVERY ONE HIS MEN. From whatever tribe they may be. It is known that they slew,9 even though Scripture does not mention this.10
6. AND BROUGHT UNTO HIS BRETHREN. He gave her to his family.
WHILE THEY WERE WEEPING. Praying to God.
7. AND WHEN PHINEHAS…SAW. When Phinehas saw this, he rose up from the midst of the congregation, which was in the courtyard of the tent of meeting.
There is a question here.11 It is possible to answer that Zimri (v. 14) was joined12 in the presence of witnesses.

8. INTO THE CHAMBER. El ha-kubbah (into the chamber) means into the tent. The word has a similar meaning in Arabic, although there is a difference in shape between an ohel (tent) and a kubbah (chamber).13
AND THRUST. Va-yidkor (and thrust) is similar to ve-dokreni (thrust me) in and thrust me through therewith (I Sam. 31:4).14
THROUGH HER BELLY. El kovatah (through her belly) means in the chamber, that is, in the chamber where she was with Zimri’s brothers.
Others say that the word that kovatah is related to is the word kevah (maw) in the shoulder, and the two cheeks, and the maw (Deut. 18:3).15
There is also a midrashic statement to the effect that ten miracles were performed for Phinehas.16 However, Scripture does not mention them.

11. IN THAT HE WAS VERY JEALOUS FOR MY SAKE AMONG THEM. There is no dagesh in the nun of be-kano (in that he was very jealous) in order to simplify enunciation.17 It means that Phinehas was jealous like his creator.18 Scripture tells us that God is a jealous God (Ex. 20:5) when it comes to idolatry.
[SO THAT I CONSUMED NOT THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL IN MY JEALOUSY.] If Phinehas had not been jealous for My sake, then I would have destroyed all of Israel in My jealousy.
12. MY COVENANT OF PEACE. The meaning of beriti shalom (My covenant of peace) is:19 My covenant, a covenant of peace.20 Compare, Thy throne God21 (Ps. 45:7).22 There are many such cases.23
Its meaning is that Phinehas should not fear the brothers of Zimri for Zimri24 was a prince of a father’s house (v. 14).
Phinehas was rewarded with the covenant of priesthood for himself and his seed forever, for all the high priests were descendants of Phinehas. It is possible that Eleazar25 had other sons.26

The word acharav (after him) (v. 13)27 is proof that Phinehas died and is in no way to be identified with Elijah.28 I have already explained it.29 Phinehas was ruler over them [Israel] (I Chron. 9:20). He was alive during the incident of the concubine from Gibeah.30

13. BECAUSE HE WAS JEALOUS FOR HIS GOD. He acted out of his love for God. He also did good for Israel.31 According to the midrashic interpretation, the father32 atoned and the children33 will atone.34
14. WHO WAS SLAIN WITH THE MIDIANITISH WOMAN. Et ha-midyanit is to be rendered, with the Midianitish woman.35 There are many such instances.36
A PRINCE OF A FATHER’S HOUSE AMONG THE SIMEONITES. One of the five fathers’ [houses] of the children of Simeon.37 The head of his father’s house was greater than he.38
15. ZUR. Zur was one of the kings of Midian. Note, each of the five kings of Midian ruled over a house.
17. HARASS. Tzaror (harass) is an infinitive.39 It is like the word zakhor40 (remember) in Remember the sabbath day, to keep it holy.
18. FOR THEY HARASS YOU. Ki tzorerim41 hem lakhem (for they harass you) is to be rendered: for they harassed you.
BY THEIR WILES. Be-nikhlehem (by their wiles) means by their evil thoughts. Be-nikhlehem is related to the word va-yitnakkelu (they conspired) in they conspired against him (Gen. 37:18).42
AND IN THE MATTER OF COZBI. Furthermore, they intend to harm you because of what happened to Cozbi their sister.
chapter.ftnote: 1 In other words, Israel was in Shittim during the incident of Balaam. They did not journey there after the incident.
2 Until Israel crossed the Jordan and entered Canaan.
3 Our verse reads: And the people did eat (va-yokhal), and bowed down (va-yishtachavu). Va-yokhal is in the singular. Va-yishtachavu is in the plural. Hence I.E.’s comment.
4 Not to the chiefs of the people. The text is vague. Hence I.E.’s comment.
5 I.E. identifies the chiefs with the judges.

6 Onkelos renders u-ketol de-chayyav ketol: execute those who are guilty of a capital crime. However, I.E.’s reference might be to Targum Jonathan, who renders ve-hiki’um, u-tzelovinun as, and hang them (Krinsky). However, it should also be noted that u-tzelovinun can also be rendered, and crucify them.
7 That the reference is to public execution. For they were hung in the mountain so that all in the vicinity could see them executed.
8 The entire clause reads, and he shall lie with thy wives in the sight of this sun. The next verse continues, but I will do this thing before all Israel, and before the sun.
9 Those who worshipped pe’or.
10 That the judges slew those who worshipped pe’or.
11 Why did Phinehas kill Zimri? Scripture does not tell us that Zimri worshipped pe’or (Weiser).
12 With Cozbi in the worship of pe’or.
13 Between what the Hebrews refer to as an ohel and the Arabic kubbah.
14 In other words, va-yidkor means and he thrust.
15 In other words, kovatah means her belly.
16 The Sifre and Tanchuma on our Torah portion list 12 miracles.
17 Kano is in the pi’el. The middle root letters in the pi’el receive a dagesh. Hence I.E.’s comment.
18 Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: He acted jealously in My place.
19 The literal meaning of beriti shalom is: My covenant peace. “Of” is not in the Hebrew text. Hence I.E.’s comment.
20 In other words, beriti shalom should be read as if written beriti, berit shalom.
21 Translated literally.
22 Which should be read as if written, Thy throne, throne of God. See I.E. on Num. 12:6.
23 Where a word is missing in the Biblical text and has to be supplied by the reader.
24 Who came from a powerful family which might avenge his death.
25 Who served as high priest after the passing of Aaron. See Num. 20:22-29.
26 The high priesthood would in any case have been passed on through Phinehas.
27 The phrase “after him” means after his death.
28 Who did not die. Some of the rabbis believe that Phinehas is Elijah. See Yalkut Shimoni on the Torah portion, Phinehas.
29 See Jud. 20:28.
30 See Judges, chapters 19-21. These citations, which occurred before the story of Elijah, prove that Phinehas could not be Elijah.
31 I.E.’s paraphrase of and made atonement for the children of Israel.
32 Phinehas.
33 Phinehas’s descendants.
34 Hence the connection between an everlasting priesthood and because he…made atonement for the children of Israel.
35 In other words, et here means with.
36 Where et has the meaning of with. See I.E. on Ex. 1:1 (Vol. 2, p. 3).

38 The tribe of Simeon was divided into five branches, each of which was called a father’s house. Zimri was a prince of one of the five branches of the tribe of Simeon (Num. 1:4). Midian was similarly divided into five houses.
39 It is vocalized with a kamatz. An imperative is vocalized with a sheva.
40 Which is also vocalized with a kamatz rather than with a sheva.
41 Tzorerim is a present form. However, Scripture tells of what the Midianites did to the Israelites. Hence I.E.’s comment.
42 Both words come from the same root, nun, kaf, lamed.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 26
chapter.p: 1. AND IT CAME TO PASS AFTER THE PLAGUE.1 God spoke to Moses. He also spoke to Eleazar via Moses.2 And Moses and the elders of Israel commanded the people3 (Deut. 27:1) and Then sang Moses and the children of Israel4 (Ex. 15:1) are similar.
Scripture states after the plague because God said, Unto these5 the land shall be divided (v. 53).
3. AND MOSES AND ELEAZAR THE PRIEST SPOKE. In place of his father.6 It is possible that Eleazar served as Moses’ spokesman as Aaron did.7
WITH THEM. Otam (with them)8 is similar to dabbero (speak…unto him) in speak peaceably unto him (Gen. 37:4).9
4. FROM TWENTY YEARS OLD AND UPWARD. This means that they took the sum of the people10 as God commanded Moses.

[AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL, THAT CAME FORTH OUT OF THE LAND OF EGYPT.] Scripture states the aforementioned because there were many among those who were numbered who came out of Egypt.11 They most likely came to about half the number of the Israelites. Scripture starts with Reuben in imitation of the manner in which the Israelites12 were first numbered in the wilderness of Sinai.
9. WHO STROVE. The word hitzu (strove) is similar in meaning to the word yinnatzu (strive) in And if men strive together (Ex. 21:22).13
10. WITH KORAH. I have already explained this.14
AND THEY BECAME A SIGN.15 Compare, that they may be a sign16 unto the children of Israel (Num. 17:3).17

11. NOTWITHSTANDING THE SONS OF KORAH DIED NOT. Samuel,18 his sons, and his grandsons who were singers19 and were called the Korahites20 is proof of this.21 The Book of Psalms states, For the leader; a Psalm of the sons of Korah (Ps. 49:1). The Torah also records the family of the Korahites (v. 58).

Scripture mentions the sons of Korah with the sons of Reuben because the adult and the minor sons of Dathan and Abiram died. The wickedness of Dathan and Abiram was thus greater than the wickedness of Korah.22

12. THE JAMINITES. Do not seek grammatical consistency in names. Compare, puvvah23 and puni (Punites) (v. 23).24 From shefufam25 Scripture derives shufami (v. 39).26 Scripture also reads: of yimnah (Imnah), the family of yimnah (v. 44), not ha-yemini27 as it does in the case of bri’ah28 and beri’iy (Beriites)29 (v. 44); Chaggi30 and shuni (v. 15) lacking the yod gentile.31 On the other hand, the yod of chaggi and shuni might be the yod gentile and the yod of the proper name32 is missing. The latter is correct.

After Reuben, Scripture lists Simeon and Gad, who pitched next to Reuben.33 However, Manasseh is mentioned before Ephraim.34 The order is reversed in the wilderness of Sinai.35 It appears that this is due to their number, for the sons of Ephraim were more numerous than the sons of Manasseh in the wilderness of Sinai by eight thousand and three hundred,36 and in the plains of Moab the sons of Manasseh numbered more than the sons of Ephraim by twenty thousand and two hundred.37
No mention is made of the family of the following five sons of Benjamin: Becher, Gera, Naaman, Rosh, and Ard.38
38. OF AHIRAM.39 Ahiram40 is the same as Ehi.41 Shephupham42 is the same as Muppim,43 and Hupham44 is the same as Huppim.45
The Ard and Naaman mentioned in our verse are the sons of Bela.46 Others say that Naaman and Ard47 were among those who descended to Egypt and that they are the sons of Bela the son of Benjamin.48
[42.] OF SHUHAM. He is the same as Hushim.49
THESE ARE THE FAMILIES OF DAN AFTER THEIR FAMILIES. For hushim was divided into many families.50
55. THE LAND SHALL BE DIVIDED. It means that the land shall be divided among the tribes by lot.
[56.] ACCORDING TO THE LOT SHALL THEIR INHERITANCE BE DIVIDED BETWEEN THE MORE AND THE FEWER. To those who were numbered.51

57. OF GERSHON. Scripture opens with the first-born.52 It mentions Gershon’s son Libni. It does not mention Shimei.53 It is possible that he had no children. On the other hand, Shimei might have had children and they died childless.

Scripture then mentions the children of Hebron the son of Kohath.54 It does not name Uzziel.55 It then mentions the sons of Merari56 and goes back and refers to the sons of Itzhar.57 Then it mentions the sons of Amram.58 Scripture places them last59 because it goes on to explain what happened to the grandsons of Amram.60

58. THE KORAHITES. They are the sons of Korah.61 Scripture mentions Jochebed out of respect to her sons. It does not speak of her mother, because Scripture is being brief.62 Asriel, whom she bore63 (I Chron. 7:14) is similar.64

62. AND THEY THAT WERE NUMBERED. The Levites. The Levites increased by seven hundred in this numbering.65 It is amazing that the Levites increased by only seven hundred. Look! The Israelites from among whom all those above the age of twenty died66 numbered about the same as they did during their first numbering.67 [The small increase in the number of Levites is strange] for the Levites were not included in the numbering of Israel.68 Eleazar the Kohen proves the latter.69
64. BUT AMONG THESE THERE WAS NOT A MAN. This verse refers to the number of the children of Israel.70
65. SAVE CALEB THE SON OF JEPHUNNEH. Caleb is mentioned before Joshua,71 following God’s word.72
chapter.ftnote: 1 This line concludes chapter 25, verse 19, and continues into chapter 26, verse 1.
2 I.E.’s interpretation of: That the Lord spoke unto Moses and unto Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest…
3 Its meaning is: Moses commanded the elders, who then commanded Israel.
4 Its meaning is: Moses taught the song to the Israelites. See I.E. on Ex. 15:1 (Vol. 2, p. 291).
5 Those who survived the plague.
6 Now that Aaron was dead, Eleazar spoke God’s word to the people.
7 He not only served as spokesman in this case but did so in all other cases.
8 Otam means them. Scripture should have read ittam (with them). Hence I.E.’s comment.

9 Dabbero is irregular, for it is a compound of dabber (speak) and oto (him). Dabbero literally means speak him. We thus sees that Scripture employs the term “him” with the meaning of “with him.” The same applies to the term otam (them). Scripture occasionally employs it with the meaning of “with them.”
10 In other words, From twenty years old and upward is short for: they took up the sum of the people from twenty years old and up.
11 Those who were under the age of twenty when they left Egypt did not die in the wilderness.
12 See Num. 1:20.
13 In other words, hitzu means strove.
14 See I.E. on Num. 16:35.
15 Hebrew, nes.
16 Hebrew, ot.
17 In other words, nes here means a sign. The word nes can mean banner or miracle. Hence I.E.’s comment.
18 The prophet Samuel.
19 In the temple.
20 See I Chron. 6:18-23.
21 That Korah’s children did not die.
22 Hence their children died. When Moses asked Dathan and Abiram to come to him, they refused and insulted Moses. We do not find the same with Korah (Num. 16:12-14).
23 Puvvah the son of Issachar.
24 We would expect puvvi rather than puni to be used for a member of Puvvah’s family.
25 The son of Benjamin.
26 As the term for a member of his family. However, we would expect the term shefufami to be used.
27 Which is the correct grammatical form for a member of the family of yimnah.
28 The son of Asher.
29 The family of Beriah.
30 Chaggi and shuni were sons of Gad. Scripture refers to members of their family by the terms chaggi and shuni rather than chaggi’iy or shuni’iy.
31 These terms are thus irregular.
32 The yod of the names of chaggi and shuni.
33 And similarly the other tribes. In other words, Scripture does not list the tribes in the order of their births but by their banners. See Num. 10:11-28.
34 In verses 28-34.
36 Hence they were there mentioned first. At the census taken in the wilderness of Sinai, Ephraim numbered 40,500 (Num. 1:33) and Manasseh numbered 32,200 (Ibid., 35).
37 Hence they were mentioned first. See verses 34 and 37.
38 See Gen. 46:21.
39 There is a discrepancy between the sons of Benjamin as given in verses 38-40 and those given in Gen. 46:21. Hence I.E.’s comments.
40 In our verse.
42 In verse 39.
44 In verse 39.
46 Whereas the persons bearing the same names mentioned in Gen. 46:21 are the sons of Benjamin.
47 Mentioned in our verse.
48 In other words, they and the Naaman and Ard mentioned in Genesis are one and the same. However, Scripture omitted their father’s name in Genesis.
49 Mentioned in Gen. 46:23. There is thus no discrepancy in the names of the son of Dan.
50 Hence the family of the Shuhamites follows of Shuham (also called Hushim).
51 Those who were counted by Moses and Eleazar. See Num. 26:1,2.
52 Of Levi. See Gen. 46:11.
53 Gershon’s other son. See Ex. 6:17.
55 Son of Kohath. See Ex. 6:18.
56 The family of the Mahlites, the family of the Mushites. Mahli and Mushi were sons of Merari. See Ex. 6:19.
57 The Korahites. See Num. 16:1.
58 Amram was Kohath’s first-born. See Ex. 6:18.
59 Even though Amram was born before Hebron and Izhar.
60 In verses 60 and 61.
61 For Korah was then dead.
62 Our verse literally reads: And the name of Amram’s wife was Jochebed, the daughter of Levi, whom she bore. Scripture does not identify the one who did the bearing, i.e., Jochebed’s mother.
63 Translated literally.
64 Here too Scripture omits the subject.

65The first time the Levites were counted they numbered 22,300. See Num. 3:39 along with I.E.’s comment on it. Their number here is given as 23,000. The Levites thus increased by 700 in close to 40 years.
66 By the time the census recorded in our chapter was taken. See verse 64.
67 The number of Israelites at the first census came to 603,550 (Num. 1:46). They now numbered 601,730.

68 By God’s decree only those above the age of 20 who were numbered in the wilderness of Sinai had died by the time of the second census. See verse 64 and Num. 14:29. This decree did not fall upon the Levites.
69 Had the Levites been included in the numbering, Eleazar too would be dead, for he was most likely above the age of twenty when the first census was taken.
70 The term these refers to the number of the children of Israel.
71 Even though Joshua was more important.
72 God mentioned Caleb before Joshua in Num. 14:30.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 27
chapter.p: 3. AND HE WAS NOT AMONG THE COMPANY. The daughters1 thought that the children of those who gathered themselves together against the Lord2 would not inherit.3

BUT HE DIED IN HIS OWN SIN. Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi the Spaniard says but he died in his own sin is to be understood as connected to and he had no sons.4 It is as we say today, such and such occurred to so and so because of his sins. This interpretation is not far off.
4. BECAUSE HE HAD NO SON. Ki en lo ben is to be rendered, because he had no son.5
7. RIGHT. Ken means true.6 Or, the thing is so.7
AND THOU SHALT CAUSE THE INHERITANCE. What he should have received, they shall receive.
8. AND HAVE NO SON. This is proof that a son inherits his father’s property.
9. UNTO HIS BRETHREN. From his father or mother.
[11.] UNTO HIS KINSMAN THAT IS NEXT TO HIM. From all of his family.8
AND HE SHALL POSSESS IT. The inheritance. I have already explained the approach of the rabbis in my comments on unto a foreign people (Ex. 21:8).9
We need rabbinic tradition to know the laws of inheritance with regard to whether a father or a mother inherits a son’s property or what a woman inherits.

The rabbis of blessed memory said that the chapter that opens with the words, Get thee up into this mountain (v. 12), follows the laws of inheritance because Moses wanted to know who would inherit his position.

14. TO SANCTIFY ME. The word le-hakdesheni (to sanctify me) is connected to meritem (ye rebelled).10 Its meaning is, ye rebelled with regard to sanctifying me.11 This, I have explained,12 is the meaning of because ye sanctified Me not in the midst of the children of Israel (Deut. 32:51).
16. THE GOD OF THE SPIRITS. He knows the spirits. He knows which spirit is fit.13
[SET.] The word yifkod (set) is related to the word pakid (official).14
17. WHO MAY GO OUT BEFORE THEM. In war.
WHO MAY LEAD THEM OUT. Va-asher yotzi’em (who may lead them out) means who will direct someone else to lead them out.15
18. IN WHOM IS SPIRIT. Now all living persons have spirit in them.16 Its meaning can only be similar to that of be thou strong therefore, and show thyself a man (I Kings 2:2).17
AND LAY THY HAND UPON HIM. To show Israel that he was in Moses’ place and that he18 was the one on whom Moses had placed his hands.
20. AND THOU SHALT PUT OF THY HONOR UPON HIM. You will honor Joshua in front of all of Israel.
THAT…MAY HEARKEN. For Israel already believes in you. When they see that you honored Joshua they will respect him, for they will follow your ways.
21. AT HIS WORD SHALL THEY GO OUT. Upon the word of Eleazar by the judgment of the Urim.19 Others say, in accordance to the judgment of the Urim.20 The first interpretation appears correct to me.
BOTH HE, AND ALL THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. In regard to that which pertains to all.
EVEN ALL THE CONGREGATION. They gathered in the tent of meeting concerning a matter that pertained to the congregation.

The reason the chapter dealing with the sacrifices follows21 is that God then22 ordered Moses to command the children of Israel regarding the sacrifices they are obligated to offer,23 for Moses was not to enter the land with them.

Scripture starts with the daily burnt offering even though it was mentioned earlier.24 It is possible that the earlier burnt offering was the one offered at Mount Sinai.25 On the other hand, it is possible that Scripture wants to insure that the arrangement of the sacrifices is in order.26
chapter.ftnote: 1 Of Zelophehad.
2 In the company of Korah (Num. 16:1-19).
3 Hence they said that their father was not in Korah’s company.
4 In other words, the meaning here is: he died without sons because of his sins.
5 In other words, the meaning of ki in our verse is because. Ki has a number of meanings. Hence I.E.’s comments.
6 According to this interpretation our clause reads: The daughters of Zelophehad speak the truth (ken).
7 According this interpretation our clause reads: The facts are (ken) as the daughters of Zelophehad speak.
8 That is closest to the deceased.

9 Our verse reads, ve-yarash otah. The rabbis render this, and he (the husband) shall inherit her (otah). According to the rabbis our verse teaches that a man inherits his wife’s property but a woman does not inherit her husband’s property. See Baba Batra 111b and I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 21:8.
10 Even though these words do not follow each other.
11 Its meaning is, you rebelled against me by not sanctifying me.
13 To lead the congregation.
14 Thus yifkod means let Him appoint a leader.
15 The verse reads va-asher yotzi’em. Yotzi’em is a hifil. It literally means shall cause them to go out. Hence I.E.’s comment.
16 Why then does Scripture say, a man in whom is spirit?
17 Solomon was a man. What point was there in telling him show thyself a man? Thus show thyself a man means show thyself to be a man of valor.
18 Only he.
19 In others words, al piv (at his word) refers to Eleazar’s word.
20 According to this interpretation, al piv (at his word) refers to the Urim. For the Urim see Ex. 28:30 and I.E.’s comment on Ex. 28:5 (Vol. 2, pp. 591-598).
21 The chapter dealing with the appointment of Joshua to succeed Moses.
22 Following the appointment of Joshua.
23 In the Land of Israel.
24 In Ex. 29:42. The point is, why repeat the law of the burnt offering.
25 When Israel camped around Mount Sinai. In other words, it does not pertain to the daily burnt offering to be made when they entered the Land of Israel.

26 Scripture repeats the law of the burnt offering here because it wants to list in order all of the burnt offerings which the congregation is obligated to bring, i.e., the daily burnt offering, the new moon burnt offering, the Passover offering, etc.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 28
chapter.p: 2. MY FOOD. I have previously explained the meaning of the term lechem (food).1
MADE BY FIRE. I have previously explained the meaning of le-ishai (made by fire).2
The meaning of lachmi le-ishai re’ach nicho’ach (My food…made by fire, of a sweet savour unto Me) is, food for my fire, for a sweet savour unto Me.
IN ITS DUE SEASON. It shall not be bought before the morning, nor delayed after evening.

4. THE ONE LAMB. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen the Spaniard says that our verse is abridged. It should be read as if written ha-keves, keves echad (the lamb, one lamb).3 However, I believe that the heh of keves is to be read as if written twice.4 I have already shown you many such cases.5

6. WHICH WAS OFFERED IN MOUNT SINAI. Its meaning is, as you offered on Mount Sinai.6 This verse7 is an additional proof that Israel did not offer burnt offerings in the wilderness after they journeyed from Sinai,8 as I previously explained with perfect proof.9
7. SHALT THOU POUR OUT A DRINK-OFFERING OF STRONG DRINK. The stem nun10 is swallowed by the samekh.11 We will rely on the words of our sages of blessed memory as to its meaning.12

10. OF EVERY SABBATH. The vav suffixed to the word shabbat13 refers to the day of Sabbath.14 This is so even though we find the word me-challelo15 (from profaning it16) in Every one that keepeth the sabbath from profaning it (Is. 56:6).
The meaning of be-shabbato (of every Sabbath) is, every sabbath and sabbath. Compare, yom be-yomo (daily) (Ex. 5:13).
BESIDE THE CONTINUAL BURNT-OFFERING. This means after the continual burnt offering. The Sabbath burnt offering shall follow it.17

11. AND IN YOUR NEW MOONS. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen the Spaniard, who rests in paradise, says that u-ve-roshe chodshekhem18 (and in your new moons) refers to the new moon of Nisan, for Scripture clearly states, it shall be the first month of the year to you (Ex. 12:2).19 Scripture then goes on to say, This is the burnt-offering of every new moon (v. 14), that is, they shall offer this burnt offering20 on every new moon. The Torah therefore adds, throughout the months of the year (Ibid.).21

Rabbi Moses’ interpretation is correct. He is right even though the yod in u-ve-roshe chodshekhem (and in your new moons) argues against his interpretation.22 However, the fact that we find hinneh chodesh machar23 (Behold, tomorrow is the new moon) (I Sam. 20:5) shows that what he says is correct.24

14. OF EVERY NEW MOON. Chodesh be-chodsho (of every new moon) is similar25 to shabbat be-shabbato (of every sabbath) (Num. 28 :10).26 According to the plain meaning of the text there is no possibility of interpreting it any other way,27 for there is no mention of the moon in our verse.28 Furthermore, we only find the Hebrew form for the verb new in the pi’el, which has a dagesh placed in it.29 However, here30 the dalet has no dagesh in it.
15. AND ONE HE-GOAT FOR A SIN-OFFERING UNTO THE LORD. Compare, upon which the lot fell for the Lord, and offer him for a sin-offering (Lev. 16:9).31

Note, in Hebrew the sin is connected to the sinner whenever the word chattat is followed by a lamed.32 Can’t you see that Scripture reads, ve-chatati le-avi 33 (I shall bear the blame to my father) (Gen. 44:32). Look, this is contrary to the midrashic interpretation.34 However, the midrashic interpretation has a secret meaning.35
16. ON THE FOURTEENTH DAY OF THE MONTH. Scripture does not mention at dusk.36 This verse is also a support for those who transmit tradition,37 even though their words need no support.

22. AND ONE HE-GOAT FOR A SIN-OFFERING. U-se’ir chattat echad (and he-goat for a sin-offering) is the same as u-se’ir izzim echad le-chattat38 (and one he-goat for a sin-offering). Our verse is abridged.39
Observe, Scripture does not mention the Sabbath burnt offering40 which is to be brought during the seven days of Passover. It similarly omits41 the burnt offering which accompanied the waved sheaf.42
We need tradition.43 For the verse (v. 10) tells us that [the burnt offering] of every sabbath shall follow the daily burnt offering.44

26. WHEN YE BRING A NEW MEAL-OFFERING UNTO THE LORD. The two waveloaves45 were the main offerings.46 The seven lambs, one young bullock, two rams and two lambs of peace offering47 were brought along with it. The burnt offering mentioned in our chapter48 refers to the obligatory sacrifice of the festival day.49

The fact that Scripture does not state50 anything at all51 about the Sabbath and festivals, but only mentions And ye shall bring an offering made by fire without telling us the number of sacrificial animals for the festival of unleavened bread (Lev. 23:8), and Sukkot (Lev. 23:36), and the holiday celebrated on the tenth day of Tishri (Lev. 23:27) is proof of the words of our sages.52 The same is true for the day of the shofar sounding.53 Scripture does not mention the new moon burnt offering.54
And the continual burnt-offering and the meal-offering thereof (Num. 29:6) refers to the first burnt offering.55
chapter.ftnote: 1 In his comments on Ex. 16:4, I.E. explains that the term lechem can refer to bread, meat, or fruit. See I.E. on Ex. 16:4 (Vol. 2, p. 316).
2 According to I.E. the word isheh means a burnt offering. Thus le-ishai means for my burnt offerings.

3 Our verse reads, et ha-keves echad (the one lamb). A word with the direct object prefixed to it cannot be in the construct. Our verse reads, the lamb one in the morning. This is incorrect syntax. Hence Rabbi Moses’ interpretation.
4 Our verse is to be read as if written, et ha-keves, keves echad ba-boker.
5 Where a letter is to be read as if written twice.
6 In other words, they were not to bring the very same offering which they had brought at Sinai, for that offering no longer existed. They were to bring a similar offering.
7 In addition to Ex. 29:42. See I.E. on Ex. 29:42 (Vol. 2, p. 620).
8 Our verse speaks of the burnt offering at Sinai. It does not speak of the one offered in the wilderness. This implies that no burnt offering was offered in the wilderness.
9 See I.E. on Ex. 29:42.
10 Of the root nun, samekh, caf, the root of hassekh (shalt thou pour out).
11 In the word hassekh (shalt thou pour out). Hence the dagesh in the samekh.

12 We will rely on the sages concerning what Scripture means by the term nesekh (strong drink). According to the sages it refers to undiluted wine. In ancient times wine for drinking was mixed with water.
13 The reference is to the vav in the word shabbato (every Sabbath).

14 Shabbat is feminine. Thus Scripture should have used the term shabbatah if the reference was to every Sabbath. Hence I.E.’s comment that the vav refers to the word yom in verse 9, which is masculine. Thus according to I.E. we should render shabbato (every Sabbath) as every Sabbath day.
15 Rather than mechallelah.
16 The reference is to the Sabbath. We thus see that Scripture treats shabbat as masculine.
17 Literally, he shall place the Sabbath burnt offering upon it.
18 Literally, and in the first of your months. Hence Rabbi Moses’ interpretation.
19 Hence the first of your months (see previous note) refers to the first month of the year, i.e., the new moon of Nisan.
20 The same burnt offering that was offered on the new moon of Nisan.
21 A similar burnt offering shall be offered on the new moons throughout the year.

22 Roshe is a plural. Hence roshe chodshekhem seems to mean the many first days of the month. If the reference was to the new moon of Nisan, then Scripture should have read u-ve-rosh chodshekem (and on the first day of your months).
23 Not hinneh rosh chodesh machar.

24 The Book of Samuel refers to the new moon as chodesh. This implies that an ordinary new moon is called chodesh, and the new moon of Nisan rosh chodesh. Otherwise Samuel would have referred to the new moon by the phrase rosh chodesh.
25 In meaning.
26 In other words, the meaning of chodesh be-chodsho is every new moon.
27 Some interpreted chodesh be-chodsho to mean when it (the moon) renews itself.
28 If we take chodesh to mean new and chodesh be-chodsho to mean as when it renews itself, then the subject (the word moon) is missing from the text.
29 In other words, if our text intended to say “when it renews itself” the text would have read, chodesh be-chiddusho, not chodesh be-chodsho.
30 In chodesh be-chodsho.
31 Our verse literally reads for a “sin” unto the Lord. Lev. 16:9 teaches us that in our context “sin” stands for, a sin offering.

32 The lamed prefaced to a word sometimes means of. Compare, mizmor le-david (a psalm of David). Thus the phrase chattat la-Adonai might be taken to mean a sin of God. Therefore I.E. points out that its meaning is, an offering to God to atone for a sin.
33 Ve-chatati le-avi literally means I will sin to my father.

34 According to the midrash, le-chattat la-Adonai (for a sin-offering unto the Lord), which literally states, for a sin offering for the Lord, means that the sin offering is offered on behalf of God for diminishing the size of the moon. See Shavu’ot 9a.

35 I.E. does not give us its secret meaning. However, in his Yesod Ha-Ibbur he indicates that the sin offering is to avert the unfavorable consequences which come about when the moon is full. See Meijler on this verse.
36 As it does in Ex. 12:6.
37 According to the rabbis the paschal lamb could be offered after midday, at the moment the sun moves to the west. See I.E. on Ex. 12:6 (Vol. 2, p. 221).
38 This is the phrase normally used for a he-goat offering. See verses 15 and 30 in our chapter and verses 5, 11, 16, and 25 in chapter 29.
39 Se’ir is short for se’ir izzim.
40 So Vat. Ebr. 38. Also see Krinsky and Meijler. The printed texts omit the word Sabbath.
41 From the Passover offerings.
42 On the second day of Passover. See Lev. 23:9-14.
43 As to when the Sabbath offering is to be brought on a Sabbath during the week of Passover (Meijler).

44 The question arises, when is the Sabbath offering to be offered on a Sabbath which falls during the week of Passover? Is it to be before or after the additional Passover offerings? According to tradition, the Sabbath offering came before the Passover offerings.
45 Which were offered on Shavu’ot. See Lev. 23:17-21.
46 In contradistinction to the sacrifices that were brought along with them.
47 Mentioned in Lev. 23:17-21.
48 In verses 27-31.
49 While those listed in Lev. 23:17-21 were secondary to the wave offering.
50 In chapter 23 of Leviticus.
51 That is, how many sacrifices are to be offered.
52 That our chapter deals with the festival offerings.
53 Lev. 23:25. Scripture does not mention there the number of burnt offerings to be brought on Rosh Ha-Shanah.
54 In citing Rosh Ha-Shanah offerings. See Lev. 23:24,25.
55 The one offered in the morning. Another was offered in the evening. Hence I.E.’s comment.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 29
chapter.p: 1. IT IS A DAY OF BLOWING THE HORN.1 It is a commandment to sound a tru’ah.2 If this statement referred to the burnt offering offered on this day,3 then why is it not mentioned with regard to the other festivals?4 Furthermore, the Torah tells us to sound a teki’ah5 over the burnt offerings, not a tru’ah.6
8. ONE YOUNG BULLOCK. Brought by the congregation. The same applies to one ram. The reference is not to the bullock and ram offered by the kohen gadol (high priest).7

I believe that the ram mentioned in the Torah portion Acahre mot,8 which the kohen took from the people,9 is not the ram mentioned in our verse, for Scripture says, with regard to the high priest’s ram and the ram of the people, and offer his burnt-offering and the burnt-offering of the people (Lev. 16:24).10 The fact that there are seven additional lambs11 is proof of this.12

The one he-goat for a sin offering13 is not to be identified with one of the he-goats chosen by lot.14 Scripture therefore states,15 beside the sin-offering of atonement (v. 11) mentioned in the Torah portion Achare mot.16
35. A SOLEMN ASSEMBLY. I have already explained the meaning of the term atzeret (a solemn assembly).17
39. OR YOUR MEAL-OFFERINGS, OR YOUR DRINK-OFFERINGS. To each and every burnt offering, in accordance with its law.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Hebrew, yom tru’ah. Literally, a day of tru’ah. I.E.’s interpretation of yom tru’ah is, a day of sounding a tru’ah.
2 A tru’ah is a wavering blast.
3 The Torah tells us to sound the trumpets over the special burnt offerings that were offered on the festivals. See Num. 10:10.

4 If the reference of yom tru’ah was to the sound to be played over the burnt offerings on the festivals cited in Num. 10:10, then the Torah should have mentioned the sounding of the tru’ah with regard to the other festivals.
5 A steady blast.
6 Our verse speaks of a tru’ah. If the reference was to the sound played over the burnt offerings, the Torah would have spoken of a teki’ah.
7 See Lev. 16:3. These came from the high priest’s personal property.
9 To offer as a sacrifice.
10 The Torah does not designate the ram in our verse as an olat ha’am (the burnt offering of the people).
11 Offered along with the bullock and ram spoken of in our verse.

12 That the ram spoken of in our verse is not to be identified with the ram spoken of in Lev. 16. For the ram offered by the kohen in our chapter was accompanied by seven lambs, while the ram spoken of in Leviticus was not so accompanied.
13 Spoken of in verse 11.
14 Mentioned in Lev. 16:6-9.
15 With regard to the he-goat.
16 Lev. 16:9. In other words, the meaning of beside the sin-offering of atonement (v. 11) is, beside the sin offering (the he-goat) mentioned in the Torah portion Achare mot.
17 See I.E. on Lev. 23:36.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 30
chapter.p: 2. UNTO THE HEADS OF THE TRIBES. I believe that this section1 followed the war with Midian.2 The Midianite war3 therefore comes after it.4 Compare, And Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses (Num. 12:1), which comes after and they abode in Hazeroth (Num. 11:35)5 as I explained.

Scripture tells us that the children of Gad came to Moses and Eleazar and the princes of the congregation, and spoke their piece (Num. 32:2-6). Scripture then writes, So Moses gave charge concerning them to Eleazar the priest, and to Joshua the son of Nun, and to the heads of the fathers’ houses (Num. 32:28). The heads of the fathers’ houses refers to the already-mentioned princes (Num. 32:2).6

Moses told the children of Gad and the children of Reuben, and do that which hath proceeded out of your mouth (Num. 32:24). Scripture therefore reads,7 And Moses spoke unto the heads of the tribes.8 saying…(v. 2). When a man voweth a vow…he shall not break his word. Scripture there9 writes, he shall do according to all that proceedeth out of his mouth (v. 3).
OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. That they should relate this to the children of Israel.
3. UNTO THE LORD. He mentions God’s name. He vows as follows: If this comes to pass, then I will give the following sum to God, or I will fast.
SWEARETH. Hishavah (sweareth) is an infinitive. It is connected to a noun.10 There are many such cases.11
HE SHALL NOT BREAK HIS WORD. Lo yahel (he shall not break) means he shall not profane. The word yahel is not related to the word mechilah (forgiveness).
We need tradition,12 for Scripture speaks of a man and a women but does not tell us at what age a person is considered a man or at what age a female is considered a women.13
4. AND BINDETH HERSELF BY A BOND. Or bindeth herself by a bond.14
[5.] HER BOND. Essarah (her bond) belongs to a different form.15 It is not the same as issar (bond).16
6. DISALLOW. The word heni (disallow) means broke or nullified. Compare, tenu’ati (My displeasure) (Num. 14:34).
IN THE DAY THAT HE HEARETH. And not on any other day.
7. WHILE HER VOWS ARE UPON HER. In her father’s house. If her father does not nullify her vows, her husband may disallow her vows.
9. HE HEARETH IT. The word from her mouth.
AND THE CLEAR UTTERANCE OF HER LIPS. The oath.
