11. AND IF A WOMAN VOWED IN HER HUSBAND’S HOUSE. If the widow vowed in an earlier time and her husband disallowed it, then she does not have to keep the vow in her widowhood. This speaks about a vow which she vowed regarding the future, and the husband died before the vow was to take effect.17
The meaning of selichah (forgiveness) has been previously explained.18
14. TO AFFLICT THE SOUL. Even to afflict the soul. I have already explained that “affliction of the soul” refers to fasting.19

15. THEN HE CAUSETH ALL HER VOWS TO STAND. He has already caused all of her vows to stand.20 Scripture then explains how he caused her vows to stand, namely, because he held his peace in the day that he heard them.
16. THEN HE SHALL BEAR HER INIQUITY. For she is under his care.
17. BETWEEN A MAN AND HIS WIFE. His wife being a woman who is an adult.
BETWEEN A FATHER AND HIS DAUGHTER. If she has not reached adulthood. Hence Scripture reads, being in her youth.
chapter.ftnote: 1 The section dealing with the laws of vows.
2 Even though it precedes it. The war with Midian is described in chapter 31.
3 Which inspired this chapter.
4 I.E.’s point is that the laws of vows and the war with Midian are juxtaposed with each other because they occurred at the same time.

5 We thus see that Scripture sometimes puts first that which came after, when that which came later was the cause of that which is described first. For Israel dwelled in Hazeroth because Miriam spoke against Moses (Krinsky).
6 The heads of the fathers’ houses are to be identified with the princes mentioned in Num. 32:6, for the princes mentioned in Num. 7 were no longer alive.
7 In our verse.
8 For they were to see to it that the tribes of Reuben, Gad and half of Manasseh kept their word.
9 That is, here.
10 When an infinitive is connected to a word, that word is usually a verb. Compare, ve-rappo yerrape (and shall cause him to be thoroughly healed) (Ex. 21:19). Hence I.E.’s comment.
11 Compare, shefot ha-shofetim (when the judges judged) (Ruth 1:1).
12 To ascertain the age at which one is obligated to keep one’s vows.
13 And is obligated to keep his or her vows.
14 The vav of ve-aserah means or, not and.
15 From issar.
16 For issar has a dagesh in the samekh. In other words, esar and issar come from the same root but belong to different forms.

17 Otherwise our verse would be repeating verse 9. For if a husband can annul his wife’s vow which was made when she was under her father’s charge, he can certainly annul avow made under his charge. Hence I.E. explains that our verse deals with a divorcee or widow who uttered a vow while married and had the vow nullified by her husband, who died before the vow became due. Our verse teaches that in such a case the nullification of the vow retains its efficacy.
18 See I.E. on Num. 14:19.
19 See I.E. on Lev. 16:29.
20 In other words, ve-hekim means: has already caused, rather than: and he will cause.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 31
chapter.p: 3. ARM YE MEN. The meaning of hechaletzu (arm ye men) is, gird your men of war.1
TO EXECUTE THE LORD’S VENGEANCE. The reference is to Israel’s vengeance2 because they were enticed3 into worshipping idols.
5. SO WERE DELIVERED. Va-yimasseru means and they were delivered. The word li-mesor4 (to deliver) (v. 16) is close in meaning to it.
6. WITH THE HOLY VESSELS. The ark.
7. AND THEY SLEW EVERY MALE. Adult males.5
8. AND ZUR. The father of Cozbi.6

BALAAM ALSO THE SON OF BEOR. Some say that after Balaam returned to his place,7 he went back to Midian as soon as he learned of the plague that struck Israel because of his advice. He came back to receive money from the elders of Midian.8
9. AND ALL THEIR GOODS. The word chelam (their goods) is a general term. It refers to gold, silver, copper, iron, and garments.
10. AND ALL THEIR CITIES IN THE PLACES WHEREIN THEY DWELT. An all-inclusive term9 followed by a limiting term.10
AND ALL THEIR ENCAMPMENTS. Tirotam (their encampments) means the palaces of the kings.11
11. AND THEY TOOK ALL THE SPOIL, AND ALL THE PREY. Malko’ach (prey) is a general term for men and cattle.
12. THE CAPTIVES. Shevi (captive) is a specific term. It refers to humans.
THE SPOIL. Shalal (spoil) refers to garments.

14. WITH THE OFFICERS OF THE HOST. The word pekudai (officers of) is related to the word yifkod (set) in Let the Lord…set (Num. 27 :16).12 It13 is similar to pekide he-chayil.14 Similarly, the word keru’e (the elect of) (Num. 1:16) means the same as keri’e (the elect of) (Num. 16:2).
THE CAPTAINS OF THOUSANDS AND THE CAPTAINS OF HUNDREDS. They totaled one hundred and thirty-two.15
15. HAVE YE SAVED ALL THE WOMEN ALIVE. The meaning of kol nekevah (all the women) is, even one woman.16 En kol (had nothing)17 (II Sam. 12:3)18 is similar.
It is also possible that have ye saved all the women alive is to be taken literally, for they kept all the females alive. There are many such instances.19
17. THE LITTLE ONES. Taf (little ones) is a general term for male and female minors.
19. YE AND YOUR CAPTIVES.20 Because of the glory which dwells among you.

20. AND ALL WORK OF GOATS’ HAIR.21 This is to be interpreted in accordance with my earlier explanation.22 Observe, the garment23 is unclean because it touched a corpse. The meaning of our verse is, the garments shall be with you24 until you are purified.25 On the other hand, titchate’u (ye shall purify) might be transitive.26 Ve-hitavvitem27 lakhem (and ye shall mark out) (Num. 34:10) is similar,28 for gevul (line)29 is the object.30
21. AND ELEAZAR THE PRIEST SAID. For the law regarding the cow31 was given to Eleazar.32 Moses told the people in a general manner, ye shall purify (v. 20). However, Eleazar explained it to them.33
22. THE TIN. The meaning of the bedil (tin) is known.34

23. NEVERTHELESS IT SHALL BE PURIFIED WITH THE WATER OF SPRINKLING.35 It would have appeared to us that the reference is to the mixture of the water and tahe ashes of the cow,36 as in because the water of sprinkling37 was not dashed against him (Num. 19:13). However, our wise men of blessed memory say that its meaning is, in the amount of water in which a menstruant bathes.38 Their mind is much greater than our minds.
26. TAKE THE SUM. I have already explained the meaning of sa et rosh (take the sum).39
OF THE PREY. Malko’ach (the prey) refers to the cattle.
THAT WAS TAKEN. Ha-shevi (that was taken) refers to humans. A vav is missing,40 as in shemesh yare’ach (sun moon)41 (Hab. 3:11).
AND THE HEADS OF THE FATHERS’ HOUSES OF THE CONGREGATION. The reference is to the princes.42
27. AND DIVIDE THE PREY. Malko’ach (prey) is a general term.43
28. ONE SOUL. Echad nefesh means the same as nefesh echad (one soul).44
30. ONE DRAWN. Achuz (drawn) is similar to ve-ha’achuz achuz (and proportionally) (I Chron. 24:6).45 As I have explained,46 they are connected.47

EVEN OF ALL THE CATTLE. Camels.48 Look, Eleazar did not take a portion from them.49 Perhaps they were few. Hence neither the number which they brought nor the amount which the Levites took is mentioned.50

32. OVER AND ABOVE THE BOOTY.51 Aside from what they consumed. Scripture therefore reads yeter (above).52 The Torah mentions the amount of spoil because it consisted of a vast number. We never heard of a similar amount of spoil.53 Scripture also mentions the tribute,54 for it too was very great.

The word mekhes (tribute) (v. 37) comes from a double root.55 It is vocalized like the word memer (bitterness)56 in and bitterness to her that bore him (Prov. 17:25). Mekhes is related to the word takhossu (ye shall make your count) in ye shall make your count for the lamb (Ex. 12:4). The meaning of mekhes (tribute) is a portion.
47. [BOTH OF MAN AND OF BEAST.] Scripture states both of man and of beast. Man57 and beast58 are general terms.
48. THE OFFICERS59. I have already explained this term.60
49. THAT ARE UNDER OUR CHARGE. Asher be-yadenu61 means that they were in their62 charge. Compare, yadekh (in your hands) in And take with thee ten loaves63 in your hands64 (I Kings 14:3).65
50. AND WE HAVE BROUGHT. In thought or by mouth.66
ARMLETS. Etzadah (armlet) is an ornament placed on the arm. This is explicitly stated in Scripture.67
AND BRACELETS. A tzamid (bracelet) is an ornament placed on the wrist.68
SIGNET-RINGS. Taba’at (signet ring) refers to an ornament placed on the finger.69
EAR-RINGS. Agil is an earring. This is clearly stated in Scripture.70 This ornament is possibly so called because it is round (agul).
GIRDLES. Kumaz (girdles) is similar to its neighboring objects.71
51. EVEN ALL THE WROUGHT JEWELS.72 Scripture tells us that there was no broken object among them.
53. FOR THE MEN OF WAR HAD TAKEN BOOTY, EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF. Scripture mentions this to inform us that each one of the men of war took a vast amount of gold and wrought articles.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Gird a sword upon your men of war (Krinsky). Or, gird the loins of your men of war. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads gird your loins. See Job 38:3 and Is. 5:27. The word hechaletzu can also be rendered as strip. Hence I.E.’s comment (Meijler).
2 Verse 2 says, Avenge the children of Israel of the Midianites. However, verse 3 states, to execute the Lord’s vengeance on Midian. Hence I.E.’s comment.
3 By the Midianites. See Num. 25:6 and Num. 31:15,16.
4 Translated literally. Verse 16 reads, li-mesor ma’al (to revolt so as to break faith).
5 The little ones were taken captive (v. 17). Hence I.E.’s comment.
6 See Num. 25:15.
8 See San. 106a.
9 Their cities.
10 Their moshvotam (the places wherein they dwelt).
11 In other words, tirotam means their palaces.
12 The pekudai he-chayil (the officers of the host) are those who are set over the host.
13 Pekudai he-chayil.
14 So Vat. Ebr. 38.
15 There were 12 captains of thousands and 120 captains of hundreds over the 12,000 Israelites who went to war.
16 In other words, the word kol (all) sometimes means a part of.
17 It does not mean did not have anything, for he had a lamb. We thus see that the word kol does not always mean all things.
18 The reference is to a poor person who had only a lamb.
19 Where a rhetorical question is raised.
20 Shall encamp outside of the camp until you are purified.
21 Hebrew, ma’aseh izzim. Literally, goats’ work. Hence I.E.’s comments.
22 See I.E. on Ex. 25:4 (Vol. 2, p. 534) “Izzim (goats) is to be rendered as goats’ hair.” In other words, “goats’ work” means a garment made out of goats’ hair.
23 Mentioned in our verse.

24 In other words, the meaning of ve-khol beged (and as to every garment) is, and with you all garments. I.E. reads our verse as follows: And all garments taken in spoil…[shall be with you outside of the camp] until you are purified. I.E. interprets thus because titchate’u is in the hitpa’el. Words in the hitpa’el are reflexive.
25 I.E. interprets titchate’u (ye shall purify) as if written ad she-titchatu’e (until you are purified).
26 In other words, titchate’u means ye shall purify, i.e., the garments.
27 It too is in the hitpa’el.
28 For it too is transitive even though it is in the hitpa’el.
29 Which follows “and ye shall mark out.”
30 Hence ve-hitavvitem (and ye shall mark out) is transitive.
31 The red heifer.
32 See Num. 19:3.
33 In detail.
34 I.E. could not find a synonym for this word. Hence his comment.
35 Hebrew, me niddah.
36 The red heifer.
37 Hebrew, me-niddah.
38 The utensils are to be immersed in a pool of water which is fit for a menstruant to purify herself. See Avodah Zara 75b.
39 See I.E. on Ex. 30:12 (Vol. 2, p. 631). Also see I.E. on Gen. 40:13 (Vol. 1, p. 369).
40 Our verse reads, malko’ach shevi (the prey that was taken). I.E. says that this should be read as if written malko’ach ve-ha-shevi (the cattle and human captives).
41 Translated literally. This is to be read as if written, shemesh ve-yare’ach (the sun and the moon).
42 Of the tribes.
43 For humans and cattle. See I.E.’s comment on verse 11.
44 Nefesh echad is the usual form. Hence I.E.’s comment.
45 The reading in I Chron. 24:6 is ve-achuz achuz, slightly different from what I.E. quotes.
46 It isn’t clear where.
47 Ve-achuz achuz is to be interpreted as one word (Filwarg). Some interpret: verse 28 and 30 are connected to each other. See Weiser.
48 Even all the cattle seems to add something new. Since cattle, flock, asses are clearly mentioned in our verse, I.E. reasons that even of all the cattle refers to camels.
49 The camels.
50 In our verse.
51 Literally, the remnant of the booty.
52 Literally, the remnant of. See previous note.
53 In Scripture.
54 Given unto the Lord. See verses 37-41.
55 Its root is kaf, samekh, samekh.
56 It is vocalized with two segols.
57 Hebrew, adam. It takes in males and females, adults and children.
58 Hebrew, behemah. It takes in cattle, asses, and camels.
59 Hebrew, ha-pekudim.
60 See I.E.’s comment on verse 14.
61 Literally, that are under our hand.
62 I.E. used the word their. However, it means our, as in the text.
63 So the Bible. Our text reads ten men.
64 Translated literally.
65 Its meaning is, take ten loaves in your charge, for it is unlikely for someone to carry ten loaves of bread in his hands.
66 The verb va-nakrev (and we brought) is a perfect. Hence its meaning must be, we dedicated.
67 See II Sam. 1:10.
68 See Gen. 24:22.
69 This is the accepted meaning of the word.
70 See Ezek. 16:12.
71 According to I.E., kumaz is a type of ornament.
72 Hebrew, keli ma’aseh. I.E. renders this as articles fit for use.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 32
chapter.p: 1. THE CHILDREN OF REUBEN. For he was the son of the mistress.1
WAS A PLACE FOR CATTLE. For there it was good pasture.
2. THE CHILDREN OF GAD…CAME. They thought of this first. Hence Scripture places them first.2
5. AND THEY SAID…LET THIS LAND BE GIVEN. Scripture repeats, and they said because they spoke at length.3

Some say that the word et is the object of yuttan (be given).4 I do not know why.5 Look, Scripture reads: netam eretz6 (the land is burnt up) (Is. 9:18); yechalek ha-aretz7 (the land shall be divided) (Num. 26:55);8 ve-lo nasa otom ha-aretz9 (and the land was not able to bear them) (Gen. 13:6); and asher hu va shammah be-kirbo10 (whither they go to be among them) (Deut. 31:16).
7. YE TURN AWAY. Teniyun (ye turn away) means you break.
9. FOR WHEN THEY WENT UP UNTO THE VALLEY OF ESHCOL. For those who went up11 to the north, went to the south.12
11. THEY HAVE NOT WHOLLY FOLLOWED ME. There is no dagesh in the lamed of mile’u (wholly followed). Mile’u is a pi’el.13 Compare, malle (fill)14 in fill thy horn with oil (I Sam. 16:1).
They did not complete what they started.15
12. CALEB THE SON OF JEPHUNNEH. Caleb is mentioned first, as in the case of God’s oath.16
The word mile’u (wholly followed) is similar to the word bikshu (have sought) in have sought after my soul (Ps. 44:5) and shilchu (they have set) in They have set Thy sanctuary on fire (Ps. 74:7).17

13. AND HE MADE THEM WANDER. Va-yeni’em (and he made them wander) is related to the word na (a fugitive) in a fugitive and a wanderer (Gen. 4:12). Scripture reads va-yeni’em because they did not rest.18

14. A BROOD. The word tarbut (a brood) is connected to the word ribbiti (brought up) in That I have dandled and brought up (Lam. 2:22). It is close in meaning to the word rav (officers) in all the officers (rav) of his house19 (Esther 1:8). The meaning of tarbut is, grown up in years.

TO AUGMENT. Li-sepot (to augment) means the same as le-hosif (to add). However, it comes from a different root.20 The word sofu (add) in Add…unto your sacrifices (Jer. 7:21) is similar,21 for we do not find this root22 among the stems that begin with a yod and drop the yod in the kal.23
16. AND CITIES. First24 for our little ones.

17. READY. The word chushim (ready) is vocalized like the word mulim (circumcised) in were circumcised (Josh. 5:5). It means quickly. It is related to the word chushah (hasten) in Make speed, hasten, stay not (I Sam. 20:38).
19. AND FORWARD. The word ve-hale’ah (and forward) is used with regard to both place25 and time.26 The meaning of ve-hale’ah is, and above.27
21. UNTIL HE HATH DRIVEN OUT. God.28
22. BEFORE THE LORD. For the ark was there.29 Before the Lord is to be taken as I have explained,30 for the phrase31 is always used in a positive sense.32
24. FOR YOUR SHEEP. The alef in tzonakhem (your sheep) is superfluous.33 It is like the alef in he’eznichu (become foul) in and the rivers shall become foul (Is. 19:6).34

27. EVERY MAN THAT IS ARMED FOR WAR. Kol chalutz tzava (every man that is armed for war) is similar to ha-aron ha-berit35 (the ark of the covenant) (Josh. 3:14). Its meaning is, every man armed, armed for war.36
29. THEN YE SHALL GIVE THEM. The meaning of u-netattem la-hem is, you shall give them.37 The vav is like the Arabic fa,38 for such is the rule of the language.39

30. THEY SHALL HAVE POSSESSIONS AMONG YOU. He gave them respect,40 for the meaning of our verse is, if they41 will not go armed before you, then you shall force them to go with you and they shall have possessions among you.42 Or, if they change their minds, then they shall have possessions among you.
The word ve-nochazu (they shall have possessions) follows the rules of a root that has a yod as its first letter,43 for the letters alef, heh, vav, and yod interchange.
31. AND THE CHILDREN OF GAD…ANSWERED. A second time for emphasis.
32. WE WILL PASS. The form nachnu (we) is the original form of the word. The alef in anachnu (we)44 is added. The half tribe of Manasseh is not mentioned until now because it was but half a tribe.
38. AND NEBO. It is likely that the reference is to Mount Nebo, where, as I shall explain,45 Moses was buried.
THEIR NAMES BEING CHANGED. These cities had their names changed.46 The same applies to Sibmah.47
39. AND DISPOSSESSED. Some say that Machir was alive.48 However, I believe that and dispossessed49 refers to the warrior that was in the family.50
40. [UNTO MACHIR THE SON OF MANASSEH.] The meaning of unto Machir the son of Manasseh is, unto the sons of Machir the son of Manasseh.51 Compare, And Judah said unto Simeon his brother (Jud. 1:3).52

41. AND JAIR THE SON OF MANASSEH. Jair was from the family of Judah.53 This is explicitly stated.54 For Hezron55 took the daughter of Machir the son of Manasseh, and she bore him Segub. Segub begot Jair,56 who had cities among the cities of Gilead.57 Jair is called after his mother’s family. There were also kohanim who were called after the name of the children of Barzillai the Gileadite.58 The latter is clearly stated in Scripture.59

This is no reason to ask: How did Jair60 inherit among another tribe,61 for it was the land of Canaan that was divided,62 not the land of the Amorites that was on the eastern side of the Jordan,63 for64 there were Amorites in the land of Canaan65 and they were the mightiest of the seven nations.
THE VILLAGES THEREOF. Chavvotehem (villages thereof) is to be interpreted in context.66 It means walled cities.
chapter.ftnote: 1 The son of Leah. Scripture mentions Reuben before Gad because he was the son of Leah whereas Gad was the son of Zilpah, who was a handmaiden. I.E. comments thus because the reverse is the case in verse 2.
2 Before the tribe of Reuben, even though the tribe of Reuben was descended from Leah and the tribe of Gad from Zilpah,
3 Verse 2 tells us that the children of Gad and the children of Reuben spoke (va-yomeru). Our verse reads, va-yomeru (and they said). The latter is superfluous. Hence I.E.’s comment.
4 Our verse reads, yuttan et ha-aretz (let…[the] land be given). Now eretz is feminine. Thus our verse should read, tuttan et ha-aretz. Hence this opinion.
5 These commentaries have to go to such extreme length.
6 Netem is masculine. We thus see that Scripture at times treats eretz as masculine.
7 Yechalek is masculine.
8 The reading in Num. 26:55 is, yechalek et ha-aretz. I.E. omits the et in his quote.
9 Nasa is masculine.
10 Be-kirbo is masculine and refers to the land previously mentioned in the verse. See I.E. on Deut. 31:16.
11 Scripture reads, and they went up. According to I.E. this implies going north.

12 They went north from Kadesh-barnea, where they were camped, to the south of Israel. See I.E. on Num. 13:17. Note that we have rendered mi-tzafon to the north, for I.E. occasionally uses the mem to mean to. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: They went from the south to the north.
13 And therefore should have a dagesh in it.
14 Malle is a pi’el and has a dagesh in it. See I.E.’s comments on verse 12.
15 The meaning of lo mile’u acharai (because they have not wholly followed me).
16 God mentioned Caleb before Joshua. See Num. 14:30. and I.E.’s comments thereto.
17 Both bikshu and shilchu are pi’els but, contrary to the rule, do not have a dagesh in them.
18 During their sojourn in the wilderness.
19 I.E. renders this as, all those brought up in his house.
20 Li-sepot comes from the root samekh, peh, heh. Hosif comes from the root yod, samekh, peh.
21 To li-sepot; i.e., it comes from the root samekh, peh, heh.
22 The root yod, samekh, heh.
23 Hence its root must be samekh, peh, heh.
24 Before we build the sheepfolds. This interpretations is contra the rabbis, who believed that the sons of Reuben and Gad valued their sheep over their little ones. See Rashi.
25 See Gen. 35:21: And Israel journeyed, and spread his tent beyond (me-hale’ah) Migdal-eder.
26 See Lev. 22:27. But from the eighth day and thenceforth (ve-hale’ah).
27 That is, forward.
28 Horisho (He hath driven out) refers to God.
29 Among the people.
30 See I.E. on Ex. 16:34 (Vol. 2, p. 332). Before the Lord means before the divine glory which is upon the cherubim.
31 Li-fene Adonai.

32 The word li-fene Adonai (before the Lord) literally means before the Lord’s face. This can be taken in a negative sense, that is, to anger God. See I.E. on the word li-fene in Gen. 11:28 (Vol. 1, p. 146).
33 The usual form of the word is tzonkhem.
34 Which is superfluous. The usual form is hiznichu.

35 Ha-aron has a heh, the definite article, prefixed to it. Such a word cannot be in the construct. Hence our phrase reads, the ark, the covenant. This should be read as if written, the ark, ark of the covenant. See I.E. on Gen. 2:9 (Vol. 1, p. 54, and the notes thereto).

36 In I.E.’s edition of the Pentateuch the word chalutz was apparently vocalized with a kamatz. This being the case, the verse read, armed, war. Hence I.E. suggests that our verse be read as if written, armed, armed for war (Motot). It should be noted that in our versions of Scripture the word chalutz is vocalized with a chataf pattach and is in the construct with tzava. It thus reads, armed for war.
37 In other words, the vav prefixed to netattem does not mean and. It is placed there for emphasis and is not to be translated.
38 See I.E. On Gen. 1:2, (Vol. 1, p. 30).
39 To employ a non-translatable yod.
40 He spoke to them with respect.
41 The tribes of Reuben and Gad and the half tribe of Manasseh.
42 Our verse says this in a diplomatic way.
43 Ve-nochazu is vocalized as if it came from the root yod, chet zayin, when in reality its root is alef, chet, zayin.
44 The more usual employed term for we.
45 See I.E. on Deut. 34:6.
46 In other words, musabbot shem (their names being changed) is not the name of a city.
47 Its name was also changed.

48 That Machir the son of Manasseh was still alive, and that it is he to whom va-yoresh (and [he] dispossessed) applies. These commentaries interpret thus because verse 40 states, And Moses gave Gilead unto Machir. The latter is taken literally.
49 Literally, and he dispossessed.
50 One of Machir’s descendants was a great warrior. He dispossessed the Amorites.
51 For Machir the son of Manasseh was no longer alive.
52 The meaning of which is, and the descendants of Judah said to the descendants of Simeon his brother, for the tribal patriarchs Reuben and Judah were no longer alive.
53 From the tribe of Judah. This raises the question: Why does Scripture identify him as a son of Manasseh?
54 In Scripture.
55 The son of Judah.
56 See I Chron. 2:1-22.
57 Ibid.
58 The children of Barzillai were not kohanim.
59 See Ezra 2:61.
60 Who was from the tribe of Judah.

61 Manasseh. Each tribe was allocated a portion by lot. Only members of the tribe received a portion in the land belonging to the tribe. The question thus arises, by what right did Jair receive a part of the land within the area allocated to Manasseh.
62 By lot.
63 The land on the eastern bank of the Jordan was not allocated by lot to the tribe of Manasseh. Hence it was possible for Jair to obtain a part of the eastern bank of the Jordan by conquest.
64 What follows is merely noted for informational purposes. It does no affect the interpretation.
65 As there were in Transjordan.
66 The word is not found elsewhere in Scripture.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 33
chapter.p: 1. THESE ARE THE STAGES. Moses recorded all the journeys of the Israelites when the children of Israel camped in the plains of Moab1 and stayed there for a number of months, until the afore-mentioned cities2 were built. They did not move from there until Aaron died.3
2. THEIR GOINGS FORTH. How they went from place to place. Therefore their goings forth follows.
BY THE COMMANDMENT OF THE LORD. This is connected to stage by stage.4
3. ON THE MORROW AFTER THE PASSOVER. I have explained this,5 and with a high hand (Ex. 14:8)6 as well.
4. UPON THEIR GODS ALSO THE LORD EXECUTED JUDGMENTS. As in the incident with Dagan’s head.7 For God said so to Moses.8
7. AND TURNED BACK. This alludes to the cloud9 or to Israel.10
8. FROM PENE-HAHIROTH. Pene-hahirot and Pi-hahiroth11 refers to the same place. The mouth is in the face.12
THREE DAYS’ JOURNEY. I have already explained this.13
16. KIBROTH-HATTAAVAH. The latter is in Kadesh-barnea,14 as I explained.
37. AND THEY JOURNEYED FROM KADESH. Kadesh is the name of a city.15
40. [AND THE CANAANITE…HEARD.] Scripture tells us this here16 because the Canaanite fought with Israel at Hor ha-Hor.17
42. ZALMONAH, AND…PUNON. I have explained this.18
46. ALMON-DIBLATHAIM. This is a general term for many journeys, as I explained in the Torah portion, This is the statute of the law (Num. 19:2).19
49. FROM BETH-JESHIMOTH. This is the valley which looks down upon the wasteland.20 God then commanded Moses to warn Israel21 because they were soon to pass over.22
52. THEIR FIGURED STONES. Maskiyyotam (their figured stones) is similar to ve-even maskit (any figured stone) (Lev. 26:1).
THEIR HIGH PLACES. Bamotam means their high places. Compare, bamate aretz (the high places of the earth) (Is. 58:14).
54. AND YE SHALL INHERIT THE LAND. Ve-hitnachaltem (and ye shall inherit) is similar to ve-hitavvitem (and ye shall mark out) (Num. 34 :10).23 Ha-aretz (the land) is the object.24
Scripture mentions to the more ye shall give the more inheritance to connect But if ye will not drive out the inhabitants (v. 55) which comes after it.25

55. AS THORNS. Sikkim refers to sharp thorns. It is related to the word mesukkato (hedge thereof)26 in the hedge thereof (Is. 5:5) and the word sakh (hedge) in behold, I will hedge up thy way with thorns (Hos. 2:8).

AND AS PRICKS. The word tzeninim (pricks) is to be explained according to its context. It means the same as u-leshotet be-tziddekhem (a scourge in your sides) (Josh. 23:13), which27 refers to a blow delivered by a whip.28 On the other hand, the word tzeninim (pricks) might refer to sharp thorns, as in Thorns (tzinnim) and snares in the way of the froward (Prov. 22:5).29
Observe, Scripture further explains30 the borders of their inheritance from which they are obligated to expel the inhabitants of the land.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Verse 48.
2 The cities mentioned in Num. 32:33-42.
3 This appears to be an error, for Aaron died at Mount Hor before Israel came to the plains of Moab. See Num. 20:22-29. The proper reading should be, until Moses died.
4 Our text should be read: Stage by stage by the commandment of the Lord.
5 See I.E. on Lev. 23:11.
6 See I.E. on Lev. 23:11.
7 I Sam. 5:4. Dagan fell headless, armless, and footless before the ark of God.

8 In other words, God executed judgment as he had told Moses he would (Ex. 12:12). I. E. notes this because Scripture does not previously tells us that God actually executed judgment on the Egyptian gods.

9 Which accompanied Israel. Va-yisu (and they journeyed) is in the plural. Va-yashav (and turned back) is in the singular. Thus our verse may be rendered: and they journeyed and it turned back. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.
10 According to this interpretation Scripture refers to Israel in the singular.
12 Pi means mouth of; pene face of. Hence the names Pi-hahiroth and Pene-hahiroth for the same place.
13 See I.E. on Num. 10:31.
14 See I.E. on Num. 20:14.
15 See I.E. on Num. 20:14.
16 After mentioning Mount Hor.
17 Following the death of Aaron. See Num. 21:1-3.
18 See I.E. on Num. 21:4.
19 See I.E. on Num. 21:18.
20 See I.E. on Num. 21:20.
21 To drive out the inhabitants of Canaan (v. 55).
22 Into Canaan.
23 Both verbs are in the hitpa’el and are transitive. Most verbs in the hitpa’el are intransitive. Hence I.E.’s comment.
24 In other words, ve-hitnachaltem is transitive.

25 In other words, the law commanding Israel to drive out the Canaanites follows the law telling Israel to inherit Canaan, in order to warn Israel that they will not inherit the land if they permit Canaanites to dwell therein.
26 The hedge spoken of in Is. 5:5 was made of sharp thorns.
27 According to its context. See Weiser.
28 So too the word tzeninim. Thus ve-litzninim be-tziddekhem (and as pricks in your sides) means, and lashes in their sides.
29 In this case, ve-litzninim be-tziddekhem (and for pricks in your sides) means, and for thorns in their sides.
30 In chapter 34.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 34
chapter.p: 2. INTO THE LAND OF CANAAN. Ha-aretz kena’an (the land of Canaan) is similar to ve-hanevu’ah oded ha-navi (even the prophecy of Oded the prophet) (II Chron. 15:8), the meaning of which is, the prophecy, prophecy of Oded the prophet. The meaning of our clause is, the land, land of Canaan.1
3. BY THE SIDE OF EDOM. The word yede2 (side of) means place of. Compare, by the side of (yad)3 the Jordan (Num. 13:29).
5. UNTO THE BROOK OF EGYPT. Nachlah mitzrayim means unto the brook of Egypt.4 It does not refer to the Nile.
6. THE GREAT SEA. The Spanish sea.5 The meaning of our verse is: And the Great Sea shall be your western border.6 The Great Sea itself shall serve as the border.7
10. AND YE SHALL MARK OUT. The alef in ve-hitavvitem (and ye shall mark out) is in place of a vav.8 Compare, ve-hitvita9 tav (and set a mark) (Ezek. 9:4). This is so, even though the forms differ.10
AND YE SHALL MARK OUT. Ve-hitavvitem (and ye shall mark out) is similar to the word ta’avat (utmost bound) in Unto the utmost bound of the everlasting hills (Gen. 49:26).11

11. AND SHALL STRIKE. The word machah (strike) is to be interpreted as the ancients did. It means it shall break.12 It is related to the word yimcha’u (clap) in Let the floods clap their hands (Ps. 98:8).
15. THE TWO TRIBES. Scripture mentions this a second time13 in order to explain the place of their inheritance.14

17. SHALL TAKE POSSESSION. Yinchalu (shall take possession) is a causative.15 The same applies to the word u-nechaltanu (and take us for Thine inheritance) (Ex. 34:9)16 in the opinion of the grammarians.

ELEAZAR. He is mentioned first17 because Joshua went out by his command. Furthermore, Eleazar was also the son of Aaron. Scripture does not mention the princes of the tribes of Reuben or Gad,18 for they19 had already taken their share.

The commentaries say that Scripture starts20 with Judah,21 for that is the way the lot came out at first.22 However, there is a great argument against them.23 Nevertheless, the comments appear correct to us.24
28. PEDAHEL. If the heh in Pedahel is silent then we have two words each with its own meaning,25 for the heh is not an implied letter.26
chapter.ftnote: 1 Ha-aretz has the definite article prefixed to it. According to the rules of Hebrew grammar, a word with the definite article cannot be in the construct. The literal meaning of ha-aretz kena’an (the land of Canaan) thus is, the land Canaan. Hence I.E.’s comment that our verse be read as if written, ha-aretz, eretz kena’an. Ve-hanevu’ah oded ha-navi (even the prophecy of Oded the prophet) (II Chron. 15:8) is, for similar reasons, to be read, ve-hanevu’ah nevu’at oded ha-navi. See I.E. on Gen. 2:9 (Vol. 1, p. 54).
2 Literally, hands of. Hence I.E.’s comment.
3 Literally, hand of. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 (Vol. 1, pp. 45-46).
4 For the heh suffixed to nachlah is in place of the preposition el (unto).
5 I.E.’s term for the Mediterranean Sea.
6 Our verse reads, u-gavel yam. This should be rendered, and for the western border not, and the sea. The word yam can mean either the sea or the west. Hence I.E.’s comment.
7 Our verse literally reads, and the border on the west, ye shall have the Great Sea, and a border. I.E. renders this, you shall have the Great Sea itself serve as your border on the west

8 Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, in place of a tav. The root of ve-hitavvitem appears to be alef, vav, heh. This root means to desire. And you shall desire appears out of place here. Hence I.E.’s suggestion that ve-hitavvitem comes from the root tav, vav, heh, which means to mark out. And you shall mark out fits in well within the context of our verse.
9 Which comes from the root tav, vav, heh.
10 Ve-hitavvitem is in the hitpa’el while ve-hitvita is a hif’il.
11 I.E. makes the same point in Genesis. See Vol. 1, p. 447.
12 When the boundary line reaches the lake of Kinneret, it will create a broken (not a straight) border (Weiser).
13 The first half of our verse repeats the previous verse.
14 The second part of our verse tells us where the two and a half tribes received their inheritance.
15 Even though it is a kal. According to I. E. the word yinchalu here should be rendered, shall cause you to take possession, rather than shall take possession.
16 According to I.E., u-nechaltanu (and take us for Thine inheritance) should be rendered, you will cause us to inherit. See I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 34:9.
17 Before Joshua.
18 In listing the princes of the tribes in verses 17-28.
19 Their tribes.
20 In listing the tribes.
21 Even though Simeon was older.
22 When the land was actually divided. See Joshua 15:1.

23 If Scripture followed the order in which the tribes actually received their inheritance, the children of Joseph should have followed Judah, for they took their inheritance after Judah. See Joshua 16.
24 For no one can offer a better reason than these commentaries for listing Judah first (Weiser).

25 The heh is silent only when it comes at the end of a word. It is not silent when it comes in the middle of a word. Since the heh in the name Pedahel is silent we must interpret it as two words, padah el (God redeemed). I.E.’s point is that while many of the Hebrew names containing God’s name are partially abbreviated, this is not the case with Pedahel.
26 In the middle of a word. See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 (Vol. 2, p. 85).

chapter.title: CHAPTER 35
chapter.p: 2. AND OPEN LAND. The meaning of migrash (open land) is known.1
10. INTO THE LAND OF CANAAN. The meaning of artzah kena’an (into the land of Canaan) is known.2 This chapter, like others,3 is connected.4
11. THEN YE SHALL APPOINT YOU CITIES. The word ve-hikritem (then shall ye appoint you) is related to the word kiryah (cities).5

15. FOR THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. This is not connected to the previous verse,6 for the preceding verse states that these cities will be cities of refuge. However, it does not state for whom they shall serve as cities of refuge. Scripture then explains7 that these six cities shall serve as cities of refuge for the children of Israel, and for the stranger…who lives among them.
19. WHEN HE MEETETH HIM. The feh of bi-figo (when he meeteth him) is vocalized with a chirik8 like the word shivri (I break) in when I break (Lev. 26:26), for vocalization changes in the infinitive.9
20. AND IF HE THRUST HIM. From a high place.
OR HURLED AT HIM. An inclining wall10 or a deadly object.
LYING IN WAIT. I have previously explained the meaning of bi-tzediyyah (lying in wait).11
22. SUDDENLY. The meaning of be-feta is suddenly.12
23. SEEING HIM NOT. Re’ot is an infinitive.
AND HE WAS NOT HIS ENEMY. He had no intention of seeking his harm.

25. THEREIN UNTIL THE DEATH OF THE HIGH PRIEST. Some say that the meaning of until the death of is, until the investigation of.13 They compare it to And wisdom shall die with you (Job. 12:2).14 However, what they say is worthless. For And wisdom shall die with you means exactly what it says,15 as does until the death of the high priest.16 For the high priest atones on behalf of Israel, and this incident happened during his lifetime.17
26. THE BORDER OF HIS CITY. Et gevul means beyond18 the border.19 Compare, et ha-ir (out of the city) in as I am gone out of the city (Ex. 9:29).
27. BLOODGUILTINESS. I have already explained the meaning of dam (bloodguiltiness).20
33. SO YE SHALL NOT POLLUTE. Do evil in secret.
SHED IT. Shofkho (shed it) is a verb.21 Compare go’alo (his redeemer)22 in then shall his redeemer…come (Lev. 25:25).

34. AND THOU SHALT NOT DEFILE23 THE LAND. The pollution shall not defile the land.24 Or it is a command.25 The land shall not be polluted because I dwell among them.26 I do not dwell there out of respect for the land but out of respect for the children of Israel. Therefore Scripture says, I the Lord dwell in the midst of the children of Israel (v. 34).
chapter.ftnote: 1 Hence there is no need to explain its meaning.
2 The heh of artzah is in place of the preposition el. Thus artzah kena’an means into the land of Canaan.
3 Like other chapters which I.E. had previously pointed out.
4 To the chapter which precedes it.
5 From the word kir, a wall. Kiryah is thus a walled city. Ve-hikritem lakhem arim thus means, and you shall build walled cities.
6 Our verse is not a continuation of the previous verse. It is an independent clause.
7 In our verse.
8 In place of a short kamatz. Compare shomoro, kotvo, etc.
9 Not all infinitives follow the same vocalization.
10 Pushed the wall down upon him.
11 See I.E. on Ex. 21:13.
12 The usual word for suddenly is pitom. Hence I.E.’s comment.
13 Until the high priest investigates the death of the victim. For other interpretations see Filwarg.
14 They render this, and with you is wisdom searched out.
15 Tamut means shall die, not shall search out.
16 Which is to be taken literally.

17 Hence the murderer shall remain in the city of exile to remind the high priest of his failing. The high priest’s piety should have prevented the murder (see Rashi). Or, the murderer shall remain in exile to remind the high priest to pray constantly that God forgive Israel for the bloodshed in its midst.
18 Literally, from.
19 The word et is usually not translated. Hence I.E. points out that here it means from.
20 Our clause literally reads, he has no blood. Hence I.E. points out that blood means bloodshed. Thus our clause should be rendered, he is not guilty of bloodshed. See I.E. on Ex. 22:1.
21 Not a noun. It is made up of the verb shofekh (shedder) and the word shelo (its)
22 Which is a verb made up of the word go’el (redeems) and shelo (him) (translated according to I.E.).
23 Hebrew, titamme. Titamme can be rendered either as you shall defile or it shall defile. Hence the interpretations which follow.
24 This interpretation renders ve-lo titamme, it shall not defile.
25 This interpretation renders ve-lo titamme, you shall not defile.
26 I.E.’s paraphrase of the Lord dwells in the midst of the children of Israel.

chapter.title: CHAPTER 36
chapter.p: 1. CAME NEAR. This chapter1 also is connected to the one that comes before it. When Moses commanded the Israelites to give the Levites cities from the inheritance of Israel [the heads of the fathers’ houses drew near].
THE HEADS OF THE FATHERS’ HOUSES. The reference is to the princes.2
4. AND WHEN THE JUBILEE…SHALL BE. Even if the jubilee shall be,3 we have no hope of the inheritance returning to us, for it shall be added to the inheritance of the tribe.4
5. THE TRIBE OF THE SONS OF JOSEPH SPEAKETH RIGHT. For the heads of the fathers’ houses spoke on behalf of the entire tribe.
7. [SO SHALL NO INHERITANCE OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL REMOVE FROM TRIBE TO TRIBE.] The meaning of tissov (remove) is, shall not turn5 from here to there,6 be it from them7 or from others.8
The meaning of so shall no inheritance be removed is, no inheritance shall be removed from this day and onward even though they had not as yet inherited the land.

8. AND EVERY DAUGHTER, THAT POSSESSETH AN INHERITANCE. After the inheritance of the land. Scripture therefore states a second time, So shall no inheritance remove [from one tribe to another tribe] (v. 9).9
11. MAHLAH, TIRZAH. Scripture first mentioned them10 in the order of their birth. It now mentions them in the order in which they were first taken by men in marriage.
12. THEY WERE MARRIED INTO THE FAMILIES. This11 is a sign that their cousins12 were not all brothers.13
13. THESE ARE THE COMMANDMENTS. Relating to inheritance,14 vows,15 and every daughter that possesseth an inheritance,16 and the laws regarding bloodshed.17
BY THE JORDAN AT JERICHO. On the eastern bank.
chapter.ftnote: 1 Like other chapters.
2 Of the tribes. Hence Scripture reads, before the princes, the heads of the fathers’ houses of the children of Israel (v. 1).
3 I.E. renders ve-im yiheyah ha-yovel (and when the jubilee shall be), and even if the jubilee shall be.
4 Into which they married.
5 Shall not move around. Tissov comes from the root samekh, bet, bet, meaning to turn.
6 Emending mi-po u-mi-po (from here and from here) to mi-po le-po (from here to there) (Filwarg).
7 The tribe of Joseph, who argued their case before Moses.
8 Any other tribe.
9 In other words, verse 7 speaks of the present. Verse 8 speaks of the future.
11 The word families.
12 The cousins who married the daughters of Zelophehad.
13 If they were, then Scripture would have read, they were married into the “family” rather than they married into the “families.”
